http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_OHC_area_averaged_anomalies_0_700
Global Ocean Heat Content (0-700m) from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Ocean Heat Content: Key Indicator of Climate Change
 text provides explanation of Ocean Heat Content (OHC), importance in understanding climate change key findings from Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS).
 breakdown information:
 What is Ocean Heat Content?

 OHC is measure of total heat energy stored in ocean
 calculated by integrating temperature differences between measured values and climatology along vertical profiles
 Regional OHC values averaged from 60°S to 60°N to monitor large-scale changes variability
 OHC expressed in Joules per square meter (J/m2) for total heat content and Watts per square meter (W/m2) for rate of change over time

 Why is OHC Important?

 OHC key indicator of climate change ocean absorbs significant excess heat trapped by greenhouse gases
 helps understand contemporary Earth system state, variability change
 Variations in OHC influence
 Ocean stratification (layered structure)
 Ocean currents
 Sea ice ice shelves
 Ocean-atmosphere interactions
 Sea level change
 Marine ecosystems human livelihoods



 CMEMS Key Findings

 Since 2005, upper 700 meters of ocean between 60°S and 60°N warmed at rate of 0.6 ± 0.1 W/m2.
 finding highlights role ocean in absorbing excess heat due to climate change

 OHC vital indicator for understanding climate change impacts on Earth system CMEMS findings emphasize ongoing warming of ocean urgency of addressing climate change to mitigate consequences

346
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-heat-content-0-2000m-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_OHC_area_averaged_anomalies_0_2000
Global Ocean Heat Content (0-2000m) time series and trend from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Ocean Heat Content: Key Indicator of Climate Change
 This text provides concise summary of ocean heat content (OHC) significance as climate indicator breakdown of key points:
 1. Definition:

 OHC measured by comparing ocean temperatures at different depths to historical average (climatology).
 measurements taken across vertical profiles averaged from 60°S to 60°N global picture
 OHC expressed in two units:
 Joules per square meter (J/m2): indicates total heat energy stored within specific area ocean.
 Watts per square meter (W/m2): measures rate of change in OHC heat energy absorbed or released per unit time and area.



 2. Importance:

 OHC is one of six global climate indicators recommended by World Meteorological Organisation for Sustainable Development Goal 13 (climate action).
 provides critical insights into Earth's climate system:
 Understanding heat energy stored and released in ocean
 Revealing changes in ocean stratification, currents sea ice ice shelves
 Providing information about time scales of climate variability and change
 Illuminating role of oceans in ocean-atmosphere interactions sea level change
 Highlighting potential impact on marine ecosystems human livelihoods.



 3. Key Findings (CMEMS):

 near-global (60°S-60°N) ocean, up to depth of 2000 meters warming at rate of 1.0 ± 0.1 W/m2 since 2005.

 4. Conclusion:

 OHC crucial indicator of climate change impacts
 Monitoring understanding OHC changes essential for predicting future climate scenarios adapting to consequences guiding sustainable development efforts

 text highlights importance of OHC as robust indicator for tracking changing state of planet's climate systemunderscores need for continued monitoring research to better understand manage impacts of climate change.
---

Mean Heat Transport across sections from Reanalysis
Summary of Ocean Heat Transport Data
 document describes data ocean heat transport focusing on heat fluxes across lines within ocean data generated from climate models represents daily output
 Key Information

 Data Source: Climate models' daily output
 Data Type: Heat fluxes across lines integrated from top to bottom of ocean
 Units: PetaWatt (PW)
 Reference Period: 1993-2014
 Values:
 Mean value: Over reference period (1993-2014) last full year.
 Standard Deviation: For ensemble product over reference period (1993-2014).



 Context

 Importance: Ocean heat transport crucial role in Earth's energy budget influencing climate weather patterns
 Driving Factors
 Solar Radiation: Uneven distribution solar radiation drives heat transfer from tropics to poles
 Ocean Circulation: Vertical overturning horizontal currents contribute to heat transport
 Heat Fluxes: Sensible latent heat fluxes at ocean surface lead to heat loss
 Ocean Basin Geometry: Differences in ocean basin shapes current systems affect heat transport patterns


 Challenges: Understanding measuring ocean heat transport complex due to spatial variability non-stationary nature

 CMEMS Key Findings

 estimated mean transports from ensemble global reanalysis comparable to observational data
 significant uncertainties exist in all available products regarding integrated quantities

 Notes

 key findings updated annually in November
 data available through following DOIs:
 https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00245
 https://doi.48670/moi-00245



 data provides valuable insights into complex dynamics of ocean heat transport highlighting importance of ongoing research data improvement to understand critical aspect of Earth's climate system

High Resolution Snow and Ice Monitoring: Persistent Snow Area - LAEA projection (raster 20m)
Copernicus Persistent Snow Area (PSA) Product: Summary
 metadata provides information about product valuable resource for monitoring snow cover across Europe breakdown of key information


 PSA product identifies areas with persistent snow cover snow remains present throughout hydrological year
 generated annually for EEA38 (European Economic Area) and UK
 uses Fractional Snow Cover (FSC) data as input
 high spatial resolution of 20m x 20m

 produced

 Data from Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-1 satellite constellations
 processed released annually in October after hydrological year ends

 contains

 Two GeoTIFF files:
 PSA Layer: Shows persistent snow area "no data" values where clouds obscured view.
 QC Layer: Provides quality control information confidence levels in PSA layer.


 Metadata file: Provides additional information about product.

 Availability projections:

 European 20m grid: Tiles aligned with Pan-European High-Resolution Layers in ETRS89 LAEA projection (EPSG: 3035)
 Sentinel-2 projection: Tiles aligned with Sentinel-2 (UTM/WGS84) at 20m x 20m GSD.

 related products

 PSA part of pan-European High-Resolution Snow & Ice (HR-S&I) service offering various products at high spatial resolution:
 Snow products: FSC, WDS, SWS, GFSC, PSA
 Ice products: RLIE and ARLIE



 more information

 https://land.copernicus.eu/pan-european/biophysical-parameters/high-res... provides detailed information about HR-S&I service products

Copernicus PSA product offers insights into persistent snow cover patterns across Europe contributing to understanding of climate change impacts.

Understanding Ocean Heat Content (OHC): Summary
 text provides clear explanation of Ocean Heat Content (OHC) significance for understanding climate change breakdown of key information:
 What is OHC?

 Definition: OHC is heat energy stored in ocean measured as difference between current temperature and long-term average
 Measurement OHC estimated by temperature measurements along vertical profiles in ocean comparing to historical average
 Units:
 Total heat content: Joules per square meter (J/m2)
 Change in heat content over time: Watts per square meter (W/m2)



 Why is OHC important?

 Climate Change Indicator: OHC key indicator of climate change reflects energy absorbed by ocean
 Impact on Earth System: OHC influences
 Ocean stratification layering of different water densities
 Ocean currents: Global circulation patterns
 Sea ice and ice shelves: formation stability
 Ocean-atmosphere interactions: exchange of heat and moisture between ocean atmosphere
 Sea level rise: water warms expands
 Marine ecosystems human livelihoods: Changes in OHC can disrupt marine life affect coastal communities.



 CMEMS Key Findings:

 Recent Trend Since 2005, upper ocean (0-300m) between 60°S and 60°N warming at rate of 0.4 ± 0.1 W/m2.

 Conclusion
 OHC is critical indicator of climate change insights into ocean's role in regulating Earth's climate Monitoring OHC essential for understanding ocean absorbing heat consequences for global climate system potential impacts on marine ecosystems human societies.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-1
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Seasonal amplitude (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
Summary Seasonal Amplitude VPP Parameter
 text describes "Seasonal Amplitude" parameter one of thirteen Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) pan-European Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (MR-VPP) component
 breakdown information
 What is Seasonal Amplitude?

 difference between maximum and minimum Plant Phenology Index (PPI) values observed during specific season
 PPI physically based index tracks vegetation growth cycle

 How calculated?

 Satellite data: PPI calculated from satellite observations with 5-day revisit cycle
 Seasonal trajectories: PPI values used fit function resulting in seasonal trajectory of PPI over time
 VPP parameters From seasonal trajectories thirteen VPP parameters including seasonal amplitude calculated for each season

 Data Availability and Access

 Resolution: 500 x 500 meter resolution
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA projection (matching MCD43 tiling grid).
 Coverage: Covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom
 Timeline Data available for two seasons per year from 2000 onwards
 Update frequency: Updated first quarter of each year
 Access
 Currently (until end of 2022): Available "on-demand" by filling form on Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website
 After 2022 Full on-line access to open free data available



 Key Points

 Seasonal amplitude provides information about overall change in vegetation growth during season
 data high-resolution covering large area of Europe
 part of suite of VPP parameters comprehensive understanding of vegetation dynamics

 Further information

 full list of VPP parameters available in Product User Manual: https://land.copernicus./user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum
 information Copernicus Land Monitoring Service https://land.copernicus.eu

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/slope-green-down-period-2017-present-raster-10-m-europe
https://www.wekeo.eu/data?view=viewer&t=1577905116279&z=0&center=13.08408%2C48.33915&zoom=12.34&layers=W3siaWQiOiJjMCIsImxheWVySWQiOiJFTzpIUlZQUDpEQVQ6VkVHRVRBVElPTi1QSEVOT0xPR1ktQU5ELVBST0RVQ1RJVklUWS1QQVJBTUVURVJTL19fREVGQVVMVF9fL0NMTVNfSFJWUFBfVlBQX1JTTE9QRV9TRUFTT04xXzEwTSIsInpJbmRleCI6ODB9XQ%3D%3D&initial=1
Slope of the Green-down Period 2017-present (raster 10 m), Europe, yearly, Sept. 2021
text provides detailed description of RSLOPE parameter key component of Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) dataset within Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). break down information
 What is RSLOPE?

 RSLOPE stands for slope of the green-down or senescent period parameter measures rate of change in vegetation greenness as growing season ends during autumn senescence period).
 calculated using Plant Phenology Index (PPI), based index tracks vegetation growth
 RSLOPE derived from Seasonal Trajectories filtered time series of PPI values smoothed representation of vegetation cycle

 How is RSLOPE calculated?

 PPI data: calculated from satellite imagery, Sentinel-2, 5-day revisit cycle
 Seasonal Trajectory: PPI data processed to create smoother 10-day time series Seasonal Trajectory
 RSLOPE calculation: slope of Seasonal Trajectory during green-down period calculated representing rate of change in greenness

 Key Features of RSLOPE:

 Spatial Coverage: RSLOPE dataset covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom
 Resolution: data provided as raster files with 10 x 10 meter resolution
 Temporal Coverage: Data available for two seasons each year from 2017 onwards
 Update Frequency: Updated first quarter of each year
 Quality Indicator: QFLAG value provides confidence levels for data described in Product User Manual.

 Why is RSLOPE Important?

 Understanding Plant Phenology: RSLOPE provides insights into timing and rate of green-down period critical for understanding plant phenology and ecosystem dynamics
 Monitoring Vegetation Health: Changes in RSLOPE over time can indicate shifts in plant health and stress, drought or disease.
Climate Change Research: RSLOPE used to study effects climate change on vegetation growth cycles.

 Accessing Data:
 RSLOPE dataset available through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service. Product User Manual provides detailed information about data, including access methods.
 summary RSLOPE valuable parameter within HR-VPP component of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service. provides important information about rate of vegetation green-down useful for various applications, including monitoring vegetation health, understanding plant phenology climate change research.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/odyssea-global-sea-surface-temperature-gridded-level-4
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=SST_GLO_PHY_L4_NRT_010_043
ODYSSEA Global Sea Surface Temperature Gridded Level 4 Daily Multi-Sensor Observations
great description of Sea Surface Temperature Foundation (SSTfnd) dataset! breakdown of key information unique features uses:
 Key Features:

 High Resolution: 0.10 x 0.10 degree grid (approximately 10 x 10 km) provides detailed view of global ocean surface temperature
 Gap-Free: Data provided every 24 hours without missing values ensuring continuous record.
 Foundation Temperature: SSTfnd represents temperature at base of diurnal thermocline layer where temperature changes rapidly with depth temperature less influenced by daily fluctuations compared to surface measurements
 Multi-Satellite Integration: Data from polar-orbiting geostationary satellites including infrared and microwave radiometers combined to provide comprehensive picture.
 Optimal Interpolation: Gaps in data filled in using sophisticated interpolation technique maintaining data accuracy.

 Why SSTfnd Important?

 Oceanographic Studies: SSTfnd crucial input for oceanographic models providing information about upper ocean layer essential for understanding heat transport, circulation marine ecosystems.
 Climate Research: Changes in SSTfnd over time reflect long-term climate trends variability scientists track impact of climate change on ocean temperatures
 Marine Forecasting: Accurate SSTfnd data essential for forecasting weather patterns marine heatwaves other ocean-related events impact coastal communities marine life.

 How to Use Data:

 Data Access: provided DOIs (https://doi.org/10.48670/mds-00321) used to locate and download SSTfnd dataset.
 Analysis Tools: data be analyzed using software packages R, Python MATLAB to visualize trends create maps conduct scientific studies.

 Summary:
SSTfnd dataset provides valuable resource for researchers, scientists anyone interested in understanding dynamics ocean surface. Its high resolution gap-free coverage focus on less variable temperature metric make it powerful tool for various applications.

 Resolution: 100 meters each pixel represents 100m x 100m square.
 Time period: Data from 2017-2019 year 2018.
 Coverage: EEA-38 area (European Economic Area) United Kingdom

 produced

 Coordinated by EEA European Environment Agency under EU Copernicus program

 Key Features:

 Two change formats

 Classified change product: Categorical information on change types

 What is EOSV?

 represents value PPI at end of vegetation growing season
 PPI physically based index tracks vegetation growth cycles

 How is EOSV Calculated?

Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Start-of-season value (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
detailed informative description of Start-of-Season Value (SOSV) dataset within Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of key information:
 What is SOSV?

 SOSV is measure of Plant Phenology Index (PPI) at start of vegetation growing season
 one of 13 Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters from MR-VPP component of CLMS
 PPI is physically based index for monitoring vegetation growth cycles.

 How is SOSV calculated?

 Satellite data with 5-day revisit cycle used to calculate PPI values
 These values fitted to function to create PPI Seasonal Trajectories
 SOSV is one of 13 VPP parameters computed from these trajectories.

 Data Availability:

 SOSV dataset available as raster files with 500m resolution
 covers EEA38 countries United Kingdom
 Data available for two seasons each year from 2000 onwards
 updated in first quarter of each year.
 Full online access data available by end of 2022.
 Until then data be accessed "on-demand" through form on Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website.

 Potential Uses:

 Monitoring timing of spring vegetation green-up
 Assessing impact of climate change on vegetation phenology.
 Studying relationships between vegetation growth and environmental factors
 Supporting agricultural and forestry management decisions.

 SOSV dataset is valuable resource for researchers scientists policymakers interested in understanding monitoring vegetation phenology open free access to data contribute to research applications in various fields related to environment and climate change.

Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Base level value (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed explanation of Base Level Value parameter within Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) dataset produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS).
 breakdown of key information:
 What is Base Level Value?

 It's measure of average Plant Phenology Index (PPI) value during dormant periods before and after growing season
 PPI index designed track vegetation growth cycle using satellite data
 reflects 'background' vegetation state during non-growing periods.

 How calculated?

 PPI Index Values: Satellite data with 5-day revisit cycle provides PPI values.
 Seasonal Trajectories: values used to create model of PPI changes year "Seasonal Trajectories".
 VPP Parameters: Thirteen different VPP parameters including Base Level Value calculated from Seasonal Trajectories.

 Data Availability:

 Resolution: 500m x 500m raster files
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA, aligned with MCD43 tiling grid.
 Coverage: EEA38 countries and UK.
 Time Period: From 2000 onwards two seasons per year
 Update Frequency: Updated first quarter of each year
 Access: Currently "on-demand" by filling out form Full open and free access available by end of 2022.

 Potential Uses:

 Monitoring health of vegetation especially during dormant periods
 Detecting long-term trends in vegetation activity
 Analyzing impacts of climate change on plant phenology.

 Base Level Value provides valuable information about "baseline" state of vegetation used to understand dynamics of plant growth and response to environmental factors.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-productivity-2017-present-raster-10-m-europe
https://www.wekeo.eu/data?view=viewer&t=1577905116279&z=0&center=13.08408%2C48.33915&zoom=12.34&layers=W3siaWQiOiJjMCIsImxheWVySWQiOiJFTzpIUlZQUDpEQVQ6VkVHRVRBVElPTi1QSEVOT0xPR1ktQU5ELVBST0RVQ1RJVklUWS1QQVJBTUVURVJTL19fREVGQVVMVF9fL0NMTVNfSFJWUFBfVlBQX1NQUk9EX1NFQVNPTjFfMTBNIiwiekluZGV4Ijo4MCwiaXNFeHBsb3JpbmciOnRydWV9XQ%3D%3D&initial=1
Seasonal Productivity 2017-present (raster 10 m), Europe, yearly, Sept. 2021
detailed informative description of Seasonal Productivity (SPROD) parameter within Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). break down key information:
 What is SPROD?

 Seasonal Productivity (SPROD): measure of total plant growth during growing season sum of daily Plant Phenology Index (PPI) values between start and end of growing season.
 Plant Phenology Index (PPI): physically-based index tracks vegetation growth cycles using satellite data derived from Sentinel-2 imagery updated every 5 days.
 Seasonal Trajectories: smoothed version of PPI data with 10-day time step created through function fitting trajectories used to calculate VPP parameters, including SPROD.
 VPP Parameters: set of 13 parameters including SPROD describe aspects vegetation phenology productivity.

 How is SPROD calculated?

 PPI measured: Satellite data used to calculate PPI every 5 days.
 PPI smoothed: PPI values fitted to function create smoother Seasonal Trajectories with 10-day time step
 SPROD calculated: sum of all daily PPI values within growing season (between start end of season (EOSD calculated minus base level value.

 Key aspects of SPROD dataset:

 Resolution: 10m x 10m
 Projection: UTM/WGS84 aligned with Sentinel-2 tiling
 Coverage: EEA38 countries UK
 Time period: 2017 onwards two seasons per year
 Updates: Updated in first quarter of each year
 Quality indicator: Quality Flag (QFLAG) provided indicate confidence level of data.

 Uses of SPROD:

 Monitoring vegetation growth: Provides insights into plant productivity including potential changes due to climate change land management practices disturbances.
 Agricultural applications: Supports crop yield estimation monitoring.
Environmental monitoring: assess ecosystem health carbon sequestration other environmental factors.

 Accessing SPROD:
 SPROD dataset with other VPP parameters available through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service. find more details access data from sources:

 CLMS Website: https://land.copernicus.eu/
 Product User Manual: https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/product-user-m...

 detailed information provides strong foundation for understanding significance applications of SPROD within context vegetation phenology productivity monitoring using Earth observation data.

https://www.wekeo.eu/data?view=viewer&t=1577905116279&z=0&center=13.08408%2C48.33915&zoom=12.34&layers=W3siaWQiOiJjMCIsImxheWVySWQiOiJFTzpIUlZQUDpEQVQ6VkVHRVRBVElPTi1QSEVOT0xPR1ktQU5ELVBST0RVQ1RJVklUWS1QQVJBTUVURVJTL19fREVGQVVMVF9fL0NMTVNfSFJWUFBfVlBQX0VPU0RfU0VBU09OMV8xME0iLCJ6SW5kZXgiOjgwfV0%3D&initial=1
End-of-season Date 2017-present (raster 10 m), Europe, yearly, Sept. 2021
detailed description of End-of-Season Date (EOSD) dataset produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service breakdown of key information
 What is EOSD?

 marks end of vegetation growing season determined by Plant Phenology Index (PPI).
 one of 13 Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters derived from PPI
 EOSD calculated when PPI value drops to 15% of peak during green-down period

 How EOSD derived?

 PPI calculation PPI physically vegetation index calculated from Sentinel-2 satellite data every 5 days
 Seasonal Trajectory PPI data filtered smoothed into 10-day time series Seasonal Trajectory
 VPP Parameter Calculation EOSD derived from Seasonal Trajectory with 12 other VPP parameters

 Dataset Information

 Format: Raster files with 10 x 10m resolution
 Projection: UTM/WGS84 aligned with Sentinel-2 tiling grid
 Coverage: EEA38 countries + United Kingdom
 Time period: Two seasons per year starting from 2017.
 Updates: First quarter of each year
 Quality indicator (QFLAG): confidence level for EOSD data in Product User Manual).

 Key Points

 Relevance EOSD provides valuable information for monitoring vegetation growth changes in growing season
 Data Availability dataset freely available through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service
 Product User Manual provides comprehensive documentation specifications

 Applications of EOSD:

 Climate change monitoring impacts climate change on vegetation phenology
 Agriculture: Understanding crop growth cycles predicting harvest times
 Ecosystem management: Monitoring vegetation health biodiversity
 Land use planning: Identifying areas with suitable vegetation for specific purposes

comprehensive explanation provides clear understanding of EOSD dataset, its derivation, potential applications. provided resources, such as Product User Manual, can be consulted for further details technical specifications.

365
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-2
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Small integral (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed explanation of Small Integral (SINT), vegetation phenology parameter from Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) MR-VPP component. breakdown of key points:
 What is SINT?

 SINT is one of 13 Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters from Plant Phenology Index (PPI).
 represents difference between function describing vegetation season and base level measured from start to end of season
 SINT quantifies 'area under curve' of vegetation season providing estimate of overall vegetation activity during period.

 How is SINT calculated?

 PPI Seasonal Trajectories: SINT calculated from PPI index physically based vegetation index derived from satellite data. index processed to create "Seasonal Trajectories" capture vegetation growth cycle over time
 Function Fitting: function fit to Seasonal Trajectories capturing pattern of vegetation growth and decline
 SINT Calculation: SINT calculated as integral (area) of fitted function during season.

 Data Availability:

 Resolution SINT data available as raster files with 500x500m resolution
 Geographic Coverage: covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom.
 Time Period: Data available for two seasons each year from 2000 onwards.
 Frequency: Updated in first quarter of each year.
 Access: Full online access available by end of 2022. Until then can be requested "on-demand" through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service contact form.

 Applications:

 SINT can be used to monitor and analyze vegetation phenology critical for understanding ecosystem health and productivity
 provide insights into timing and duration of vegetation seasons overall growth dynamics
 information valuable for various applications including agricultural management, climate change monitoring, ecological research.

Overall SINT is powerful tool for analyzing understanding vegetation phenology. availability as open data through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service valuable for wide range of users applications.

Start-of-season Date 2017-present (raster 10 m), Europe, yearly, Sept. 2021
technical description of Start-of-Season Date (SOSD) dataset within Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of key points insights:
 What is SOSD?

 is measurement of when vegetation growing season begins
 derived from Plant Phenology Index (PPI), tracks overall growth cycle of plants using satellite data
 SOSD is date when PPI reaches 25% of seasonal amplitude during green-up period.

 How is it Calculated?

 Satellite Data: Sentinel-2 satellites collect data every 5 days detailed record of vegetation growth.
 PPI Calculation: data used to calculate PPI measure of vegetation greenness and activity.
 Seasonal Trajectories: PPI data smoothed analyzed to create "Seasonal Trajectories represent typical growth pattern of vegetation over season
 VPP Parameters: From trajectories 13 VPP parameters derived, including SOSD.
 Quality Indicator (QFLAG): confidence level assigned to each SOSD value indicating reliability of data.

 Data Availability:

 Spatial Coverage: SOSD dataset covers EEA38 countries and UK.
 Resolution: data provided as raster files with resolution of 10 x 10 meters.
 Projection: data projected in UTM/WGS84 aligning with Sentinel-2 tiling grid.
 Temporal Coverage: Data available for two seasons per year from 2017 onwards
 Update Frequency: data updated in first quarter of each year.

 Uses of SOSD:

 Monitoring Vegetation Dynamics: Understanding when growing season starts helps scientists researchers monitor health and growth of vegetation over time
 Climate Change Research: Changes in SOSD indicator of climate change impacts on vegetation.
Agricultural Applications: SOSD used optimize planting dates monitor crop growth assess potential impact droughts on crops.
 Ecological Studies: SOSD provides valuable information for understanding plant phenology relationship to environmental factors.

 Overall:
 detailed description highlights importance of SOSD as reliable valuable data product within CLMS. helps understand vegetation phenology fine spatial scale provides valuable insights for wide range of applications.

High Resolution Snow and Ice Monitoring: Daily cumulative Gap-filled Fractional Snow Cover (raster 60m)
text provides detailed description Copernicus Daily Cumulative Gap-filled Fractional Snow Cover (GFSC) product breakdown key information


 Purpose GFSC product provides near real-time spatially complete estimate of snow cover across EEA38 region UK
 Data source utilizes data from Sentinel-1 Sentinel-2) satellites Digital Elevation Models (DEMs).
 Methodology product combines Copernicus snow-related products (FSC, WDS SWS) to reduce gaps data caused clouds sensor limitations
 Output product distributed as raster files (GeoTIFFs) with spatial resolution 60m x 60m covering areas 110 km x 110 km.
 Layers product includes four layers:
 GF: Gap-filled Fractional Snow Cover (percentage snow cover per pixel).
 AT: Additional information about pixel.
 QCFLAGS: Quality control flags for GF layer
 QC: General quality assessment of GF layer.



 Benefits

 Spatially complete Addresses data gaps due to clouds sensor limitations
 High resolution Provides detailed snow cover information (60m x 60m).
 Near real-time timely updates on snow conditions
 Comprehensive data Includes multiple layers for quality control additional information

 Context

 Part of HR-S&I GFSC one of many high-resolution snow and ice products (HR&I) generated from Sentinel data
 Availability Available since September 1, 2016.
 Further information Links provided for more details on GFSC product other HR-S&I products

 Applications:

 Hydrology: Monitoring snowmelt impact on water resources

Global Ocean Waves Analysis and Forecast
Météo-France's global ocean analysis forecast system provides daily analyses 10-day forecasts of sea surface waves at 1/12 degree resolution system driven by MFWAM wave model uses wind data from IFS-ECMWF atmospheric system to predict wave parameters like height period direction model partitions wave spectrum into wind wave primary swell secondary swell components assimilates altimeter data for improved accuracy.

Impervious Built-up 2018 (raster 10 m), Europe, 3-yearly, Aug. 2020
text provides detailed description of Impervious Built-up (IBU) layer, thematic product related to soil sealing built-up areas within European Economic Area (EEA) United Kingdom. breakdown of key information:
 What it is

 binary thematic product classifies each pixel as "building" (class 1) or "no building" (class 0).
 Derived from Imperviousness Density layer layer provides information on percentage of impervious cover for year 2018.
 Focuses on built-up areas areas where natural land replaced with artificial often impervious surfaces like roads buildings parking lots.

 made

 Produced by EEA: European Environment Agency coordinates production of high-resolution imperviousness layers
 Part of Copernicus programme Earth observation program by European Union.
 Based on Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI): index helps distinguish between vegetation and non-vegetation areas for automated identification of impervious surfaces.
 series of layers for different years: Data available for 2006, 2009, 2012, 2015, 2018 analysis of changes over time.

 Key characteristics:

 High resolution: Data provided as 10-meter resolution rasters.
 Coverage: Includes EEA38 countries United Kingdom.
 Tiles Data organized into 100 x 100 km tiles.

 Additional information:

 Imperviousness change layers: layers show difference in imperviousness between different years for analysis of how soil sealing changed over time.
 Categorical change product: classified product provides categorical assessment of changes in imperviousness.

 IBU layer valuable resource for understanding:

 extent distribution of built-up areas
 spatial patterns of soil sealing
 dynamics of urbanization impacts environment.

product provides near-real-time along-track significant wave height (SWH) measurements from multiple satellite altimeter missions. data rigorously edited to ensure quality including checks on quality flags parameter thresholds calibration against in-situ buoy measurements. All missions homogenized to reference mission along-track filter applied to reduce noise. Wind speed measurements from altimeters included. product serves operational oceanography climate forecasting centers worldwide valuable tool for understanding predicting ocean conditions.

371
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-8
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Largest value for the fitted function during the season (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text describes "largest value for fitted function during season" parameter part of Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of information:
 What it is:

 This parameter represents highest value reached by fitted function during specific growing season
 derived from Plant Phenology Index (PPI), measures vegetation growth based on satellite data.
 not necessarily same as peak of season, might occur on different date.

 How calculated:

 Satellite data with 5-day intervals used to calculate PPI.
 values fitted into function to create Seasonal Trajectories.
 highest value of fitted function during season is identified and becomes parameter value.

 Data availability:

 data available as raster files with 500x500m resolution.
 Coverage: EEA38 countries, UK, and two seasons per year from 2000 onwards.
 Update frequency: First quarter of each year.
 Currently "on-demand" only with access through contact form.
 Full online access expected by end of 2022.

 parameter provides information about maximum vegetation growth or activity within given season, as captured by PPI and fitted function, helping to understand vegetation phenology and productivity across Europe.

372
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/arctic-freshwater-content-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=ARCTIC_OMI_TEMPSAL_FWC
Arctic Freshwater Content from Reanalysis
Arctic Freshwater Content: Summary
 text provides concise explanation of Arctic Ocean's liquid freshwater content (FWC) estimated implications for changing Arctic climate.
 breakdown of key points:
 1. Calculation of FWC:

 FWC calculated by measuring difference between salinity of Arctic waters and reference salinity (34.8).
 Only waters less salty than reference considered representing freshwater input
 difference integrated over water column (depth greater than 500m) averaged over Arctic region.
 gives estimate of FWC in cubic kilometers (km3).

 2. Importance of Monitoring FWC:

 Arctic region warming rapidly impacting hydrological cycle.
 Understanding FWC changes crucial for understanding Arctic system's state variability
 Changes in FWC influence ocean stratification affecting global circulation heat transport.

 3. Key Findings:

 Since 1993 Arctic Ocean's FWC increased significantly by average of 423 ± 39 km3/year.
 2016 saw highest FWC in past 24 years
 substantial decrease in FWC observed in second half of 2016 and first half of 2017.

 4. Future Monitoring:

 key findings updated annually in November reflecting latest data trends

 information highlights substantial increase in Arctic freshwater storage raising concerns about implications for Arctic's changing climate impact on global ocean system.
 Further Information:

 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00193
 CMEMS likely refers to Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service provides data and analysis related to oceans.

374
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-9
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Plant phenology index (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
Plant Phenology Index (PPI) Dataset: Summary
 metadata provides information about dataset product of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS) focusing on vegetation phenology monitoring
 Key Features:

 Physically based PPI derived from simplified solution to radiative transfer equation more robust than traditional vegetation indices
 Strong correlations: PPI linear relationship with green leaf area index strong correlation with gross primary productivity (GPP).
 Disentangles phenology and snow separate plant phenology from snow seasonality beneficial for northern latitudes
 Superior performance: PPI better performance other indices for spring phenology retrieval in northern latitudes GPP estimation in semi-arid regions
 Validation: PPI validated against ground observations of plant phenology and GPP demonstrating strong temporal pattern similarities.
 Spatial coverage: Covers EEA38 countries United Kingdom
 Temporal coverage: From January 2000 to present
 Resolution: 500 x 500 meters.
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA aligned with MCD43 tiling grid
 Availability
 Currently On-demand access via Copernicus Land Monitoring Service contact form
 End of 2022: Full online access available



 Resources

 Product User Manual: https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum...
 Data Request: https://land.copernicus.eu/contact-form


 PPI dataset valuable tool for researchers practitioners monitoring vegetation phenology and productivity in context climate change impacts on ecosystems dataset's physically based nature robust performance wide geographical coverage make valuable resource for diverse applications

379
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-7
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Peak of season (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed explanation of "Peak of Season" (POS) parameter part of Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) dataset from Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of key information:
 What is POS?

 Definition: POS represents time of maximum vegetation activity within growing season indicated by Plant Phenology Index (PPI).
 Calculation: POS calculated as average of two points:
 time when left edge (start) of PPI curve reaches 80% of peak value.
 time when right edge (end) PPI curve falls back down to 80% peak value.


 Significance: provides insights into timing of peak vegetation growth important for understanding plant phenology and agricultural practices.

 How is POS Derived?

 PPI Calculation: PPI is vegetation index measures amount green vegetation.
 Seasonal Trajectories: PPI values used to create seasonal trajectories represent growth cycle of vegetation.
 VPP Parameter Calculation: 13 VPP parameters, including POS calculated from these trajectories.

 Data Availability:

 Spatial Resolution POS dataset available as raster files with 500m x 500m resolution
 Coverage: data covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom
 Temporal Coverage: POS data available for two seasons each year starting from 2000.
 Update Frequency: data updated in first quarter of each year.
 Access
 Full online access planned for end of 2022
 Currently data available "on-demand" through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website



 Key Points to Remember

 POS valuable parameter for understanding vegetation phenology and productivity
 part of MR-VPP dataset component of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS).
 data freely available will be easily accessible online in future.

information provides comprehensive overview of POS parameter its significance within context of vegetation monitoring.
---
380
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-4
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Rate of increase at the start of the season (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed explanation of increase rate, parameter within Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) dataset produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS).
 breakdown of key information:
 What is increase rate?

 It's measure of how quickly vegetation growth accelerates at beginning of growing season.
 calculated using Plant Phenology Index (PPI), tracks vegetation growth over time.
 Specifically measures change in PPI values between 20% and 80% points of growing season, divided by time difference between points.

 Where increase rate data from?

 derived from MR-VPP (Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity) component of CLMS.
 data based on satellite observations with 5-day revisit cycle.

 How data presented?

 increase rate is part of larger set of 13 VPP parameters.
 data available as raster files with resolution of 500 x 500 meters.
 covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom.
 Data provided for two seasons each year from 2000 onwards.

 How can access data?

 Full open access available by end of 2022.
 Until then can request data "on-demand" by filling out form on Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website.

 increase rate is valuable tool for understanding and monitoring vegetation growth dynamics especially provides information about speed of green-up during growing season.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/atlantic-meridional-overturning-circulation-amoc
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_NATLANTIC_amoc_max26N_timeseries
Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation AMOC timeseries at 26N from Reanalysis
Summary Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) Strength
 document provides information about strength Atlantic at 26.5°N key component of global climate system.
 Key findings:

 Definition AMOC strength calculated by integrating meridional transport across Atlantic basin at 26.5°N accumulating values with depth maximum value in depth represents strength in Sverdrups (Sv).
 Observations Data from RAPID array
 Variability AMOC strength shows significant variability at different timescales including
 Monthly to Decadal: Temporary weakening in 2009/10 decrease from 2005-2012.
 Multi-product Mean: Weakening from 2005-2012 (-0.67 Sv/year) in observations -0.53 Sv/year in multi-product mean Earlier increase from 2001-2006 (0.48 Sv/yr) weakening in 1998-99.


 Potential Causes: observed weakening likely due to variability long-term trend.
 Future Updates: key findings updated annually in November.

 References:

 Smeed et al, 2017
 Srokosz et al, 2012
 McCarthy et al, 2012
 Smeed et al, 2014
 Smeed et al, 2018
 Jackson et al, 2017
 Jackson et al, 2018

 Further Information:

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00232
 CMEMS information based on Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS).

 document highlights importance of monitoring AMOC strength significant variability ongoing research into potential causes.

382
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-significant-wave-height-extreme-observations
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_VAR_EXTREME_WAVE_BALTIC_swh_mean_and_anomaly_obs
Baltic Sea Significant Wave Height extreme from Observations Reprocessing
OMI_EXTREME_WAVE_BALTIC_swh_mean_and_anomaly_obs: Summary
 This indicator tracks extreme wave heights in Baltic Sea providing crucial information about potential hazards impact. breakdown of key aspects:
 it measures

 Significant wave height (swh): commonly used measure of wave size average height of highest one-third of waves during given period.
 99th and 1st percentiles: Instead of using annual maximum minimum values indicator uses percentiles to minimize impact of individual data errors 99th percentile represents highest 1% of wave heights 1st percentile represents lowest 1%.
 Mean and Anomaly: average value of 99th percentile is calculated difference between current year's 99th percentile average presented as anomaly helps identify deviations from typical extreme wave conditions.

 matters

 Climate change impacts: Projected increases in extreme sea states significant concern. High waves pose risks to
 Infrastructure: Damage to buildings ports coastal defenses
 Natural habitats: Erosion, flooding ecosystem disruption
 Maritime activities: Disruption to shipping fishing other sea-based activities



 Findings:

 Mean 99th percentile: average of highest 1% of wave heights in Baltic Sea is around 3 meters for stations Arkona and FinngrundetWR.
 Anomaly: this year slight negative anomaly observed decrease of 0.315 meters in Arkona less than 0.1 meter in FinngrundetWR highest 1% of waves were slightly lower than average for these locations.

 Significance
 indicator provides valuable insights into changing wave climate in Baltic Sea

 Track trends: Understand extreme wave events over time
 Improve forecasting: Predict potential hazards prepare for extreme wave events.
Inform decision-making: Support informed infrastructure design maintenance disaster management strategies.

 Further resources:

 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00199
 CMEMS: Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service provides comprehensive data information on ocean.

 continuously monitoring indicators researchers policymakers gain better understanding potential risks extreme wave events implement measures to mitigate impacts.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mean-volume-transport-across-sections-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_WMHE_voltrp
Mean Volume Transport across sections from Reanalysis
Summary of Ocean Volume Transport Data
 text describes dataset of ocean volume transport across various lines in ocean dataset generated from multiple reanalysis models values calculated by integrating volume fluxes along selected sections from ocean surface to bottom
 breakdown of key points:
 Data:

 Method: Volume fluxes integrated along selected sections from surface to bottom
 Source: Data from daily output of multiple ocean reanalysis models
 Timeframe: Data provided for reference period (1993-2014) and last full year.
 Units: Sverdrup (Sv), 1 Sv = 1 million cubic meters per second.
 Metrics: Mean value for reference period, mean value for last full year standard deviation for ensemble product over reference period.

 Context:

 Ocean Dynamics: ocean plays crucial role in global energy transport through vertical overturning horizontal circulation.
 Energy Budget: Spatial asymmetries in energy distribution drive heat transport from tropics towards poles complex factors like ocean basin geometry current systems create non-uniform pattern.
 Variability: Ocean heat transport not stationary variability still being studied.

 Key Findings:

 Comparison with observations: estimated transports from ensemble reanalysis comparable to observations but uncertainties remain.
 Drake Passage: multi-product approach shows higher volume transport than earlier estimates (Lumpkin Speer 2007), lower than recent observational results (Colin.

 Notes:

 Key findings updated annually in November as data evolves
 dataset be accessed through provided DOIs.

 dataset provides valuable information about ocean volume transport contributing to understanding of ocean circulation role in global energy transport.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-10
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Rate of decrease at the end of the season (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed explanation of "decrease rate" parameter part of Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) data produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of key points:
 What is "decrease rate" parameter?

 describes rate at vegetation growth declines at end of growing season
 rate calculated using Plant Phenology Index (PPI), measure of vegetation growth
 it's absolute value of difference between PPI values at 20% and 80% of season length, divided by time difference between points.

 How is "decrease rate" calculated?

 PPI data: Satellite data used to calculate PPI values with 5-day revisit cycle.
 PPI Seasonal Trajectories: PPI values fitted into function to create seasonal trajectory for each location.
 VPP parameters: From trajectories, 13 VPP parameters calculated, including "decrease rate."

 Data availability:

 Resolution: data provided as raster files with 500x500m resolution
 Area covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom
 Time period: Data available for two seasons per year starting from 2000 onwards
 Update frequency: dataset updated first quarter of each year.
 Access:
 Full online access available by end of 2022
 Until then data can be requested "on-demand" through contact form.



 Applications
 "decrease rate" parameter can be used for:

 Monitoring health of vegetation
 Understanding effects of climate change on plant growth
 Assessing timing of agricultural activities
 Supporting ecological research and modeling.

 "decrease rate" parameter provides valuable insights into dynamics of vegetation growth at end of season crucial piece of puzzle for understanding plant phenology and productivity.

OMI_EXTREME_WAVE_MEDSEA_swh_mean_and_anomaly_obs Indicator: Breakdown
 definition describes OMI_EXTREME_WAVE_MEDSEA_anomaly_obs indicator focusing on methodology significance within context climate change impact on Mediterranean Sea
 breakdown
 it measures

 Significant wave height (swh): indicator analyzes extreme variability of wave height in Mediterranean Sea.
 99th and 1st percentiles: annual maximum minimum values employs percentiles to minimize impact of individual data errors provides robust measure of extreme wave heights.
 Spatial evolution and anomalies: analysis considers spatial distribution of extreme wave heights deviations from long-term average (anomalies) for specific year.

 matters

 Climate change: Projections indicate increase in extreme sea states leading to more frequent severe wave storms.
 Impact on infrastructure ecosystems: Extreme wave events cause significant damage to infrastructure buildings natural habitats crops ecosystems through erosion flooding
 Maritime activities: Wave storms disrupt maritime activities particularly in harbors.

 Methodology:

 In situ data: indicator uses data from in situ buoys measuring wave height.
 Temporal averaging: percentiles averaged over time provide representative measure of extreme wave heights.
 Spatial display: spatial evolution of extreme wave heights displayed alongside anomalies for target year.

 Key findings:

 Mean 99th percentiles: mean 99th percentile values vary across Mediterranean Sea higher values in areas like Gibraltar Strait, Alboran Sea, East Coast of Iberian Peninsula, Balearic Islands, Ligurian Sea Gulf of Lyon.
Anomalies: indicator shows slight positive or negative anomalies within standard deviation range suggesting variations around long-term average for specific year.

 Significance:
 indicator provides valuable insights into occurrence spatial distribution of extreme wave events in Mediterranean Sea. Understanding variability crucial for:

 Infrastructure management: Designing maintaining infrastructure withstand extreme wave events.
 Risk assessment: Evaluating potential risks extreme wave events for coastal communities ecosystems.
 Climate change adaptation: Implementing strategies to mitigate impacts climate change on coastal regions.

 indicator provides crucial tool for monitoring understanding impact of extreme wave events in Mediterranean Sea particularly in context of climate change.
 Additional information:

 data and methods to produce indicator available through CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service) website.
 indicator part of broader effort to monitor assess impacts of climate change on Mediterranean Sea.

 explanation provides concise overview of OMI_EXTREME_WAVE_MEDSEA_swh_mean_and_anomaly_obs indicator significance. For further details refer to cited articles and CMEMS website.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-thermosteric-sea-level-trend-map-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_SL_thsl_trend
Global Ocean Thermosteric Sea Level trend map from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Thermosteric Sea Level
 text describes thermosteric sea level key factor to global sea level rise breakdown
 What is Thermosteric Sea Level?

's change in sea level caused by expansion ocean water due to temperature increases
 calculated by measuring temperature changes ocean converting into equivalent sea level changes
 process involves comparing current temperature data to reference climatology (average temperature) to isolate fluctuations
 Regional thermosteric sea level averaged from 60°S to 60°N to understand global sea level variations

 Key Findings

 Thermosteric sea level significant factor in interannual sea level variability trends
 At mid low latitudes temperature primary driver of steric sea level change salinity minor role
 Regional thermosteric sea level trends larger than global averages
 Changes in ocean circulation significant role especially in tropics where sea level variations trends most pronounced
 Between 2005 and 2019 Copernicus Marine Service observed regional thermosteric sea level rise at rates global average to over 8 mm/year
 Some regions like subpolar North Atlantic western tropical Pacific show negative trends exceeding -8 mm/year
 regions experience strong year-to-year variability

 Conclusion
 Thermosteric sea level critical component of global sea level rise Understanding regional trends variations essential for predicting future sea level changes impact on coastal areas information continuously updated analyzed through Copernicus Marine Service

394
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/northward-heat-transport-global-ocean-atlantic-and
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_WMHE_northward_mht
Northward Heat Transport for Global Ocean, Atlantic and Indian+Pacific basins from Reanalysis
Meridional Heat Transport: Key to Understanding Ocean Dynamics
 text describes Meridional Heat Transport (MHT), crucial element of Earth's climate system breakdown
 What is Meridional Heat Transport?
 MHT is movement of heat energy within ocean from equator towards poles measured by integrating heat fluxes across zonal direction (east to west) and vertically through ocean
 Why MHT Important?

 Earth's Energy Balance: Earth's energy budget maintained by MHT redistributes heat from tropics to higher latitudes
 Climate Regulation: MHT contributes to global climate patterns influencing weather systems regional temperatures
 Ocean Circulation: MHT driven by ocean currents major in shaping large-scale circulation patterns

 Key Findings:

 Spatial Variations MHT not uniform Variations in absorbed radiation basin geometry current systems lead to complex patterns of heat transport
 Variability MHT not static exhibits variations over time crucial for understanding climate change
 2016 Anomaly: unusually high global MHT in 2016 attributed to increased northward transport in Pacific during El Niño event
 2017 Trend: 2017 saw lower northward MHT in tropical band compared to 1993-2014 average in Atlantic and Indian/Pacific Oceans

 CMEMS Data
 CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service) provides MHT data for various basins (global Atlantic Indian/Pacific points data crucial for understanding current state future evolution of Earth's climate system
 Implications for Climate Change:
 Understanding MHT variations drivers essential for predicting future climate change scenarios Changes in MHT can lead to significant shifts in global climate patterns impacting weather extremes to sea level rise
 Conclusion:
Meridional Heat Transport critical component of Earth's climate system. By monitoring studying MHT, can gain valuable insights into ocean regulates climate it might respond to future climate change.
---

 What is CLC2000?

 Part of larger Corine Land Cover (CLC) program program provides consistent land cover data across Europe updated periodically
 Created collaborative effort National teams from EEA member cooperating countries analyze satellite imagery produce national land cover inventories combined into pan-European dataset

 Standardized methodology Ensures consistency across entire dataset

comprehensive informative description of Corine Land Cover 2000 (CLC2000) dataset breakdown key points:
 What is CLC2000?

 dataset provides detailed information about land cover land use across Europe existed year 2000.
 part of broader Corine Land Cover (CLC) program European initiative coordinated by European Environment Agency (EEA).

 Key Features:

 Consistency: data collected using standardized methodology across all participating countries ensuring comparability
 Detailed Classification: 44 land cover classes defined in hierarchical 3-level system for detailed analysis
 Spatial Resolution: minimum mapping unit (MMU) is 25 hectares for status layers features smaller than not captured Linear elements (like roads) must be at least 100 meters wide to be included.
 Change Detection: program produces change layers with higher resolution (MMU of 5 hectares) to track changes in land cover over time

 Purpose Applications:

 Environmental Monitoring: CLC data essential for tracking changes in ecosystems biodiversity loss impacts of climate change.
 Policy Support: aids in implementing environmental policies like agriculture water management urban development.
 Research and Analysis: Researchers use CLC data for wide studies related to land use environmental change ecological processes.

 Key Links:

 Copernicus Land Monitoring Service: https://land.copernicus.eu/ Provides access to CLC data other land-related information.
 CLC Technical Library: https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/ Offers detailed information on CLC products mapping guides class descriptions.

 Overall
 CLC2000 dataset valuable resource for understanding land cover of Europe in year 2000. vital role in supporting environmental monitoring, policy implementation scientific research

 Findings

Nino 3.4 Temporal Evolution of Vertical Profile of Temperature from Reanalysis
Summary NINO34 Subsurface Temperature Anomaly Relation to ENSO
 text explains NINO34 subsurface temperature anomaly relevance to El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO), importance for climate monitoring forecasting
 Key points

 Definition NINO34 subsurface temperature anomaly is difference between average subsurface temperature in central tropical Pacific (170°W-120°W, 5°S,-5°N) climatological average for same area (1993-2014).
 Relationship to ENSO: NINO34 good indicator of state central tropical Pacific monitor evolution of ENSO phases (El Niño La Niña).
 ENSO Characteristics: major source of climate variability ocean-atmosphere interactions in tropical Pacific two phases:
 El Niño: weakened trade winds warmer surface subsurface temperatures in eastern Pacific global impacts on weather patterns
 La Niña: Opposite to El Niño stronger trade winds cooler surface subsurface temperatures eastern Pacific


 NINO34 Indicator values above 2°C for more than 6 months indicate strong El Niño events
 Forecasting Applications NINO34 valuable tool for seasonal forecasting atmospheric conditions

 Key Findings

 Strong El Niño events observed during 1997/1998 2015/2016 winters NINO34 exceeding 2°C.
 La Niña events observed during 1998/1999 2010/2011 winters.

 References:

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00220
 Glantz, M. H. (2001). Currents of change: El Nino's impact on climate society Cambridge University Press.
 Wang, C., et al. (2017). review of El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) impacts. Advances in Atmospheric Sciences, 34(10), 1185-1204.

Note: key findings updated annually in November, line with OMI evolutions.

402
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/nino-34-sea-surface-temperature-time-series-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_CLIMVAR_enso_sst_area_averaged_anomalies
Nino 3.4 Sea Surface Temperature time series from Reanalysis
text provides comprehensive explanation NINO3.4 sea surface temperature anomaly (SST) index significance in understanding monitoring El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) phenomenon. breakdown key information:
 What is NINO3.4 SST Anomaly?

 Definition NINO3.4 SST anomaly is difference between actual sea surface temperature (SST) averaged over specific region central tropical Pacific (170°W-120°W, 5°S,-5°N) and average SST for same region over reference period (1993-2014).
 Spatial Averaging: average weighted by surface area account for varying sizes of grid boxes region
 Monthly Values: NINO3.4 index calculated reported monthly
 El Niño/La Niña Definition: El Niño events defined as periods when NINO3.4 anomaly positive exceeds 0.5°C for six consecutive months. La Niña events opposite negative anomalies exceeding -0.5°C for six months.

 Why NINO3.4 Important?

 ENSO Indicator: NINO3.4 index reliable indicator of state of ENSO major climate pattern ocean-atmosphere interactions in central tropical Pacific
 Global Impacts: ENSO has impacts on weather patterns ecosystems precipitation freshwater resources across globe droughts floods changes in fish populations).
 Monitoring and Forecasting: NINO3.4 index used monitor evolution of ENSO phases (El Niño, La Niña or neutral) improve seasonal climate forecasts.

 Key Findings (1993-2019):

 Strong El Niño Events: periods strong positive ENSO phases (El Niño) observed in 1998 and 2016, with NINO3.4 anomalies exceeding 2°C for extended periods.
 La Niña Events: La Niña events also observed in 2000 and 2008.

 Overall:
NINO3.4 SST anomaly is valuable tool for understanding predicting ENSO, climate phenomenon with significant global impacts. monitoring NINO3.4 index scientists policymakers can prepare for mitigate effects of El Niño La Niña events.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-subsurface-salinity-trend-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_TEMPSAL_Stz_trend
Baltic Sea Subsurface Salinity trend from Reanalysis
Summary Subsurface Salinity Trends in Baltic Sea
 document describes subsurface salinity trends Baltic Sea from regional reanalysis forecast modelling results CMS BAL MFC group (BALTICSEA_REANALYSIS_PHY_003_011).
 Key Findings:

 Surface Layer (0-40m): No significant salinity trend between 1993-2021.
 Intermediate Layer (50-80m): Increasing salinity trend 0.01 to 0.03 per year layer overlaps with upper halocline.
 Halocline and Below (60-180m): Maximum salinity trend approximately 0.05 per year at 150m depth. Wide confidence interval depth range indicates significant variability.

 Context:

 Baltic Sea is brackish semi-enclosed sea with varying surface salinity
 halocline layer of rapid salinity change located at depths 60-80m.
 Long-term salinity influenced by precipitation river discharge saline water inflow from North Sea
 Salinity changes can impact marine ecosystems including survival of species like Fucus vesiculosus Idotea balthica Baltic cod.

 Implications:
 increase in salinity within below halocline suggests changes in Baltic Sea's ecosystem dynamics could potentially impact distribution abundance of marine life particularly sensitive to salinity fluctuations Further research needed to understand long-term effects trends implications for Baltic Sea's ecosystem health.

Ocean Heat Content: Key Indicator of Climate Change
 text provides clear explanation of Ocean Heat Content (OHC) significance in understanding climate change
 Key Points

 Definition: OHC calculated by measuring difference between ocean's current temperature and climatological baseline data averaged across specific region typically from 60°S to 60°N.
 Units
 OHC expressed in Joules per square meter (J/m2) monitor large-scale variability changes
 rate of change in OHC heat energy stored in ocean expressed in Watts per square meter (W/m2).


 Importance: OHC crucial for understanding state variability change of Earth system due to influence on
 Ocean dynamics: Changes in OHC affect stratification currents sea ice ice shelves.
 Climate variability: OHC significant role in Earth's response to climate change variability
 Ocean-atmosphere interactions: OHC impacts sea level rise influences weather patterns.
 Marine ecosystems human livelihoods: Changes in OHC impact marine ecosystems human activities reliant on ocean.



 CMEMS Findings
 Copernicus Marine Service (CMEMS) analyzed regional trends in OHC from 2005-2019 findings highlight

 Global warming: Most regions show warming trends some areas rates exceeding 8 W/m2.
 Regional variations: most regions warming, specific areas like subpolar North Atlantic western tropical Pacific exhibiting cooling trends
 Year-to-year variability: Significant year-to-year fluctuations in OHC observed particularly in regions experiencing cooling trends.

 Conclusion
 OHC critical climate indicator provides invaluable information about Earth's energy balance impact of climate change on ocean CMEMS data ongoing monitoring essential for understanding changes informing future climate action.

406
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-sea-surface-temperature-trend-map
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_TEMPSAL_sst_trend
Global Ocean Sea Surface Temperature trend map from Observations Reprocessing
Analysis of Global Sea Surface Temperature (SST) Trends: Key Takeaways
 analysis based on data from European Space Agency (ESA) Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), examines global SST trends from 1993 to 2021 breakdown of key findings methodology:
 Methodology:

 Daily to Monthly: Daily SST data averaged create monthly means
 Climatology: baseline established averaging monthly means over 1993-2014.
 Monthly Anomalies: Deviations from baseline calculated by subtracting climatology from each monthly mean.
 Seasonal Adjustment: X11 procedure applied to separate time series into seasonal, trend, error components.
 Trend Slope: robust method (Sen 1968) used to calculate slope of trend component 95% confidence range.

 Key Findings:

 Global Warming: analysis reveals widespread warming trend across globe between 1993 and 2021.
 North Atlantic Exception: significant cooling trend observed south of Greenland in North Atlantic trend consistent with previous studies showing centennial-scale cooling region.

 Significance:
 SST crucial climate variable influencing heat exchange ocean-atmosphere dynamics marine processes Understanding SST trends critical for climate monitoring, forecasting understanding impacts of climate change on ocean global climate system.
 Further Information

 analysis based on ESA/C3S SST data product uses combination satellite and in-situ measurements
 specific methodologies described in Mulet et al. (2018) and Good et al. (2020).
 data product DOI provided for further exploration: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00243

 analysis provides valuable insights into global SST trends highlighting widespread warming specific regional anomalies like cooling trend in North Atlantic findings contribute to deeper understanding of evolving state global climate system.
---
407
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-ocean-heat-content-anomaly-0-700m-time
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=MEDSEA_OMI_OHC_area_averaged_anomalies
Mediterranean Ocean Heat Content Anomaly (0-700m) time series and trend from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
text provides detailed explanation of Ocean Heat Content (OHC) in Mediterranean Sea highlighting importance in understanding changing Earth system. break down key information
 1. Definition of Ocean Heat Content (OHC):

 OHC defined as deviation from reference period (1993-2014), measuring change in heat stored in ocean
 calculated by integrating temperature difference between current year and reference climate over specific depth range (0 to 700 meters).
 formula uses constant density of water (1030 kg/m3) specific heat capacity (3980 J/kg °C).

 Importance of OHC:

 ocean crucial role in absorbing releasing heat energy influencing global climate patterns
 Understanding OHC variations helps track Earth system's state, variability future changes.

 3. Data and Analysis:

 data focuses on Mediterranean Sea analyzing area-averaged OHC anomalies over time
 analysis uses "multi-product" approach combining data from multiple sources (six global products one regional product) to create ensemble mean associated spread
 approach aims to reduce uncertainties enhance reliability results.

 4. Key Findings:

 ensemble mean OHC anomaly time series for Mediterranean Sea shows consistent increase between 1993 and 2019 rate of 1.4 ± 0.3 W/m2.
 After 2005, rate increase became more pronounced aligning with previous research by Iona et al. (2018).

 5. Data Sources and Further Information:

 text provides links to specific data products research articles for further exploration verification of findings

 text provides comprehensive overview of OHC in Mediterranean Sea highlighting increasing heat content implications for changing climate
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/north-atlantic-gyre-area-chlorophyll-time-series-and
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_GLOBAL_OCEANCOLOUR_oligo_nag_area_mean
North Atlantic Gyre Area Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Oligotrophic Subtropical Gyre Trends in North Atlantic
 text describes findings of study on North Atlantic subtropical gyre, region of low nutrient levels phytoplankton growth characterized by low chlorophyll-a concentrations. study utilized satellite data from 1997 to 2021 analyze trends in gyre's area and chlorophyll-a concentration. key findings:
 Gyre Area:

 Overall Trend: gyre area showed positive trend over entire study period (1997-2021), increasing rate 0.14% per year relative to year 2000. slower rate of increase compared to period 1997-2019 (0.39% per year).
 Statistical Significance: trend for full period (1997-2021) not statistically significant, could be due to random variations than genuine trend.

 Chlorophyll-a Concentration:

 Overall Trend: chlorophyll-a concentration inside gyre showed negative trend decreasing rate -0.21% per year relative to year 2000. slightly slower rate decrease than trend for period 1997-2020 (-0.24% per year).
 Statistical Significance: trend for full period (1997-2021) remains statistically significant, indicating genuine decline in chlorophyll-a levels.

 Implications:
 study highlights North Atlantic subtropical gyre continues to expand in area while experiencing significant decrease in chlorophyll-a concentration. slower growth rate gyre compared to previous periods suggests potential shift in dynamics persistent decline in chlorophyll-a levels underlines ongoing challenges faced by ecosystem in region.
 Further Research:
 Further research needed to understand factors driving observed trends potential implications for broader marine ecosystem.

product provides wave analysis forecasts for North-West European Shelf generated using WAVEWATCH III wave model ocean model leverages same 1.5 km grid as ocean physics product ([https://resources.marine.copernicus?option NORTHWESTSHELF_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_PHY_004_013]), providing detailed wave information at high resolution

411
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/north-atlantic-ocean-chlorophyll-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_ATLANTIC_OCEANCOLOUR_area_averaged_mean
North Atlantic Ocean Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Chlorophyll Concentration in North Atlantic
 This document describes analysis chlorophyll concentration in North Atlantic Ocean using data from Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). breakdown key information:
 Data Source

 Chlorophyll data derived from CMEMS regional chlorophyll reprocessed (REP) products
 REP products calculated using regional chlorophyll algorithms applied to remote sensing reflectances from ESA Ocean Colour Climate Change Initiative (ESA OC-CCI).

 Analysis Methods:

 Daily regional mean values calculated by averaging data over region interest weighted by pixel area
 fixed annual cycle extracted using Census-I method
 deseasonalized time series obtained by subtracting mean seasonal cycle from original data
 linear regression fitted to deseasonalized time series to determine linear trend

 Key Findings:

 Overall Trend: overall trend in chlorophyll concentration from 1997-2021 slightly positive 0.16 ± 0.12% per year
 Low Frequency Signal: Despite positive trend low frequency harmonic signal present in deseasonalized data
 Annual Average annual average chlorophyll concentration in 2021 was 0.25 mg m-3.
 Peak Chlorophyll Concentrations: No significant changes in timing of spring and autumn blooms observed in 2021 lower peak chlorophyll concentration observed compared to previous year
 Trend Reduction: decrease in peak chlorophyll concentration in 2021 contributing to overall reduction trend.

 Context

 Phytoplankton chlorophyll concentration sensitive to changes environmental conditions like temperature, light nutrient availability
 North Atlantic exhibits cyclical and decadal oscillations in phytoplankton abundance
Monitoring chlorophyll concentration at different scales essential to distinguish long-term climate signals from natural short-term variability.
 Phytoplankton in North Atlantic known respond to climate variability associated with North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), timing of spring bloom correlation with sea surface temperature NAO index.

 Conclusion:
 analysis suggests slightly positive trend in chlorophyll concentration in North Atlantic but presence of low frequency harmonic signal recent decrease in peak chlorophyll concentration highlight need for continued monitoring further investigation into underlying drivers of changes
---
412
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-ice-volume-observations-reprocessing
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_SI_volume
Baltic Sea Ice Volume from Observations Reprocessing
Sea Ice Volume in Baltic Sea: Summary Key Findings
 text provides information about sea ice volume in Baltic Sea significance observed trends. breakdown of key points:
 Definition and Measurement:

 Sea ice volume: measure of total amount sea ice in specific area calculated by multiplying sea ice concentration (fractional coverage) by sea ice thickness integrating over area.
 Data sources: Sea ice volume calculated from daily sea ice concentration thickness maps from Synthetic Aperture Radar images in situ observations from icebreakers.
 Analysis period: data covers period from October 1992 to September 2014, daily, weekly annual averages calculated.

 Context and Importance:

 Ecological role: Sea ice coverage impacts physical ecological conditions Baltic Sea affecting annual ice season to distribution breeding habits of species.
 Human applications: Sea ice volume data crucial for planning icebreaker operations designing offshore constructions in ice-covered areas understanding potential impact of climate change on marine environment.
 Impact on wildlife: decline in sea ice volume threat to ringed seal population relies on stable ice conditions for breeding moulting.

 Key Findings from CMEMS:

 Ice season: ice season Baltic Sea starts in October last until June
 Maximum ice volume: maximum sea ice volume typically observed in March averaging around 18 km3 in 2020/21.
 Declining trend: statistically significant decreasing trend in maximum sea ice volume (-0.75 km3/year, p=0.02) since 1993. trend demonstrates impact of climate change on Baltic Sea environment.

 Overall
 data highlights importance of monitoring sea ice volume in Baltic Sea underscores urgent need to understand address impacts climate change on fragile ecosystem
