text provides overview Corine Land Cover 2018 (CLC2018) dataset highlighting key features importance
 What is CLC2018?

 A land cover/land use dataset provides information on type land cover across Europe in 2018.
 Part of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service key component of European Union's Copernicus Programme focusing on environmental monitoring
 Based on satellite images National teams across Europe classify satellite images create national CLC inventories
 Integrated into European map national inventories combined into single comprehensive land cover map Europe

 Key Features of CLC2018:

 Standardized methodology nomenclature participating countries use same classification system 44 land cover classes organized into three levels
 Minimum mapping unit (MMU): minimum size of feature 25 hectares for status layers 5 hectares for change layers
 Minimum width of linear elements Linear features like roads need at least 100 meters wide to be mapped

 Importance of CLC2018:

 Supports EU environmental policies provides crucial data for implementing policies
 Protecting ecosystems
 Preventing biodiversity loss
 Monitoring climate change impacts
 Tracking urban expansion
 Assessing agricultural trends
 Managing water resources


 Pan-European data CLC data available for entire continent comprehensive analyses comparisons

 Provides detailed information on CLC product descriptions mapping guides class descriptions

Corine Land Cover 2006 (CLC2006): Detailed Summary
 text provides comprehensive overview of Corine Land Cover 2006 (CLC2006) dataset crucial component of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service breakdown of key information:
 What is CLC2006?

 dataset representing land cover land use status of Europe in year 2006.
 part of Corine Land Cover (CLC) program coordinated by European Environment Agency (EEA).

 Key Features of CLC2006:

 Comprehensive Coverage: Provides consistent detailed land cover information for entire European continent
 Standardized Methodology Uses standard classification system with 44 classes in hierarchical 3-level structure
 High Accuracy: Achieves high accuracy through satellite imagery interpretation national team collaboration
 Defined Resolution: Utilizes Minimum Mapping Unit (MMU) of 25 hectares for status layers minimum width of 100 meters for linear elements
 Change Layers: Provides additional data on land cover changes with higher resolution (MMU of 5 hectares for LCC).

 Importance Applications:

 Environmental Monitoring Supports implementation EU environmental policies protecting ecosystems biodiversity monitoring climate change impacts
 Urban Planning Aids tracking urban sprawl urban development patterns
 Agricultural Management Helps assess changes in agricultural land use potential impacts
 Water Resources Supports monitoring water resources understanding relationship with land cover

 Data Accessibility Resources:

 Open Access CLC dataset publicly available through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website
 Technical Documentation: Detailed product descriptions mapping guides class descriptions available online.

 Overall
 CLC2006 valuable dataset for wide range of applications comprehensive accurate picture of European land cover in 2006. standardized methodology high-resolution data open accessibility make essential resource for environmental monitoring, planning research

421
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-yearly-co2-sink-multi-observations
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_HEALTH_carbon_co2_flux_integrated
Global Ocean Yearly CO2 Sink from Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Ocean CO2 Sink Information
 text provides information about global ocean CO2 sink crucial factor in mitigating climate change breakdown of key points:
 What is ocean CO2 sink?

 represents CO2 absorbed by ocean from atmosphere annually
 measured in PgC (petagrams of carbon) per year
 information covers period 1985 to 2021

 Key findings

 Increasing trend: ocean's CO2 absorption rate increasing over time
 rate change increased by 0.04±0.03e-1 PgC/yr2 from 1985-2021
 increase pronounced since 2000, growth rate of 0.06±0.04e-1 PgC/yr2.


 Recent absorption: In 2021 ocean absorbed 2.41±0.13 PgC/yr slightly lower than 2.50±0.12 PgC/yr in 2020.
 Average absorption: period average ocean CO2 sink was 1.61±0.10 PgC/yr.
 Variability ocean's CO2 absorption varies from year to year (interannual variability standard deviation of 0.46 PgC/yr.
 Historical significance Since Industrial Revolution ocean absorbed approximately 28% of all anthropogenic CO2 emissions as buffer against global warming.

 Additional information

 Data source information from Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS).
 Data method ocean CO2 sink calculated from 100-member ensemble of CO2 flux estimates
 Context ocean's CO2 uptake driven by increasing atmospheric CO2 concentrations influenced by natural climate variability

 Further reading

 Ocean State Report 4 (section 2.10): Provides detailed discussion on ocean CO2 sink
 Chau et al (2022): Offers more insights into research behind data

information highlights ocean's role in mitigating climate change by absorbing significant portion of anthropogenic CO2 emissions varying absorption rate potential future changes in ocean chemistry due to climate change require ongoing monitoring research.
---

South Atlantic Gyre Area Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Oligotrophic Subtropical Gyre Analysis
 document presents analysis of South Atlantic subtropical gyre region low productivity in ocean using satellite data from 1997 to 2021.
 Key findings:

 Area gyre area shown slight positive trend (0.01% increase) compared to 2000-01-01 values trend not statistically significant (p>0.05)
 Chlorophyll concentration: trend in chlorophyll concentration positive statistically significant (p<0.05) significant increase in phytoplankton growth within gyre trend higher than 1997-2020 period (0.73% year-1 compared to 0.35% year-1)
 Recent Deviation: last two years data show increased deviation from mean suggesting potential shifts in gyre dynamics.

 Context:

 Oligotrophic Gyres regions known as "ocean deserts" due to low nutrient levels
 Importance: Despite low productivity cover significant portion of Earth's surface contribute to global biogeochemical cycles Changes in size chlorophyll levels can significant impacts on global ecosystem
 Past Trends: Previous studies shown area of subtropical gyres expanding trend reversed in Pacific between 2007-2016.

 Further research:

 observed deviation from mean in last two years warrants further investigation to understand causes potential implications
 Continued monitoring of gyres crucial for understanding role in global ecosystem potential impacts of climate change.

 Data sources:

 Chlorophyll data from satellite observations available through CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service).

 summary based on provided information not delve into technical details of analysis methods
 provided DOI links may provide access to further details full study

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/corine-land-cover-change-2012-2018-vector-europe-6-yearly
https://land.copernicus.eu/pan-european/corine-land-cover/lcc-2012-2018
CORINE Land Cover Change 2012-2018 (vector), Europe, 6-yearly - version 2020_20u1, May 2020
summary of Corine Land Cover Change (CLC) dataset particularly CHA1218 version breakdown of key information:
 What?

 CHA1218 is dataset showing land cover changes in Europe between 2012 and 2018.
 part of larger Corine Land Cover (CLC) program long effort to map and track land use across Europe
 produced by Copernicus Land Monitoring Service component of European Union's Copernicus program



 Satellite imagery used to observe land cover changes
 National teams within EEA (European Environment Agency) and cooperating countries process imagery create national CLC inventories
 national inventories combined to create seamless European map.

 Key characteristics:

 44 land cover classes organized hierarchically in 3-level system.
 Minimum mapping unit (MMU):
 25 hectares for status layers
 5 hectares for change layers (CHA)


 Minimum width of linear elements: 100 meters

 important

 Supports environmental policies like protecting ecosystems biodiversity water resources
 Helps track impacts of climate change and urbanization
 Provides data for various sectors including agriculture urban planning.

 more information:

 Copernicus Land Monitoring Service: https://land.copernicus.eu/
 Technical library: https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/ (includes mapping guides CLC class descriptions)

 dataset provides valuable resource for understanding changes in land use over time impact on European environment
---

Atlantic - European North West Shelf - Ocean Biogeochemistry Analysis and Forecast
product provides daily forecasts hindcasts biogeochemical variables North-West European Shelf using ERSEM model NEMO-NEMOVAR ocean assimilation model
 Key Features:

 Model: ERSEM (European Regional Seas Ecosystem Model) NEMO-NEMOVAR
 Resolution: 7 km horizontal resolution
 Data Assimilation: Uses ocean color satellite data physical variables
 Products Daily 25-hour averages of chlorophyll nitrate phosphate oxygen phytoplankton biomass net primary production light attenuation pH CO2 partial pressure.
 Depth: Interpolated to 24 standard geopotential depths
 Time Coverage: 6-day forecast 2-day assimilative hindcast
 Availability Updated daily
 Associated Products Coupled with hydrodynamic model (NEMO) reanalysis product.

 data valuable for

 Understanding dynamics marine ecosystem North-West European Shelf
 Monitoring forecasting key biogeochemical variables
 Supporting research management activities related marine environment

North West Shelf Significant Wave Height extreme from Observations Reprocessing
_EXTREME_WAVE_NORTHWESTSHELF_swh_mean_and_anomaly_obs Indicator: Breakdown
 definition outlines_EXTREME_WAVE_NORTHWESTSHELF_anomaly indicator focuses on extreme wave events Northwest Shelf region breakdown key points
 Indicator Definition

 Focus Measures extreme wave height events using 99th percentile in-situ buoy data
 Data Source: Significant wave height (swh) measurements from buoys
 Method: 99th percentile high) 1st percentile low events calculated to mitigate data errors
 Analysis: Percentiles temporally averaged displayed spatially including anomaly compared to mean

 Context Importance

 Climate Change Extreme sea states expected become frequent due to climate change
 Impacts Severe wave storms cause damage to infrastructure ecosystems maritime activities
 Hydrodynamic Processes Understanding extreme waves crucial for managing infrastructure protecting coastal areas

 3. CMEMS Key Findings

 Spatial Variation 99th percentile mean for significant wave height shows regional variation
 English Channel 2.5m 0.3m standard deviation
 Helgoland Bight 3-5m 0.3-0.5m standard deviation
 Skagerrak Strait 4m 0.5m standard deviation
 Central North Sea 6m 0.3m standard deviation
 North of British Isles 8-9m 0.5-0.75m standard deviation


 Anomaly in 2020 Most areas show positive anomalies within standard deviation range North of British Isles experienced significant +1m anomaly
 Specific Storms Several severe storms in 2020 like Brendan, Dennis Bella produced waves exceeding 10m recorded by buoys

 4. Conclusion
indicator provides insights into spatial variation temporal trends of extreme wave events in Northwest Shelf data highlights potential impact of climate change on wave activity emphasizes importance of understanding mitigating risks associated with extreme phenomena.
 Note:

 provided DOI links point to same resource, likely error.
 Further research needed to understand specific impact of extreme wave events on region particularly in light climate change projections.

Summary OMI_VAR_EXTREME_SST_BALTIC_sst_mean_and_anomaly_obs Indicator
 indicator focuses on extreme sea surface temperature (SST) in Baltic Sea using in situ buoy data between 0 and 5 meters depth highlights aspects SST variability relation climate change potential impact on Baltic ecosystem
 Key features

 Method: Calculates 99th and 1st percentiles of SST data robust measure of extremes less affected by individual measurement errors
 Focus Analyzes spatial distribution temporal evolution of extreme SST values including mean values and anomalies (deviations from average).
 Context Recognizes importance of monitoring extreme SST events observed warming trend in Baltic Sea particularly summer months
 Significance: Extreme SST events impacts on marine ecosystems changes in species distribution population dynamics overall biodiversity.

 CMEMS Findings:

 Mean 99th percentile: Ranges from 18.7°C in Slipshavn to 21.2°C around Zealand Region standard deviation of 1°C to 2°C.
 Annual Anomaly: Shows slight positive anomaly in central Baltic Sea (+0.5°C), moderate positive anomaly in Bomholm and Arkona Basins (+2.8°C in Slipshavn), negative anomaly in southwest of Zealand Region (-1.5°C to -2.5°C).

 Overall
 indicator provides valuable information about current state recent changes in extreme SST values in Baltic Sea knowledge crucial for understanding potential impacts of climate change region supporting informed decision-making ecosystem management conservation.

428
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-sea-surface-temperature-time-series-and
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_TEMPSAL_sst_area_averaged_anomalies
Global Ocean Sea Surface Temperature time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Sea Surface Temperature (SST) Analysis:
 document describes analysis of global average sea surface temperature (SST) data from 1993 to 2021 analysis conducted using daily SST data from European Space Agency (ESA) and Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).
 Key Findings:

 Global Warming Trend: 1993-2021 global average SST increased 0.015 ± 0.001°C per year (with 95% confidence).
 2021 SST: 2021 sixth warmest year in analyzed time series.
 El Niño and La Niña Influence: Variations in time series beyond global warming trend associated with El Niño and La Niña events Peaks time series correspond to strong El Niño events in 1997/1998 2015/2016.

 Methodology:

 Daily to Monthly: Daily SST data averaged to create monthly means
 Climatological Base: climatology calculated by averaging monthly means over 1993-2014.
 Monthly Anomalies: Monthly anomalies calculated by subtracting climatology from monthly means
 Area Averaging: Monthly anomalies averaged over globe weighting each grid cell by area.
 Trend Extraction: area-averaged time series subjected to X11 seasonal adjustment procedure separates time series into trend, residual seasonal component errors.
 Trend Slope: slope trend component calculated using robust method (Sen 1968). method calculates 95% confidence range in slope.

 Significance:
 analysis highlights ongoing increase in global average SST with significant influence from El Niño and La Niña events. SST critical climate variable influencing global heat balance, ocean circulation weather patterns marine ecosystems Understanding trends crucial for climate monitoring predicting future climate change impacts.
---

Iberia Biscay Ireland Ocean Heat Content Anomaly (0-2000m) time series and trend from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Ocean Heat Content (OHC) in Iberia-Biscay-Ireland (IBI) Region
 text describes ocean heat content (OHC) in focusing on trends variability breakdown:
 Definition and Methodology

 OHC: deviation from reference period (1993-2020), proportional to average temperature change from surface to 2000m depth
 Calculation: Average time series error bars calculated using data from four CMEMS products (IBI-MYP, GLO-MYP CORA, ARMOR).
 Data Sources: products provide temperature data for IBI region

 Key Findings:

 Variability: OHC anomaly time series shows strong year-to-year variations
 Trend slight ocean warming trend of 0.49±0.4 W/m2 detected not statistically significant.

 Context and Significance:

 OHC's Role: OHC crucial role in ocean-atmosphere interactions sea level change marine ecosystems human livelihoods
 Regional Trends: North Atlantic Ocean experienced shifts in temperature and salinity trends. Decadal warming (1990-2004) followed by cooling and freshening (2005-2014). variations likely influenced by ocean internal dynamics air-sea interactions
 Impact on IBI Region: Changes in North Atlantic connectivity with Mediterranean Sea trends influence temporal evolution of regional ocean heat content in IBI region

 Overall
 study highlights significant year-to-year variability in OHC in IBI region warming trend exists weak not statistically significant Further research needed to understand complex interplay of factors influencing regional OHC variability region

Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Season length (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed description of raster file containing temporal trends in length vegetation growing season breakdown of key information:
 Data Source:

 MODIS MCD43 NBAR product provides surface reflectance data from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS).
 Plant Phenology Index (PPI): vegetation index from MODIS data for tracking growth cycle vegetation
 TIMESAT software: calculate start and end dates growing season from PPI temporal curve.

 Data Content:

 Season Length (LENGTH): primary data product representing number of days between start and end growing season for each year
 Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (VPP) parameters: Season Length one of 13 VPP parameters from PPI Seasonal Trajectories providing information on aspects vegetation growth

 Data Format and Availability:

 Raster files data provided in raster format with resolution 500m x 500m.
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA projection matching MODIS MCD43 tiling grid
 Coverage: Covers EEA38 countries United Kingdom
 Temporal Coverage: Two seasons per year starting from 2000 onwards
 Availability: Currently available on demand Full open free access available by end of 2022.

 Key Points:

 data valuable for understanding changes in vegetation growth patterns over time especially relation to climate change
 use of MODIS data and physically-based vegetation index (PPI) provides reliable source for tracking vegetation phenology
 data provided at high spatial resolution (500m), for detailed analysis of regional trends

 dataset provides valuable information for researchers environmental managers policymakers interested in understanding vegetation dynamics, climate change impacts related issues

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/arctic-ocean-chlorophyll-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_ARCTIC_OCEANCOLOUR_area_averaged_mean
Arctic Ocean Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Arctic Chlorophyll Time Series Analysis
 document describes analysis chlorophyll concentration in Arctic Ocean using data from Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). breakdown key information:
 Data Source:

 Regional Chlorophyll Reprocessed (REP) products from CMEMS derived from ESA Ocean Colour Climate Change Initiative (ESA OC-CCI) data
 Daily regional mean values calculated from weighted averages pixel area

 Methodology:

 Seasonal cycle removal: Census-I method used extract remove annual cycle from original time series
 Linear trend calculation: linear regression fitted to deasonalised time series determine linear trend

 Context

 Phytoplankton chlorophyll concentration critical indicators of Arctic Ocean health responding to changes in light nutrients sea-ice cover
 Recent studies observed increasing annual net primary production earlier chlorophyll concentration peaks linked to sea-ice decline

 CMEMS Key Findings:

 Overall positive trend (1997-2021): average linear trend shows increase in chlorophyll concentration rate 0.86 ± 0.17% per year
 Plateauing trend since 2013 time series exhibits plateau in linear trend amplitude baseline of seasonal cycle decrease
 Significant decrease in 2021 annual average for 2021 is 1.05 mg m-3 30% reduction compared to 2020.
 No major changes in bloom timing No significant changes timing amplitude spring autumn blooms observed in 2021

 Implications

 trend suggests complex interplay of factors influencing chlorophyll concentration in Arctic
 plateauing trend decrease in 2021 highlight need for continued monitoring to understand drivers variability
 Further research needed to disentangle impact of climate change natural variability other factors on Arctic chlorophyll dynamics

 References

Sathyendranath, S., et al. (2019). Ocean Colour Climate Change Initiative (ESA OC-CCI).
 Jackson, T. (2020). Regional Chlorophyll Algorithms.
 Vantrepotte, V., al. (2009). Census-I method removing seasonal cycle time series.
 Arrigo, K. R. van Dijken, G. (2015). Increasing primary production Arctic Ocean
 Kahru, M., et al. (2011). Earlier spring phytoplankton blooms Arctic Ocean.
 Sathyendranath, S., al. (2018). CMEMS Arctic Chlorophyll Time Series Report.

 summary provides concise overview findings document deeper understanding analysis refer original document cited references.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-sea-mean-sea-level-extreme-observations
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_VAR_EXTREME_SL_MEDSEA_slev_mean_and_anomaly_obs
Mediterranean Sea Mean Sea Level extreme from Observations Reprocessing
OMIVAR__EXTREME_SL_MEDSEA_slev_mean_and_anomaly_obs Indicator: Deep Dive
 definition provides detailed explanation of indicator significance in understanding variability of sea level extremes in Mediterranean Sea breakdown
 it measures

 indicator analyzes 99th and 1st percentiles of sea level data from tide gauges Mediterranean coastline percentiles represent highest and lowest sea level values observed annually providing insights into extreme events
 using percentiles instead of annual maximum minimum values indicator less susceptible to measurement errors enhancing reliability
 indicator calculates annual mean sea level and anomaly (deviation from long-term average) for each year

 matters

 Sea level is critical Essential Ocean Variable affected by climate change
 Global mean sea level rise accelerated since 1990s due to warming oceans melting glaciers
 global rise accompanied by regional variations particularly in Mediterranean influenced by oceanographic meteorological factors
 Extreme sea level events exacerbated by storms pose threats to coastal communities leading to flooding erosion infrastructure damage.

 CMEMS Key Findings:

 indicator calculated for 11 tide gauge stations in Mediterranean most in Western Mediterranean
 99th percentiles reflect spatial variability of tidal regimes along coast ranging from 0.23 meters in Ibiza to 0.39 meters in Málaga
 Most stations show negative anomalies in 99th percentile for 2020 indicating lower than average extreme sea levels anomalies more pronounced towards north reaching -12 cm in Marseille.
 Some locations like Valencia and Ibiza exhibit positive anomalies suggesting higher than average extreme sea levels in 2020.

conclusion OMIVAR__EXTREME_SL_MEDSEA_slev_mean_and_anomaly_obs indicator provides insights into variability of extreme sea levels in Mediterranean Sea. analysis highlights importance of monitoring these events to understand changing patterns impact on coastal communities.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-5
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Large integral (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed description Total Productivity (TPROD) dataset key component pan-European High Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity (HR-VPP) project breakdown information
 Dataset Overview

 Data: Temporal trend aboveground vegetation biomass productivity
 Source: MODIS BRDF-Adjusted Reflectance product (MODIS MCD43 NBAR).
 Index: Plant Phenology Index (PPI).
 Calculation: Area under temporal curve above baseline (LINT) using TIMESAT software
 Coverage: EEA38 countries United Kingdom
 Resolution: 500m x 500m
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA
 Temporal Frequency: Two seasons per year starting from 2000.
 Update Frequency: First quarter each year

 Key Concepts:

 Plant Phenology Index (PPI): physically based vegetation index growth cycle vegetation
 Seasonal Trajectories: Derived from index values capturing vegetation growth pattern over season
 Total Productivity (TPROD): One of 13 VPP parameters representing growing season integral (sum of daily values).
 Start of Season Date (SOSD): Beginning growing season
 End of Season Date (EOSD): End growing season

 Data Availability:

 Full access Expected available online by end of 2022
 On-Demand: Available via form Copernicus Land Monitoring Service website

 dataset offers valuable information about vegetation productivity trends across Europe calculated from satellite data providing insights into health growth patterns vegetation over time

 Headline: "Visualize the Urban Heat Island Effect Across Europe (2008-2017)"

 Understand magnitude spatial distribution of UHI effect
 Identify areas vulnerable to heat stress.
 Develop informed strategies for mitigating impacts urban heat."

 providing more context visuals make application description engaging informative encouraging potential users to explore valuable insights.

thorough description of Corine Land Cover Change 1990-2000 (CHA9000) dataset breakdown key information
 What?

 Purpose dataset tracks land cover changes in Europe between 1990 and 2000.
 Source derived from satellite imagery analyzed by national teams across Europe
 Method: change detection based comparing two sets images

 Key Features

 Classification Uses hierarchical system with 44 land cover classes
 Resolution: Land cover status mapped at 25 hectares minimum change layers higher resolution (5 hectares).
 Linear Elements minimum width features 100 meters.

 Relevance

439
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/corine-land-cover-change-2006-2012-vector-europe-6-yearly
https://land.copernicus.eu/pan-european/corine-land-cover/lcc-2006-2012/view
CORINE Land Cover Change 2006-2012 (vector), Europe, 6-yearly - version 2020_20u1, May 2020
text provides comprehensive overview of Corine Land Cover Change 2006-2012 (CHA0612) dataset break down key information
 What is CHA0612?

 dataset documenting changes in land cover land use between 2006 and 2012 across Europe
 part of Corine Land Cover (CLC) service project coordinated by European Environment Agency (EEA).
 data derived from satellite imagery comparing images from 2006 and 2012.

 How produced?

 National teams from EEA member cooperating countries contribute to project
 create national CLC inventories by classifying satellite images
 national inventories combined into European land cover map

 Key features of CHA0612:

 Classification uses hierarchical 3-level CLC nomenclature with 44 classes.
 Resolution:
 Status layers cover have minimum mapping unit (MMU) of 25 hectares
 Change layers (showing changes between 2006 and 2012) have higher resolution with MMU of 5 hectares.


 Linear elements: status and change layers have minimum width of 100 meters for linear features like roads or rivers

 Importance of CHA0612:

 valuable resource for monitoring environmental changes across Europe understand
 impact of climate change
 loss of biodiversity
 Urban sprawl
 Changes in agriculture
 Water resource management



 more information

 Copernicus Land Monitoring Service: https://land.copernicus.eu/
 CLC product description and mapping guides: https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/
 CLC class descriptions: https://land.copernicus/user-corner/technical-library/corine-land-co...

 CHA0612 significant dataset providing detailed view of land cover changes across Europe over crucial period key resource for researchers policymakers interested in environmental monitoring and management

441
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/atlantic-european-north-west-shelf-ocean-physics-0
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=NORTHWESTSHELF_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_PHY_004_013
Atlantic - European North West Shelf - Ocean Physics Analysis and Forecast
comprehensive description of ocean physics analysis forecast system for North-West European Shelf simplified summary:
 Key Features:

 High-resolution model: Uses NEMO (Nucleus for European Modelling of the Ocean) at 1.5 km resolution with wave model.
 Data assimilation: Incorporates observations like surface temperature salinity profiles satellite sea level data to improve accuracy.
 Real-time updates: Provides daily updates with 6-day forecast 2-day hindcast.
 Detailed outputs: Offers hourly quarter-hourly daily averages of various oceanographic parameters including temperature salinity currents sea level mixed layer depth.

 system:

 Combines sophisticated ocean model with data assimilation techniques provide comprehensive accurate picture of ocean's current state future evolution
 Utilizes data from various sources including satellite observations atmospheric models river discharge data.

 Overall
 ocean physics analysis forecast system critical role in understanding predicting dynamics of North-West European Shelf significant implications for marine ecosystems coastal communities maritime activities.

Sea Ice Area/Volume Transport in the Nordic Seas from Reanalysis
Summary of Sea Ice Transport in Arctic:
 This text describes importance of sea ice transport for Arctic Ocean's freshwater balance impact on North Atlantic focuses on two key areas:
 1. Fram Strait:
 Major gateway for freshwater export from Arctic to North Atlantic
 Represents significant sea ice export contributing to ~10% of total sea ice volume export annually
 Shows distinct seasonal cycle maximum transport in winter
 Displays slight positive trend in volume transport over past 25 years.
 2. Barents Sea:
 Sea ice transport from Polar Basin crucial role in formation of Barents Sea Polar Front dividing sea into Arctic and boreal regions
 experienced significant decrease in sea ice thickness reducing sea ice import from Polar Basin by nearly 90%.
 Winds critical role in influencing temporal variations in sea ice transport.
 information highlights

 crucial role of sea ice transport in Arctic's freshwater budget influence on global ocean circulation
 impact of climate change on sea ice transport in Arctic significant implications for marine ecosystem resources
 importance of further research and monitoring of sea ice transport in Arctic

 Key takeaway: Arctic undergoing significant changes decreasing sea ice volume and transport affecting entire system Understanding these changes impact crucial for managing Arctic's resources predicting future climate scenarios.

https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: End-of-season date (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed description of "End-of-Season Date (EOSD)" time series dataset product of Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS). breakdown of key information:
 it is

 Data: time series of raster files representing date vegetation growing season ends
 Basis: Derived from Plant Phenology Index (PPI), calculated from MODIS satellite data
 Method: EOSD determined by analyzing annual PPI curve using TIMESAT software marking date when PPI reaches 15% of seasonal amplitude during green-down period.

 Key Features:

 Resolution: 500m x 500m
 Projection: ETRS89-LAEA aligned with MCD43 tiling grid.
 Coverage: EEA38 countries United Kingdom
 Time Period: 2000 to present updates first quarter of each year
 Availability: Currently "on-demand" via form full online access planned for end of 2022.

 Significance
 EOSD dataset valuable for various applications including:

 Monitoring vegetation phenology Understanding timing of seasonal changes
 Climate change research Analyzing impact climate change on plant growth patterns
 Agricultural monitoring: Assessing length of growing season for different crops
 Ecological studies: Understanding plant responses to environmental variations.

 summary
 EOSD time series dataset provides valuable resource for monitoring end of vegetation growing season across Europe high resolution wide coverage availability through Copernicus Land Monitoring Service make valuable tool for researchers, environmental managers decision-makers

446
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/medium-resolution-vegetation-phenology-and-productivity-3
https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clms_mrvpp_pum_d1-0.pdf
Medium Resolution Vegetation Phenology and Productivity: Start-of-season date (raster 500m), Oct. 2022
text provides detailed description of raster file dataset containing time series data for start of vegetation growing season across Europe. breakdown of key information:
 dataset represents:

 Start of Growing Season: dataset records date vegetation growing season begins each year.
 Time Series: dataset covers period from 2000 to 2021 provides start-of-season date for each year timeframe.

 Data Source and Methodology:

 MODIS Data: dataset derived from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) satellite data MCD43 NBAR product provides adjusted reflectance values.
 Plant Phenology Index (PPI): dataset utilizes PPI, vegetation index designed monitor plant growth stages. PPI calculated from MODIS data using radiative transfer models.
 TIMESAT Software: start-of-season date determined by analyzing annual PPI curve using TIMESAT software.
 SOSD Definition: start-of-season (SOSD) defined as date when PPI reaches 25% of seasonal amplitude during green-up period.

 Dataset Characteristics:

 Spatial Resolution: data provided as raster files with resolution of 500m x 500m.
 Projection: data uses ETRS89-LAEA projection aligned with MODIS MCD43 tiling grid.
 Coverage: dataset covers EEA38 countries and United Kingdom.
 Frequency dataset includes two growing seasons per year.
 Availability: data available on-demand by filling form Full online access planned for end of 2022.

 dataset valuable resource for researchers scientists interested in studying:

 Vegetation Phenology: Understanding timing of plant growth stages respond to climate change
 Land Monitoring: Tracking changes in vegetation dynamics over time
 Climate Modeling: Integrating vegetation phenology data into climate models.

If interested in accessing dataset, encourage you to check provided website and contact information.

 Dataset Overview

 Deprecated dataset outdated newer version available use updated version instead
 Data Type: Gridded data organized in grid format

 Spatial Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° translates to 10km x 10km grid cell size
 Vertical Coverage: Data for various altitudes surface 50m 250m 500m 1000m 2000m 3000m 5000m
 Temporal Coverage dataset includes data for 2018 2020.
 Resolution Data in monthly files 1-hourly analyses
 File Format: NetCDF (Network Common Data Form), common format for scientific data
 Update Frequency dataset updated twice a year

 Main Variables
 dataset contains air quality variables

 Ammonia (NH3): μg m-3 per cubic meter
 Carbon monoxide (CO): μg m-3
 Nitrogen dioxide (NO2): μg m-3

 Non-methane volatile organic compounds (VOCs): μg m-3
 Ozone (O3): μg m-3
 PM10 dust fraction: μg m-3 (particulate matter diameter less than 10 micrometers
 PM2.5 secondary inorganic aerosol fraction: μg m-3 diameter less than 2.5 micrometers
 Particulate matter d < 10 μm (PM10): μg m-3
 Particulate matter d < 2.5 μm (PM2.5): μg m-3
 Peroxyacyl nitrates (PANs): μg m-3
 Sulphur dioxide (SO2): μg m-3

provided dataset is deprecated, seek updated version for most accurate up-to-date information.
 dataset provides detailed spatial and temporal coverage of air quality across Europe.
 dataset useful for analyzing air quality trends for understanding distribution of pollutants over space and time.

 Key Points:

 Definition: SIE is area ocean covered by 15% sea ice concentration (SIC), calculated from satellite observations
 Trend slight increase in SIE Southern Hemisphere since 1979 trend not statistically significant.
 Annual Mean: +0.07 +/- 0.05 106 km2 per decade (+0.62% per decade).
 Winter (September): +0.10 +/- 0.06 106 km2 per decade (+0.55% per decade).
 Summer (February): +0.03 +/- 0.05 106 km2 per decade (+0.76% per decade).
 Interannual Variability: Significant interannual variability exists 2016-2019 lower values recovery in 2020.
 Comparison to IPCC: trend in line with IPCC's assessment no statistically significant trend Antarctic sea ice extent (1979-2018).
 2021: SIE slightly above 1979-2021 average between March August.

Sea Ice Extent (SIE): Key Indicator Climate Change
 text provides comprehensive explanation Sea Ice Extent (SIE) importance indicator climate change breakdown key points
 Definition

 Sea Ice Extent (SIE): area ocean covered by 15% Sea Ice Concentration (SIC).
 Sea Ice Concentration (SIC): ocean surface covered by sea ice measured using satellite data
 SIE measured in millions square kilometers (106 km2) Trends expressed in 106 km2 per decade

 Importance

 Floating Sea Ice Acts blanket insulating ocean from cold polar atmosphere
 Seasonal Cycle Formation melting sea impacts human activities ecosystems wildlife
 Monitoring Climate Change Changes in SIE crucial indicator climate health

 CMEMS Key Findings

 Northern Hemisphere SIE Trend decreased annual rate -0.51 +/- 0.02 106 km2 per decade (-4.36% per decade) since 1979
 Summer vs. Winter Loss Summer (September) SIE loss greater than winter (March) loss
 Summer (September) Trend -0.81 +/- 0.06 106 km2 per decade (-12.50% per decade).
 Winter (March) Trend -0.39 +/- 0.03 106 km2 per decade (-2.54% per decade).


 Extreme Events 2012 record minimum Northern Hemisphere SIE followed by 2020.
 Recent Data July 2021 second lowest mean July SIE

 Conclusion
 decreasing SIE trend particularly summer indicates significant changes in Arctic climate system trend impacting ecosystems Arctic communities global climate patterns Monitoring SIE essential for understanding impacts climate change implementing mitigation strategies

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-chlorophyll-time-series-and-trend-observations

Baltic Sea Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Analysis Chlorophyll Trends Baltic Sea
 text provides detailed analysis of chlorophyll concentration trends Baltic Sea using time series from regional chlorophyll reprocessing by CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service). breakdown key points:
 Data and Methodology:

 Source: Chlorophyll data from CMEMS based on merged satellite data from sources (MERIS, MODIS-AQUA SeaWiFS NPP-VIIRS OLCI-A) processed at 1km resolution.
 Algorithm: Chlorophyll derived using Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) neural network trained on field measurements BiOMaP program.
 Time Series: Monthly regional mean values calculated deseasonalized using X-11 methodology.
 Trend Analysis: Mann-Kendall test Sens's method applied determine magnitude trend.

 Context Significance:

 Chlorophyll as Proxy: Chlorophyll concentration serves proxy for phytoplankton abundance sensitive to environmental factors like light temperature nutrients mixing.
 Importance of Monitoring: Monitoring chlorophyll at temporal spatial scales crucial to distinguish long-term climate signals from short-term natural variability.
 Baltic Sea Dynamics: Phytoplankton Baltic Sea responds to variations Sea Surface Temperature (SST) associated climate variability.

 Key Findings:

 Positive Trend: Baltic Sea shows positive trend in chlorophyll concentration period 1997-2021 slope of 0.67 ± 0.46% per year.
 Caution on Comparison: trend estimate not directly comparable to previous reports due to changes in chlorophyll algorithm.
 Year-to-Year Variability: Maxima minima values similar year-to-year clear maximum in 2008 minimum in 2004.
 Recent Increase: Chlorophyll increasing weakly since 2019.

Overall, analysis reveals positive trend in chlorophyll concentration in Baltic Sea over past 25 years further investigation needed to understand driving factors behind trend potential consequences for Baltic Sea ecosystem.
 Additional Information:

 DOI: data and analysis available through provided DOI.
 CMEMS: For more information about CMEMS products, visit their website.
 Related Research: text cites various research articles for further reading on subject.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-zonal-mean-subsurface-temperature-cumulative
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_TEMPSAL_Tyz_trend
Global Ocean Zonal Mean Subsurface Temperature cumulative trend from Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Breakdown Ocean Warming Trend Definition Key Findings
 text describes method for analyzing ocean warming trends subsurface focusing on period 1993-2019. breakdown key points:
 1. Definition:

 Goal: measure average change in subsurface ocean temperature over time (1993-2019).
 Method:
 Linear Regression: Calculates slope linear trend at each grid point (depth latitude) determine rate temperature change
 Global Mean: Averages linear change across all grid points create global mean depth-latitude plot temperature trend.
 Multi-Product Approach: Uses data from 5 datasets to estimate trend averages results improve reliability robustness findings
 Standard Deviation: Calculates standard deviation between 5 datasets assess consistency reliability results.



 2. Context:

 Importance of Subsurface Warming: surface temperature changes influenced by atmospheric exchange deeper ocean temperatures affected by complex dynamics.
 Impacts of Warming: Ocean warming contributes to significant environmental changes including
 Changes in marine ecosystems biodiversity species distribution
 Increased coral bleaching ocean acidification.
 Intensification of tropical cyclones.



 3. Key Findings:

 Overall Warming: upper ocean (top 300m) experienced significant warming trend between 1993 and 2019.
 Depth Variation: warming signal extends to around 800m depth in some regions Southern Ocean), signal weaker in deeper layers due to increased variability noise.
 Regional Variations: Interannual decadal fluctuations can mask or amplify warming trend in specific regions subpolar North Atlantic shows "cold event" with less clear warming trends below 100m depth.

 4. Limitations:

 findings based on limited time period (1993-2019).
reliability of trend limited in deeper layers where signal-to-noise ratio low.
 Decadal variations significantly influence observed trends.

 5. Conclusion:
 analysis indicates clear trend of ocean warming in upper layers (top 300m) over past 27 years signal becomes less clear in deeper layers, highlighting need for further investigation longer time series to understand long-term trends in subsurface ocean warming.
---

satellite-cloud-properties
summary of Essential Climate Variable (ECV) Cloud Properties dataset breakdown of key information emphasizing clarity organization
 dataset?

 Focus Describes state Earth's upper atmosphere using cloud properties crucial for understanding weather climate Earth's energy budget
 Importance Clouds vital role in
 water cycle (evaporation transport precipitation
 Atmospheric circulation (influencing wind patterns
 Earth's energy balance (reflecting sunlight absorbing re-emitting infrared radiation)


 Challenge Clouds major source of uncertainty in climate models due to complex behavior

 Key Data Variables
 dataset provides four main variables categorized into

 Averaged Cloudiness: Overall cloud coverage
 Cloud Height Products: altitude of cloud layers
 Cloud Physical Properties:
 Liquid water content: water liquid form within clouds
 Ice water content: water frozen form within clouds



 Dataset Structure

 Two Product Families
 CLARA (CM cLoud Albedo surface Radiation): High temporal spatial resolution
 CCI (Climate Change Initiative): Lower resolution multiple organizations


 Organizations involved
 CM SAF (Climate Monitoring Satellite Application Facility)
 CCI (Climate Change Initiative)
 C3S (Copernicus Climate Change Service)


 Data Records
 TCDRs (Thematic Climate Data Records): Long consistent continuous datasets suitable for climate change analysis
 ICDRs (Interim Climate Data Records): Regular updates extending TCDRs to cover recent periods



 Documentation and Validation

 Comprehensive documentation detailing algorithms data description validation results available for further investigation

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-level-black-sea
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-level-black-sea
satellite-sea-level-black-sea
detailed description of dataset containing sea level anomaly data for Black Sea breakdown information:
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose dataset provides daily measurements of sea level anomalies in Black Sea calculated relative to 20-year average (1993-2012).
 Data Type: Gridded data organized in structured grid with defined horizontal and vertical resolutions
 Spatial Coverage dataset covers entire Black Sea
 Temporal Coverage: data spans from January 1st, 1993 to June 3rd, 2020.
 Resolution:
 Horizontal: 0.125 degrees by 0.125 degrees (approximately 14 kilometers at equator).
 Temporal: Daily.


 File Format: NetCDF (Network Common Data Form)
 Version: vDT2018
 Update Status: dataset no longer updated

 Data Variables
 dataset includes variables:

 Sea level anomaly (m): primary variable representing difference between sea surface height and mean sea surface for reference period (1993-2012).
 Geostrophic velocity anomalies meridian component (m s-1): Represents northward component of geostrophic current
 Geostrophic velocity anomalies zonal component (m s-1): Represents eastward component geostrophic current

 Key Points

 Reference Period sea level anomalies calculated relative to 20-year mean reference period (1993-2012).
 Data Accuracy: use of multiple satellite missions dedicated mapping algorithm for Black Sea region contributes to improved accuracy sampling
 Uncertainties dataset includes uncertainty estimates for each grid cell.
 Documentation documentation offers detailed information about data retrieval, filtering optimization procedures error estimation

 Uses
 dataset be used for various applications related to oceanography climate science including

 Sea Level Change Studies: Monitoring sea level rise or fall over time.
Ocean Circulation Research: Analyzing dynamics of currents water masses in Black Sea.
 Climate Modeling: Providing inputs for climate models require accurate sea level information.
 Environmental Monitoring: Assessing potential impacts climate change on coastal areas.

 Note: data no longer updated essential to consult recent datasets for up-to-date information Black Sea sea level anomalies.

Summary Oligotrophic Subtropical Gyre Trends South Pacific
 report focuses on South Pacific subtropical gyre vast region low nutrient levels low phytoplankton activity crucial to global biogeochemical cycles.
 Key Findings:


 Gyre Area:

 Slight increase: gyre area positive trend increasing by 0.04% relative to 2000-01-01 values between 1997 and 2021.
 Decadal Oscillations: underlying cyclical signal observed period approximately decade suggesting fluctuations in gyre size over time.
 Lower Trend: trend lower than increase 0.16% for 1997-2020 period direction of change remains positive.
 Statistical Significance: current trend not statistically significant (p<0.05).



 Chlorophyll Concentration:

 Positive Trend: Chlorophyll concentration gyre positive trend increasing by 0.66% per year relative to 2000-01-01 values between 1997 and 2021.
 Higher Trend: rate higher than previously increase 0.45% per year for 1997-2020 period.
 Statistical Significance: current trend statistically significant (p<0.05).
 Increased Variability: last two years time series show increased variation from mean chlorophyll concentration.



 Contrasting Findings:

 Previous Studies:
 Polovina et al. (2008) found expansion of subtropical gyres based satellite data.
 Ocean State Report (Sathyendranath et al. 2018) reported reversal of trend in Pacific Ocean increase in gyre area from 2007 to 2016, linked to 2016 El Niño event.



 Overall:
 South Pacific gyre exhibits complex nuanced pattern of change Despite slight increase in area positive trend in chlorophyll concentration suggests overall increase in productivity gyre observed decadal oscillations increased variability recent years highlight importance of continued monitoring research understand long-term dynamics of crucial oceanic regions.
 Important Notes:

 statistical significance of trend in gyre area not conclusive.
 report covers 1997-2021 period further analysis needed to understand long-term trends.
 relationship between El Niño events gyre dynamics warrants further investigation.

 dataset includes seven variables related to solar (shortwave) and thermal (longwave) radiation:
 Incoming (downwelling) radiation
 Outgoing (upwelling) radiation
 Net radiation

 Climate change research
 Evaluation of climate models
 Renewable energy resource assessment (e solar power)



 Key Features of Dataset:

 Two Product Families:
 CLARA: Higher temporal resolution (more frequent data)
 CCI: Higher horizontal resolution (more detailed spatial data)

North West Shelf Sea Surface Temperature extreme from Observations Reprocessing
OMI_VAR_EXTREME_SST_NORTHWESTSHELF_sst_mean_and_anomaly_obs Indicator Explained
 indicator focuses on extreme sea surface temperature (SST) events in Northwest Shelf area includes North Atlantic and North Sea utilizes in situ buoy data measure SST between 0 and 5 meters deep.
 Key aspects indicator:

 Percentiles: indicator uses 99th and 1st percentiles of SST data less affected by individual measurement errors compared to annual maximum minimum values
 Temporal and Spatial Evolution: percentiles averaged over time spatial evolution of mean and anomaly displayed
 Anomaly: anomaly refers to difference between current year's SST and long-term average.

 Why indicator important?

 Climate Change Impacts: SST crucial ocean variable affected by climate change indicator monitor extreme SST events significant ecological societal impacts.
 North Atlantic and North Sea: Northwest Shelf area exhibits diverse SST trends North Atlantic experienced anomalous cold conditions since 2014, North Sea warming trend Understanding trends crucial for managing marine resources predicting future impacts
 Ecological Impacts: Extreme SST events impact on marine ecosystems affecting population dynamics biodiversity fisheries.

 CMEMS Key Findings:

 SST Range: mean 99th percentile SST varies across Northwest Shelf from 14oC in Northwest of British Isles to 20-21oC around Denmark.
 Standard Deviation standard deviation 99th percentile ranges from 0.5oC in English Channel to 1.7oC in buoys around Denmark
 Current Year Anomalies: year's anomalies showed positive and negative deviations from standard deviation in different regions Aarhus station in North East of Zealand Island showed significant negative anomaly of -2.0oC.

indicator provides valuable information on spatial temporal evolution of extreme SST events in Northwest Shelf. helps track changes in extreme SST crucial for understanding impacts of climate change on marine ecosystems managing marine resources effectively.

Summary of Oligotrophic Subtropical Gyre Trends in North Pacific
 document analyzes trends in size chlorophyll concentration of North Pacific subtropical gyre region ocean characterized by low nutrient levels low productivity.
 Key Findings:

 Gyre Area: North Pacific gyre area increasing positive trend 1.75% increase relative to 2000-01-01 values period 1997-2021 trend statistically significant (p<0.05).
 Chlorophyll Concentration: Chlorophyll concentration in gyre decreasing negative trend -0.26% per year relative to 2000-01-01 values period 1997-2021 trend statistically significant (p<0.05).

 Comparison with Previous Studies:

 Gyre Expansion: trend consistent with earlier studies showed expanding gyre areas (Polovina et al. 2008) rate of expansion slightly lower than previously reported.
 Chlorophyll Decline: observed decline in chlorophyll concentration consistent with previous findings (Sathyendranath et al 2018). trend slightly less negative than reported for 1997-2020 period.
 ENSO Influence: 2016 El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) event likely responsible for large increase in gyre area in Pacific in 2016, associated with significant declines in chlorophyll.

 Implications:

 Global Biogeochemical Impacts: subtle changes in gyre area chlorophyll concentration can impact global biogeochemical cycles.
 Ecosystem Response: trends highlight dynamic nature of ocean “deserts” potential vulnerability to changes climate other factors.

 Further Research:

 Investigating underlying mechanisms driving trends including influence of climate change other factors
 Understanding implications of changes for marine ecosystems broader global biogeochemical cycles.

 Data Source:

 CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service) satellite data (1997-2021).

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-cod-reproductive-volume-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_HEALTH_codt_volume
Baltic Sea Cod Reproductive Volume from Reanalysis
Summary of Cod Reproductive Volume in Baltic Sea
 document provides detailed analysis of cod reproductive volume in Baltic Sea crucial factor for recovery of economically important fish species
 Key points:

 Definition: Cod reproductive volume calculated based on volume water meeting specific criteria: salinity > 11 g/kg oxygen concentration > 2 ml/l water temperature > 1.5°C factors essential for successful cod reproduction
 Importance: volume fluctuates significantly peaks linked to Major Baltic Inflows bring saline, oxygenated water to deep basins inflows impact cod reproduction to increase in stock size years later
 Trends reproductive volume typically ranges between 200-400 km3 can reach 700-800 km3 during following Major Baltic Inflows.
 Recent Observations: In 2019 high volume of 800 km3 observed declining to 200 km3 by end of 2021.
 Challenges: Oxygen content declines faster than salinity in bottom layers limiting duration of suitable reproductive conditions.

 cod reproductive volume in Baltic Sea highly variable influenced by Major Baltic Inflows Continued monitoring volumes crucial for understanding supporting recovery of cod stocks
 Key takeaways:

 Major Baltic Inflows play vital role in cod reproduction
 Oxygen content critical factor limiting duration suitable reproductive conditions
 Fluctuations in cod reproductive volume have long-term implications for cod stock
 Further research monitoring essential for effective cod management.

cams-global-radiative-forcing-auxilliary-variables
dataset provides information on aerosol optical depths radiative effects crucial for understanding climate change breakdown of key features:
 Dataset Overview

 Focus: Aerosol optical depths radiative effects broken by aerosol origin (anthropogenic mineral dust marine land-based fine-mode natural aerosols).
 Purpose: complement "CAMS global radiative forcings" dataset providing breakdown of aerosol origin
 Methodology: dataset uses proxy method based on aerosol size to differentiate between anthropogenic natural aerosols CAMS reanalysis doesn't provide information directly

 Data Characteristics:

 Type: Gridded data
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Coverage: Global
 Resolution: 1° x 1° horizontal single level vertically
 Temporal Range: 2003-2017
 Resolution Daily data in monthly files
 Format: NetCDF 4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6

 Key Variables:

 Aerosol absorption optical depth at 550 nm: Dimensionless light absorbed by aerosols at specific wavelength
 Aerosol optical depth at 550 nm: Dimensionless total amount light scattered absorbed by aerosols
 Radiative effect of aerosol-radiation interactions Measured in W m-2 impact of aerosols on Earth's energy balance

 Significance

 Climate Change Research dataset essential for climate modeling understanding role of aerosols in climate change
 Atmospheric Research: provides insights into sources distribution of aerosols impact on radiation influence on atmospheric processes
 Environmental Monitoring dataset to track changes in aerosol properties impact on air quality

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/kuroshio-phase-observations-reprocessing
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_CURRENTS_kuroshio_phase_area_averaged
Kuroshio Phase from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Kuroshio Extension Phase Variations Indicator
 document describes indicator for monitoring variability Kuroshio Extension, crucial current in North Pacific Ocean. indicator based on Eddy Kinetic Energy (EKE) from satellite altimeter data DUACS (Data Unification and Altimeter Calibration System).
 breakdown key points:
 1. Indicator Definition:

 indicator calculated by averaging standardized high frequency altimeter EKE within specific area (142-149°E and 32-37°N).
 Data used from delayed-time (reprocessed) and near real-time altimeter sea level products from CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service).
 slight changes occurred due to updated data extended time series, general variability of Kuroshio Extension remains robust (correlation coefficient of 0.988).

 2. Context and Importance:

 Kuroshio Extension crucial current influences distribution of phytoplankton and fish in region
 path variability significant for local economies marine ecosystems
 Understanding behavior essential for accurate predictions monitoring.

 3. Key Findings:

 Kuroshio Extension exhibits two distinct states:
 Elongated state (Strong state): narrow, strong steady jet.
 Contracted state (Weak state): weaker unsteady jet spread over wider latitudinal band.


 Kuroshio Extension path upstream more variable in contracted state less variable in elongated state.
 Eddy kinetic energy levels higher in contracted state lower in elongated state.
 Extension often transitions between two phases with intermediate states.
 In 2018, indicator showed elongated state followed by weakening neutral phase.

 4. Data Access:

 indicator data and further details available through CMEMS website and provided DOIs:
 https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00222
 https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00222



 conclusion this indicator provides valuable tool for monitoring predicting variability Kuroshio Extension contributing to better understanding of its crucial role in North Pacific Ocean ecosystem implications for various sectors.

Black Sea Ocean Heat Content Anomaly (0-300m) time series and trend from Reanalysis & Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Ocean Heat Content (OHC) in Black Sea
 document provides information about ocean Black Sea focusing on recent trends implications
 Key Definitions Methods:

 OHC: Defined as deviation from reference period (1993-2014) calculated by integrating temperature difference between monthly average climatological values from surface to 300m depth
 Data Sources: OHC data derived from global regional products including
 Black Sea Reanalysis
 Global Reanalysis
 Observation-based products like CORA ARMOR3D


 Ensemble Mean: Averages data from different sources to reduce uncertainties provide robust estimate

 Key Findings:

 Significant Warming: Black Sea experienced continuous increase in OHC (0-300m) since 2005, reaching record values recent years
 Warming Rate: Black Sea warming at rate of 1.00±0.09 W m-2 higher than global average
 Impact on CIL: increasing OHC weakens Cold Intermediate Layer (CIL), periods of cooling 2012 2017) favor CIL restoration

 Significance:

 Understanding changing OHC in Black Sea crucial for comprehending evolving Earth system implications for future climate change
 increasing OHC has significant ecological consequences influencing marine ecosystems affecting overall health of Black Sea
 Monitoring analysis of OHC data provide valuable insights for improving predictions mitigating impacts climate change on Black Sea region.

 References:

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00306
 Relevant Research: Lima et al., 2020; von Schuckmann et al., 2018; Akpinar et al., 2017; Stanev et al. 2019.

 conclusion Black Sea experiencing significant warming trend impacting ocean heat content influencing key features Cold Intermediate LayerFurther monitoring analysis of this phenomenon crucial to understanding long-term impacts on Black Sea ecosystem potential implications for surrounding region.

Antarctic Sea Ice Extent from Reanalysis
Summary of Antarctic Sea Ice Extent Data
 document overview of Antarctic sea ice extent data collected from 1993 to present highlights key findings importance of monitoring sea ice changes for understanding health Earth
 Key definitions

 Sea ice extent: total area ocean surface covered by 15% sea ice concentration
 Multi-product approach: ensemble mean of five global sea ice products robust estimate

 Key findings

 Large variability: Antarctic sea ice extent exhibits significant fluctuations with high and low periods
 Record highs and lows Record highs observed in 2014, record lows in 2017 2018.
 Alternating trends: annual sea ice extent shows alternating positive and negative trends since 1993.
 Slight decrease: slight decrease of -0.01*106km2 per decade observed between 1993-2018 loss of 0.1% per decade
 Significant losses: last quarter of 2016, 2017 2018 witnessed unusual losses of ice
 Uncertainties: Large uncertainties exist trend due to natural variability

 Importance of monitoring sea ice

 Climate change indicator: Sea ice changes sensitive indicator climate change
 Ocean processes Sea ice impacts ocean stratification vital role in climate system
 Ecosystem health: Sea ice essential for polar ecosystems influences human activities

 Key Resources

 CMEMS Ocean State Report: detailed scientific evaluations data on sea ice.
 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00186

 Conclusion
 Monitoring Antarctic sea ice extent critical for understanding impact climate change on polar regions uncertainties exist trend suggests slight decrease in sea ice cover Further research ongoing monitoring crucial to understand dynamics of sea ice implications for global climate system

Summary Black Sea Sea Surface Temperature Anomalies (2021)
 document provides information Black Sea Sea Surface Temperature (SST) anomalies for 2021 derived from CMEMS Reprocessed Black Sea L4 SST satellite product
 Key Findings

 Decreasing trend: 2021 decrease in SST anomalies compared previous years (2018-2020). highest anomaly (~2°C) January 2021 lowest (~-0.27°C) observed May.
 Long-term warming From 1993 to 2021 Black Sea SST warmed 0.072 ± 0.004 °C/year average increase approximately 2°C over 29 years
 Possible shift: trend suggests potential shift towards decreasing tendency

 Data Methodology

 data derived from CMEMS Reprocessed Black Sea L4 SST satellite product (SST_BS_SST_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_010_022) combines data from ESA Climate Change Initiative (CCI), Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), AVHRR Pathfinder version 5.3.
 SST anomalies calculated as deviations from 1993-2014 reference period
 product includes unfiltered 24-month filtered SST anomalies

 Context

 SST crucial climate variable influences climate regulation variability
 Monitoring SST essential for understanding global climate system detecting changes climate
 Long-term SST variability provides insights into slow changes SST temperature trends
 Short-term SST anomalies identify extreme events like marine heatwaves.

 dataset produced on behalf of Copernicus Climate Change Service provides climatological indicators on European winter windstorms economic impact. draws on ERA5 reanalysis data synthetically derived set of physically realistic windstorm events based on modelled climatic conditions. dataset covers [time period], spatial resolution of [grid spacing] kilometers.
 primary users include insurance sector, reinsurers insurance industry service providers require catalogue of historical windstorm events within Europe to assess risk understand event distribution. dataset can also support sectors energy, transport, civil engineering government.
 data categorized as follows:

Windstorm Tracks: spatial track on location maximum relative vorticity above threshold defining windstorm moves over North Atlantic Ocean Europe.
 Windstorm Footprints: maximum wind speed of gusts for each grid point domain during passage storm over period 72 hours since selected storm first identified.
 Summary Indicators (Tier 1): Uses windstorm tracks maximum 10m wind speed annual decadal summary statistics for land regions in Europe. Examples include [List 2-3 specific summary indicators].
 Loss and Risk Indicators (Tier 3): Describes socio-economic impact of windstorms for various land cover building types in Europe. Examples include [List 2-3 specific risk indicators].

 By providing comprehensive dataset users gain deeper understanding of European windstorm patterns, potential impact associated risks. [If applicable, mention where dataset can be accessed].

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/black-sea-chlorophyll-time-series-and-trend-observations
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_BLKSEA_OCEANCOLOUR_area_averaged_mean
Black Sea Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Black Sea Chlorophyll Trends
 document describes analysis chlorophyll concentration trends in Black Sea using data from Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). breakdown
 Data Source
 Multi-sensor chlorophyll reprocessing product (MY) from CMEMS
 Derived from SeaWiFS, MODIS VIIRS MERIS OLCI satellite data
 Uses two regional algorithms: band-ratio (B/R) and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP).
 Methodology
 Monthly regional mean values calculated from 2D monthly mean (weighted by pixel area).
 Deseasonalized time series obtained using X-11 seasonal adjustment methodology
 Mann-Kendall test Sen's method applied determine trend magnitude
 Key Findings
 1997-2021 significant negative trend in chlorophyll concentration (-1.39±0.91% per year).
 Trend Characteristics
 Marked change in chlorophyll concentrations between 2002 and 2004.
 Variable minima maxima from 2004 onwards
 Continuous decrease in maxima from 2015 to mid 2020.
 Relative high chlorophyll values in 2021
 Comparison
 Trend aligns with findings Sathyendranath et al. (2018) contrasting trend to other European seas
 Context
 Chlorophyll concentration proxy for phytoplankton abundance
 Phytoplankton respond rapidly to changes environmental conditions (light temperature nutrients mixing).
 Long-term climate signals be separated from natural variability
 Black Sea influenced by North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO).

 analysis reveals negative trend in chlorophyll concentration Black Sea from 1997 to 2021 highlighting potential shifts in marine ecosystem Further research needed to investigate driving forces behind trend including influence climate variability human activities

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-subsurface-temperature-trend-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_TEMPSAL_Ttz_trend
Baltic Sea Subsurface Temperature trend from Reanalysis
Summary Baltic Sea Subsurface Temperature Trends
 text provides comprehensive analysis of subsurface temperature trends Baltic Sea from 1993 to 2021 based on regional reanalysis results (BALTICSEA_REANALYSIS_PHY_003_011). breakdown key findings:
 General Trend:

 Warming across all depths Baltic Sea shows consistent warming trend approximately 0.05 °C per year at all depths
 Strongest warming at thermocline and halocline largest warming trend (0.06 °C/year) at 20m depth coinciding with seasonal thermocline similar trend at 60-70m depth upper part permanent halocline.

 Contextual Information

 Seasonal cycle Baltic Sea's upper mixed layer experiences strong seasonal cycle driven by solar radiation peak temperatures in July/August minimum in February.
 Thermocline Halocline seasonal thermocline forms between 10-30m maximum in summer permanent halocline at 60-80m depth separating well-mixed upper layers from deeper isolated layers.
 Deep layer dynamics Temperature variations deep layers driven by mixing processes horizontal advection.
 Connection other trends surface warming trend correlates with increasing light attenuation (Kd490) chlorophyll concentration potentially leading to accelerated oxygen consumption ecosystem changes.

 Supporting Evidence:

 Previous studies research identified surface warming trends in Baltic Sea since 1990s decreasing trend in start date of spring phytoplankton bloom.
 Long-term data Measurements by Savchuk (2018) confirm deep-layer warming trend of 0.04 °C/year since 1979.

 Uncertainty:

 Confidence interval widest confidence interval for temperature trend in 60-m depth most significant interannual variability in this layer.

Conclusion:
 Baltic Sea experiencing widespread warming trend in subsurface layers strongest warming at thermocline and halocline depths. These changes, with other observed trends like decreasing bloom start dates increasing light attenuation highlight ongoing impact of climate change on Baltic Sea ecosystem necessitate continued monitoring research efforts.

Baltic Sea Chlorophyll-a trend map from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Baltic Sea Chlorophyll Trend Map Product
 product provides map of long-term trend in chlorophyll concentration Baltic Sea from 1997 to 2021 based on satellite data uses advanced processing techniques reliable consistent trend analysis
 Key Features

 Data Source: Satellite data from MERIS, MODIS-AQUA SeaWiFS NPP-VIIRS OLCI-A merged at 1km resolution
 Algorithm: Multi Layer Perceptron neural network trained on field measurements resulting in chlorophyll product
 Trend Analysis: Mann-Kendall test Sens's method applied to deseasonalized monthly time series calculate trend magnitude significance
 Visualization Trend map showing areas with significant positive or negative chlorophyll changes (%) per year

 Context

 Importance of Chlorophyll proxy for phytoplankton key players in carbon cycle Essential Climate Variable
 Baltic Sea Concerns Eutrophication major issue long-term chlorophyll data vital for monitoring environmental changes

 Key Findings

 Overall Positive Trend Baltic Sea shows average chlorophyll trend of 0.5% per year increase consistent with other European seas
 Regional Variations: Some areas northern Bothnian Bay Gulf of Finland exhibit weak negative trends

 Implications
 product provides valuable information for understanding long-term changes in chlorophyll in Baltic Sea inform management strategies environmental policies addressing eutrophication other challenges
 Further Exploration

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00198
 Source: CMEMS OC-TAC Regional Chlorophyll Reprocessed (MY) product
 References: Brando et al. (2021a; 2021b), Colella et al. (2016) Zibordi et al. (2011)

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-necd
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-necd
app-necd
great start to application analyze impact of weather events on EU member states' ability to meet emission targets. breakdown of provided improve it:
 Strengths:

 Clear Purpose: clearly state application's purpose: helping to identify exceptionally cold winters or dry summers in context NEC Directive.
 Relevant Data: chosen appropriate variables (temperature and precipitation) good data source (ERA5).
 User-Friendly Interface: map layers time slider provide intuitive way to explore data.

 Areas for Improvement:

 Expand on Functionality:
 Threshold Calculation: Explain calculating 10th percentile threshold for each member state and year Provide clear definition of "exceptionally cold" and "exceptionally dry" in threshold.
 Averaging Feature: Implement averaging functionality in NEC Directive (Article 5(2)). Allow user to view three-year average for each member state highlight if average exceeds emission reduction commitment.
 Temporal Analysis: Allow user to select multiple years to compare trends.


 Visual Enhancements:
 Member State Labels: Label each member state on map for clarity.
 Color Schemes: Use contrasting meaningful colors for map layers For example
 Red: Member states exceeding emission commitments.
 Blue: Member states below threshold.
 Green: Member states within acceptable range.




 Additional Features:
 Data Download: Allow users download data in map and tables.
 Documentation: Provide clear documentation on application works and limitations.



 Example Implementation:

 Threshold Calculation: 10th percentile calculated using ERA5 data for each member state.
 Averaging Feature: Allow user to select three consecutive years application calculate average for each member state compare to emission reduction commitment.
Visual Enhancements: Implement color scheme suggestions to highlight data points.

 Overall this application has potential to be powerful tool for analyzing impact of weather events on EU member states' ability to meet emission targets implementing suggested improvements create user-friendly informative application.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-sea-chlorophyll-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_MEDSEA_OCEANCOLOUR_area_averaged_mean
Mediterranean Sea Chlorophyll-a time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Analysis of Chlorophyll Concentration Mediterranean Sea: Summary
 document analyzes chlorophyll concentration in Mediterranean Sea using data from CMEMS (Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service) for period 1997-2021.
 Key findings:

 Overall Negative Trend: average trend for chlorophyll concentration Mediterranean Sea period slightly negative (-0.62±0.56% per year). contrast to increasing trend in chlorophyll concentration across European Seas reported by Sathyendranath et al. (2018).
 Significant Drop in Recent Years: minima values remained constant until 2015, noticeable decrease occurred between 2015 and 2020 reaching absolute minimum below 0.04 mg m-3 in 2020. downward trend evident in deseasonalized time series particularly between 2020 and 2021.
 Variability in Maxima: minima values consistent maxima exhibited variability year by year peak in 2015 exceeding 0.14 mg m-3. since 2016, reduction in maximum values observed.
 Potential Causes: decline in chlorophyll concentration Mediterranean Sea likely influenced by factors natural variability climate change human activities. Climate variability linked to North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) affect phytoplankton abundance region (Basterretxea et al. 2018, Colella et al. 2016).

 Methodology:

 Data Source: time series data analysis derived from CMEMS's regional chlorophyll reprocessed (MY) product, combines multi-sensor observations regional algorithms for chlorophyll estimation.
 Processing: Monthly mean values calculated followed by deseasonalization using X-11 method Mann-Kendall test and Sen's method applied to determine magnitude of trend.

 Significance:

Understanding long-term trends in chlorophyll concentration essential for assessing health marine ecosystems predicting impact climate change on marine life
 analysis highlights need for further investigation to pinpoint specific drivers behind decrease in chlorophyll concentration in Mediterranean Sea explore potential implications for marine ecosystem dynamics.

 Further Resources:

 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00259

 summary provides concise overview of analysis For detailed information on data methodology results consult original source cited references.
