https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-heat-and-cold-spells
sis-heat-and-cold-spells
dataset provides information on heat waves cold spells across Europe breakdown of key features used:
 Dataset Highlights:

 Multi-definition Approach: uses various definitions for heat waves cold spells European-wide national/regional comparisons understanding diverse events
 Future Projections: includes data for future time periods (1986-2085) incorporating climate change scenarios to analyze potential changes in extreme weather events
 Gridded Data: data provided as gridded dataset high spatial resolution (0.1° x 0.1°) for detailed analysis
 Ensemble Averaging: presents data averaged across multiple climate models reducing uncertainty robust estimate.

 Data Description Summary

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Coverage: European region (27N – 72N, 22W – 45E)
 Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° (high spatial detail)
 Time Period: 1986 to 2085
 Time Resolution: Yearly (season average)
 File Format: NetCDF 4
 Conventions: CF Metadata Convention v1.6, ACDD v1.3

 Main Variables:

 Cold spell days: Number days year cold spells specific definitions
 Heat wave days: Number days heat waves specific definitions

 Potential Applications:

 Climate Change Research: Analyze trends in heat waves cold spells over time understand response climate change assess potential impact on sectors
 Public Health Studies: Investigate health risks with extreme temperatures develop mitigation strategies
 Risk Assessment: Evaluate vulnerability of infrastructure communities to extreme weather events identify potential hazards
 Policy and Planning: Inform decision-making regarding adaptation measures disaster preparedness resource allocation for heat wave cold spell mitigation.

 Key Points to Consider:

Definitions: examine definitions for heat waves cold spells to ensure align with research needs.
 Uncertainty: Acknowledge inherent uncertainty in climate model projections especially for future periods.
 Regional Variations: Consider spatial variability of heat waves cold spells across Europe may differ significantly between regions.

 This dataset offers comprehensive valuable resource for studying heat waves cold spells in Europe. leveraging its capabilities researchers can gain deeper understanding of these events, impacts potential future scenarios.

http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BLKSEA_OMI_TEMPSAL_sst_trend
Black Sea Surface Temperature cumulative trend map from Observations Reprocessing
Summary blksea_omi_tempsal_sst_trend Product
 provides cumulative Sea Surface Temperature (SST) trend Black Sea from 1993 to 2021 breakdown


 Data Cumulative SST trend calculated as rate of change (°C/year) multiplied by number years (29)
 Source Derived from CMEMS Reprocessed Black Sea L4 SST satellite data (SST_BS_SST_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_010_022) data combines ESA Climate Change Initiative (CCI), Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), adjusted AVHRR Pathfinder dataset version 5.3.
 Methodology
 Daily (nighttime) SST maps with 0.05° grid resolution created
 X-11 seasonal adjustment procedure filters data for interannual variations
 Mann-Kendall test Sens’s method assess trend slope



 Key findings

 General warming trend Black Sea widespread warming tendency rates ranging from 0.053 °C/year to 0.080 °C/year
 Spatial pattern warming homogeneous throughout basin higher values eastern basin lower values western coasts major rivers
 Highest intensity Black Sea's SST trend most intense among all European Seas

 Importance

 Understanding climate change SST key indicator of climate change impact environment
 Monitoring marine ecosystems SST fluctuations impact marine life ecosystems
 Predicting extreme events SST anomalies signal marine heatwaves extreme events

 References

 Copernicus Marine Service Ocean State Report (OSR), Section 1.1 (Roquet et al., 2016; Mulet et al., 2018).
 QUID documentation: http://marine.copernicus.eu/documents/QUID/CMEMS-OMI-QUID-BLKSEA-SST.pdf

https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00218

North West Shelf Sea Surface Temperature extreme from Reanalysis
Summary CMEMS NORTHWESTSHELF_OMI_tempsal_extreme_var_temp_mean_and_anomaly Indicator:
 This indicator tracks extreme variability of Sea Surface Temperature (SST) in Northwest European Shelf region utilizes data from two CMEMS products

 North-West Shelf Multi Year Product: Provides map of average 99th percentile of SST period 1993-2019.
 Analysis Product: Provides 99th percentile of SST for year 2020 anomaly calculation (deviation from average).

 Key Findings:

 99th percentile represents warmest 4 days of summer SST
 In 2020 warmest anomalies observed in western approaches, Celtic and Irish Seas, English Channel southern North Sea increases up to 4°C compared to 1993-2019 average
 aligns with exceptionally warm sunny summer of 2020 in southern UK heatwaves in June and August
 northern UK experienced more average temperatures.

 Significance
 indicator provides valuable information about extremes of SST spatial variations understanding impacts of climate change potential risks to marine ecosystems human activities
 Context

 Northwest European Shelf characterized by North-South temperature gradient influenced by local currents shallow depths
 Atmospheric heat waves impact SST particularly in shallower areas like southern North Sea.

 Further details

 Scientific evaluations found in CMEMS Ocean State Report.
 indicator updated annually in November.

 Note summary provides concise overview of indicator For more detailed information refer to provided links original documentation.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/black-sea-oxygen-trend-observations-reprocessing
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BLKSEA_OMI_HEALTH_oxygen_trend
Black Sea Oxygen Trend from Observations Reprocessing
Black Sea Deoxygenation: Summary
 text summarizes oxygenation status of Black Sea open basin critical for marine life
 Key points:

 Permanent stratification: Due to different densities incoming water Black Sea permanently stratified restricts oxygenation to shallow surface layer
 Three indicators: Oxygen penetration depth, oxygen density oxygen inventory track health oxygenated layer
 Shrinking oxygenated layer: Over last 60 years oxygenated layer shrunk from 140m to 90m
 Deoxygenation trend: Argo profiler data suggests ongoing deoxygenation trend average oxygen penetration depth 72m in 2016, lowest on record.
 Cold water formation: Oxygenation linked to cold water formation hindered by warmer winter temperatures Recent winters with less cold water formation led to less oxygenation
 Record low oxygen inventory oxygen inventory reached lowest value in 2021 highlighting alarming trend of deoxygenation.

 Implications:

 Habitat loss: shrinking oxygenated layer reduces habitat for marine life
 Impact on ecosystems: Deoxygenation lead to changes in species distribution population declines ecosystem disruption
 Need for action: Understanding addressing factors driving deoxygenation critical to ensure health Black Sea ecosystem

 Further research:

 Continuous monitoring of oxygenation status using Argo profilers other methods
 Investigation into impacts of deoxygenation on specific marine species ecosystems
 Development of strategies to mitigate deoxygenation trend restore Black Sea ecosystem.

 information emphasizes urgent need to monitor address deoxygenation trends in Black Sea

Nordic Seas Volume Transports from Reanalysis
Atlantic Water Transport Overflow Waters: Summary
 text describes importance of Atlantic Water transport to Arctic role Overflow Waters in global ocean circulation
 Key Points:

 Atlantic Water Flow: warm saline water flows from North Atlantic into Nordic Seas influencing Arctic climate sea ice ecosystems
 Overflow Waters: dense cold waters form in Nordic Seas due to cooling salinization of Atlantic Water exit Nordic Seas through Denmark Strait Faroe Shetland Channel contributing to North Atlantic Deep Water Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC).
 Impact of Atlantic Water:
 Influences sea ice cover in Barents Sea near Svalbard
 vital role in forming overflow waters in Nordic Seas
 Transports nutrients zooplankton commercially important fish species
 Defines physical biological border between boreal and Arctic realms.


 Variability: Changes in Atlantic Water flow impact position ice edge distribution of species in Barents Sea ecosystem.
 CMEMS findings:
 Faroe Shetland Channel: Model estimates long-term average transport of 2.5 Sv comparable to observations of 2.7 Sv.
 Barents Sea Opening: Model suggests long-term average inflow of 2.2 Sv slightly higher than observed 1.8 Sv.
 Fram Strait: Model indicates positive trend in Atlantic Water transport potentially linked to increased temperature in West Spitsbergen Current.



 conclusion exchange of Atlantic Water Overflow Waters between North Atlantic Arctic plays crucial role in regional global ocean dynamics Understanding processes variability of water masses essential for predicting future changes in Arctic global climate system.

Summary BALTIC_OMI_TEMPSAL_sst_trend product
 provides cumulative trend in sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies for Baltic Sea between 1993 and 2021 breakdown key information


 Data: Cumulative trend in SST anomalies calculated as rate of change (°C/year) multiplied by number of years (29)
 Spatial Resolution: 0.02 degrees in latitude and longitude
 Temporal Resolution: Monthly averages from January 1993 to December 2021
 Methodology
 Based on reprocessed SST_BAL_SST_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_010_016 data
 Trend calculation uses Sen's method confidence intervals from Mann-Kendall test





 SST crucial climate variable influencing weather models air-sea interactions climate change monitoring
 Baltic Sea requires specific attention semi-enclosed nature natural variability influence from land large-scale atmospheric processes

 Key Findings

 average SST trend in Baltic Sea (east of 9°E longitude) 0.049 °C/year warming of 1.42 °C over study period
 including North Sea trend decreases to 0.03 °C/year warming of 0.87 °C
 Highest trends in Baltic Sea region North Atlantic especially offshore Norway

 more information

 Copernicus Marine Service Ocean State Reports: (Section 1.1 in Von Schuckmann et al., 2016 and Section 3 in Von Schuckmann et al., 2018)

 Additional Context

 Previous studies indicated warming in Baltic Sea Høyer and Karagali (2016) warming of 1-2°C from 1982 to 2012.
product provides recent updated assessment of warming trend in Baltic Sea, highlighting importance of long-term monitoring for understanding climate change impacts.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-ice-extent-observations-reprocessing
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_SI_extent
Baltic Sea Ice Extent from Observations Reprocessing
Sea Ice Extent in Baltic Sea: Summary Key Findings
 text provides comprehensive overview of sea ice extent in Baltic Sea importance recent trends
 Definition

 Sea ice extent: area ocean covered by 15% sea ice concentration
 Sea ice concentration: fraction of ocean area covered by sea ice

 Context

 Importance: Sea ice coverage crucial for Baltic Sea's physical ecological conditions safe winter navigation
 Impact on Environment:
 Influences annual course Baltic Sea's physical ecological conditions
 Affects vertical stratification onset of spring blooms


 Impact on Navigation
 Requires specialized ships icebreaker assistance
 Provides valuable information for coastal offshore construction planning



 Key Findings

 Seasonal Cycle: Sea ice formation begins October lasts until June.
 2020/21 Season:
 Moderate maximum ice extent (121,000 km2)
 Asymmetry towards earlier ice season
 Rapid ice extent increase early February quick decrease second half of February
 Maximum ice extent reached level of mean maximum extent
 Maximum ice extent occurred mid-February earlier than usual beginning of March


 Historical Context:
 Full ice cover Baltic Sea reached 422,000 km2 last observed in 1940s
 29% Baltic Sea covered by ice in 2020/21.


 Trend
 decreasing trend in sea ice extent observed from 1993 to 2021, not statistically significant



 Data Sources:

 Synthetic Aperture Radar images
 In situ observations from icebreakers

 Conclusion
 Baltic Sea exhibits strong seasonality in sea ice coverage clear trend towards earlier ice season decreasing trend in sea ice extent observed not statistically significant Continued monitoring further research crucial to understand long-term implications of climate change on sea ice in Baltic Sea

488
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/north-pacific-gyre-oscillation-observations-reprocessing
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_CLIMVAR_NPGO_sla_eof_mode_projection
North Pacific Gyre Oscillation from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of North Pacific Gyre Oscillation (NPGO):
 North Pacific Gyre Oscillation) is climate pattern describes variability of North Pacific Gyre's intensity impacting sea surface height (SSH) sea surface temperature (SST) in Northeast Pacific.
 Key Points:

 Definition: NPGO defined as second dominant mode of variability in SSH and SST anomalies in Northeast Pacific.
 Index: NPGO index calculated from second principal component of SSH anomalies based on data from 1950-2004 updated using satellite altimeter data since 2004.
 Influence: NPGO influences oceanographic factors including surface salinity nutrients, chlorophyll-a temperature.
 Phase: positive NPGO phase characterized by negative SSH anomaly north of 40°N positive anomaly south of 40°N stronger gyre circulation. negative phase exhibits opposite pattern weaker circulation.
 Relationship to Atmospheric Patterns: NPGO linked to North Pacific Oscillation (NPO), dominant atmospheric pattern.
 Current Phase: NPGO index in negative phase indicating weaker gyre circulation reduced coastal upwelling lower salinity and nutrient levels.

 Further Reading:

 CMEMS Ocean State Report #3: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00221
 NPGO Website: https://www.o3d.org/npgo/

 conclusion NPGO is important climate pattern affecting Northeast Pacific influencing oceanographic variables potentially linked to atmospheric patterns. Understanding NPGO helps scientists policymakers predict adapt to changes in North Pacific ecosystem.
---
489
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/iberia-biscay-ireland-coastal-upwelling-index-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=IBI_OMI_CURRENTS_cui
Iberia Biscay Ireland Coastal Upwelling Index from Reanalysis
Summary Coastal Upwelling Index (CUI)
 document describes intensity upwelling along coasts Africa Iberian Peninsula breakdown key information
 What is CUI?

 calculated by finding temperature difference between warmest and coldest points within 3.5° longitude band westward from coast at each latitude between 27°N and 42°N
 higher CUI value indicates stronger upwelling conditions

 How CUI calculated?

 CUI uses data from Copernicus Marine products:
 IBI-MYP (1993-2019)
 IBI-NRT (2020 onwards)


 follows methodology similar to other upwelling indices detailed explanation in Copernicus Marine Service Ocean State report (Sotillo et al., 2016)

 Why CUI important?

 Coastal upwelling vital oceanographic process brings nutrient-rich deep water to surface supporting abundant marine life
 CUI provides insight into variability intensity process better understanding management of marine ecosystems

 Key Findings

 Northwest Africa (NWA) Coast (latitudes below 34°N):
 Relatively consistent upwelling intensity periodicity
 periods of increased upwelling: 1993-1995 2003-2004
 2020 showed stronger upwelling than average


 Iberian Peninsula (IP) Coast (latitudes above 37°N):
 More pronounced interannual variability
 Years with strong upwelling: 1994, 2004, 2015-2017
 Periods weaker upwelling: 1996-1998 2003, 2011, 2013.
 2020 exhibited weak upwelling activity
 significant positive trend in CUI between 1993-2019 suggests increase in temperature differences between coastal and offshore waters (~0.02°C/year).



 Further Information

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00248
Copernicus Marine Service Ocean State Report (Sotillo et al, 2016) provides in-depth analysis scientific evaluation.

 Key findings updated annually November with OMI evolutions.
---
490
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-acidification-mean-sea-water-ph-trend-map
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_HEALTH_carbon_ph_trend
Global ocean acidification - mean sea water pH trend map from Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Ocean Monitoring Indicator (OMI): Surface Ocean pH Trend
 definition provides comprehensive overview of key ocean monitoring indicator focusing on long-term trends in surface ocean pH breakdown


 Metric: Annual mean rates change in surface ocean pH (measured in units of pH per year, yr-1)
 Spatial Resolution: 1° x 1° grid cells covering global ocean
 Time Period: From 1985 to recent year
 Data Source: Copernicus Marine product MULTIOBS_GLO_BIO_CARBON_SURFACE_REP_015_008 (Chau et al., 2022a).
 Methodology
 Monthly pH time series calculate linear trends using least-squares regression
 slope of regression line represents trend (μ).
 Uncertainty represented by residual standard deviation (σ).
 Data points with high uncertainty (σ/μ ratio above 90th percentile threshold) excluded to ensure reliable trend estimates



 Context Significance

 Ocean Acidification: decreasing pH values direct result of ocean absorbing increased atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) from human emissions
 Environmental Impacts Ocean acidification threats to marine ecosystems organisms significant consequences for food web economic activities
 Monitoring Importance Tracking pH trends crucial for understanding progression ocean acidification impact on marine life better predictions mitigation strategies

 Key Findings

 Global Trends ocean basins exhibit decreasing pH trends between -0.0008 yr-1 and -0.0022 yr-1.
 Regional Variations
 Tropical subtropical regions show pH trends within interquartile range (-0.0012 yr-1 to -0.0018 yr-1)
 eastern equatorial Pacific experiences faster rate change exceeding -0.0024 yr-1
 sector south of Indian Ocean exhibits high rate of change
polar subpolar North Atlantic Southern Ocean show no significant trends.



 Further Information:

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00277
 QUIDO Document: QUID document provides detailed description illustrations of methodology used for this indicator.

 summary OMI provides valuable insights into ongoing process ocean acidification highlighting global regional trends in surface ocean pH emphasizing urgent need for monitoring mitigation efforts.
---

 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: Provides daily global SST sea ice fraction data for climate analysis research
 Source: Combined satellite data from ATSR AVHRR sensors using NEMOVAR and OSTIA algorithms
 Deprecation: dataset no longer actively maintained newer more accurate datasets may be available
 Relevance: deprecated dataset offers long-term record of SST sea ice fraction from 1991 to 2010.

 Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded data values organized on regular grid
 Horizontal Coverage: Global covering entire Earth's surface
 Horizontal Resolution: 0.05° x 0.05° detailed spatial resolution
 Temporal Coverage: 1991 to 2010, significant period
 Temporal Resolution: Daily frequent data updates
 File Format: NetCDF common format for scientific data

 Main Variables

 Sea Ice Fraction:
 Units: Percentage (%)
 Description proportion of each grid cell covered by sea ice


 Sea Surface Temperature:
 Units: Kelvin (K)
 Analysed daily average SST temperature of water at approximately 20 cm depth



 Related Variables

 dataset includes additional variables related to uncertainty data variables provide estimates of possible variations in main variables due to changes in processing algorithms
 variable indicating presence of ocean, land or sea ice in each grid cell provided

 Key Points to Consider

 Deprecation: valuable, dataset outdated Newer datasets likely offer improved accuracy may cover longer period
 Uncertainty dataset acknowledges inherent uncertainty considered when analyzing data
Applications: dataset can be used for climate research especially for studying long-term trends in SST sea ice cover. can used to analyze regional variations events.

 Alternatives: Search for newer actively maintained datasets of SST sea ice fraction provide higher accuracy more recent data.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/arctic-sea-ice-extent-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=ARCTIC_OMI_SI_extent
Arctic Sea Ice Extent from Reanalysis
Summary of Arctic Sea Ice Extent Trends:
 This document presents analysis of Arctic sea ice extent trends from 1993 to 2019 focusing on large-scale variability and long-term changes. Key findings include:
 Overall trend:
 Significant decrease: Arctic sea ice extent declined significantly since 1993 average annual rate of -0.75 million km2 per decade.
 Loss of 5.8% per decade: translates to total sea ice extent loss of 5.8% per decade over period 1993-2018.
 Seasonal trends:
 Summer (September) loss: most dramatic decline occurs during summer months loss of 1.18 million km2 per decade (-14.85% per decade).
 Winter (March) loss: less pronounced decrease in winter ice extent loss of 0.57 million km2 per decade (-3.42% per decade).
 Key observations:
 Accelerating loss: rate of sea ice loss exceeds previous estimates trends higher than reported in IPCC AR5 assessment (which covered data up to 2012).
 Summer minimums: past 12 years seen lowest summer minimums recorded since 1993 2012 lowest minimum.
 Continuing decline: trend of recent years summer and winter ice levels below average for 1990s and 2000s persists.
 Significance:
 Climate change indicator: Sea ice loss sensitive indicator of climate change highlighting impact of rising global temperatures on polar regions.
 Environmental implications: Changes in sea ice cover impact ocean stratification, global and regional sea levels role of polar regions in Earth's climate system.
 Human and ecological impacts: Declining sea ice affects human activities like shipping and fishing habitats of marine species.
 Note data based on multi-product approach using five global datasets regularly updated to reflect recent trends.complete analysis and scientific evaluations available in CMEMS Ocean State Report.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-glaciers-extent
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-glaciers-extent
insitu-glaciers-extent
great description of Randolph Glacier Inventory (RGI) dataset! breakdown of information key points to consider:
 What is RGI?

 Global Glacier Outlines: RGI provides detailed outlines of glaciers worldwide compiled from various sources like maps, aerial photos satellite images.
 Snapshot in Time: data represents single point in time predominantly from around 2000-2010 important to remember when analyzing changes over time.
 Comprehensive and Homogeneous: RGI is most complete consistent glacier outline dataset available valuable resource for research.

 How Used?

 Glacier Change Studies: Scientists use RGI to track glacier growth, retreat overall changes.
 Sea Level Rise: Glacier meltwater contributes to rising sea levels RGI helps quantify contribution.
 Hydrology: RGI informs understanding of water resources in glacier-fed regions.
 Climate Modeling: Models predict future glacier behavior rely on accurate glacier outlines like RGI.

 Key Features of Dataset:

 Format: RGI available as ESRI shapefiles (for) and CSV files (for tabular data).
 Geographic Coverage: RGI covers all glacierized regions globally.
 Resolution: Most glacier outlines have resolution of 30 x 30 meters detailed information.
 Versions: RGI updated over time. versions 5.0 and 6.0 available.

 to Keep in Mind

 Temporal Limitations: RGI represents snapshot in time To study glacier changes over extended periods need to combine dataset with other data sources.
 Data Accuracy: RGI is high-quality dataset, inaccuracies may exist due to nature of data collection and processing.
Data Accessibility: RGI brokered through GLIMS glacier database at NSIDC, making easy to access and use.

 Overall Randolph Glacier Inventory is a vital resource for understanding global glaciers, role in climate change, impact on environment.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-acidification-mean-sea-water-ph-time-series
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_HEALTH_carbon_ph_area_averaged
Global Ocean acidification - mean sea water pH time series and trend from Multi-Observations Reprocessing
Ocean Acidification: Summary of Key Findings
 text provides comprehensive explanation of ocean acidification causes implications for global ocean break down key points
 What is Ocean Acidification?
 is ongoing decrease in pH of ocean water due to absorption atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) lower pH indicates higher acidity
 How is Ocean Acidification Measured?

 Global mean pH: Calculated from gridded ocean surface pH data using
 Alkalinity Estimated LIAR method
 Partial pressure of CO2 (pCO2) Obtained from CMEMS product based SOCAT data
 CO2 system calculations: Applied to reconstructed pCO2 alkalinity.


 Uncertainty: Estimated at 1σ range of (0.0023, 0.0029) pH unit.
 Trend: -0.0017±0.0004e-1 pH units per year since 1985.

 Causes of Ocean Acidification:

 Anthropogenic CO2 primary driver acidification from human activities like burning fossil fuels
 Other chemical additions/subtractions other chemicals added ocean can influence pH

 Impacts of Ocean Acidification:

 Marine ecosystems at risk Ocean acidification disrupts balance marine ecosystems threatening survival of species
 Coral bleaching reef degradation Ocean acidification weakens coral reefs susceptible to bleaching disease
 Shellfish production impacted Ocean acidification makes harder for shellfish to form shells affecting growth survival

 Monitoring Ocean Acidification

 In situ observations Data from SOCAT provides valuable information limited in spatial temporal coverage
 Need for more observations Denser networks observations direct pH measurements crucial for comprehensive monitoring especially in coastal areas

 Key Findings from CMEMS:

Global ocean surface pH decreasing rate -0.0017±0.0004e-1 per year since 1985.
 Ocean acidification significant indicator of global change requires continuous monitoring research.

 Importance of Ocean Acidification Monitoring:

 Understanding impact of climate change: Monitoring ocean acidification helps assess consequences of human activities on ocean environment.
 Developing mitigation strategies: Understanding drivers impacts of ocean acidification essential for developing strategies to mitigate effects
 Protecting marine resources: Monitoring ocean acidification supports efforts conserve manage valuable marine ecosystems resources.

 Conclusion
 Ocean acidification serious threat to global ocean significant implications for marine ecosystems human well-being. Continued monitoring research crucial to understand extent problem develop solutions protect planet's vital marine resources.
---
495
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-major-baltic-inflow-bottom-salinity-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_WMHE_mbi_bottom_salinity_arkona_bornholm
Baltic Sea Major Baltic Inflow: bottom salinity from Reanalysis
Summary of Major Baltic Inflows:
 This document provides overview of Major Baltic Inflows (MBIs), crucial events bring saline oxygen-rich water from North Sea into deep basins Baltic Sea.
 Key points:

 MBIs are rare happen sporadically sometimes many years apart.
 Salinity changes key indicators: Salinity increase in Arkona Basin initial sign of inflow significant increase of 2-3 units in Bornholm Basin definitive indicator of MBI.
 Impact on Baltic Sea: MBIs counteract typical brackish water conditions Baltic Sea help replenish oxygen levels in deep basins.
 Stagnation periods: Long periods without MBIs lead to oxygen depletion salinity decline in deep waters known as stagnation periods.
 CMEMS data analysis: time series of salinity in Arkona Bornholm basins temperature, salinity dissolved oxygen data in Gotland basin provide valuable insights into frequency impact of MBIs.

 CMEMS findings:

 Arkona Basin: Salinity varies between 11 and 25 g/kg peaks to MBIs in 1993, 2002 2014. Periods low salinity indicate outflow events strength of recent inflows decreased since 2015.
 Bornholm Basin: Three distinct MBIs identified: 1993, 2002, 2014. last MBI increased salinity to 20 g/kg decreased to 16 g/kg in seven years salinity recovery after 2002 MBI faster taking three years.

 information highlights importance of MBIs for Baltic Sea's ecosystem monitoring of events crucial for understanding long-term health stability of unique vulnerable environment.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-satellite-humidity-latitude-distribution
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-satellite-humidity-latitude-distribution
app-satellite-humidity-latitude-distribution
detailed description of application visualizes analyzes global humidity data from satellite-based Radio Occultation (RO) measurements breakdown information:
 Application Purpose:

 Visualize analyze latitudinal distribution of humidity in lowest 12 km Earth's atmosphere
 Show variability humidity across latitudes
 Demonstrate influence of Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) on humidity patterns

 Key Features:

 Interactive Data Visualization: application displays two panels:
 Left Panel Shows average humidity profile for each latitude band
 Right Panel Shows variability (standard deviation) of humidity for each latitude band.


 User-Selectable Parameters:
 Year: choose year of data (2007-2020).
 Month: choose specific month of data (January-December).


 Data Source: data derived from EUMETSAT's Radio Occultation Meteorology Satellite Application Facility (ROM) facility
 Data Coverage: dataset encompasses entire globe from surface up to altitude 12 km with high vertical resolution.
 Data Download: Users download displayed data for further analysis.

 Scientific Significance:

 Climate System Atmospheric humidity crucial for Earth's climate system due to strong greenhouse effect role in global energy transport
 Hydrological Cycle: Humidity central to hydrological cycle influencing rainfall patterns
 Biosphere Humidity critical role in determining conditions for life Earth including rainfall drought patterns.

 Explanation of ITCZ Impact:

 Peak Humidity: humidity peaks near equator due to ITCZ's intense convection transports water vapor upwards
 Seasonal Shift: ITCZ shifts seasonally causing peak humidity move slightly north and south.
Variability Peaks: variability peaks slightly south and north of humidity peak because of longitudinal variations in humidity.
 Low Variability at Peak: variability low right at humidity peak due to uniform humidity in ITCZ region.

 Summary:
 application provides valuable tool for understanding global distribution of humidity, variability influence of ITCZ interactive nature ability to download data make it suitable for research and educational purposes.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/global-ocean-mean-sea-level-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=GLOBAL_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
Global Ocean Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Ocean Monitoring Indicator on Mean Sea Level
 document defines ocean monitoring indicator mean sea level outlining derivation significance.
 Key Points:

 Data Source: indicator utilizes sea level anomaly data from DUACS delayed-time (DT-2021) altimeter gridded maps distributed Copernicus Climate Change Service Copernicus Marine Service catalogue.
 Calculation: Global mean sea level (GMSL) calculated by averaging gridded sea level maps weighted by latitude Periodic signals (annual semi-annual) removed time series low-pass filtered GIA (Glacial Isostatic Adjustment) effect corrected using ICE5G-VM2 model.
 Correction for Topex-A Drift: drift in TOPEX-A altimeter during 1993-1998 accounted for revealing quadratic trend indicating acceleration in mean sea level.
 Trend Uncertainty: trend estimated with 90% confidence interval considering errors related altimeter observation system uncertainty linked to interannual signal not included.
 Importance: indicator crucial index of climate change sea level rise driven by ocean warming melting glaciers/ice sheets.
 Observed Trend: period 1993/01/01 to 2021/08/02 GMSL rises rate 3.3 ± 0.4 mm/year consistent with recent estimates.

 Context:

 Sea Level Rise: Global mean sea level increased by 0.20 m between 1901 and 2018 accelerating rate since 1960s Human activity primary driver of rise since 1970.
 Impacts: Rising sea level poses threats to coastal populations infrastructure increasing vulnerabilities risks to food security particularly in low-lying areas island states.
 Adaptation & Mitigation: restoring mangroves coastal wetlands reduce risks rising sea level.

 Key Findings from CMEMS:

observed global trend in GMSL (3.3 ± 0.4 mm/year) aligns with recent estimates importance of continuous monitoring understanding sea level change

 ocean monitoring indicator on mean sea level provides crucial information for tracking climate change impacts adaptation mitigation strategies

Analysis of Mediterranean Sea Chlorophyll Trend Map
 document details comprehensive analysis of Mediterranean Sea's chlorophyll trend map, generated using multi-sensor satellite data regional chlorophyll algorithms. analysis focuses on period 1997-2021 highlights key findings about chlorophyll trends in basin.
 key takeaways:

 Negative Trend: striking observation is widespread negative trend in chlorophyll concentrations across Mediterranean Sea. trend more pronounced than previously observed (1997-2020).
 Limited Positive Trends: Positive trends limited to southern part western Mediterranean basin, Rhode Gyre northern coast of Aegean Sea.
 Average Trend: average chlorophyll trend across Mediterranean Sea is approximately -0.6% per year.
 Western and Eastern Trends: Contrary western and eastern parts Mediterranean Sea show similar negative trends no discernible differences.
 Ligurian Sea Trend Shift: trend in Ligurian Sea shifted to negative values contradicting previous positive trends earlier periods.
 Po River Mouth Trend: waters off Po River mouth show weak negative trends differing from notable negative trend observed previously (1998-2009) shifting from positive trend observed in recent studies (1998-2014).

 Significance:
 study reveals consistent trend of decreasing chlorophyll concentrations across Mediterranean Sea. decreasing phytoplankton abundance has important implications for marine ecosystem carbon cycle. Understanding drivers trend crucial for informing management strategies conservation efforts.
 Further Considerations:

 Eutrophication: impact of anthropogenic pressure nutrient loads on eutrophication regimes should be investigated.
 Climate Change: influence of climate change on observed trends needs to be further explored.
Regional Variations: specific drivers of observed trends in different sub-regions Mediterranean should be investigated.

 Overall this study provides valuable insights into long-term trends in chlorophyll concentrations in Mediterranean Sea. Further research needed to understand underlying causes trends implications for ecosystem.

sis-health-vector
detailed description of dataset on climatic suitability for Aedes albopictus (tiger mosquito) in Europe breakdown of information:
 Problem:

 Aedes albopictus mosquito vector for diseases like dengue chikungunya.
 As temperatures rise due to climate change mosquito's range expanding increasing risk diseases in Europe

 Dataset:

 Focus: Provides information on suitable European environments for Aedes albopictus mosquito
 Data Type: Gridded - data organized in grid with specific coordinates for spatial analysis.
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid data mapped onto standard grid system for geographic consistency.
 Coverage: European region (27N – 72N, 22W – 45E)
 Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° - each grid cell represents small area good spatial detail.
 Time Period: 1986 – 2085 data covers long period understand climate change impacts
 Time Resolution: Season or year, averaged over 30 years provides smoothed average reducing variability from individual years.
 File Format: NetCDF common format for storing scientific data for easy analysis.
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6, Attribute Convention for Dataset Discovery (ACDD) v1.3 standardized metadata ensures consistency discoverability.

 Key Variables:

 Season Length (Day): Indicates duration (in weeks) environmental conditions suitable for mosquito to active.
 Suitability (Dimensionless): score between 0 and 100 likelihood of favorable conditions for mosquito's presence 0 indicates no suitability 100 indicates optimal conditions.

 Data Can Tell Us:

 Current and Future Risk: data helps identify areas where mosquito currently prevalent and areas likely to become suitable future due to climate change.
Seasonal Patterns: provides insights into duration mosquito seasons may change future.
 Disease Transmission Risk: information crucial for public health officials to make informed decisions about mosquito control measures disease preparedness.

 Important Considerations:

 Ensemble Average: data based on ensemble of climate models results represent average prediction not precise forecast
 Uncertainty: inherent uncertainty in climate models data should be used with caution alongside other information.

 Applications:

 Public Health: Decision-making for vector control disease surveillance public health campaigns.
 Environmental Management: Developing strategies to mitigate impact climate change on mosquito populations.
 Research: Studies on spread of mosquito-borne diseases climate change impacts future projections.

Mediterranean Sea Surface Temperature cumulative trend map from Observations Reprocessing
Summary medsea_omi_tempsal_sst_trend Product
 provides comprehensive analysis Sea Surface Temperature (SST) trends Mediterranean Sea 1993 to 2021 highlights key points
 Product Details:

 Data Source: CMEMS Reprocessed Mediterranean L4 SST product (SST_MED_SST_L4_REP_OBSERVATIONS_010_021)
 Resolution: 0.05° grid
 Time Period 1993-2021 (29 years)
 Method: X-11 seasonal adjustment procedure, Mann-Kendall test Sen’s method
 Output: Cumulative/net SST trend (°C/year) multiplied by 29 years

 Context & Significance:

 Importance of SST SST crucial climate variable impacting climate regulation variability essential for monitoring global climate system
 Mediterranean Hotspot Mediterranean Sea experiencing significant warming trends since early 1980s warming accelerating since 2000.
 Understanding SST Trends Analyzing long-term SST variability helps understand slow changes ocean temperatures provides insights extreme events like marine heatwaves

 Key Findings:

 General Warming Mediterranean shows widespread warming trend 0.002 °C/year to 0.063 °C/year
 Eastern & Central Warming Eastern Central Mediterranean basins exhibit higher warming rates than Western basin
 Specific Regions Balearic, Tyrrhenian Adriatic Northern Ionian Aegean-Levantine seas experience most significant warming (0.04 °C/year to 0.05 °C/year).
 Gyre Influence: Pelops Anticyclone Cretan gyre Rhodes Gyre show pronounced warming trends
 Southward Trend previous studies indicated eastward increase warming latest analysis shows North-South trend Levantine basin warming faster than Western

 References

CMEMS Ocean State Report: first second issues Copernicus Marine Service Ocean State Report (OSR), Section 1.1 (Roquet et al., 2016; Mulet et al., 2018)
 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00269

 product provides valuable up-to-date assessment Mediterranean Sea SST trends highlighting accelerating warming implications region's climate ecosystems.

Global Ocean Mean Sea Level trend map from Observations Reprocessing
Sea Level Trend Monitoring Indicator: Breakdown
 definition describes key climate change indicator: sea level trend. highlights importance indicator role in understanding ongoing rise in sea level impact on coastal communities.
 breakdown of key points:
 What indicator?

 uses satellite altimeter data from Copernicus Climate Change Service and Copernicus Marine Service.
 data covers period from 1993 to 2021
 calculates rate of change in sea level for various regions using linear regression
 uncertainty of trends estimated based on altimeter measurement errors.

 Why important?

 Sea level rise is major consequence of climate change
 affects coastal populations infrastructure increasing vulnerability to flooding other hazards
 Understanding regional trends helps assess localized impact of sea level rise.

 findings?

 indicator shows significant regional variations in sea level trends
 Some regions like western tropical Pacific Ocean experience rising sea levels at rates exceeding 10 mm/year.
 trends influenced by various factors including ocean warming wind patterns Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation.

 limitations?

 indicator doesn't consider uncertainty by interannual variations in sea level
 doesn't include corrections for factors like glacial isostatic adjustment instrumental drift.

 Overall indicator provides valuable insights into complex phenomenon of sea level rise emphasizing importance of monitoring regional trends to inform adaptation mitigation strategies.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-water-mass-formation-rates-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_VAR_EXTREME_WMF_MEDSEA_area_averaged_mean
Mediterranean Water Mass Formation Rates from Reanalysis
text describes formation rates of different water masses in Mediterranean Sea using data from Mediterranean Sea Reanalysis key findings
 Western Mediterranean Deep Water (WMDW):

 Formation rates increased after 1999 coinciding with Eastern Mediterranean Transient event
 increase after 2005 termed Western Mediterranean Transition
 reanalysis confirms major formation events in 2009 aligns with other studies.

 Eastern Mediterranean Deep Water (EMDW):

 Significant formation periods occurred between 1988-1993 1996 1999 2000.
 Weak formation in 2006 aligns with observations
 Intense formation detected in 2012-2013 large events started in 2017.

 Cretan Intermediate Water (CIW):

 Larger peaks in formation rates occurred between 1989 and 1993 1992 1993 aligning with Eastern Mediterranean Transient

 Cretan Deep Water (CDW):

 Formation in 1992 and 1993 highest densities period

 Levantine Deep Water (LDW):

 largest formation rates in Rhode Gyre region occurred between 1992 and 1993.



 analysis highlights importance of deep intermediate water formation in Mediterranean Sea's overturning circulation
 reanalysis captures key events trends in previous studies providing valuable insight into dynamics water masses

 context emphasizes importance of understanding water mass formation rates for comprehending complex dynamics Mediterranean Sea's circulation study valuable comprehensive overview of processes connections to events like Eastern Mediterranean Transient Western Mediterranean Transition
---
507
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-level-mediterranean
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-level-mediterranean
satellite-sea-level-mediterranean
text describes dataset sea level anomaly data for Mediterranean Sea breakdown information:
 Dataset Overview

 Data type: Gridded data organized in grid of cells each representing specific location
 Spatial coverage: Mediterranean Sea specifically area bounded by (29.47, 45.16)°N (-6.00, 36.60)°E
 Spatial resolution: 0.125° x 0.125° (each grid cell represents square area approximately 14 km by 14 km)
 Temporal coverage: 1 January 1993 to 3 June 2020
 Temporal resolution: Daily (data available for each day
 File format: NetCDF common format for scientific data
 Version: vDT2018
 Update frequency: No longer updated

 Sea Level Anomaly Definition

 Sea level anomaly is difference between actual sea level at specific location time and long-term average sea level for location (specifically average over 1993-2012 period).

 Key Variables
 dataset contains variables related to sea level ocean currents:

 Absolute dynamic topography (m): height of sea surface above geoid reference surface representing average sea level), calculated by combining sea level anomaly with mean dynamic topography measure ocean's internal pressure).
 Absolute geostrophic velocity (m/s): represents current velocity calculated from slope sea surface assuming balance between pressure gradient and Coriolis forces (geostrophic balance).
 Meridian component: Northward component velocity
 Zonal component: Eastward component velocity


 Geostrophic velocity anomalies (m/s): difference between absolute geostrophic velocity and long-term average velocity
 Meridian component: Northward component
 Zonal component: Eastward component anomaly


 Sea level anomaly (m): main variable dataset represents deviation sea surface from 20-year mean (1993-2012).

 Additional Information

Uncertainty: dataset includes information about uncertainty with each grid cell.
 Documentation: dataset accompanied by documentation details about data processing methods to estimate sea level anomalies sources of error.

 Applications
 dataset valuable for researchers studying:

 Sea level rise: Understanding spatial temporal patterns of sea level change in Mediterranean Sea.
 Ocean circulation: Investigating dynamics of ocean currents in region.
 Climate change: Analyzing impacts climate change on sea level ocean currents.
 Coastal management: Providing information for planning mitigating effects of sea level rise on coastal communities.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/black-sea-significant-wave-height-extreme-reanalysis
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BLKSEA_OMI_SEASTATE_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly
Black Sea Significant Wave Height extreme from Reanalysis
Summary of CMEMS BLKSEA_OMI_seastate_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly Indicator
 OMI indicator focuses on extreme significant wave height (SWH) in Black Sea using data from two CMEMS products
 1. Multi Year Product (BLKSEA_MULTIYEAR_WAV_007_006): Provides mean 99th percentile of annual SWH from 1979-2019.
 2. Analysis Product (BLKSEA_ANALYSISFORECAST_WAV_007_003): calculate anomaly of 99th percentile in 2020.
 Key Findings

 Mean 99th percentile: Shows clear west-east gradient highest values (around 3.5m) in southwestern Black Sea lower values (around 2.5m) in east attributed to high winds longer fetch in west
 2020 anomaly: Mostly negative decrease in extreme SWH compared to long-term average
 Highest negative anomalies southeast long-term mean low
 Highest positive anomalies southwest eastern coast
 pattern consistent with yearly displacement of storm tracks.



 Significance

 Understanding extreme wave events crucial for managing maritime activities coastal infrastructure biodiversity in marine protected areas
 use of percentiles annual maxima provides more robust measure of extreme events less influenced by individual data points
 indicator provides valuable insights into spatial temporal variability of extreme SWH in Black Sea inform adaptation strategies climate change assessments.

 Further Information:

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00214
 CMEMS Ocean State report (Álvarez-Fanjul et al., 2019): Provides in-depth scientific evaluation context.

 Key findings updated annually in November.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-solar-radiation-timeseries
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-solar-radiation-timeseries
cams-solar-radiation-timeseries
text provides comprehensive description CAMS solar radiation services
 What is CAMS?
 CAMS stands for "Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service." European Union-funded program providing atmospheric data information for various applications including

 Climate monitoring: Understanding changes atmosphere impact climate
 Air quality forecasting: Predicting air pollution levels issuing alerts
 Weather forecasting data for numerical weather prediction models
 Solar energy: Supporting development integration of solar energy systems.

 CAMS solar radiation service offer?
 service provides historical data (from February 2004 onward on different types of solar radiation including

 Global Horizontal Irradiation (GHI): Total solar radiation reaching horizontal surface.
 Direct Horizontal Irradiation (BHI): Solar radiation arriving directly from sun hitting horizontal surface
 Diffuse Horizontal Irradiation (DHI): Solar radiation scattered by atmosphere hitting horizontal surface
 Direct Normal Irradiation (BNI): Direct solar radiation hitting surface perpendicular to sun's rays

 Key features service:

 Global Coverage: Cloud-free data available for any location worldwide All-sky data limited to Meteosat satellite field-of-view (Europe, Africa, Atlantic Ocean Middle East).
 High Temporal Resolution: Data available in various time intervals 1-minute, 15-minute 1-hourly daily monthly
 Clear-Sky and All-Sky Data: service provides separate datasets for clear-sky conditions (calculated atmospheric models all-sky conditions (inferred from satellite observations).
 Expert Mode: Users access additional input data calculations (aerosol optical properties water vapor concentration in special ASCII format for more detailed analysis
 Data Formats: Data offered in CSV) netCDF Form) formats

Applications of CAMS solar radiation data:
 data used for:

 Policy Development: Supporting European national policies to solar energy climate change.
 Commercial Services: Providing input for planning monitoring improving efficiency of solar energy systems.
 Public Services: Supporting integration of solar energy systems into energy grids.

 summary
 CAMS solar radiation service provides valuable data for researchers businesses policymakers involved in solar energy atmospheric science service offers high-quality high-resolution data with various temporal spatial coverage options versatile tool for wide range of applications.

514
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-meridional-overturning-circulation-index
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_CIRCULATION_MOC_MEDSEA_area_averaged_mean
Mediterranean Meridional Overturning Circulation Index from Reanalysis
Summary of Mediterranean Meridional Overturning Index (MOI)
 document describes tool monitor clockwise overturning circulation in western eastern Mediterranean Sea.
 Key Points:

 Definition: MOI derived from Eulerian meridional streamfunction calculated using Copernicus Marine Mediterranean Sea reanalysis data over 1987-2020 represents strength of overturning circulation in specific areas.
 Significance: MOI linked to deep intermediate water mass formation crucial for Mediterranean Sea's stratification oxygen exchange.
 Western MOI (WMOI): Focuses on deep-water formation regions in western basin excluding Gibraltar inflow.
 Eastern MOI (EMOI): Focuses on Levantine and Cretan areas strongest meridional overturning cell locations.
 Results: EMOI has higher values than WMOI indicating stronger overturning circulation in eastern Mediterranean.
 Key Events EMOI peaked in 1992 due to Eastern Mediterranean Transient (EMT) event difference between EMOI and WMOI decreased in 1999 as EMT water masses reached Sicily Strait flowed into western basin WMOI peak in 2006 linked to anomalous deep-water formation during Western Mediterranean Transition.

 MOI valuable tool for

 Long-term monitoring of overturning changes in Mediterranean Sea
 Understanding influence of key events like EMT Western Mediterranean Transition on circulation
 Assessing health of Mediterranean ecosystem contributing to Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 13.3 on early warning systems for climate-related hazards.

 Further Information:

 More detailed information in Copernicus Marine Ocean State Report issue 4 (OSR4).
 Data and methodology details available through product DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/mds-00317

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-extreme-indices-cmip6
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-extreme-indices-cmip6
sis-extreme-indices-cmip6
detailed description of climate data set focused on climate extremes heat stress indicators breakdown key information
 dataset contains

 Climate Extreme Indices (ETCCDI): standard metrics measure climate extremes including temperature precipitation calculated using climdex.pcic R package ensuring consistency reliability.
 Heat Stress Indicators (HSI): indicators combine temperature humidity pressure assess potential impacts of heat on human health represent conditions indoors or shaded calm areas.
 Bias-adjusted HSI: indicators undergo correction process (ISIMIP3b method) using WFDE5 dataset reference valuable for studies require accurate representation of heat stress.

 Dataset Features:

 Data Source: CMIP6 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6) major international effort provide climate projections
 Time Period: 1850 to 2300 some models products shorter periods.
 Spatial Coverage: Global
 Resolution Varies depending model from 0.5° x 0.5° to 2.8125° x 2.8125°
 Temporal Resolution: Yearly, monthly daily
 File Format: NetCDF-4
 Metadata Standards: Follows Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6 Attribute Convention for Dataset Discovery (ACDD) v1.3.
 Data Availability: Available through Climate Data Store Earth System Grid Federation.

 Key Benefits:

 Comprehensive: Covers wide range of climate extreme indices heat stress indicators
 Consistent: Uses standardized methods for calculation bias adjustment.
 Uncertainty Estimation: Some models multiple ensemble members for estimation of uncertainty
 Pre-calculated: Saves time computational resources for researchers.
 Bias-Adjusted Data: Offers raw and adjusted data catering to different study needs.

 Who find dataset useful:

Climate scientists: For analyzing trends climate extremes understanding model uncertainties conducting climate change impact studies.
 Impact researchers: For evaluating potential effects climate change on human health infrastructure vulnerable systems.
 Policy makers developing adaptation strategies mitigation policies to address risks associated climate extremes.

 summary dataset provides valuable resource for researchers decision-makers need reliable comprehensive data on climate extremes heat stress.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era-interim
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era-interim
reanalysis-era-interim
good description of ERA-Interim reanalysis dataset! breakdown of information few additions:
 Key Points:

 Superseded: ERA-Interim no longer recommended dataset. Users should switch to ERA5.
 Coverage: Covers globe from 1979 to 2019 valuable historical climate record.
 Resolution: 80km for most variables higher resolution for ocean wave data (1 degree).
 Variables: Includes vast array of atmospheric, land ocean-surface variables.
 Temporal Resolution: Analysis variables available every 6 hours forecasts available every 3 hours.

 Additional Notes:

 Why use ERA-Interim? ERA5 newer superior, specific applications where ERA-Interim useful:
 Legacy Data: If research requires ERA-Interim period and variables.
 Availability: ERA-Interim might be available in some archives or software packages.


 Caveats: mindful of limitations of reanalysis datasets:
 Model Bias: model used for ERA-Interim has inherent biases.
 Assimilation: Reanalysis relies on data assimilation can lead to inaccuracies in certain regions or time periods.



 Suggestions:

 ERA5 Documentation: transition to ERA5 review documentation for latest details on variables, temporal resolution other important information.
 Data Discovery: Utilize resources like Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) or ECMWF website to explore data find specific variables need.

 Let me know if other questions about ERA-Interim or ERA5!

 Assuming data loaded into DataFrame called 'df'

 month_label.pack()
 month_entry = Entry(root

 root.mainloop()

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-europe-air-quality-reanalyses
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-europe-air-quality-reanalyses
cams-europe-air-quality-reanalyses
detailed description of CAMS (Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service) air quality reanalysis dataset for Europe break down information understand implications:
 Dataset Provides

 Annual air quality reanalyses: dataset provides estimates of air quality for each year based on combining observations model simulations.
 European Domain: focus on Europe with specific geographical boundaries defined
 High Spatial Resolution: 0.1 degrees (approximately 10 km x 10 km) resolution provides detailed picture of air quality across continent
 Multiple Air Quality Models: dataset uses nine air quality models ensemble to improve accuracy provide estimate of uncertainty.
 Data Assimilation: dataset combines model output with real-world observations (from ground stations satellites sources create complete accurate picture.
 Interim and Validated Reanalyses: Two versions provided:
 Interim: Based on near-real-time data not fully quality controlled available faster might have minor inaccuracies.
 Validated: fully quality-controlled data with delay of one year more reliable.


 Hourly Time Steps: data available at hourly time steps for detailed temporal analysis.
 Vertical Levels: Data provided at multiple heights (surface, 50m 100m insight into vertical air quality profiles.
 Comprehensive Variables: dataset covers wide range of important air quality pollutants:
 Ammonia (NH3)
 Carbon monoxide (CO)
 Nitrogen dioxide (NO2)
 Nitrogen monoxide (NO)
 Non-methane volatile organic compounds (VOCs)
 Ozone (O3)
 PM10 (particulate matter diameter < 10 μm)
 PM2.5 < 2.5 μm)
 Peroxyacyl nitrates (PANs)
 Elementary carbon (various fractions)
 Sulfur dioxide (SO2)



 Implications for Research and Applications
 dataset valuable for variety of applications:

 Air Quality Research: Scientists use to
 Study long-term trends in air quality
 Analyze impact of pollution sources
 Assess effectiveness of air quality policies.
 Develop refine air quality models.


 Policy and Regulation:
 Governments regulatory agencies use data to
 Set enforce air quality standards
 Monitor compliance with regulations.
 Make informed decisions about pollution control measures.


 Public Health:
 Researchers study relationship between air pollution health effects
 Health officials use data to
 Issue warnings about poor air quality
 Target interventions public health campaigns.




 Climate Change:
 Air quality and climate change intertwined dataset help researchers understand impact of climate change on air quality vice versa



 Summary
 CAMS European air quality reanalysis dataset rich valuable resource for understanding addressing air quality issues in Europe high resolution comprehensive variables detailed time series make ideal for fundamental research practical applications

Black Sea Surface Temperature extreme from Reanalysis
CMEMS BLKSEA_OMI_tempsal_extreme_var_temp_mean_and_anomaly Indicator: Summary Key Findings
 OMI indicator focuses on extreme variability Sea Surface Temperature (SST) in Black Sea using 99th percentile annual SST data utilizes two CMEMS products

 BLKSEA_MULTIYEAR_PHY_007_004 Provides mean 99th percentile period 1993-2019.
 BLKSEA_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_PHYS_007_001 (Analysis product): Provides 99th percentile for 2020 anomaly calculations

 Key Findings


 Mean 99th percentile (1993-2019):

 Values range 25.50 to 26.50 °C in western central Black Sea
 Values increase eastward exceeding 27.5 °C
 Lower values (below 25.75 °C) found in specific areas
 West of Crimean Peninsula near Sevastopol anticyclone
 Northern Ukraine region (Odessa, Karkinytska Gulf) due to freshwater input
 Narrow area Turkish coastline south





 Anomaly in 2020

 Negative anomalies in Bosporus Bulgarian offshore region up to Crimean peninsula
 Positive anomaly Northwest shelf Eastern basin
 Highest positive value Eastern Turkish coastline near Batumi gyre area potentially related to higher warming southern regions



 Context

 SST is Essential Ocean Variable crucial for understanding ocean circulation marine ecosystems ocean-atmosphere interactions
 Black Sea's cyclonic circulation ocean-atmosphere interactions influence SST variability
 warming trend in Black Sea SST observed recent years higher positive trend in eastern region



 indicator provides insights into extreme SST variability warming trends in Black Sea
Using percentiles instead of annual maxima reduces impact individual data points on analysis.
 study of extreme variability extends previous research on sea level SST wave height.

 key findings updated annually in November.

 indicator contributes to understanding of Black Sea's dynamic environment response to climate change.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-water-quality-swicca
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-water-quality-swicca
sis-water-quality-swicca
great description of dataset summary key points
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose dataset provides modeled data on nitrogen phosphorus concentrations loads in European catchments created to speed up impact assessments facilitate climate change adaptation in water management
 Source: Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute's E-HYPE model
 Focus: Water quality indicators nitrogen phosphorus breakdown into organic/inorganic particulate/soluble forms
 Temporal Coverage: 1971-2100 historical future projections
 Spatial Coverage: Pan-European irregular catchment polygons (average size 215 km2)
 Format: NetCDF

 Key Features

 Reference Period: 1971-2000 absolute values for all indicators
 Future Periods: Relative changes compared to reference period provided for all indicators
 Water Temperature: Included for reference period changes for future periods
 Data Types: Concentrations (μg/l), loads (kg), temperature (°C).
 Breakdown Nitrogen separated into organic inorganic forms phosphorus separated into particulate soluble forms

 Strengths Dataset

 Comprehensive Covers broad geographic area (Europe) detailed information on water quality indicators
 Future Projections insights into potential changes in water quality due to climate change
 Detailed Breakdown separation of nitrogen phosphorus forms enhances understanding nutrient cycling potential impacts
 Standardized Format: NetCDF ensures accessibility compatibility with common data analysis tools

 Potential Applications

 Water Quality Monitoring Tracking trends in nitrogen phosphorus concentrations loads
 Climate Change Adaptation: Assessing potential impacts climate change on water quality developing adaptation strategies
 Environmental Management Informing decisions water pollution control sustainable water management
Research: Providing valuable data source for studies on water quality nutrient cycling climate change impacts.

 Important Considerations:

 Model-Based: data is based on model simulation may not reflect real-world conditions.
 Resolution: irregular catchment polygons with median size of 215 km2 may limit analysis of smaller localized features.
 Temporal Resolution: data not temporally resolved represents averages over long periods (30 years), potentially masking shorter-term variations.

 Overall dataset provides valuable resource for understanding managing water quality across Europe, particularly respect climate change impacts.

521
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-major-baltic-inflow-timedepth-evolution-sto2
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_WMHE_mbi_sto2tz_gotland
Baltic Sea Major Baltic Inflow: time/depth evolution S,T,O2 from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Major Baltic Inflows Impact on Gotland Basin
 text describes Major Baltic Inflows rare events large volumes of saline oxygen-rich water from North Sea enter Baltic Sea inflows significant impact on hydrophysical conditions central Baltic Sea particularly Gotland Basin
 Key Points:

 Infrequency: Major Baltic Inflows occur sporadically sometimes years apart
 Impact on Salinity: Inflows raise salinity Gotland Basin's bottom layers maximum salinity observed 1.5 years after event.
 Impact on Temperature: Inflows typically bring colder water to bottom recent years seen warmer water reaching basin
 Impact on Oxygen: Inflows temporarily oxygenate bottom waters oxygen levels decline rapidly due to biological consumption warm water conditions.
 Stagnation Periods: absence of inflows deeper layers Gotland Basin experience oxygen depletion leading to stagnation periods periods prominent in 1920s/1930s, 1950s/1960s 1980s/early 1990s.

 Recent Observations:

 1993, 2002 2014: Major Baltic Inflows clear impact on Gotland Basin affecting salinity temperature oxygen levels up to 100-meter depth.
 Since 2017: Salinity below 150 meters decreased halocline (boundary between fresh saline water) risen indicating transport of saline water to intermediate layers.
 Warming Trend: Deep water temperatures risen since 1998 warm water now occupying layer below 100 meters.
 Oxygen Depletion: Oxygen levels declined rapidly especially after 2014, due to biological consumption warm water In 2021 oxygen completely depleted below 75 meters.

 Significance:

 Major Baltic Inflows play crucial role in maintaining health Baltic ecosystem
 influence distribution of marine life particularly at different trophic levels.
increasing frequency of warmer inflows associated oxygen depletion concerning potentially leading to further ecological changes.

 Further Research:

 Continued monitoring of Major Baltic Inflows necessary to understand long-term effects on Baltic Sea.
 Research needed to investigate impact climate change on frequency intensity inflows.

 summary highlights critical importance of Major Baltic Inflows in shaping Baltic Sea's environment need for further investigation to understand long-term impacts
---

 Create Folium map

 Add markers based on selected year month
 update_map(year, month):
 filtered_data = data[(data["Year"] == year) (data["Month"] == month)]
 index row filtered_data.iterrows():
 folium.Marker(
 location=[row["Latitude"] row["Longitude"]]
 popup=f"XCO2: {row['XCO2']
 ).add_to(my_map

Add event listeners to elements call update_map function when values change
 Display map
 my_map.save("co2_map.html")
 ``

text provides detailed description of tool assess potential impact climate change on spread mosquito-borne diseases in Mediterranean region breakdown key points:
 Problem:

 Mediterranean densely populated susceptible to spread diseases transmitted by mosquitoes particularly tiger mosquito (Aedes albopictus).
 Climate change expanding areas suitable for tiger mosquito breeding increasing length mosquito season.

 Solution:

 Copernicus Climate Change Service developed application to model spread of tiger mosquitos diseases transmit
 application utilizes climate variables like rainfall temperature to calculate
 Climate suitability: favorable conditions for mosquito breeding survival (ranging from 0 to 100).
 Season length: duration of mosquito season in weeks.


 tool allows users to explore data for specific locations within Mediterranean.

 Data Functionality:

 Input Variables:
 Season length (days): Represents duration mosquito season.
 Climate suitability (dimensionless): Indicates likelihood of suitable conditions for mosquito presence.


 Output Variables:
 Active season length (days): Equivalent to input "season length."
 Climate suitability for mosquitoes (dimensionless): Similar to input "climate suitability."


 Interactive Features:
 Users can select locations on map or search for specific cities.
 tool displays "mosquito-stripes" bar chart showing change in suitability season length over time.



 Significance:
 tool provides valuable insights into potential impact climate change on spread mosquito-borne diseases By understanding changing environmental suitability for tiger mosquitoes public health officials can

 Develop targeted surveillance prevention strategies
 Prepare for potential outbreaks diseases like dengue chikungunya.
 Allocate resources to combat threat mosquito-borne illnesses.

 Overall, application is crucial resource for understanding link between climate change mosquito ecology human health in Mediterranean region.

text provides detailed description of application to explore heat waves cold spells in Europe using climate projections from EURO-CORDEX climate models. breakdown of information provided:
 Application Does:

 Provides Heat Wave Definitions: application uses three heat wave definitions:
 Climatological EURO-CORDEX: Based on 99th percentile of daily maximum temperatures over control period.
 Euroheat Project: Considers maximum apparent temperature and minimum temperature thresholds.
 National Definitions: Uses definitions by 9 European countries.


 Visualizes Projections: application allows users to visualize number of heat wave days predicted to change throughout 21st century for different Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs).
 Interactive Map: Users interact with map to explore heat wave data by country or region.

 Key Features:

 Time Slider: Allows users see number of heat wave days expected change over time.
 Regional Focus: Data presented at NUTS level 3 administrative regions for more localized analysis.
 Data Source: application draws data from EURO-CORDEX ensemble climate models collaborative effort to produce regional climate projections for Europe.

 Application Doesn't Cover:

 Cold Spells: text mentions cold spells doesn't provide details on how application explores or visualizes cold spells.
 Specific National Definitions: text only mentions national definitions used; doesn't specify which countries or definitions.

 Overall application provides valuable tool for researchers, policymakers public to understand projected impacts of climate change on heat waves in Europe. To further explore application need to access specific platform where it hosted.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-ice-concentration
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-ice-concentration
satellite-sea-ice-concentration
comprehensive description of sea ice concentration dataset! breakdown of key information:
 dataset provides

 Daily gridded data of sea ice concentration maps showing percentage of sea ice covering ocean for each day broken into grid cells
 Data for both hemispheres: dataset covers Arctic and Antarctic regions
 Two products:
 SSMIS product (1979 - present daily updates): Coarse resolution (30-60 km), long consistent record.
 AMSR product (2002-2017): Medium resolution (15-25 km), more detail especially in marginal ice zone.



 data important:

 Sea ice crucial part of climate system impacts weather patterns Earth energy balance marine ecosystems
 Sea ice retreat significant indicator of climate change Tracking changes in sea ice essential for understanding impacts of warming temperatures.

 Key features of dataset:

 Derived from satellite data Passive microwave brightness temperatures from different satellite sensors used
 Same polar projection and grid resolution (25 km): comparing data from different periods easier
 Common algorithm baseline Ensures consistency between two products despite different origins
 Level 4 products: Gaps in data filled through temporal and spatial interpolation (but not for days with no satellite data).

 Benefits of using dataset:

 Long-term analysis: SSMIS product provides comprehensive historical record of sea ice changes
 Detailed spatial information AMSR product offers higher resolution for studying specific areas particularly marginal ice zone
 Common data format Facilitates working with both products for analysis comparison.

 further information:

 Documentation: Details about each product available in Documentation section.
 Climate Data Store: Information on other sea ice parameters (thickness, edge, type) found there

 dataset valuable resource for researchers scientists interested understanding sea ice dynamics role in climate system

app-soil-erosion-what-if-analysis
detailed well-structured description of soil erosion modeling application breakdown of key features:
 Functionality:

 Scenario Exploration: core purpose to allow users understand land use practices climate change impact soil erosion in Italy.
 Interactive Mapping: Users visualize soil loss across Italy zoom in on specific areas see soil loss changes with different scenarios.
 NUTS Level Focus: application focuses on NUTS (Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics) level when users zoom in providing regional-level insights.
 User-Defined Adjustments: Users modify land cover management practices within selected NUTS area application calculates resulting soil loss showcasing impact of changes.

 User Interface:

 Drop-down Menus select time periods greenhouse gas scenarios land use factors.
 Interactive Map: visual representation of soil loss data zooming navigation capabilities.
 Focused View Window: Displays detailed information for selected NUTS area including original recalculated soil loss values.
 Text Input Widget: Enables users input new value for average land cover management practice within selected NUTS.

 Data and Calculations:

 Rainfall Data: application utilizes rainfall time series from ERA5-Land reanalysis (for past) EURO-CORDEX simulations (for future scenarios).
 Soil Erosion Model: application uses Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE) to estimate soil loss based on factors rainfall, soil properties land use.
 Recalculated Soil Loss: Based on user-defined adjustments to land cover management application recalculates soil loss visualizes changes.

 Strengths of Application:

 User-friendly Interface: combination of interactive maps drop-down menus focused views makes application easy to navigate use
Comprehensive Scenario Exploration: ability to select various time periods greenhouse gas concentrations land use changes allows for wide range of scenario analysis.
 Data-Driven Insights: application leverages high-quality climate soil erosion data providing users reliable informative results
 Practical Implications: application can help decision-makers farmers stakeholders understand potential impact of land use decisions on soil erosion develop mitigation strategies.

 Potential Enhancements:

 Integration of Additional Factors: Expanding application to include other factors influencing soil erosion soil properties topography land management practices enhance accuracy usefulness.
 Uncertainty Analysis: Implementing methods to assess visualize uncertainty with model outputs provide complete picture of potential range outcomes.
 Scenario Planning Tools: Adding features allow users to develop test specific land management scenarios make application more powerful for decision-making.

 Overall application is valuable tool for understanding complex interplay of land use, climate change soil erosion. providing simple powerful interface for exploring different scenarios application can facilitate informed decision-making to protect manage soil resources for future generations.

CMEMS_OMI_tempsal_extreme_var_temp_mean_and_anomaly: Breakdown
 document describes IBI_OMI OMI indicator monitors extreme sea surface temperature (SST) variability Iberia-Biscay-Ireland (IBI) region uses two CMEMS products

 IBI_MULTIYEAR_PHY_005_002 (Multi Year Product): Provides long-term average (1993-2019) of 99th percentile annual SST represents typical extreme SST events region.
 IBI_ANALYSISFORECAST_PHY_005_001 (Analysis Product): Provides 99th percentile SST for 2020 analysis of anomalies compared to long-term average.

 breakdown key points:
 Key Parameters:


 Map of 99th mean percentile:

 Computed from Multi Year Product averaging 99th percentile each year between 1993 and 2019.
 Shows typical distribution extreme SST events IBI region



 Anomaly of 99th percentile in 2020:

 Computed from Analysis Product comparing 2020 99th percentile to long-term mean
 Highlights deviations from typical extreme SST events specific year (2020).



 Context:

 Importance of SST SST essential ocean variable impacting ocean circulation marine ecosystems global climate.
 North Atlantic Variability: IBI region experiences complex temperature variations due to factors
 Latitudinal gradient SST increases southward
 Subtropical gyre Transports cool water from north
 North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO): Influences interannual interdecadal temperature variability
 Upwelling Brings colder nutrient-rich water from depths particularly coast.



 CMEMS Key Findings:


 Mean 99th percentile (1993-2019):

Exhibits north-south pattern reflecting climatological temperature distribution
 Shows influence of upwelling in coastal regions Africa Iberian Peninsula
 Consistent with findings previous research.



 Anomaly of 99th percentile in 2020

 Predominantly positive values exceeding climatic standard deviation
 Shows localized regions of positive negative anomalies some exceeding twice standard deviation
 Higher positive anomalies in open ocean areas between 30°N-45°N 50°N-56°N
 Stronger negative anomalies (up to -3°C) observed in upwelling regions near northwest African coast (30°N-33°N).



 Conclusion
 indicator provides insights into spatial temporal variability of extreme SST events in IBI region helps monitor potential changes events impact on marine environment climate.
 References
 document provides references to relevant publications for further exploration IBI region SST variability related research
