https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/north-atlantic-ocean-eutrophication-observations
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=OMI_HEALTH_CHL_ATLANTIC_OCEANCOLOUR_eutrophication
North Atlantic Ocean Eutrophication from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Eutrophication and Oligotrophication Study in North Atlantic Ocean
 document outlines study examining eutrophication oligotrophication trends in North Atlantic Ocean using satellite-derived chlorophyll data from 1998-2017.
 Key findings:

 Methodology: study developed method to identify eutrophic oligotrophic areas comparing daily chlorophyll data with long-term climatological values (P90 and P10).
 Spatial trends:
 Oligotrophication: increase in oligotrophic areas observed in Northern Atlantic in 2021 reduction in coastal and shelf waters for oligotrophication in 2020.
 Eutrophication: eutrophication remained low in Northern Atlantic in 2021 significant increase in eutrophic areas observed in Southern Atlantic particularly around Azores.


 Comparison to previous studies: study shows reversal of trends in eutrophication and oligotrophication compared to Third Integrated Report on Eutrophication Status of OSPAR Maritime Area (2017) reported improvements in Greater North Sea.

 Significance:

 Understanding long-term trends: study provides valuable insights into dynamic nature of eutrophication oligotrophication in North Atlantic highlighting spatial temporal variations
 Monitoring environmental change: methodology monitor track changes in nutrient levels algal blooms over time understanding of ecological shifts in marine environments
 Supporting policy decisions information inform efforts to manage nutrient pollution protect marine ecosystems from negative impacts of eutrophication.

 Further research:

 Investigate causes Further investigation needed to understand drivers of observed changes in eutrophication oligotrophication particularly Southern Atlantic
 Improve data collection: Enhancing satellite data coverage accuracy incorporating in-situ measurements refine assessment of eutrophication oligotrophication trends

study emphasizes importance of continuous monitoring research to address complex challenges of eutrophication oligotrophication in North Atlantic Ocean.

https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-total-column-water-vapour-land-ocean
satellite-total-column-water-vapour-land-ocean
detailed description of dataset containing Total Column Water Vapor (TCWV) data from MERIS SSM/I instruments breakdown of key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides long-term record of global TCWV crucial for climate studies weather forecasting understanding Earth's energy balance
 Data Sources Combines MERIS (near data over land coastal areas with SSM/I (microwave data over ocean surfaces
 Coverage Global coverage May 2002 to March 2012.
 Resolution:
 Spatial: 0.5° x 0.5° and 0.05° x 0.05°
 Temporal: Monthly


 Format: NetCDF4

 Key Points

 Importance of TCWV essential for understanding cloud formation cloud physics Earth's heat budget
 Merging Data Sources dataset leverages MERIS and SSM/I for comprehensive global coverage
 Data Quality
 MERIS TCWV retrieval relies on differential absorption technique in NIR water vapor band reliable
 ERA-Interim reanalysis data provides a priori information for MERIS TCWV retrieval higher spatial resolution improved uncertainty estimates


 Related Data separate dataset provides higher-resolution TCWV over oceans
 dataset produced maintained by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).

 Main Variable

 Total Column Water Vapor (TCWV): Measured in kg/m2 representing integrated mass of water vapor in entire atmospheric column above 1 square meter area

 Auxiliary Variables

 dataset includes variables related to uncertainty statistical distribution of main variable (TCWV). Refer to documentation for detailed information

this dataset provides valuable resource for researchers scientists interested in studying climate variability water cycle processes role of water vapor in Earth's climate system.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/baltic-sea-mean-sea-level-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BALTIC_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
Baltic Sea Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Baltic Sea Sea Level Monitoring Indicator
 document provides detailed description Baltic Sea sea level monitoring indicator derived from satellite altimetry data summary key points:
 Data Source:

 Data from Copernicus Climate Change Service and Copernicus Marine Service (SEALEVEL_GLO_PHY_CLIMATE_L4_MY_008_057)
 Uses delayed-time (DT-2021) altimeter gridded maps of sea level anomalies
 Based on data from stable constellation of two altimeters

 Methodology:

 Calculates basin-wide mean sea level (RMSL) by averaging gridded sea level maps weighted by latitude
 Removes annual semi-annual periodic signals
 Applies low-pass filter to time series
 Corrects for regional mean effect of Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA) using ICE5G-VM2 GIA model.

 Key Findings

 Over period 1993/01/01 to 2021/08/02 RMSL in Baltic Sea rose rate 4.5 ± 0.84 mm/year.

 Context:

 indicator crucial for understanding climate change impacts on sea level
 Global mean sea level (GMSL) rising since 1960s rate rise accelerated since 1970s primarily driven by human activity
 Regional sea level changes influenced by factors local ocean dynamics atmospheric forcing Earth gravity vertical land motion
 Rising sea levels pose risks to coastal populations infrastructure increasing vulnerability to flooding storms extreme events
 Adaptation mitigation measures crucial to reduce risks rising sea levels

 Limitations:

 indicator not account for uncertainty related interannual signal influence trend estimation
 TOPEX-A instrumental drift correction applied to GMSL not yet applied to RMSL due to uncertainties in applying global correction at regional scale.

 Overall
Baltic Sea sea level monitoring indicator provides insights into rate impact of sea level rise in important regional ecosystem. highlights need for continued monitoring understanding of various factors contribute to sea level change.
---

Summary Mediterranean Outflow Water Monitoring
 document describes monitoring Mediterranean Outflow Water (MOW) salinity anomalies at 1000m depth using data from CMEMS products goal to understand inter-annual variability trends of water mass in Iberia-Biscay-Ireland (IBI) region
 Key Points

 What is MOW? warm, saline water mass mixing Mediterranean North Atlantic waters impacts salinity North Atlantic influencing circulation patterns climate
 Monitoring Approach Salinity anomalies calculated relative to monthly climatology averaged in specific boxes representing MOW reservoir main spreading pathways
 Data Sources Data combined from CMEMS products (IBI-MYP IBI-NRT GLO-MYP CORA ARMOR) robust multi-product result
 Key Findings
 Reservoir (b): No long-term trends observed suggesting stable MOW formation processes
 North (c): Alternating periods positive negative anomalies recent negative period (2016-present) linked to decrease in northward MOW pathway Potential return to steady conditions in 2020-2021
 West (d): Cyclical pattern negative (2015-2017) positive (2017-present) anomalies Positive anomalies associated with increased westward salinity transport into North Atlantic potentially maintained in 2020-2021.


 Consistency with Other Studies: Results align with independent research suggesting westward displacement of MOW contraction of northern boundary

 Significance Monitoring MOW variability crucial for understanding climate system evolution impact on oceanographic processes

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/black-sea-mean-sea-level-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=BLKSEA_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
Black Sea Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary Black Sea Mean Sea Level Monitoring Indicator
 document describes Black Sea sea level (RMSL) monitoring indicator methodology key findings utilizes satellite altimetry data estimate RMSL trend considers factors influencing
 key takeaways:
 Methodology

 Data Source Uses DUACS delayed-time (DT-2021 version) altimeter gridded maps sea level anomalies from Copernicus Climate Change Service Copernicus Marine Service
 Processing
 Averages gridded sea level maps weighted by cosine of latitude
 Removes annual semi-annual periodic signals using sinusoidal function
 Low-pass filters time series with 175-day cut-off
 Corrects for regional mean effect of Glacial Isostatic Adjustment using ICE5G-VM2 GIA model


 Trend Calculation Estimates trend based on corrected time series with 90% confidence interval
 Limitations:
 Does not include correction for TOPEX-A instrumental drift might affect regional trend estimates
 Uncertainty linked interannual signal not accounted for



 Key Findings:

 RMSL Trend RMSL Black Sea rising rate 1.7 ± 0.83 mm/year over period 1993/01/01 to 2021/08/02.
 Influencing Factors:
 Anthropogenic climate change (steric expansion)
 Mass changes from water exchange with Mediterranean Sea river discharge precipitation/evaporation variations



 Context

 Global Sea Level Rise indicator contributes to understanding global sea level rise major consequence climate change
 Regional Variability Black Sea RMSL rise exhibits regional variability influenced by local ocean dynamics atmospheric forcing land motion changes
 Impacts Rising sea levels impact coastal populations infrastructure food security increase vulnerability to flooding storms cyclones.

 Further Research

 Assessing impact TOPEX-A instrumental drift on regional trend estimations.
 Incorporating uncertainty interannual signal in trend estimations.
 Exploring contribution of different factors to observed RMSL trend.

 Black Sea RMSL monitoring indicator provides valuable information about sea level change region contributing to understanding impacts climate change informing adaptation mitigation strategies.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-biodiversity-thermal-suitability-fish
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-biodiversity-thermal-suitability-fish
app-biodiversity-thermal-suitability-fish
detailed description of climate change impact assessment application focused on thermal suitability of fish habitats breakdown of key features how works


 Predicts Fish Habitat Changes: application uses climate projections from 10 Global Circulation Models (GCMs) to predict changes in sea surface temperature (SST) affect suitability of habitats for 14 commercially important fish species
 Spatial Visualization: Interactive maps allow visualize thermal suitability and SST for different regions seasons time periods (historical near future mid-future far future).
 Scenario Comparison: compare impact of two climate change scenarios (RCP4.5 - moderate, RCP8.5 - pessimistic).
 Species-Specific Analysis: application incorporates species-specific thermal climate envelopes preferred temperature ranges for each fish species
 Time Series Analysis: Users explore change in thermal suitability over time insight into potential for habitat shifts future impacts on fish populations

 Key Features:

 User-Friendly Interface: application designed user-friendly researchers policymakers general public explore climate change impacts on fish habitats
 Multiple Variables: Users select to view SST or thermal suitability option to choose different seasons (annual, summer winter) time frames
 Regional Analysis: application allows users focus on specific regions including defined by International Council for the Exploration of the Seas (ICES) Marine Ecoregions of the World (MEOW).
 Historical Comparison: Historical thermal suitability data presented alongside future projections easy to see habitats changing

 Works

 Climate Projections: application uses data from 10 GCMs bias-adjusted to ERA5 reanalysis data to create projections of future SST.
Thermal Climate Envelopes: Species-specific thermal climate envelopes from Aquamaps habitat models define preferred temperature ranges for each fish species.
 Thermal Suitability Calculation: application calculates thermal suitability of each grid cell by comparing projected SST with species-specific thermal climate envelope
 Visualization: results visualized using interactive maps, time series plots historical comparisons users explore potential impacts of climate change on fish habitats.

 Significance:
 application valuable for

 Understanding impact of climate change on fish populations provides insights into changing temperatures alter distribution abundance of important fish species
 Developing effective fisheries management strategies information guide decisions about sustainable fishing practices conservation efforts
 Raising awareness about impacts climate change user-friendly interface clear visualizations make for wide audience to understand challenges facing marine ecosystems.

 Potential Enhancements:

 Include Additional Factors: Expand analysis to incorporate additional factors ocean acidification oxygen depletion changes in currents
 Higher Resolution: Use higher-resolution climate models habitat data detailed assessment of thermal suitability
 Integrate with Fisheries Data: Combine thermal suitability data with fisheries catch data to assess potential economic impacts of climate change.

 application provides powerful tool for exploring complex interactions between climate change and marine ecosystems can contribute to understanding of challenges facing fish populations guide efforts to mitigate impacts climate change.

seasonal-postprocessed-pressure-levels
text provides description climate dataset containing monthly pressure-level data for seasonal forecasts focuses on key aspects
 Introduction

 Explains concept of seasonal forecasts highlighting long-range nature role of slow-varying components like ocean temperatures
 Contrasts seasonal forecasts with weather forecasts limitations of predicting precise local changes beyond days due to atmospheric chaos
 Introduces use of ensembles multi-model approaches to quantify uncertainties in long-range forecasts

 Data Source and Processing

 Explains role of climate models in seasonal forecasts representation of key Earth system components like atmosphere ocean land surface
 Mentions importance of model initialization with real-world data use of ensembles to account for initial condition uncertainties
 Introduces C3S multi-system seasonal forecast service combines data from European forecast centers to improve forecast accuracy

 Data Description

 Provides information dataset's characteristics
 Data type: Gridded
 Projection Regular latitude-longitude
 Horizontal coverage: Global
 resolution: 1° x 1°
 Vertical coverage: From 1000 hPa to 10 hPa
 Temporal coverage: 2017 to present
 Monthly
 File format: GRIB
 Update frequency Real-time forecasts released monthly on 6th) and 10th (other) at 12UTC

 Lists available variables in dataset
 Geopotential anomaly (m2 s-2)
 Specific humidity anomaly (kg
 Temperature anomaly (K)
 U-component of wind anomaly (m s-1)
 V-component of wind anomaly (m s-1)

540
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-lake-water-level
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-lake-water-level
satellite-lake-water-level
great description of lake water level dataset breakdown of key information additional insights potential uses:
 Data Overview

 Source: dataset produced by CLS (Collecte Localisation Satellites) Copernicus Climate Change Services (C3S) of European Commission
 Focus: Provides lake water level measurements from satellite radar altimetry
 Key Features:
 Global Coverage: Covers 229 lakes across four continents
 High Temporal Resolution: Data collected between 1 and 10 days frequent updates
 Long Time Series: Data spans from 1992 to present
 Essential Climate Variable (ECV): Lake water level key indicator of climate change



 Advantages of Satellite Altimetry

 Global Coverage: Unlike ground systems satellite altimetry monitor lakes worldwide including remote inaccessible areas
 Regular Temporal Sampling: Consistent data collection provides continuous record of water levels
 Rapid Data Delivery: Information processed distributed quickly compared to ground-based methods

 Limitations of Satellite Altimetry

 Nadir Sampling: Data only collected along satellite's ground tracks not all lakes covered at all times
 Size and Surrounding Environment: Measurement accuracy depends on lake's size reflecting properties of surroundings (topography vegetation).
 Uncertainty: dataset includes uncertainty estimates for each measurement

 Potential Applications

 Climate Change Research: Analyzing long-term water level trends understand impact of climate change on lakes water resources
 Hydrological Modeling: Data used to calibrate validate hydrological models improving understanding of water movement storage within watersheds
 Water Management: Monitoring water levels inform decisions water resource management flood forecasting drought prediction
 Ecosystem Monitoring: Lake water level fluctuations affect aquatic ecosystems data assess manage impacts.

Additional Notes

 Data Format: data provided in NetCDF-4 format, standard for scientific data exchange.
 Metadata Conventions: dataset follows Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention Attribute Convention for Dataset Discovery (ACDD), ensuring consistency discoverability.

 dataset provides valuable resource for researchers policymakers water resource managers interested in understanding managing lakes role in global water cycle.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/north-west-atlantic-shelf-mean-sea-level-time-series-and
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=NORTHWESTSHELF_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
North West Atlantic Shelf Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Ocean Monitoring Indicator on Mean Sea Level in North-West Shelf Region
 document provides detailed explanation of ocean monitoring indicator focusing on mean sea level (MSL) changes in North-West Shelf region key findings context surrounding indicator summarized below:
 Definition:

 indicator based on altimeter data from Copernicus Climate Change Service and Copernicus Marine Service processed to remove seasonal variations corrected for Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA).
 indicator is regional average of sea level anomalies weighted by latitude represents long-term trend of sea level rise.
 acknowledged uncertainty associated with trend due to limitations in altimeter data instrumental drift inter-mission bias corrections impact of interannual variability.

 Context:

 Global mean sea level (GMSL) rising since 1960s rate rise accelerating in recent decades
 rise attributed to human activities primarily climate change impact on glaciers ice sheets ocean warming
 Regional sea level variations influenced by additional factors beyond GMSL local ocean dynamics atmospheric forcing gravity changes land motion.
 Sea level rise poses significant risks to coastal communities including increased flooding storm surges threats to infrastructure food security.

 Key Findings:

 Over period 1993 to 2021 North-West Shelf (NWS) region experienced basin-wide RMSL rise of 3.0 ± 0.83 mm/year.

 Further Considerations

 TOPEX-A instrumental drift correction applied globally not yet at regional scale due to lack of validation consensus on appropriate methods.
 indicator's uncertainty not fully account for impact of interannual variability can influence trend estimation.
long-term trend in NWS region modulated by decadal variations linked to Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO).

 this indicator provides valuable insights into rise of sea level in North-West Shelf region highlighting potential impacts of climate change need for further research refine understanding regional variations.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-monthly-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/seasonal-monthly-pressure-levels
seasonal-monthly-pressure-levels
text provides detailed description of pressure-level data for seasonal forecasts breakdown of key information:
 Data Represents:

 Pressure-level data organized by pressure levels atmosphere (from 1000 hPa to 10 hPa), representing different altitudes.
 Monthly time resolution: data aggregated presented as monthly averages.
 Seasonal forecasts data used for long-range predictions of weather patterns over weeks to months forecasts based on ocean temperatures influence atmospheric conditions

 Key Features of Data:

 Source: data from Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) multi-system seasonal forecast service data collected from several state-of-art seasonal forecast systems across Europe
 Coverage:
 Spatial: Global horizontal resolution of 1° x 1°.
 Temporal: 1993 to 2016 (hindcasts) and 2017 to present (forecasts).


 Format: GRIB (Gridded Binary) format
 Update Frequency: Real-time forecasts released monthly on 6th (ECMWF) or 10th (other centers) at 12UTC.

 Key Variables:

 Geopotential: measure of gravitational potential energy related to altitude
 Specific Humidity: mass of water vapor per unit mass of air
 Temperature: Air temperature in Kelvin
 U-component of wind: wind speed in eastward direction
 V-component of wind: wind speed northward direction

 Data Important

 Understanding Climate Variability: Seasonal forecasts help understand climate patterns change months
 Planning and Decision-Making: data used in various applications like
 Agriculture: Predicting crop yields planning irrigation
 Energy: Forecasting energy demand and supply
 Disaster Management: Preparing for extreme weather events



 Key Takeaway:
pressure-level data provides valuable information for understanding predicting seasonal changes in Earth's climate system combining data from multiple forecast systems offers robust comprehensive resource for researchers policymakers anyone interested in climate-related information

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/atlantic-iberian-biscay-mean-sea-level-time-series-and
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=IBI_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
Atlantic Iberian Biscay Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Analysis Ocean Monitoring Indicator Regional Mean Sea Level Irish-Biscay-Iberian (IBI) Region
 document provides detailed analysis ocean monitoring indicator regional mean sea level (RMSL) Irish-Biscay-Iberian (IBI) region derived from satellite altimeter data breakdown key information:
 Data Source Methodology:

 Data: DUACS delayed-time (DT-2021 version) altimeter gridded maps sea level anomalies from Copernicus Climate Change Service Copernicus Marine Service.
 Region: IBI region covering waters surrounding Ireland Biscay Bay Iberian Peninsula
 Calculation: Average gridded sea level maps weighted by latitude removal annual semi-annual signals sinusoidal function fitting
 Filtering: Low-pass filter 175-day cutoff.
 Correction: Corrected for regional mean effect Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA) ICE5G-VM2 model.
 Trend Uncertainty: 90% confidence interval considering altimeter observation system errors (orbit determination geophysical corrections inter-mission bias).

 Context Significance

 Sea Level Rise crucial indicator climate change driven by ocean warming glacier melt ice sheet melt
 Global Trends Global mean sea level (GMSL) rose by 0.20 m between 1901 and 2018 accelerating since 1960s Human activity main driver rise since 1970
 Regional Variability: RMSL not change uniformly affected by local dynamics atmospheric forcing gravity land motion
 Impacts: Rising sea level poses risks to coastal populations infrastructure food security increases vulnerabilities to floods storms cyclones
 Mitigation & Adaptation: restoring mangroves coastal wetlands mitigate sea level rise impacts

 Findings IBI Region

Trend: RMSL in IBI region rising 3.8 ± 0.82 mm/year between 1993 and 2021.
 Decadal Variability: RMSL trend modulated by decadal variations linked to Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO).
 NAO Influence: NAO affects AMOC along-slope winds influencing local sea level variability European coasts.

 Limitations & Future Considerations:

 TOPEX-A Drift: drift TOPEX altimeter instrument during 1993-1998 may have overestimated global sea level trends correction not applied regionally due to lack of consensus data availability.
 Interannual Variability: uncertainty related to influence of interannual signals on trend estimation not included.
 Future Research: Further research needed to refine regional corrections for TOPEX-A drift assess impact of interannual variability on RMSL trends.

 Conclusion:
 RMSL indicator in IBI region highlights significant rate sea level rise influenced by long-term trends decadal variability information crucial for understanding climate change impacts developing effective adaptation strategies Further research needed to address current limitations improve accuracy of estimates.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-original-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/seasonal-original-pressure-levels
seasonal-original-pressure-levels
text describes dataset of pressure-level data from multi-system seasonal forecast service breakdown:
 What is data?

 Seasonal forecasts: long-range predictions of weather patterns climate conditions over weeks to months based on factors like ocean temperatures slow-changing components of Earth's system
 Multi-system: Data from several different seasonal forecast systems each developed independently by different research centers helps account for different modeling approaches increase reliability of forecasts
 Pressure-level data: Information about atmospheric variables (like temperature, wind humidity) at different pressure levels atmosphere crucial for understanding atmospheric circulation weather patterns
 Original time resolution: data collected at original frequency every 12 hours provides detailed view of changes over time

 Key features:

 Coverage: Global coverage from 1000 hPa to 10 hPa in atmosphere
 Resolution: 1° x 1° horizontally 12-hour intervals temporally
 Data format: GRIB (Gridded Binary) format standard format for meteorological data
 Availability: Data available from 1993 to present hindcasts (historical simulations) and real-time forecasts
 Update frequency: Real-time forecasts updated monthly typically 6th and 10th of each month
 Variables: Includes geopotential specific humidity temperature wind components (U and V).

 Purpose uses:

 Climate monitoring and research: Understanding long-term trends in atmospheric conditions impact on climate system.
 Seasonal forecasting: long-range predictions for sectors like agriculture, energy water management.
 Decision support: Helping stakeholders make informed decisions about planning resource allocation.

 dataset provides valuable resource for researchers, forecasters decision-makers need comprehensive high-resolution information about long-term atmospheric conditions

satellite-total-column-water-vapour-ocean
text provides detailed description Hamburg Ocean Atmosphere Parameters and Fluxes from Satellite Data (HOAPS) dataset focusing on Total Column Water Vapour (TCWV) data product
 Key Points about Dataset:

 measures dataset provides TCWV data measure of total water vapor in atmosphere variable crucial for understanding weather, climate cloud formation
 Data Source: data derived from measurements Special Sensor Microwave Imager (SSM/I) and Special Sensor Microwave Imager Sounder (SSMIS) instruments aboard satellites
 Spatial Coverage: Global ice-free ocean surfaces.
 Temporal Coverage:
 TCDR (Thematic Climate Data Record): 1988 to 2014
 ICDR (Interim Climate Data Record): 2015 to 2020


 Temporal Resolution: Monthly means) 6-hourly data
 Spatial Resolution: 0.5° x 0.5°. Some gaps expected due to data limitations
 Data Format: NetCDF4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.7
 Algorithm: HOAPS version 4.0
 Availability dataset available through EUMETSAT's Satellite Application Facility on Climate Monitoring (CM SAF) Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).

 Key Features of HOAPS Dataset:

 Long Time Series: provides long-term record of TCWV data spanning over 30 years.
 Global Coverage: Data available for most Earth's oceans
 High Resolution data relatively high resolution (0.5° x 0.5°).
 Multiple Temporal Scales: monthly means and 6-hourly data provided researchers investigate various climate processes

 HOAPS Dataset Used
 valuable for numerous research applications including

 Climate Monitoring: Tracking long-term trends in atmospheric water vapor key indicator of climate change
Weather Forecasting: Understanding atmospheric water vapor content essential for improving weather prediction models.
 Cloud Modeling: Water vapor crucial for cloud formation dataset used to improve cloud models.
 Climate Modeling: HOAPS data incorporated into climate models to improve representation of water vapor processes.

 Additional Information:

 dataset contains auxiliary variables uncertainties statistical distributions helpful for data analysis.
 related dataset providing TCWV data over land and ocean (at monthly resolution) available uses different sensors and algorithms.

 Overall HOAPS TCWV dataset offers comprehensive valuable source of information for understanding atmospheric water vapor role in climate weather systems.

Arctic Region, Bio-Geo-Chemical, L3, daily observation
High-Resolution Ocean Colour (HR-OC) Consortium Data
 dataset provides high-resolution ocean color data from Sentinel-2/MSI satellite imagery 20km coastal zone
 Key features

 High Resolution 100m resolution detailed information ocean properties
 Multiple Variables Includes Remote Sensing Reflectances (RRS), Turbidity (TUR), Solid Particulate Matter Concentration spectral particulate backscattering chlorophyll-a concentration (CHL).
 Regional Focus Covers Arctic (ARC) region LAEA projection (EPSG:6931, EASE2)
 Near Real-Time (NRT) Delivery Products available within 24 hours of data acquisition
 Quality Control Includes uncertainty estimates for RRS Quality Index (QI) for TUR SPM CHL

 Data processing

 Data processed through robust pipeline atmospheric correction in-water processing merging
 Daily monthly aggregations generated temporal analysis
 Gap filling techniques provide partially gap-filled daily products

 Applications

 Marine Safety Monitoring water quality turbidity for navigation
 Marine Resources Assessing phytoplankton abundance productivity fisheries management
 Marine & Coastal Environment Studying impact pollution climate change ocean
 Climate & Seasonal Studies Analyzing long trends variability in ocean properties

 Data access

 DOI: https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00061
 CMEMS Web Portal Detailed information product calibration/validation activities

 File formats

 NetCDF-4, CF-1.7
 INSPIRE compliant

 dataset provides valuable information for researchers policymakers understanding managing Arctic marine environment

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-radiative-forcings
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-radiative-forcings
cams-global-radiative-forcings
dataset valuable resource for climate scientists researchers understanding radiative forcing of atmospheric constituents breakdown of information
?
 dataset provides geographical distributions of radiative forcing (RF) caused by key atmospheric components RF measures energy imbalance in Earth's climate system due to changes in atmospheric composition
 Key Features

 Constituents dataset covers
 Carbon dioxide (CO2)
 Methane (CH4)
 Tropospheric Ozone (O3)
 Stratospheric Ozone (O3)
 Anthropogenic aerosols (affecting radiation clouds)


 Spatial and Temporal Coverage:
 Global coverage
 Horizontal resolution: 3° x 3° (1° x 1° for v1.5 aerosol/cloud interactions)
 Vertical levels: Surface, tropopause top-of-atmosphere
 Temporal coverage: 2003-2018 (version 2)
 Temporal resolution Monthly (daily for v1.5 aerosol/cloud interactions)


 Data Format: NetCDF-4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6

 Importance of Radiative Forcing

 Climate Change Indicator: RF direct measure of human activities altering energy balance planet
 Predicting Temperature Changes: RF good indicator of global temperature changes rapid adjustments in atmosphere
 Comparing Climate Impacts: allows researchers to compare potential effects of different climate change drivers



 Positive vs. Negative RF Greenhouse gases like CO2 CH4 exert positive RF warming planet Aerosols cause negative RF reflecting sunlight to space cooling planet
 All-Sky vs. Clear-Sky Data provided for both conditions show clouds modify radiative effects
 Data Versions Newer versions incorporate updated data methods best to use latest available
Related Data dataset includes links to aerosol optical depth data provides additional information about aerosol characteristics.

 Applications:
 dataset used for various research purposes including

 Assessing climate change trends Analyzing RF changed over time
 Modeling climate scenarios: Incorporating RF values into climate models project future climate change
 Evaluating mitigation strategies Assessing impact policies reduce greenhouse gas emissions aerosols

 dataset provides valuable information for understanding radiative forcing of key atmospheric components essential for understanding mitigating climate change.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-ecv-cmip5-bias-corrected
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-ecv-cmip5-bias-corrected
sis-ecv-cmip5-bias-corrected
detailed description of climate data set breakdown key information additional points potential uses:
 Data Overview

 Focus: Essential Climate Variables (ECVs) for hydrological modeling
 Source: 18 Global Climate Models (GCMs) from CMIP5.
 Variables:
 Daily precipitation rate (kg m-2 s-1)
 Daily mean maximum minimum temperatures (K)


 Spatial Resolution: 0.5° x 0.5° global grid
 Temporal Coverage: 1978 to 2100
 Bias Adjustment: Distribution Based Scaling (DBS) method against HydroGFD2.0 (Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute).

 Key Features

 Post-Processing:
 Consistency Adjustments: Ensures maximum/minimum temperatures don't contradict mean temperature climatological anomalies
 Interpolation: Fills in missing values due to DBS limitations using temporal spatial interpolation
 Nearest Neighbor: If interpolation not possible data from nearest grid cell used



 Data Quality Reliability

 Bias Adjustment: DBS method reduce biases in GCM outputs accurate for hydrological applications
 Post-Processing: consistency checks interpolation techniques improve data quality reduce potential inconsistencies
 Limitations: DBS can result in missing values outliers data used with awareness of limitations

 Potential Uses

 Hydrological Modeling: dataset designed for hydrological impact studies
 Flood prediction
 Drought analysis
 Water resource management
 Impact of climate change on water systems


 Climate Change Studies long time series (1978-2100) allows for analysis of climate change impacts projections
 Research dataset valuable for wide range research topics climate hydrology environmental science

 Additional Considerations

Data Availability: description mentions NetCDF format, essential to know where data available for download.
 Metadata: provided description is excellent, but detailed metadata crucial for understanding data's limitations, uncertainties, specific processing steps.

 Summary:
 This dataset offers valuable resource for hydrological modeling climate change research. thorough bias adjustment post-processing steps enhance quality and reliability., important to be aware of potential limitations use data accordingly.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-health-heat-waves-current-climate
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-health-heat-waves-current-climate
app-health-heat-waves-current-climate
great start to description heatwave application! revised version more user-friendly informative focusing on key points
 Explore Heat Waves in Europe: Data-Driven Look
 application lets dive into changing patterns heat waves across Europe using high-resolution climate data from ERA5 reanalysis analyze heatwaves using three accepted definitions:

 Climatological EURO-CORDEX: Defines heatwaves as three consecutive days with daily maximum temperatures exceeding 99th percentile for May-September (1971-2000).
 Euroheat project: Heatwaves occur when maximum apparent temperature and minimum temperature exceed 90th percentiles for two consecutive days during June-August.
 National Definitions: include heatwave definitions from eight EU member states one former member state applied within national boundaries For detailed descriptions refer to documentation.

 Interactive Features:

 Time Slider Visualize evolution of heatwave days from 1979 to 2022.
 Interactive Map: Explore distribution of heatwave days across Europe at NUTS 3 administrative region level Click on countries regions view detailed time-series data Zoom in/out for greater accuracy.

 Data Insights:
 application utilizes ERA5 hourly data on single levels comprehensive information on

 Air Temperature (K): Temperature measured at 2 meters above surface.
 Dew-point Temperature (K): measure of air humidity calculate relative humidity.

 Key Output:
 application outputs number of heatwave days for each region valuable information for understanding climate change impacts supporting adaptation strategies.
 Get Started
 Explore interactive map time slider to gain insights into frequency distribution of heatwaves across Europe Learn how climate change affecting extreme events potential impact on human health environment.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-urban-climate-cities
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-urban-climate-cities
sis-urban-climate-cities
great description of dataset provides clear overview of data including
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: Simulate study urban heat island effect (UHI) urban climate variables
 Data Source: UrbClim urban climate model developed at VITO.
 Spatial Resolution: 100 meters.
 Temporal Resolution: Hourly.
 Coverage: 100 European cities January 2008 to December 2017.
 Data Format: NetCDF-4.

 Key Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded (spatial data organized into grid).
 Horizontal Coverage: European
 Horizontal Resolution: 100m x 100m.
 Temporal Coverage: January 2008 to December 2017.
 Temporal Resolution: Hourly
 File Format: NetCDF-4.
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6, Attribute Convention for Dataset Discovery (ACDD) v1.3.

 Main Variables
 description defines variables included in dataset units descriptions:
 Variable Name  Units  Description

 Air temperature Air temperature at 2m above surface
 Land-sea mask  Dimensionless  1 for land NaN for water CORINE land cover
 Relative humidity  % Relation between actual and saturation humidity at 2m height (0-100%).
 Rural-urban mask  Dimensionless  1 for rural areas NaN for urban areas CORINE land cover
 Specific humidity  kg kg-1 Mass of water vapor per unit mass of air at 2m height
 Wind speed  m s-1 Wind speed at 2m above surface calculated from zonal and meridional wind components
 Additional Points

 Downscaling: ERA5 reanalysis weather data downscaled to agglomeration (city) scale
Urban Impacts: UrbClim simulates impact of urban development on weather parameters.
 City Selection: 100 European cities chosen based on health community needs spatial distribution, with focus on Eastern Europe.
 Data Production: data produced for Copernicus Climate Change Service.

 Overall: This comprehensive well-written description of dataset provides essential information needed to understand data, its origin, potential applications.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-european-wind-storm-synthetic-events
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-european-wind-storm-synthetic-events
sis-european-wind-storm-synthetic-events
detailed description of synthetic windstorm dataset for Europe breakdown of information key takeaways:


 Synthetic Windstorm Events: dataset collection of simulated windstorm events not actual historical data aims to provide realistic representation of potential windstorms for risk analysis in insurance industry
 Physically Realistic: events generated using climate model (HadGEM3) incorporate plausible climatic conditions scientifically sound
 Not a Historical Record: dataset not align with actual observed storms but serves valuable tool for assessing risk comparing against stochastic (randomly generated) event sets

 important

 Risk Assessment: Insurance companies need to understand potential for windstorm damage dataset provides way simulate range of scenarios
 Climate Change Impact: dataset considers windstorm characteristics in warming climate for analysis of potential changes in risk
 Comparison Tool: provides standardized baseline for comparing against other windstorm datasets modeling results

 Key features:

 Coverage: Covers Europe specifically northern hemisphere winter months (September-May).
 Time Period: Spans from 1986 to 2011.
 Resolution Uses grid resolution of 4.4 km detailed representation of windstorm events
 Variables main variable is maximum 3-second wind gusts at 10 meters above ground level
 Methodology: Three different sets of simulations (Synthetic set 1.2, Synthetic set 2, set 3) created using different techniques include
 Recalibrating using historical events (Xynthia Kyrill Daria 87J)
 Using storm severity index to select strongest events
 Downscaling based on station observations


 Ensemble Simulations Multiple simulations (ensembles) run to capture uncertainty in forecasting increase number of events.

 Key takeaways:

dataset provides valuable tool for risk assessment in insurance industry for understanding potential impact climate change on windstorms.
 important to note dataset is a simulation not represent actual historical events.
 different simulation sets provide range of possibilities for analysis.

 Further research:
 dataset can be used for various research and analysis purposes:

 Analyzing frequency, intensity spatial distribution of simulated windstorms.
 Evaluating impact climate change on windstorm risk.
 Comparing results of different windstorm models datasets.
 Developing improved methods for assessing managing windstorm risk.

 Let me know if any other questions.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-upper-troposphere-humidity
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-upper-troposphere-humidity
satellite-upper-troposphere-humidity
comprehensive description Upper Tropospheric Humidity (UTH) dataset through Climate Data Store (CDS). breakdown key information:
 What is UTH?

 Importance: UTH crucial for understanding Earth's greenhouse effect climate change influences atmospheric processes like water vapor cloud feedback amplify climate system response to greenhouse gas increases
 Measurement: UTH measure relative humidity upper troposphere (500 hPa to 200 hPa).
 Derivation derived from observations AMSU-B MHS microwave humidity sounders on NOAA MetOp satellites.

 Data Characteristics:

 Type: Gridded data (regular latitude-longitude grid)
 Coverage: Global
 Resolution: 1.0° x 1.0° horizontally single column value vertically
 Temporal Coverage: From 1999 to present
 Resolution: Daily (average of ascending and descending satellite passes)
 File Format: NetCDF-4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6

 Main Variables:

 Upper Tropospheric Humidity (%): core data representing relative humidity upper troposphere provided for
 Daily Mean: Average of all observations day
 Ascending Pass Mean: Average observations ascending pass (South to North)
 Descending Pass Mean: Average observations descending pass (North to South)



 Related Variables:

 Standard Deviation: Indicates spread data around mean
 Median: middle value when data ordered
 Number of Valid Retrievals: number valid observations used calculate mean
 Total Number of Observations: Includes valid and invalid observations
 Longitude & Latitude: Coordinates grid box
 Observation Day: Date observation
 Quality Controlled Brightness Temperatures: Raw satellite measurements after quality control

 Data Providers:

 TCDR (Thematic Climate Data Record): Produced by Met Office behalf EUMETSAT's Climate Monitoring Satellite Application Facility (CMSAF)
 ICDR (Interim Climate Data Record): Produced by Met Office behalf Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S)

 Key Points:

 dataset provides valuable insights into changing state atmospheric humidity key factor in climate change.
 data well-documented uses standardized conventions for easy use by researchers
 data available through CDS, valuable resource for climate science and research.

 Let me know if specific questions about UTH dataset or how to use for research!

558
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-sea-mean-sea-level-time-series-and-trend
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=MEDSEA_OMI_SL_area_averaged_anomalies
Mediterranean Sea Mean Sea Level time series and trend from Observations Reprocessing
Summary of Mediterranean Sea Regional Mean Sea Level (RMSL) Indicator
 document provides detailed description of Mediterranean Sea Regional Level (RMSL indicator derived from satellite altimetry data.
 Key findings:

 RMSL trend: period 1993 to 2021 RMSL in Mediterranean Sea risen rate 2.7 ± 0.83 mm/year.
 Data source: indicator based on altimeter gridded maps of sea level anomalies by Copernicus Climate Change Service Copernicus Marine Service.
 Methodology: indicator calculated as average of gridded sea level maps weighted by cosine of latitude. Annual semi-annual periodic signals removed time series low-pass filtered Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA) effect corrected for.
 Uncertainty: trend uncertainty provided in 90% confidence interval considering errors related altimeter observation system Uncertainty related interannual variability not accounted for.
 Global vs. regional correction: global correction for TOPEX-A instrumental drift applied to global mean sea level (GMSL), not to regional RMSL due to lack of consensus apply at regional scale.

 Context:

 Global sea level rise: indicator contributes to understanding global sea level rise driven by ocean warming melting of glaciers ice sheets.
 Mediterranean Sea variability: Mediterranean Sea shows significant interannual variability in RMSL influenced by steric effects deep-water formation North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO).
 Impact of sea level rise: Rising sea level poses risks to coastal populations infrastructure particularly in low-lying areas island states.

 Further research:

 Regional correction: Further research needed to determine appropriate method for applying global TOPEX-A instrumental drift correction at regional scale.
Interannual variability: impact of interannual variability on RMSL trends needs further investigated incorporated into uncertainty assessment.

 Overall this indicator provides valuable information about changing sea level in Mediterranean Sea contributes to understanding of global sea level rise impacts.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-europe-air-quality-forecasts
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-europe-air-quality-forecasts
cams-europe-air-quality-forecasts
great description of European air quality dataset! breakdown of information provided, insights:
 Key Features:

 High Resolution: dataset boasts spatial resolution of 0.1 degrees (approximately 10 km x 10 km), detailed picture of air quality across Europe.
 Ensemble Approach: uses ensemble of 11 different air quality forecasting systems, strength. Ensemble forecasting helps account for model uncertainties produces more accurate results.
 Data Assimilation: dataset combines model data with real-world observations from European Environment Agency (EEA), enhancing accuracy and reliability.
 Multi-level Data: data available at various vertical levels (surface, 50m, 100m,.), providing insights into air quality at different heights.
 Hourly Time Steps: dataset provides hourly updates fine-grained picture of air quality changes throughout day.

 Important Considerations:

 Limited Validation: some key pollutants like nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide, ozone, PM validated, forecasts for other variables considered experimental should be treated with caution.
 Rolling Archive: dataset maintains three-year rolling archive substantial time series for analysis.

 Potential Applications:

 Air Quality Monitoring: dataset valuable for tracking understanding air quality trends across Europe.
 Public Health Research: used to study health impacts of air pollution develop public health interventions.
 Environmental Policy: data can inform environmental regulations policies at improving air quality.
 Climate Change Research: Understanding air quality trends over time provide insights into effects of climate change.

 Further Exploration:

 Documentation: "Documentation section" crucial for understanding how data was collected, processed limitations of dataset.
 Variable Descriptions: helpful to have more detailed description of each variable and units, especially those not validated.

Overall, this European air quality dataset valuable resource for researchers, policymakers, anyone interested in understanding monitoring air quality across Europe.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-satellite-humidity-seasonal-variation
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-satellite-humidity-seasonal-variation
app-satellite-humidity-seasonal-variation
text describes application visualizes analyzes time series specific humidity data from satellite-based Radio Occultation (RO) measurements breakdown key aspects:
 Data and Methodology

 Data Source data from EUMETSAT's ROM SAF facility provides gridded monthly-mean tropospheric humidity dataset from RO measurements 2006 to present
 Data Coverage: Global coverage surface up to 12 km altitude high vertical resolution
 Anomaly Calculation: Two types of anomalies shown
 Seasonally Adjusted Anomalies: Calculated by subtracting long-term average for each latitude-height bin from monthly means retains seasonal cycles
 De-seasonalised Anomalies: Calculated by subtracting mean annual cycle for entire time series from monthly means highlights variations beyond annual cycle ENSO effects long-term trends.



 Visualizations

 Time Series Plots:
 upper two figures show seasonally adjusted anomalies two ways
 Height-resolved Time series for different altitudes within selected latitude band
 Vertically averaged: Time series averaged over three 4-km height layers


 lower two figures show de-seasonalised anomalies
 Height-resolved For selected latitude band
 Vertically averaged selected latitude band global average




 User-Selectable Parameters:
 Region Allows users select specific latitude bands for analysis (90S-60S 60S-30S 30S-30N 30N-60N 60N-90N



 Key Findings Insights:

 Dominance of Seasonal Cycle Time variations in humidity driven by seasonal cycle amplitudes varying by latitude
 ENSO Influence application highlights global impact of strong El Niño events (2009-2010 2015-2016) on humidity anomalies
Identification Long-term Trends: De-seasonalised anomalies reveal variations beyond annual cycle potentially indicating long-term trends.

 Significance Applications:
 application provides insights into variability atmospheric humidity crucial for understanding

 Climate Change: Assessing changes humidity patterns over time provide information about Earth's climate system.
 Hydrological Cycle: Understanding humidity variability essential for predicting rainfall patterns droughts.
 Global Energy Transport: Humidity significant role in global energy transport influencing weather climate patterns.

 application offers powerful tool for researchers scientists to analyze visualize global humidity trends implications for climate hydrological processes.

satellite-precipitation-microwave
Summary Copernicus micrOwave-based pRecipitAtion (COBRA) Dataset
 provides global estimates of daily monthly precipitation based passive microwave observations from Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites
 breakdown key information
 Strengths

 Purely Microwave-Based Unlike datasets infrared rain COBRA uses only microwave observations overcoming limitations IR sparseness rain gauges especially over oceans
 Global Coverage Provides precipitation estimates entire globe
 High Quality Uses advanced retrieval algorithms (HOAPS PNPR-CLIM) for accurate precipitation estimations
 Comprehensive Data Includes daily monthly precipitation rates standard deviation data quality flags platform sensor information observation counts

 Limitations

 Limited Temporal Resolution Relies on LEO satellite passes lower temporal resolution compared geostationary IR observations
 Spatial Resolution 1.0°x1.0° may too coarse for some applications

 Data Description

 Data Type Gridded
 Horizontal Coverage Global
 Resolution 1.0°x1.0°
 Vertical Coverage Surface
 Single level
 Temporal Coverage January 2000 to December 2017
 Monthly daily
 Gaps No gaps
 File Format: NetCDF4
 Conventions CF Metadata Convention v1.6, ACDD v1.3
 Versions 1.0
 Update Frequency No expected updates

 Main Variables

 Precipitation: mm day-1 Represents water-equivalent volume rate per area per day of atmospheric water in liquid or solid phase reaching Earth's surface

 Related Variables

 Standard deviation of precipitation rates
 Data quality flag
 Platform sensor information
 Number of observations per cell
 Number of hours within day/month covered by measurements

 Overall
COBRA dataset provides valuable resource for understanding global precipitation patterns has limitations in temporal resolution, microwave-based approach offers unique perspective on precipitation dynamics complements other precipitation datasets.

563
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-gridded-observations-alpine-precipitation
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-gridded-observations-alpine-precipitation
insitu-gridded-observations-alpine-precipitation
detailed description of LAPrec dataset breakdown of key information important aspects for understanding resource
 What is LAPrec?

 Purpose: provides monthly precipitation data for Alpine region eight countries dating back to 1871 designed for historical climate analysis particularly region impacted by climate change
 Accuracy: uses combination homogenized station data (HISTALP) and gridded daily data (APGD) ensure temporal consistency accurate representation of precipitation patterns in complex terrain
 Versions: choice between two versions (LAPrec1871 and LAPrec1901) flexibility depending on research needs (temporal range and spatial accuracy).

 Key Features:

 Spatial Coverage: Covers Alpine region spanning 43–49°N, 4–17.5°E (land area only).
 Resolution 5 km horizontal resolution
 Temporal Coverage Extends from 1871 to 2020.
 Data Format: NetCDF4 to CF-1.6 conventions

 Data Sources & Method

 HISTALP Provides long-term back to 19th century) homogenized monthly precipitation station data
 APGD Supplies daily precipitation gridded data from 1971-2008 over 8,500 rain gauges.
 Reconstruction Method: LAPrec uses Reduced Space Optimal Interpolation (RSOI), combines Principal Component Analysis (PCA) Optimal Interpolation (OI) to bridge gap between station and grid data

 Access & Updates

 Frequency Updated every two years end of February).
 Documentation: user guide Documentation tab for detailed information on data sources, methods access

 Main Variable

 Precipitation (kg m-2): Represents accumulated monthly precipitation calculated from daily measurements between 07:00 CET respective day and 07:00 CET following day

LAPrec dataset valuable resource for researchers interested in:

 Historical climate analysis in Alps.
 Understanding long-term precipitation trends.
 Assessing impact of climate change on Alpine region.
 Developing climate models and projections.

 If considering using LAPrec dataset important to consult user guide for detailed information on data limitations usage guidelines access procedures.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-humidity-profiles
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-humidity-profiles
satellite-humidity-profiles
detailed description of dataset containing tropospheric humidity profiles from GPS radio occultation (RO) measurements breakdown of key information:
 Dataset Overview

 Source: EUMETSAT Radio Occultation Meteorology Satellite Application Facility (ROM SAF)
 Data Type: Gridded, globally distributed zonal means
 Spatial Resolution: 5° latitude
 Vertical Resolution: 0.2 km
 Temporal Coverage: From 2006 to present
 Resolution: Monthly
 File Format: NetCDF 3
 Frequency: Quarterly updates

 Data Contents

 Key Variable: Specific humidity (g kg-1) representing monthly mean for 5-degree latitude bands altitudes below 12 km.
 Other Variables: Several variables related to data distribution uncertainty included information on possible variations due to processing algorithms assumptions

 Advantages of dataset:

 High Vertical Resolution: RO observations provide detailed vertical profiles of atmospheric humidity
 Cloud-Independent: RO measurements not affected by clouds consistent observations regardless of weather conditions
 Surface-Independent: technique not influenced by surface below (land or consistent global view

 Importance of Tropospheric Humidity

 Greenhouse Effect: Water vapor strong greenhouse gas contributing to Earth's climate
 Energy Transport crucial role in global energy transport vertically atmosphere horizontally between regions
 Cloud and Precipitation Formation Tropospheric humidity essential for cloud formation precipitation impacting rainfall patterns drought conditions
 Biosphere influences biosphere by controlling distribution of rainfall determining availability of water for ecosystems

 dataset provides valuable resource for climate research weather forecasting understanding role of humidity in Earth's climate system
 further information

 Consult product user guide and specification for detailed descriptions of data and variables
Contact EUMETSAT ROM SAF additional support inquiries.

565
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-gridded-observations-nordic
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-gridded-observations-nordic
insitu-gridded-observations-nordic
great overview of Nordic Gridded Climate Dataset (NGCD)! breakdown of information provided additional insights:
 Strengths of NGCD:

 High Resolution: 1km x 1km resolution valuable for regional climate analysis impacts studies.
 Long Time Series: Data from 1971 to present allows for study of climate trends and variability over significant period.
 Multi-Country Coverage: Encompassing Finland, Sweden, Norway provides comprehensive view of Nordic climate.
 Regular Updates: 6-monthly updates ensure data current.
 Open Access: available to public makes dataset valuable for researchers, policymakers anyone interested in Nordic climate.
 Standard Formats: Using NetCDF-4 and CF-1.6 conventions makes data easy to work with integrate into other analysis tools.
 Combined Interpolation Methods: Utilizing both deterministic and stochastic approaches leads to more robust accurate interpolation.

 Potential Areas for Exploration:

 Understanding the Data: user guide essential for understanding specific algorithms details of interpolation methods.
 Data Quality: NGCD based on observational data important to be aware of limitations in interpolation methods.
 Further Analysis: dataset can be used for wide range of research,
 Climate change projections and impacts
 Regional climate modeling
 Agricultural and hydrological modeling.
 Identifying climate extremes and impacts.



 Key Points to Remember:

 Data Coverage: dataset covers Fennoscandia, not entire Nordic region.
 Interpolation Methods: specific interpolation methods used not fully described in this text; user guide will provide information.
 Data Sources: source of input data important to know for understanding potential biases or limitations.

 Overall NGCD valuable well-documented dataset for climate research applications in Nordic region.Its high resolution long time series regular updates make valuable resource for researchers policymakers.
---

viewer-sis-fisheries-ocean-fronts
Okay, understand you're looking to create viewer application for dataset related to ocean fronts. provided detailed description of variables included in dataset. breakdown of how to approach building viewer application considerations for design and functionality:
 1. Understanding Data and Purpose

 Analyze Data: examine meaning of each variable units need solid grasp of each metric represents implications for oceanographic studies.
 Identify Key Relationships: Consider how different variables relate to each other. For example how "Distance to Nearest Major Front" impact "Frontal Gradient Magnitude"?
 Target Audience: Who using viewer? Researchers, students, policymakers or general public? shape level of complexity types of visualizations create.

 2. Choose Right Visualization Tools

 Mapping Libraries: dealing with geographic data need mapping libraries. popular options:
 Leaflet: Lightweight open-source JavaScript library for interactive maps.
 Mapbox: Offers advanced features like custom basemaps satellite imagery.
 Google Maps API: for detailed maps with additional services.
 D3.js: JavaScript library for creating customizable data visualizations, including maps.


 Data Visualization Libraries: Consider libraries excel at representing time-series data, statistical relationships comparisons:
 Plotly: Generates interactive graphs, charts dashboards.
 Chart.js: Good for basic well-designed charts.
 Highcharts: Powerful for building complex charts interactive visualizations.



 3. Design User Interface

 Map View: core of application likely be map where users explore ocean fronts.
 Controls: Provide ways to
 Select variables: Allow users to choose which variable to display on map (e.g. "Distance to Nearest Major Front," "Frontal Gradient Magnitude").
Choose time periods: Enable users view data for different months years time intervals.
 Zoom and pan: Allow users explore different regions ocean.
 Toggle layers: Display or hide specific layers on map (e.g coastlines ocean currents).


 Data Display: Consider options for presenting additional data alongside map:
 Data tables: Show numerical values of variables for selected locations.
 Time-series graphs: Plot variables change over time at specific locations.
 Histograms and box plots: Visualize distribution data for different variables.



 4. Implement Application

 Data Loading and Processing: Develop mechanism to load ocean front dataset process efficiently. need use libraries like D3 for data manipulation or libraries Pandas for working with data in Python.
 Map Integration: Integrate chosen mapping library into application translate data coordinates (likely latitude and longitude) into map coordinates.
 Visualizations: Implement chosen visualization tools to render data.
 User Interactions: Handle events zoom, pan data selection.
 User Interface Development: Choose suitable UI framework (e React, Angular, Vue) or build basic HTML/CSS UI.

 Example User Flow

 User visits viewer
 select variable (e "Distance to Nearest Major Front").
 choose time period (e January 2020).
 map displays visualization of variable for chosen period with color-coding represent different values.
 user zooms in on specific region
 click on point on map to view data values for location in table.

 Key Considerations

 Performance: Be mindful of data loaded processed especially working with large datasets Optimize code for efficiency.
 Accessibility: Design interface user-friendly accessible to individuals with disabilities.
 Data Sources: Ensure data is accurate, reliable properly documented.

Additional Tips

 Start Simple: Build basic prototype first add more features gradually.
 Use Open Source Tools: many open-source libraries tools available simplify development.
 Document Your Code: Write clear comments documentation to make code understandable maintainable.

 Let me know if more questions about specific aspects of building viewer application.

sis-european-risk-flood-indicators
detailed description dataset urban pluvial flood risk in Europe breakdown key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose assess pluvial flood risk heavy rainfall in 20 European cities vulnerable
 Scope Covers Europe 20 vulnerable cities
 Resolution: High resolution
 EU-DEM: 25m x 25m
 Lidar-derived: 1m x 1m & 2m x 2m (depending city)


 Time Period: 1989-2018 (30 years)
 Data Source: Copernicus Climate Change Service data from
 Climate Data Store (ERA5
 Copernicus Land Monitoring Service (CLMS)


 Format: NetCDF-4

 Key Variables

 Expected Damage (€/m2): Direct damage assets from pluvial flooding different return periods (5, 10 25 50 100 years).
 Urban Depression (dimensionless): Areas without outlet prone to water accumulation
 Water Depth (m): Depth pluvial flood water different return periods
 Water Mask (dimensionless): Indicates flooded areas (0 affected 1 =

 Methodology

 Precipitation Data ERA5 reanalysis data dynamically downscaled to 2km x 2km COSMO-CLM regional climate model urban parameters for city-scale analysis
 Hazard Modeling: Hourly precipitation data used with digital elevation models (DEMs) from CLMS simulate pluvial flood hazards
 Damage Modeling models estimate economic impact of flooding

 Significance
 dataset provides valuable information for city stakeholders policymakers

 Risk Assessment Understand spatial distribution pluvial flood risk cities
 Planning and Mitigation Identify high-risk areas inform urban planning strategies reduce flood impacts
 Disaster Response Develop preparedness plans emergency response protocols
Climate Change Adaptation: Evaluate potential impacts future climate change on flood risk adapt accordingly.

 high-resolution dataset offers powerful tool for understanding managing risks urban pluvial flooding in Europe.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cems-glofas-forecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cems-glofas-forecast
cems-glofas-forecast
detailed description of GloFAS (Global Flood Awareness System) river discharge dataset breakdown of key information:


 Modelled Time Series dataset provides predictions of river discharge not direct measurements
 Global Coverage: covers entire globe excluding Antarctica
 Consistent Representation: data consistent across globe useful for comparisons analysis
 Hydrological Variable: River discharge crucial indicator of water availability potential flood risks

 Data Details:

 Gridded: data organized in grid format each point representing specific location
 Projection uses regular latitude-longitude grid for easy understanding integration with other geospatial data
 Resolution: current version (v4.0) has high resolution of 0.05° x 0.05° more detail than older versions
 Temporal Coverage: dataset covers from November 5, 2019 to near real-time for operational updates includes historical data
 Frequency: New data generated updated daily
 File Format: data stored in GRIB2 format standard for meteorological hydrological data

 Data Sources & Generation:

 LISFLOOD Model: dataset produced using open-source LISFLOOD hydrological model
 ECMWF Forecasts: model driven by weather forecasts from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).

 Related Datasets:

 Elevation Data: Provides mean elevation above sea level for each grid point
 Upstream Area Data: Indicates catchment area for each river segment showing total area contributing to river flow location

 Key Variables:

 River Discharge: main variable measured in cubic meters per second (m3/s), representing volume of water flowing through river cross-section

 Applications

 Flood Forecasting & Warning: data helps in predicting mitigating flood risks
Water Resource Management: provides crucial information for managing water resources effectively.
 Climate Research: data used analyze impact climate change on river flow patterns.

 Important Notes:

 Operational & Legacy Versions: current version (v4.0) is operational updated regularly Older versions available for historical analysis.
 European Data: For specific European hydrological data European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) provides detailed information.
 Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS): GloFAS and EFAS datasets contribute to operational flood forecasting within CEMS managed by European Commission's Joint Research Centre.

 GloFAS river discharge dataset valuable resource for applications water management flood forecasting climate research.

569
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-greenland-ice-sheet-velocity
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-greenland-ice-sheet-velocity
satellite-greenland-ice-sheet-velocity
comprehensive description of Greenland Ice Sheet velocity dataset. breakdown of key information useful:
 Dataset Contains

 Annual Ice Velocity Maps: maps show fast ice sheet moving in various directions at different locations.
 Derived from Sentinel-1 Data: data acquired using radar satellites (Sentinel-1) important because radar can penetrate clouds see through snow ideal for monitoring ice movement.
 High-Resolution: data available at resolutions of 250 meters and 500 meters detailed information about ice flow.
 Covers Entire Ice Sheet: dataset includes velocity of entire Greenland Ice Sheet.
 Multiple Components: captures horizontal velocity (easting and northing), vertical velocity (how fast ice rising or falling).

 Data Important

 Understanding Climate Change Impacts: By tracking fast glaciers moving scientists can understand quickly Greenland Ice Sheet melting contributing to sea level rise.
 Predicting Future Changes: data helps to model ice sheet change in future scientists to predict sea levels rise and impacts on coastal communities.
 Monitoring Glacier Stability: Changes in ice velocity can indicate shifts in stability potentially leading to ice calving (breaking off) or accelerated melt.

 Data Details

 Projection: Polar-stereographic, WGS84 (a standard geographic coordinate system).
 File Format: NetCDF (a common format for scientific data).
 Versions: dataset updated annually new versions released with improved accuracy and spatial resolution.
 Temporal Coverage: dataset spans from October 1st, 2017 to September 30th, 2021.

 Main Variables

 Vx, Vy, Vz: represent easting (x), northing (y), and vertical (z) components of ice velocity.
Velocity Magnitude: absolute speed of ice flow, calculated from horizontal components.

 Related Variables

 Measurement Count: indicates how many data points used to calculate velocity at each location.
 Standard Deviation: measures uncertainty in velocity estimate.

 Key Points to Note

 Annual Averaging: data represents average velocity for entire year providing snapshot of overall trends.
 Dynamic Ice-Ocean Mask: Newer versions of dataset (v1.4 and later) include more accurate representation of boundary between ice sheet and ocean.

 Conclusion
 dataset is valuable resource for scientists, researchers policymakers in understanding addressing impacts of climate change particularly effects of glacial melt on sea level rise. providing detailed information on ice velocity helps to paint clearer picture of dynamic nature of Greenland Ice Sheet role in changing world.
---

High-Resolution Ocean Colour (HR-OC) Consortium Data

 Variables

 Chlorophyll-a concentration (CHL): in μg/l

 Product Types

 Monthly L4 products (P1M): Aggregated data from daily L3 products entire month potential gaps in cloudy areas
 Daily gap-filled L4 products (P1D): Uses DINEOF) reconstruct missing data in cloudy areas

 Data Delivery

 Geographic lat-lon grid (EPSG:4326)
 Tiles of 600x800 km2

 Processing Chain

 Coastal mask applied retaining 20km coastal area
 Level 2 processing Atmospheric correction in-water processing merging produce 60m product with data for optics transparency geophysics
 Daily L3 aggregation Merges water pixels from Level 2 mosaics within target tile
 Monthly L4 Combines all Level 3 products month for target tile
 Gap filling (P1D): Uses DINEOF reconstruct missing data daily products

 Comprehensive data Includes optics transparency geophysics variables

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/iberia-biscay-ireland-significant-wave-height-extreme-0
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=IBI_OMI_SEASTATE_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly
Iberia Biscay Ireland Significant Wave Height extreme from Reanalysis
CMEMS IBI_OMI_seastate_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly Indicator
 document describes CMEMS IBI_OMI_seastate_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly OMI indicator monitors extreme values of annual significant wave height (SWH) in Iberia-Biscay-Ireland (IBI) region indicator aims spatial temporal variability of extreme wave events
 Key points

 Data Sources indicator utilizes data from two CMEMS products:_MULTIYEAR_WAV_005_006 mean 99th percentile) and_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_WAV_005_005 (for 2020 anomaly).
 Parameters indicator considers two parameters
 Map of 99th mean percentile represents average annual 99th percentile of SWH from 1993 to 2019 highlighting areas with high wave height extremes.
 Anomaly of 99th percentile in 2020 shows deviation of 2020 99th percentile from long-term mean (1993-2019), indicating increases or decreases in extreme wave events


 Methodology Using percentiles instead of annual maxima makes analysis less sensitive to individual data points more robust representation of extreme wave events
 Importance Extreme wave events impact maritime activities coastal ecosystems human infrastructure indicator helps understand spatial temporal variability improved coastal management risk assessment

 Key findings

 Climatic Mean (1993-2020): clear north-south gradient in 99th percentile of SWH observed highest values (above 8m) in northern latitudes lower values (2-3m) southeast of Canary Islands.
 2020 Anomaly: Negative anomalies widespread across eastern North Atlantic from Canary Islands to Ireland surpassing climatic standard deviation.suggests decrease in extreme wave events in 2020 compared to long-term average.

 Driving forces:

 North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO): atmospheric pressure pattern influences wave climate variability region impacting frequency intensity of storms wave height.
 Other Atmospheric Climate Modes: Studies identified relationships between sea state variability other climate modes East Atlantic pattern, Arctic Oscillation East Atlantic Western Russian pattern.

 Implications:

 indicator highlights importance of long-term analysis to identify trends in extreme wave events understand drivers.
 information crucial for developing effective strategies for coastal adaptation risk mitigation in changing climate conditions.

 Further details scientific evaluation in CMEMS Ocean State report (Álvarez-Fanjul et al., 2019).
 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00249

satellite-sea-surface-temperature-ensemble-product
fantastic summary of GHRSST GMPE dataset clear informative well-organized key takeaways:
 dataset provides

 Global Daily Sea Surface Temperature (SST): daily snapshot of SST across globe multi-product ensemble approach
 Comparison of SST Analyses: dataset allows users compare outputs of different SST analysis systems
 Climate Version: designed for climate studies focusing on long-term trends

 Key Features:

 Multiple Input Products: Data from 7 SST providers including ESA SST CCI, CMEMS NCEI CMC HadISST JMA.
 Spatial Completeness: Uses infilling techniques ensure global coverage
 Common Grid: data on consistent 0.25°x0.25° grid for easy comparison
 Temporal Coverage: From September 1981 to December 2016.

 Variables in dataset:

 Analysed SST: median of all 16 input SST analyses
 Gradient fields: horizontal SST gradient for each input analysis final ensemble product.
 SST anomaly: difference between each input SST analysis median
 SST standard deviation: standard deviation of SST across all input analyses

 Strengths of dataset:

 Multi-product approach robust representation of SST incorporating multiple sources
 Comparison capabilities understand similarities differences between SST analysis systems
 Climate focus: Suitable for long-term climate studies trend analysis
 Comprehensive metadata: dataset uses CF and ACDD conventions standardized descriptive information

 Possible uses:

 Climate research: Analyzing long-term SST changes identifying trends studying climate impacts
 Oceanographic studies: Understanding ocean circulation, variability heat transport.
 Validation of other datasets: Comparing against other SST datasets to assess accuracy consistency
Education training: Providing valuable resource for learning about SST data analysis techniques.

 valuable dataset for anyone working with sea surface temperature data particularly interested in climate studies multi-product analysis.
