https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/iberia-biscay-ireland-strong-wave-incidence-index
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=IBI_OMI_SEASTATE_swi
Iberia Biscay Ireland Strong Wave Incidence index from Reanalysis
Strong Wave Incidence Index: Summary of Key Information
 document provides detailed description Strong Wave Incidence (SWI) index metric variability of strong wave conditions in Iberia-Biscay-Ireland (IBI) regional seas breakdown key information
 What is SWI index?

 Purpose Quantifies variability of strong wave conditions in IBI region
 Calculation index is difference between observed frequency and climatic frequency exceeding specific threshold of Significant Wave Height (SWH).
 Threshold: 90th percentile of SWH determined through sensitivity testing
 Interpretation
 Positive values indicate higher average occurrence strong wave events
 Negative values indicate lower average occurrence strong wave events



 Data Sources:

 IBI-WAV-MYP: IBI_REANALYSIS_WAV_005_006 (reanalysis product)
 IBI-WAV-NRT: IBI_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_WAV_005_005 (near-real-time product)

 Context Importance

 Ocean wave impact Strong wave events impacts on coastal ecosystems infrastructure human activities
 Regional focus IBI region vulnerable due to location in North Atlantic major wave generation zone
 Climate connection SWI index influenced by large-scale climate oscillations North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) other atmospheric patterns

 Monitoring Regions:

 WAV1: West coast of Iberian Peninsula
 WAV2: Bay of Biscay
 WAV3: Northern half of IBI domain
 WAV4: North-East African coast, Gulf of Cadiz, Canary Islands

 Key Findings

 No significant trends SWI analysis from 1992-2020 show significant trends in strong wave conditions
Notable events document highlights significant wave events across monitoring regions particularly February 2014 April 2020.
 Event propagation: strong wave events observed propagate across multiple monitoring regions.

 Further Information:

 Full scientific evaluation Available in CMEMS Ocean State report (Pascual et al., 2020)
 DOI (product): https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00251

 SWI index provides valuable tool for understanding variability strong wave conditions in IBI region implications for coastal management climate research planning human activities.

578
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-ozone
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-ozone
satellite-ozone
detailed description of ozone dataset breakdown of key information interpreted
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides monthly mean estimates of ozone concentration mixing ratio mole content globally using data from satellite sensors
 Focus: Climate monitoring track ozone trends variability for climate change research
 Data Source: ESA (European Space Agency) Ozone Climate Change Initiative Project
 Data Processing Levels:
 Level-3: Regular latitude/longitude grid potential gaps in space time
 Level-4: Further processed to fill gaps Level-3 data


 Data Types:
 CDR (Climate Data Record): Long-term consistent continuous data for detecting climate change
 ICDR (Interim Climate Data Record): Short-term early access data consistent with CDR baseline


 Additional Aggregations
 Zonal Averages: Ozone data averaged across specific latitude bands mid
 Merged Products: Data from multiple sensors combined into single dataset



 Data Description

 Gridded Data: dataset organized as grid over globe
 Horizontal Coverage: Global
 Horizontal Resolution: 1°x1° grid (except for zonal averages use 10°x10° grid).
 Vertical Resolution: Varies depending on product
 Total Column: Ozone amount measured through entire atmospheric column
 Tropospheric Column: Ozone amount measured only within troposphere
 Profiles: Ozone concentration at different altitude levels


 Temporal Coverage: from 1995 to present may shorter for specific sensors
 Temporal Resolution: Monthly averages
 File Format: NetCDF-4 (compliant with GHRSST 2.0 data specifications).
 Update Frequency: Typically annually delay of four months

 Key Variables:

Ozone Concentration (mol m-3): number ozone molecules per unit volume air.
 Ozone Concentration Anomaly (%): percentage deviation of monthly ozone concentration from average concentration month.
 Ozone Mixing Ratio (ppmv): fraction of ozone molecules in air (parts per million by volume).
 Ozone Mole Content (mol m-2): total number ozone molecules in vertical column air (Dobson units sometimes used).

 Auxiliary Variables:

 Air Temperature Air Pressure: included for some products additional atmospheric information.

 How to Use Dataset:

 Understand Data Products: read documentation to determine products relevant to research variables available within each product
 Choose Temporal and Spatial Scales: Determine time period geographic area of interest for analysis
 Consider Data Processing Levels: Decide fully processed Level-4 data or Level-3 data with potential gaps
 Account for Data Uncertainty: aware of inherent uncertainties in satellite measurements data processing consider potential biases.

 Example Applications:

 Climate Change Studies: Analyze long-term trends in ozone concentration assess impact climate change on atmospheric ozone.
 Air Quality Monitoring: Track regional variations in ozone levels identify areas with high ozone pollution
 Atmospheric Chemistry: Investigate chemical processes influence ozone production and depletion.

 dataset provides valuable resource for researchers studying atmospheric ozone role in climate, air quality atmospheric chemistry.
---

Black Sea, Bio-Geo-Chemical, L4, monthly means and interpolated daily observation
High-Resolution Ocean Colour (HR-OC) Consortium L4 Products Summary
 HR-OC Consortium (Brockmann Consult, Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences Flemish Institute for Technological Research) provides high-resolution (100m) Level 4 (L4) ocean colour products from Sentinel 2/MSI data products cover 20km coastal zone distributed in 600x800 km2 tiles
 Products

 Optics
 Particulate Backscattering at 443nm (BBP443 m-1) derived from L3 RRS products quasi-analytical algorithm


 Transparency
 Turbidity (TUR, FNU) retrieved automated switching algorithms RRS spectra
 Solid Particulate Matter Concentration (SPM, mg/l) retrieved automated switching algorithms RRS spectra


 Geophysics
 Chlorophyll-a Concentration (CHL, μg/l) retrieved multi-algorithm approach optimized quality flagging



 Product Frequencies

 Monthly (P1M): Temporal aggregates of daily L3 products complete view Available 4 days after last acquisition date month
 Daily (P1D): Gap filled DINEOF approach reconstructing missing data high resolution capabilities Available one month after period

 Data Availability

 Daily products contain gaps in cloudy areas no overpass
 Monthly products aggregate non-cloudy contributions data gaps
 DINEOF gap-filled products reconstruct missing data more complete daily products

 Processing Chain

 Resampling Sentinel-2 MSI L1C data to 60m mosaicking within single UTM zone
 coastal mask to extract data within 20km coastal zone
 Level 2 processing with atmospheric correction in-water processing merging
Identifying invalid pixels due to factors including clouds glint bottom reflection
 Daily L3 aggregation merging Level 2 mosaics with target tile
 Monthly L4 aggregation combining Level 3 products month tile
 Gap filling using DINEOF generate gap-filled daily products

 Key Features

 High spatial resolution (100m) for detailed coastal analysis
 Comprehensive ocean colour parameters
 Monthly daily products for varying temporal needs
 Data gap filling using DINEOF for improved data coverage

 Intended Use

 Educational purposes
 Marine safety management
 Marine resource management
 Marine coastal environment management
 Climate seasonal studies.

 Datasets:

 cmems_obs_oc_blk_bgc_geophy_nrt_l4-hr_P1M-v01 (Monthly Geophysics)
_l4-hr_P1M-v01 Transparency
_blk_bgc_optics_nrt_l4-hr_P1M-v01 (Monthly Optics
_geophy_nrt_l4-hr_P1D-v01 (Daily Geophysics
_bgc_transp_nrt_l4-hr_P1D-v01 (Daily Transparency
_bgc_optics_nrt_l4-hr_P1D-v01 (Daily Optics

 Format:

 NetCDF-4, CF-1.7
 INSPIRE compliant

 DOI:

 https://doi.org/10.48670/moi-00087

 summary provides concise overview of HR-OC Consortium L4 products further information refer to CMEMS website related documentation
---
580
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/derived-utci-historical
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/derived-utci-historical
derived-utci-historical
detailed informative description of ERA5-HEAT dataset breakdown of key information insights:
 What is ERA5-HEAT?

 Purpose: ERA5-HEAT provides historical reconstruction of human thermal stress discomfort in outdoor conditions tells us how humans experienced weather throughout time
 Significance: dataset crucial for understanding climate change impacts on human health well-being particularly relation to heat stress discomfort
 Source: based on ERA5 reanalysis reliable dataset from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).

 Key Features:

 Variables:
 Mean Radiant Temperature (MRT): measure of overall heat radiated from environment sun, sky surrounding surfaces.
 Universal Thermal Climate Index (UTCI): comprehensive index combines air temperature wind speed humidity radiation to estimate humans experience thermal environment.


 Spatial Coverage: Global except for Antarctica.
 Temporal Coverage: From January 1940 to near real time (constantly updated).
 Resolution:
 Spatial: 0.25° x 0.25° each grid cell represents area of about 28 km x 28 km
 Temporal: Hourly data.


 Format: NetCDF (a standard format for climate data).

 Important Considerations

 Data Updates: dataset regularly updated daily update for near-real-time information monthly updates for consolidated data.
 New Version: new version of ERA5-HEAT expected in early 2023 use new thermofeel library available in GRIB format.

 Potential Applications:

 Climate Change Studies: Analyzing long-term trends in thermal stress understand impact of climate change on human health outdoor activities
 Urban Planning: Designing cities infrastructure resilient to heat waves extreme weather events
 Public Health: Developing strategies to protect vulnerable populations from heat-related illness.
Agriculture: Assessing impact of changing thermal conditions on crop yields livestock.

 Overall ERA5-HEAT valuable resource for researchers policymakers anyone interested understanding relationship between climate weather human well-being.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-lake-water-temperature
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-lake-water-temperature
satellite-lake-water-temperature
detailed description of dataset containing lake surface water temperature (LSWT) data retrieved from satellite sensors breakdown of key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: provide comprehensive record of LSWT for research applications climate change hydrology lake ecology
 Source: Derived from multiple satellite sensors ATSR AVHRR MODIS SLSTR
 Coverage
 Spatial: 2000 lakes globally
 Temporal: June 1995 to September 2022 (with gaps).


 Resolution
 Horizontal: 0.05° x 0.05°
 Vertical: Single surface layer (lake surface).
 Temporal: Daily


 Format: NetCDF-4
 Metadata Standards: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6 Attribute Convention for Dataset Discovery (ACDD) v1.3

 Data Characteristics

 Gridded: Data organized on regular latitude-longitude grid
 Bias Adjusted: Temperatures from different sensors adjusted for consistency
 Gaps dataset contains observations may missing data in time space
 Quality Control: Includes quality levels uncertainty estimates assess data reliability

 Key Variables

 Lake surface water temperature primary variable daily gridded temperature at surface each lake
 Bias correction flag Indicates reference sensor adjustment applied
 Lake id: Unique identifier for each lake (based Global Lakes and Wetlands Database).
 Observation instruments Indicates satellite sensor(s) used for measurement
 Quality levels: Categorical values representing confidence in data
 Total uncertainty: Quantitative estimate of error associated with LSWT measurement

 Applications
 dataset used for various research applications including

 Climate change studies Assessing long-term trends in lake temperatures relationship to climate change
Hydrological modeling: Understanding role of lakes in hydrological cycle influence on water balance.
 Lake ecology research: Analyzing impact of water temperature on lake ecosystems distribution of aquatic organisms
 Water resource management: Monitoring lake temperatures for water quality assessment management.

 Access and Documentation
 dataset produced by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) likely available for download through website or data portals Product User Guide detailed information on data access formats usage guidelines.

app-climate-mediterranean-sea-level
detailed description of application assesses impact sea level rise on UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Mediterranean breakdown information provided
 Purpose:

 understand quantify risks of coastal flooding to cultural heritage sites Mediterranean due to rising sea levels extreme weather events

 Methodology:


 Data Sources:

 Sea Level Change Time Series: Data from satellites measuring changes sea level over time.
 ERA5 Reanalysis: dataset global atmospheric oceanic reanalysis includes information on tides surges factors contributing to extreme sea levels.
 CMIP6 Models: Climate models project future sea level rise scenarios.



 Analysis:

 1 in 100-year Extreme Event: Calculates projected sea level height for rare potentially devastating storm surge event once every 100 years).
 Flood Risk Index: measure of risk coastal flooding based on projected sea level rise location heritage site
 Interactive Map: Visual representation flood risk index for each heritage site.



 Inputs:

 Mean Sea Level: average increase sea level over specific period
 Sea Level Anomaly: Deviations from average sea level short-term changes.
 Total Water Level Return Period: Includes combined effects of tides surges sea level rise

 Outputs:

 Flood Risk Index: numerical representation likelihood flooding for each heritage site
 Observed Sea Level Change from Satellites: Historical sea level trends measured by satellites.
 Sea Level (1 in 100-year Extreme Event): predicted sea level during severe storm surge event future

 Key Features:

 Focus on UNESCO World Heritage Sites application targets sites recognized for cultural significance.
 High-Resolution Data: Uses detailed data modeling accurate risk assessments at local level
Interactive Tool: easy-to-use interface allows heritage managers policymakers understand risks plan accordingly.

 Benefits:

 Improved Understanding of Risks: Provides valuable information inform adaptation strategies for cultural heritage sites.
 Informed Decision-Making: Enables heritage managers prioritize conservation efforts implement mitigation measures.
 Increased Awareness: Highlights importance of addressing climate change protect cultural heritage.

 application offers powerful tool for managing risks by sea level rise to cultural heritage in Mediterranean region provides data analysis to guide decision-making ensure long-term preservation of valuable sites protect shared cultural legacy.

 Related Variables

 leverages various data sources: satellite imagery in-situ measurements model data

 On-demand mapping maps of disaster impacts upon request

586
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-soil-moisture
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-soil-moisture
satellite-soil-moisture
great summary of Global Land Surface Soil Moisture dataset breakdown of information provided organized for clarity additional context:
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: dataset provides estimates of surface soil moisture across globe from satellite sensors designed support climate research monitoring
 Methodology: dataset uses sophisticated methodology European Space Agency's (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (CCI) for soil moisture current best practice for satellite-based soil moisture data
 Alignment with Standards: adheres to Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) requirements for satellite-based climate data records

 Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded data
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Spatial Coverage: Global
 Spatial Resolution: 0.25° x 0.25° each grid cell represents area approximately 27.8 km by 27.8 km)
 Temporal Coverage: 1978 to present
 Temporal Resolution: Daily, 10-day Monthly
 File Format: NetCDF
 Metadata Follows Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.8 standardized data organization description)

 Data Products

 "Active" Product Derived from scatterometer data measures backscatter of radar signals from Earth surface
 "Passive" Product from radiometer data measures brightness temperature Earth's surface in different microwave frequencies
 "Combined" Product: blend of "Active" and "Passive" products combining strengths both techniques

 Climate Data Records (CDR) and Interim-CDR (ICDR)

 CDR (Climate Data Record): long-term consistent dataset detect climate variability change rigorously checked and validated.
ICDR (Interim Climate Data Record): Provides near real-time snapshot data shorter delay expected consistent with CDR baseline hasn't undergone extensive checks.

 Versions

 v201706: First release dataset equivalent to CCI version 3.
 v201812: Includes algorithm updates sensor updates (SMOS included), equivalent to CCI version 4.
 v201912: Deprecated temporal extension of v201812 equivalent to CCI version 3.
 v201912.1: Correction to v201912.
 v202012: Further algorithm sensor updates (SMAP included), equivalent to CCI version 5.
 v202212: Latest version with algorithm sensor updates (including ASCAT-C, FengYun 3B/C/D GPM), equivalent to CCI version 7.

 Update Frequency

 ICDR: Updated every 10 days 10-day latency 10-day delay between data acquisition release).
 CDR Updated annually.

 Key Variables

 Surface Soil Moisture: percentage of total saturation reflecting content liquid water in top 2-5 cm soil.
 Volumetric Soil Moisture: Expressed as m3 of water per m3 of soil volumetric measurement of soil moisture in top 2-5 cm.

 Benefits Applications
 dataset provides valuable resource for

 Climate research monitoring Understanding role soil moisture in global climate system drought monitoring water resource management climate modeling
 Agricultural applications: Assessing crop water stress optimizing irrigation practices improving crop yield predictions
 Hydrological modeling Improving accuracy flood prediction models understanding movement water landscape managing water resources
 Ecosystem monitoring: impact of soil moisture on vegetation health carbon cycling.

 Access Data
 Global Land Surface Soil Moisture dataset available through:

Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S): primary provider distributor of dataset.
 EarthData Search: NASA portal provides access to wide range Earth science data, including this dataset.

 Important Considerations

 Gaps in Space and Time: dataset aims global coverage, may be gaps in space time due to limitations in satellite coverage data processing
 Accuracy: Like all remote sensing data inherent uncertainties in soil moisture estimates. Researchers consider these uncertainties when using dataset.

 Let me know if more questions about dataset or need assistance finding specific data products!

comprehensive description of ERA5 and ERA5.1 datasets clear concise summary of key characteristics including
 Data Type:
 Gridded
 Projection
 Reduced Gaussian grid for atmosphere and land variables (N320 for ERA5, N160 for ensemble
 Reduced latitude/longitude grid for ocean wave variables (0.36 degrees for ERA5 1.0 degree for ensemble)
 Horizontal Coverage:
 Global
 Horizontal Resolution:
 ERA5: 31km x 31km for atmosphere/land 0.5 x 0.5 degrees for wave variables
 Ensemble: 63km x 63km for atmosphere/land 1.0 x 1.0 degrees for wave variables
 Vertical Coverage:
 Single level for surface variables
 From surface to 80km for model levels
 1000 hPa to 1 hPa for pressure levels
 Vertical Resolution:
 137 model levels
 37 pressure levels
 16 potential temperature levels
 1 potential vorticity level
 Temporal Coverage
 ERA5: January 1940 to present
 ERA5.1: January 2000 to December 2006
 Temporal Resolution
 ERA5: Hourly
 Ensemble: 3-hourly
 File Format
 Part GRIB-1, part GRIB2
 Update Frequency
 ERA5: Daily
 ERA5.1: None
 Key Points

 ERA5.1 specifically for 2000-2006 due to stratospheric/tropospheric temperature discrepancies ERA5
 ensemble component provides uncertainty information
 data used in fields climate science weather forecasting energy production machine learning

588
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cems-glofas-seasonal
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cems-glofas-seasonal
cems-glofas-seasonal
detailed description of GloFAS dataset! breakdown of key information:
 What is GloFAS?

 Purpose: GloFAS is Global Flood Awareness System provide global flood forecasts
 Data: produces gridded time series of river discharge predicts water flowing in rivers at different locations and times.
 Model: GloFAS uses LISFLOOD hydrological model driven by weather forecasts from ECMWF
 Resolution: data available at 0.05° (version 4.0) and 0.1° (older versions) resolution translates to approximately 5 km and 11 km at equator
 Frequency: Forecasts updated monthly with 24-hour timestep cover 123 days.

 Data Characteristics:

 Type: Gridded data organized in grid with values assigned to each grid cell
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid compatible with many Geographic Information Systems (GIS) software
 Coverage: Global excluding Antarctica covering area between 90° North and 60° South latitude
 Vertical Resolution: Surface level only represents river discharge at surface not different depths within river
 Temporal Coverage: Data available from December 1st, 2020 to near-real-time for operational forecasts Historical data available for legacy versions
 File Format: GRIB2, used format for meteorological and climate data

 Key Variables:

 River Discharge (m3 s-1): main variable representing volume of water flowing through river cross-section per second.

 Related Variables:

 Elevation (m): Mean elevation above sea level for each grid cell context for river locations.
 Upstream Area (m2): Total catchment area for each river segment area contributes water to river

 Additional Information:

Versions: GloFAS dataset continually updated current version 4.0.
 Documentation: full dataset description documentation likely available on Climate Data Store (CDS) website.
 EFAS: Users interested in European hydrological data refer to European Flood Awareness System (EFAS), regional extension of GloFAS.
 Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS): GloFAS data part of CEMS uses Earth observation modeling to support disaster management.

 Potential Uses:

 Flood Forecasting: GloFAS provides valuable information for flood risk assessment early warning systems.
 Water Resource Management: Understanding river discharge helps manage water resources plan irrigation assess drought conditions.
 Hydrological Research: dataset used to study hydrological processes climate change impacts relationship between weather and river flow.

 Remember:

 data is model output approximation of reality
 refer to dataset's documentation for specific details on accuracy, limitations how to use it effectively.

 Forest monitoring
 Desertification analysis
 Scientific research

 Projection: Plate Carrée
 Coverage: Global

 Vertical Coverage: Surface
 Resolution Single level
 Temporal Coverage: 1992 to present one-year delay).
 Resolution Yearly

 Observation Count: Number of valid satellite observations for each pixel
 Processed Flag: Indicates pixel classified (0 = not processed 1 = processed).

cems-glofas-reforecast
detailed description of GloFAS (Global Flood Awareness System) river discharge dataset breakdown of key information


 gridded time series of modeled river discharge dataset provides estimated river flow rates across globe calculated using hydrological model
 Forced by meteorological reforecasts model uses weather forecasts from ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-range Weather Forecasts) to predict river discharge
 Global coverage covers entire globe except Antarctica
 High resolution: Version 4.0 has resolution 0.05° x 0.05° older versions resolution 0.1° x 0.1°.

 used

 Flood forecasting: GloFAS key component of Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS) for predicting monitoring floods
 Hydrological research provides valuable data for studying water flow patterns analyzing flood risk understanding impacts of climate change on river systems

 Data characteristics

 Data type: Gridded (values assigned to regular grid of points).
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Temporal coverage Covers years 2003 to 2022 updates from March 2023 to near real-time
 Temporal resolution Initialised twice weekly 24-hour time steps 46-day lead time
 File format: GRIB2 standard for meteorological data).

 Key variables

 River discharge in last 24 hours (m3/s): volume of water flow per second through river cross-section
 Elevation (m): Mean height above sea level for each grid point
 Upstream area (m2): total area contributes water to river segment at given grid point

 Important points to consider

 Reforecasts dataset uses historical forecasts researchers assess skill operational forecasts
 Operational version version GloFAS provides real-time forecasts
Companion datasets: Other datasets available for historical simulations seasonal forecasts European-specific hydrological data.

 GloFAS river discharge dataset valuable resource for understanding predicting river flow patterns applications from flood forecasting to hydrological research.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-tourism-fire-danger-indicators-projections
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-tourism-fire-danger-indicators-projections
app-tourism-fire-danger-indicators-projections
detailed description application analyzes fire danger in Europe using Canadian Fire Weather Index (FWI) system
 Key Features

 FWI Model application utilizes Canadian Fire Weather Index (FWI) system recognized standard in fire danger assessment
 EFFIS Classification incorporates European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) classification of fire risk user-friendly interpretation of FWI values
 Climate Data leverages ERA5 reanalysis data for current climate (1981-2005) future projections from various climate models for different time horizons
 Uncertainty Estimation: application presents multi-model statistics account for inherent uncertainty in climate projections
 Bias Adjustment: Future projections bias-adjusted against ERA5 reanalysis data improve accuracy
 Time Horizons offers FWI data for current climate near future (2021-2040) mid-century (2041-2060) end of century (2079-2098).
 Interactive Map application features interactive map displaying FWI indicators averaged over NUTS level 3 (NUTS3) regions Europe
 Side-Panel Bar Charts Clicking NUTS3 region reveals side-panel bar chart comparing fire danger indicators model statistics climate change scenarios time horizons

 Main Variables
 application analyzes important variables related fire danger

 Daily Fire Weather Index (FWI): dimensionless value representing daily fire danger Higher values indicate greater potential for fires to ignite spread
 Number of Days with High, Moderate Very High Fire Danger values reflect number of days per year when FWI exceeds specific thresholds (30, 15, 45) different levels of danger defined by EFFIS
 Seasonal Fire Weather Index represents average FWI over European fire season (June-September).

 Application's Purpose:
application provides insights into fire danger trends in Europe currently and future under climate change scenarios presenting data visually allowing users explore parameters empowers decision-makers researchers public to

 Understand current fire risk Assess current fire danger across Europe
 Plan for future fire events Prepare for potential changes in fire risk due to climate change
 Develop mitigation strategies Develop effective fire management strategies based on projected fire danger
 Promote awareness Raise awareness about fire risk implications.

 Strengths:

 Comprehensive data analysis Utilizes robust FWI model multiple climate projections
 Interactive interface Provides user-friendly access to data allows for easy comparisons
 Focus on uncertainty Acknowledges uncertainty in climate projections provides multi-model statistics
 Relevance to fire management: Offers valuable data for planning mitigating fire risks.

 application valuable tool for fire management climate change adaptation in Europe provides comprehensive overview of fire danger trends helps inform strategies for mitigating fire risks in changing climate.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-water-level-change-timeseries
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-water-level-change-timeseries
sis-water-level-change-timeseries
detailed description of valuable dataset on water level time series for Europe. breakdown of key information:
 Dataset Provides

 Understanding of Coastal Dynamics: dataset offers insights into tides, surges sea level rise affect European coastlines critical for understanding potential future impacts of climate change.
 Data for Coastal Applications: dataset used for various coastal-related studies applications:
 Coastal Flooding: Assessing risk planning mitigation measures.
 Coastal Erosion: Understanding erosion patterns developing protection strategies.
 Harbours and Ports: Designing infrastructure resilient to rising sea levels and storms.



 Dataset is Created

 GTSM Model: core dataset generated using Deltares Global Tide and Surge Model (GTSM), model simulates coastal hydrodynamics.
 Regional Climate Forcing: GTSM fed with data from HIRHAM5 model provides regional climate information downscaled from global EC-EARTH model.
 Sea Level Rise Initial Conditions: model incorporates projected sea level rise based on different climate scenarios.
 Climate Scenarios: dataset includes simulations for:
 Historical: Representing current conditions.
 RCP4.5: optimistic scenario emissions start declining.
 RCP8.5: pessimistic scenario where emissions continue to rise (business-as-usual).


 ERA5 Reanalysis: historical dataset based on ERA5 reanalysis provides additional data for specific event analysis.

 Important Considerations

 Uncertainty: Users aware dataset's projections based on single combination of regional and global climate models dataset underestimates uncertainty associated with future predictions.
 Data Description: information about data types, coverage, resolution variables comprehensive important to understand these aspects when using dataset.

 Overall
dataset is valuable resource for researchers, policymakers coastal managers need to understand plan for effects of climate change on European coastlines It provides consistent high-resolution comprehensive view of water level dynamics, but essential to acknowledge limitations and uncertainties associated with climate model projections.

https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-ghg-reanalysis-egg4-monthly
cams-global-ghg-reanalysis-egg4-monthly
fantastic summary of ECMWF Atmospheric Composition Reanalysis (EAC4) dataset focusing on long-lived greenhouse gases like CO2 and CH4 breakdown of information significance:
 Key Features of Dataset:

 Comprehensive Coverage: Global coverage 2003 to 2020 long-term perspective on greenhouse gas dynamics
 High Resolution: 0.75° x 0.75° horizontal resolution allows for detailed regional analysis
 Multi-level Data: Includes data from surface, total column model levels pressure levels comprehensive understanding of atmospheric processes
 Data Assimilation: Uses sophisticated data assimilation method (4D-Var) combine model output with observations improves accuracy consistency dataset
 Monthly Resolution: Provides monthly averages for identifying trends seasonal variations.

 Data Description:

 Variables: dataset includes key variables related to greenhouse gases atmospheric conditions surface processes.
 Units: Consistent units for each variable
 File Formats: Available in GRIB and NetCDF formats compatible with standard climate analysis tools

 Significance of Dataset:

 Understanding Climate Change: dataset essential for understanding evolution of greenhouse gas concentrations, sources (emissions), sinks (natural removal processes) in atmosphere
 Climate Modeling: used to validate improve climate models by comparing model output with reanalysis data.
 Policy Decision-Making: Provides data crucial for informing policies related to greenhouse gas emissions climate change mitigation.
 Research: valuable resource for researchers studying atmospheric composition, climate change global carbon cycle.

 Additional Points:

 Data Availability: original 3-hourly data accessed through Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) website.
Documentation: Detailed information about dataset methodology available in documentation section of CAMS website.

 In summary, EAC4 dataset offers valuable comprehensive resource for analyzing long-lived greenhouse gases, contributing significantly to understanding of climate change informing policy decisions related to mitigation.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-ice-sheet-mass-balance
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-ice-sheet-mass-balance
satellite-ice-sheet-mass-balance
detailed description of dataset on Antarctic Greenland ice sheet mass change breakdown key information:
 Dataset Contains

 Time Series Data: dataset provides monthly records of mass change for Antarctic Greenland ice sheets from 2003 to 2020.
 Spatial Coverage: covers entire Antarctic Greenland regions including major drainage basins
 Resolution: Data provided for each drainage basin (one time series per basin).
 Measurement Type: data from NASA's GRACE and GRACE-FO missions use satellite measurements of Earth gravity to infer mass changes over time
 Units: Mass change measured in Gigatons (Gt).

 Key Variables:

 "Antarctic Basin X Ice Mass Balance": Tracks mass change for each 27 Antarctic basins.
 "Greenland Basin X Ice Mass Balance" Tracks mass change for each 8 Greenland basins.
 "Antarctic Ice Mass Balance" Total mass change for entire Antarctic ice sheet.
 "Greenland Ice Mass Balance" Total mass change entire Greenland ice sheet.
 "Antarctic Peninsula Ice Mass Balance" Total mass change for Antarctic Peninsula
 "East Antarctic Ice Mass Balance" Total mass change for East Antarctica
 "West Antarctic Ice Mass Balance" Total mass change for West Antarctica

 Additional Information

 Data Format: data stored in NetCDF-4 files to Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention.
 Uncertainty Estimates: for all variables provided crucial for understanding reliability data
 Complementary Data: dataset complements other datasets surface elevation change rates further insights into ice sheet dynamics

 Relevance
 dataset crucial for understanding impact climate change on ice sheets significant contributors to global sea level rise provides valuable information for

Monitoring Understanding Ice Sheet Dynamics: Researchers track changes in mass over time identify areas significant mass loss analyze trends.
 Climate Modeling Projections: data used to improve climate models make accurate projections about future sea level rise.
 Policy Decision-Making: dataset informs policy decisions climate change mitigation adaptation strategies.

 Where to Access:
 exact location of dataset depend on source in original documentation. look for it on ESA's Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheet Climate Change Initiative project websites or other relevant data repositories like NASA's Earthdata website.

595
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cems-glofas-seasonal-reforecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cems-glofas-seasonal-reforecast
cems-glofas-seasonal-reforecast
detailed description of GloFAS (Global Flood Awareness System) dataset provides global gridded time series of river discharge breakdown of information highlighting key points:
 What is GloFAS?
 GloFAS system provides global flood forecasting uses meteorological reforecasts (predictions weather) to drive hydrological model (LISFLOOD) to estimate river discharge data crucial for flood risk assessment management.
 Key Features of Dataset:

 Global Coverage: Covers entire globe except Antarctica
 High Resolution: resolution of 0.05° x 0.05° in latest version (v4.0), detailed information
 Long Time Period: Data available from 1981 to present for historical analysis trend identification
 Seasonal Focus: data based on seasonal reforecasts provides predictions of river discharge over 3-month periods useful for planning preparedness.
 Ensemble Approach: reforecasts use ensemble of multiple model runs range of potential outcomes reducing uncertainty.
 Open-Source Model: Based on LISFLOOD hydrological model methodology transparent accessible
 Regular Updates: dataset updated regularly most up-to-date information.

 Data Variables:

 River Discharge in last 24 hours: main variable representing volume of water flowing through river cross-section Measured in cubic meters per second (m3/s).
 Elevation: (Ancillary Data) mean elevation above sea level for each grid cell.
 Upstream Area: (Ancillary Data Represents total area contributes water to specific river segment at given grid point.

 Applications:

 Flood Forecasting and Warning: Predicting potential flood events for early warning preparedness measures.
 Water Resources Management: Understanding water availability variability for irrigation, hydropower other uses.
Climate Change Impact Assessment: Analyzing river flows changing over time potentially due to climate change.
 Hydrological Modeling: Providing validation data for other hydrological models.

 Accessing Data:

 Climate Data Store (CDS): primary source for downloading GloFAS data. more information on CDS website including details on how to access and use data.

 Overall:
 This dataset valuable resource for range of hydrological applications. provides high-quality globally consistent data on river discharge supported by ancillary information enhances interpretation use of seasonal reforecasts ensemble approach relevant for planning mitigating flood risks.
---

598
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cmip5-daily-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cmip5-daily-pressure-levels
projections-cmip5-daily-pressure-levels
description of CMIP5 climate data clear understanding contents applications breakdown of key information:
 What?

 catalogue entry describes climate projections from CMIP5 (Coupled Model Intercomparison Project, Phase 5)
 data consists of daily climate information at multiple pressure levels shows changes atmosphere at different altitudes).

 Why important?

 CMIP5 data used in climate research IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) reports including AR5 (Fifth Assessment Report) published 2014.
 helps scientists
 Understand climate system complexities
 Estimate future climate change uncertainties
 Plan adaptation measures climate change
 Evaluate accuracy of climate models



 key data characteristics?

 Data type: Gridded organized regular spatial grid).
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid (covering entire globe).
 Resolution: Varies depending model from 0.125° x 0.125° to 5° x 5° horizontally
 Vertical resolution: Levels at 10, 50, 100, 250, 500, 700, 850, 1000 hPa (depending model).
 Temporal coverage: 1850 to 2300 (shorter for some experiments).
 resolution Daily
 File format: NetCDF common format for scientific data).

 types of experiments included?

 Historical experiments: Simulate past climate (typically 1850-2005) assess model performance
 AMIP (Atmospheric Model Intercomparison Project) experiments: Simulate climate with prescribed ocean conditions removing ocean-atmosphere feedbacks (typically 1950-2005).
 RCP (Representative Concentration Pathways) experiments Simulate future climate different greenhouse gas emission scenarios (typically 2006-2100 some extend to 2300).

 main variables included?

 Geopotential height: measure of altitude (proportional to elevation above sea level).
Temperature: Air temperature.
 U-component of wind: Eastward component wind velocity.
 V-component of wind: Northward component wind velocity.

 Additional Notes:

 CMIP5 data often used as input for Regional Climate Models (RCMs) detailed regional climate projections.
 CMIP6, successor to CMIP5, currently being released provide more comprehensive updated climate data.

 description provides solid foundation for understanding valuable resource CMIP5 data represents learn more about accessing using this data from relevant climate data repositories Climate Data Online (CDO) portal.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-greenhouse-gas-inversion
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-greenhouse-gas-inversion
cams-global-greenhouse-gas-inversion
comprehensive description of dataset containing atmospheric greenhouse gas data valuable for climate change research break down information:
 Key Points:

 Focus: dataset centers around carbon dioxide (CO2) methane (CH4) nitrous oxide (N2O), all significant greenhouse gases influencing Earth's climate
 Source: data from atmospheric inversion, technique models to link observed greenhouse gas concentrations with surface fluxes (emissions removals).
 Value: data crucial for
 Understanding climate change: tracking changes in greenhouse gas fluxes scientists understand drivers climate change.
 Policymaking: data informs international climate agreements emissions reduction targets.
 Research: vital for studies on global carbon cycle atmospheric chemistry climate modeling.


 Data Details:
 Data Type: Gridded data organized spatially over grid)
 Coverage: Global
 Resolution: spatial resolution varies by gas (CO2 and N2O have finer resolution than CH4)
 Temporal Coverage: Data spans decades start year varies by gas
 Temporal Resolution: temporal resolution data collection varies from 3-hourly to monthly.
 File Format: NetCDF (a common format for scientific data)



 Main Variables:

 Greenhouse Gas Concentrations: dataset includes atmospheric mixing ratios at different model levels and column-mean atmosphere) mixing ratios for each gas
 Surface Fluxes: data includes prior and posterior surface fluxes
 Prior fluxes initial estimates of surface fluxes based on existing models or knowledge
 Posterior fluxes fluxes estimated after applying atmospheric inversion process


 Flux Breakdown: For methane dataset separates fluxes into different sources including fossil fuels, biomass burning, wetlands rice cultivation
Units: units for each variable clearly defined.

 Additional Notes:

 Versioning: dataset updated regularly with new data added and older data reprocessed for consistency indicated by version numbers.
 Documentation: description mentions detailed documentation about dataset essential for understanding its limitations and how data processed.

 Overall dataset appears to valuable resource for interested in studying climate change, greenhouse gas emissions, or atmospheric processes. detailed information provided, including variable names, units, data characteristics makes it easy to use and interpret.

great summary of dataset on offshore wind farm operations maintenance under different climate scenarios breakdown of key points additional insights:
 Strengths of Dataset:

 Real-world Relevance: dataset uses industry-standard performance indicators applicable to wind farm developers operators.
 Climate Change Impact: considering different climate scenarios dataset offers valuable insights into potential effects of climate change on wind farm operations.
 Methodological Rigor: use of ForeCoast Marine software established climate models (HIRHAM5, EC-EARTH) strong foundation for analysis.
 Accessibility: NetCDF-4 format CF/ACDD conventions ensure easy access interoperability with common climate data tools.

 Limitations to Consider:

 Uncertainty: dataset acknowledges underestimation of uncertainty due to using single climate model combination interpret results with in mind
 Single Wind Farm Configuration: analysis based on single wind farm configuration specific metocean data potentially limiting generalizability of results to other locations farm designs.
 Focus on Weather Windows: dataset captures downtime power production due to weather may not fully account for other factors impacting operational performance turbine maintenance grid constraints.

 Potential Applications:

 Financial Planning: Wind farm developers use dataset to assess potential impact of climate change on energy production operational costs informing financial modeling investment decisions.
 Operational Optimization: Operators use data to anticipate future weather patterns plan maintenance schedules resource allocation
 Policy & Regulation: dataset provide valuable data to policymakers regulators for developing effective climate change adaptation strategies for offshore wind industry.

 Additional Considerations:

 Spatial Variability: dataset covers seven locations in North West European seas Additional data from other regions would enhance broader applicability.
Temporal Resolution: monthly, annual campaign-based data provided, finer-grained temporal resolutions (e. hourly) could be beneficial for detailed operational analysis.

 this dataset represents valuable contribution to understanding potential impact of climate change on offshore wind farm operations provides starting point for further research practical applications acknowledging limitations in using single climate model combination wind farm configuration.

sis-tourism-climate-suitability-indicators
detailed description of dataset on climate suitability indicators for tourism in Europe
 breakdown key information additional insights:
 Dataset Purpose

 Assess impact climate change on tourism activities Europe specifically urban beach tourism
 Method Utilizes climate suitability indices (HCI and CIT) to quantify rank climate conditions for different tourism activities
 Value decision-making tool for tourists tourism industry to understand adapt changing climate conditions

 Key Features

 Indices:
 HCI (Holiday Climate Index): Evaluates climate suitability for urban tourism activities
 CIT (Climate Index for Tourism): Evaluates climate suitability beach tourism activities


 Climate Scenarios:
 Historical: Data from 1970-2005 reference period
 Future Projections: Utilizes four Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios (historical, RCP2.6 RCP4.5 RCP8.5) project future climate conditions


 Climate Projections Derived from EURO-CORDEX ensemble model output
 Spatial Coverage: Europe (27°N to 72°N 22°W to 45°E).
 Resolution: 0.11° x 0.11° horizontal resolution
 Temporal Coverage: From 1970 to 2100
 Resolution Daily, dekadal monthly seasonal

 Data Variables

 Daily Index: core indicator representing HCI or CIT values for urban or beach tourism
 Number of Fair Days: Counts days within "fair" range for chosen index
 Number of Good Days days within "good" range for chosen index
 Number of Unfavourable Days: Counts days outside "fair" ranges index

 Potential Applications

 Tourism Planning Identify regions periods vulnerable to climate change impacts tourism
 Marketing and Promotion Develop strategies target destinations with favorable future climate conditions
Investment Decisions Guide infrastructure development resource allocation based projected climate suitability.
 Climate Adaptation Strategies: Develop measures mitigate climate risks enhance tourism resilience.

 Further Considerations:

 Model Uncertainty: Climate projections based on models have inherent uncertainties.
 Socioeconomic Factors: dataset focuses on climate factors socioeconomic factors like infrastructure tourism demand play crucial role
 Data Access: Understanding access use data essential for effective application.

 dataset offers valuable insights into potential impacts climate change on European tourism provides framework for assessing climate suitability supporting informed decisions fostering resilient tourism practices.

 Core Functionalities

 Visualization of Soil Erosion Indicators application displays two key indicators
 Soil Loss: amount soil lost per hectare annually
 R Factor (Rainfall Erosivity): intensity of rainfall's erosive power


 Scenario Selection: choose from multiple scenarios:
 Reference Period (1981-2010): Historical data for comparison
 Near Future (2021-2050): Projections under RCP 8.5.
 Ensemble Mean: Average of multiple climate models.
 Difference to Reference Period: Shows change compared historical period.
 Relative Difference: Shows percentage change historical period.


 Far Future (2051-2080): Projections under RCP 8.5.
 Ensemble Mean: Average of multiple climate models
 Difference to Reference Period Shows change compared historical period
 Relative Difference Shows percentage change compared historical period




 Spatial Exploration: zoom in out map explore soil erosion patterns at various levels:
 National (Italy)
 Geographical Regions
 Administrative Regions (Italian regions
 Provinces


 Focused Views: on specific region or province provides detailed information
 Map Plots: Visual representation of selected indicator for different scenarios
 Interactive Boxplot Displays key statistical information (minimum, maximum median quartiles) for selected area scenario allows see soil erosion indicators vary across region


 What-if Analysis Tool explore land use practices influence soil loss under different climate scenarios modify factors related to
 Vegetation Cover: type density vegetation
 Land Management: Farming practices management techniques
 Soil Erosion Protection Practices: Measures to reduce soil loss

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/mediterranean-sea-significant-wave-height-extreme-0
http://marine.copernicus.eu/services-portfolio/access-to-products/?option=com_csw&view=details&product_id=MEDSEA_OMI_SEASTATE_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly
Mediterranean Sea Significant Wave Height extreme from Reanalysis
Summary of CMEMS MEDSEA_OMI_seastate_extreme_var_swh_mean_and_anomaly Indicator
 document provides summary of CMEMS OMI indicator focusing on annual 99th percentile of Significant Wave Height (SWH) in Mediterranean Sea utilizes two CMEMS products: MEDSEA_MULTIYEAR_WAV_006_012) and MEDSEA_ANALYSIS_FORECAST_WAV_006_017
 Key aspects indicator

 Purpose: monitor extreme annual SWH evaluate spatio-temporal variability
 Parameters:
 99th mean percentile map Computed from Multi Year Product (1993-2019) each year averaged across entire period.
 Anomaly of 99th percentile in 2020: Calculated from Analysis product obtained by subtracting mean percentile from 2020 value.


 Methodology Uses percentiles instead of annual maxima for robust study of extreme events

 Context:

 Sea state significance Affects maritime activities physical connectivity coastal ecosystems biodiversity in marine protected areas
 Extreme wave height Impacts coastal environments infrastructure adaptation strategies mitigate natural hazards.
 Mediterranean Sea characteristics complex orographic features create strong regional wind regimes drive high waves
 Wind patterns wave heights Northerly winds (Mistral, Tramontana, Bora, Etesian) primary drivers of high waves specific areas characterized by high wave heights due to wind strength fetch length.

 CMEMS Key Findings (2020):

 Positive anomalies Observed across northern Mediterranean eastern Alboran Sea African coast anomalies exceed climatic standard deviation reaching maximum values up to 1.1 m.
 Notable events contributing to positive anomalies:
Storm "Gloria" (19/1 – 24/1): Caused exceptional eastern winds Ligurian Sea leading record-breaking wave heights Western Mediterranean.
 Other contributing storms: Karine, Bernardo Hervé Ianos.


 Negative anomalies Found southern Mediterranean southeastern Ionian Sea west of mainland Greece exceeding two times climatic standard deviation might suggest less severe southerly wind activity 2020.

 Note information based on provided text updated annually November.
 References:

 Format: NetCDF-4

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-c3s-monthly-climate-covid-19-explorer
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-c3s-monthly-climate-covid-19-explorer
app-c3s-monthly-climate-covid-19-explorer
detailed description of application visualizes COVID-19 data climate information breakdown of key elements insights:
 Application Purpose:

 Exploratory Tool: application designed to explore potential relationships between COVID-19 spread climate factors exploratory tool not establish definitive cause-and-effect relationships.
 Combining Data Sources: draws data from diverse sources:
 COVID-19: Johns Hopkins University CSSEGISand Data repository provides number of deaths.
 Climate: Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) Climate Data Store provides air temperature humidity (ERA5 reanalysis).
 Air Quality: Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) Atmosphere Data Store provides PM10 NO2 concentrations.



 Key Features:

 Interactive World Map: application uses map to display
 Climate/Air Quality Variables: Air temperature humidity PM10 NO2 visualized for selected months.
 COVID-19 Fatalities: Circles on map represent regions with COVID-19 deaths size proportional to number of fatalities.


 Time Evolution: Clicking on circle provides detailed view
 Fatality Time Series: Shows daily number of deaths in region
 Local Climate Time Series: Shows air temperature humidity at point close to center of circle for same time period.


 User-Selectable Parameters: Users can customize displayed data
 Variable: Temperature, humidity PM10 NO2.
 Month: Select month for COVID-19 climate data.
 Previous Month: For temperature humidity select previous month for comparison



 Important Considerations:

 Data Limitations: application acknowledges potential limitations in data
 Data Quality: COVID-19 data sourced from CSSEGISand Data not subject to C3S quality control.
Time Lags: application assumes direct correlation between selected month COVID-19 deaths without accounting for time lag between infection death
 Climate Averaging: Atmospheric composition data uses long-term averages (2003-2018), might not represent current conditions.


 Exploratory Nature: application emphasizes exploratory tool relationships between climate/air quality COVID-19 complex require further research.

 Potential Insights:
 application can help users

 Visualize Geographic Patterns Observe high COVID-19 death rates coincide with specific climate air quality conditions
 Explore Temporal Correlations See if certain months exhibit higher death rates specific climate patterns
 Generate Research Hypotheses: application could inspire further studies investigate potential impacts of climate air quality on COVID-19 spread.

 Overall
 application offers valuable resource for exploring potential relationships between COVID-19 environmental factors crucial to understand limitations use as tool to generate further research questions definitive conclusions.

satellite-ocean-colour
great summary of global ocean surface chlorophyll-a concentration remote sensing reflectance dataset! breakdown of key points:
 Dataset Contains:

 Chlorophyll-a: measure of phytoplankton abundance essential for understanding marine ecosystems global carbon cycle.
 Remote Sensing Reflectance (Rrs): amount light reflected back from ocean surface used to derive chlorophyll-a other oceanographic information.

 Importance of Dataset:

 Monitoring Marine Health: Provides insights into health productivity of marine ecosystems.
 Climate Change Impacts: Helps quantify effects climate change on ocean ecosystems.
 Global Carbon Cycle: Contributes to understanding role of oceans in global carbon cycle

 Key Features of Dataset:

 Global Coverage: Covers entire Earth's surface
 Daily Resolution: Provides daily updates for detailed monitoring of changes
 Multiple Sensors: Combines data from various satellites for greater accuracy coverage
 Blended Chlorophyll-a Estimate: Uses multiple algorithms produce accurate chlorophyll-a estimates across different water types
 Open Data: Freely available for researchers interested in oceanographic data

 Technical Details:

 Data Type: Gridded data organized in spatial grid
 Projections regular latitude-longitude and sinusoidal grids available
 Spatial Resolution: High resolution (4km x 4km) for detailed analysis
 Temporal Coverage: Long-term dataset spanning from September 1997 to present
 File Format: NetCDF-4 common format for scientific data

 Additional Variables:

 Ancillary variables Provide information like observation count, water class uncertainty estimates

 dataset valuable resource for scientists researchers anyone interested in understanding monitoring health of oceans

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-shipping-consumption-routes
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-shipping-consumption-on-routes
sis-shipping-consumption-on-routes
detailed description of valuable dataset for shipping industry breakdown of information significance:
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: provide insights into impact of weather on ship performance for optimized routes reduced fuel consumption
 Target Audience: Traders fleet managers to estimate journey times fuel usage risk of delays
 Data Sources:
 ECMWF Reanalysis: ERA5 (wind and waves), ORAS4 (currents), SEAS5 (seasonal wind forecasts). high-quality global datasets for weather climate research


 Data Types:
 Point data (measurements along specific routes)
 NetCDF-4 (standard format for climate and oceanographic data)


 Temporal Coverage: 1993 to 2019
 Frequency: Monthly updates

 Key Variables
 dataset contains crucial variables for optimizing ship operations:

 Fuel Consumption at Fixed Power/Speed: data shows fuel consumption route under different conditions (fixed power vs. fixed speed), considering factors wind waves currents
 Shaft Power at Fixed Speed: variable represents engine power maintain constant speed over ground
 Ship Speed at Fixed Shaft Power: shows actual speed with fixed engine power highlighting impact of weather on performance
 Trip Duration at Fixed Power data provides estimated time taken for journey under given power setting considering weather factors

 Benefits for Shipping
 dataset offers benefits for shipping companies:

 Fuel Efficiency: understanding impact of weather fleet managers choose optimal routes speeds to minimize fuel consumption saving costs reducing emissions
 Time Optimization: Predicting impact of weather on journey duration allows for accurate arrival time estimates improved scheduling reduced delays
 Risk Management: dataset provides data on uncertainty associated with meeting target arrival times better risk assessment for potential delays

dataset is powerful tool for shipping industry. combines high-quality climate data with sophisticated fuel consumption model offer actionable insights for improving operational efficiency sustainability.

610
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cmip5-monthly-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cmip5-monthly-pressure-levels
projections-cmip5-monthly-pressure-levels
detailed informative catalogue entry for CMIP5 climate projections data. breakdown of key information:
 What is CMIP5?

 Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5: major international effort to coordinate compare climate model simulations from various research groups worldwide goal is to improve understanding of climate change, projections associated uncertainties

 Data Description:

 Type: Gridded data data organized into grid system covering globe
 Coverage: Global - data covers entire Earth.
 Resolution:
 Horizontal: Varies from 0.125° x 0.125° (very fine) to 5° x 5° (coarse) depending on specific model
 Vertical: includes pressure levels at 10, 20, 30... 1000 hPa (hPa unit of pressure). data available at different heights in atmosphere.


 Time:
 Coverage: From 1850 to 2300, shorter for some experiments.
 Resolution: Monthly - data provided for each month.


 Format: NetCDF - common format for storing scientific data

 Key Variables:

 Geopotential Height: measure of height above mean sea level represent vertical levels in atmosphere
 Relative Humidity: Indicates moisture in air compared to maximum holding capacity at given temperature
 Specific Humidity: ratio of water vapor mass to total air mass.
 Temperature: temperature of air.
 U-component of wind: eastward component of wind velocity.
 V-component of wind: northward component of wind velocity.

 CMIP5 Experiments:

 Historical Experiments: Simulations covering period where modern climate observations available (typically 1850-2005). experiments to assess models represent past climate.
 AMIP Experiments: Simulations where ocean conditions prescribed (fixed). eliminates complexity of ocean-atmosphere interactions researchers to focus on atmospheric processes
RCP Experiments: Simulations based on different "Representative Concentration Pathways" (RCPs) represent future scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions radiative forcing. experiments provide projections of future climate change under various emissions scenarios.

 Ensemble of Experiments:

 CMIP5 utilizes multiple model runs (ensembles) to account for uncertainties in model parameters initial conditions. helps provide robust reliable projections.

 Uses of CMIP5 Data:

 Address scientific questions: answer questions from IPCC reports
 Improve climate system understanding: deeper understanding climate system
 Estimate future climate change: Provide projections of future climate change impacts
 Adaptation to climate change: Inform adaptation strategies policies to mitigate effects climate change
 Climate predictability: Explore predictable climate on decadal time scales
 Model evaluation: Evaluate models simulate recent past.

 Regional Climate Models (RCMs):

 CMIP5 data used as input for regional climate models (RCMs) provide higher resolution climate simulations for specific regions.

 CMIP6:

 next phase of CMIP project building on foundation of CMIP5 include new experiments improved models expanded data sets.

 CMIP5 data is valuable resource for researchers policymakers on climate change issues provides wealth of information about past, present future climate to understand respond to challenges of climate change effectively
---
611
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-monthly-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/seasonal-monthly-single-levels
seasonal-monthly-single-levels
well-structured description of dataset containing monthly single-level climate data breakdown of information significance:
 Data Overview

 Focus: dataset provides single-level climate data represents variables at specific height or level in atmosphere).
 Time Resolution: Data aggregated monthly basis summarizes climate conditions for each month
 Purpose data primarily used for seasonal forecasting focuses on long-range predictions of climate patterns weeks to months into future

 Data Source and Characteristics

 Source data from multi-system seasonal forecast service combines forecasts from multiple climate models across Europe
 Forecast Types dataset includes
 Real-time forecasts: Produced regularly (usually monthly for current time period
 Hindcasts: Historical simulations generated using past conditions to assess model performance understand past climate variability


 Coverage
 Spatial: Global 1° x 1° horizontal resolution
 Temporal: 1993-2016 (hindcasts) 2017 to present (forecasts).


 Format: GRIB (Gridded Binary), standard format for meteorological data

 Why Multiple Models?

 Uncertainty Reduction: multiple models account for uncertainty from
 Initial Conditions Imperfect knowledge of current state Earth system
 Model Approximations Simplifications limitations in climate models


 Improved Accuracy: Combining forecasts from different models to more robust reliable predictions

 Key Variables
 dataset includes wide range of climate variables representing different aspects of Earth's atmosphere surface like

 Wind: Speed, direction gusts
 Temperature: Air temperature dew point temperature
 Precipitation: Total precipitation snowfall
 Surface Conditions: Sea surface temperature snow depth soil temperature
 Radiation: Solar radiation thermal radiation
 Cloud Cover: Total cloud cover cloud water content
Stress and Flux: Surface stress latent sensible heat flux.

 Applications
 dataset supports numerous applications including:

 Seasonal Forecasting: Predicting monthly seasonal climate patterns for regions.
 Climate Research: Analyzing long-term trends climate variability impacts of climate change.
 Disaster Mitigation: Preparing for potential droughts floods weather-related events
 Water Resource Management: Optimizing water use allocation based on seasonal rainfall predictions.
 Agriculture: Predicting growing conditions crop yields optimizing agricultural practices.

 Additional Considerations

 Documentation: Refer to documentation for detailed information about dataset including data processing methods limitations recommended usage.
 Data Access: Information about access data provided in documentation or data provider's website.

 dataset provides valuable information for understanding predicting climate variations supporting research decision-making planning activities.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-ocean-wave-indicators
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-ocean-wave-indicators
sis-ocean-wave-indicators
great summary of European wave climate dataset! breakdown of information additional thoughts:
 Key Points:


 Purpose: dataset provides insights into European wave climate under influence climate change data crucial for coastal sectors studies including

 Port Management: Understanding wave conditions essential for port design safety operations
 Shipping: Wave climate impacts shipping routes vessel safety fuel efficiency
 Coastal Management: Predicting wave action helps with coastal erosion mitigation infrastructure planning understanding impact of storms.



 Data Source: data generated by ECMWF's Wave Model (SAW) uses wind forcing ice coverage information.


 Climate Scenarios: dataset includes:

 Historical (1976-2005): Baseline wave climate.
 ERA5 Reanalysis (2001-2017): recent historical data.
 RCP4.5 (2041-2100): Optimistic emission scenario.
 RCP8.5 (2041-2100): Pessimistic "business-as-usual" emission scenario.



 Key Variables:

 Peak Wave Period (s): Indicates period most energetic waves.
 Significant Wave Height (m): average height of highest one-third of waves crucial for assessing sea state swell.



 Additional Thoughts:

 Spatial Resolution: 30 km coastal grid points offer good coverage might be too coarse for highly localized studies
 Temporal Resolution: dataset provides monthly averages might not be ideal for studying specific storm events
 Future Developments: interesting to see if dataset updated with higher resolution data more detailed information about frequency intensity of extreme wave events potentially include data on wave direction.

 Overall dataset valuable resource for coastal management marine engineering climate change research related to European watersprovides solid foundation for understanding present future wave climate, supporting informed decision-making in variety of sectors.

614
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-fisheries-abundance
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-fisheries-abundance
sis-fisheries-abundance
detailed informative description of dataset containing fish catch abundance projections. breakdown of key information implications:
 Strengths of Dataset:

 Mechanistic Model: SS-DBEM model powerful tool considers ecological physiological factors makes projections more realistic potentially accurate than simple statistical models.
 Climate Change Impact: model accounts for effects of climate change (warming, deoxygenation) on fish populations crucial for understanding future fisheries.
 Fishing Pressure: dataset includes different fishing management scenarios (MSY levels), researchers to explore combined impact of climate change and fishing on fish stocks.
 Spatial and Temporal Coverage: dataset covers significant portion of European seas with high spatial resolution (0.5° x 0.5°) extends to 2098.
 Open Data: dataset publicly available valuable for wide range research management applications.

 Limitations of Dataset:

 Relative Values: model outputs relative to initial starting values not absolute numbers makes challenging to directly predict actual fish stocks.
 Single GCM-RCM Combination: Using only one GCM-RCM pairing underestimates potential uncertainty in future climate projections model results likely represent narrower range of possibilities than exists.
 Model Simplifications: Like model SS-DBEM makes simplifications assumptions can lead to discrepancies between model predictions real-world observations.

 Research Applications:
 dataset can be used for:

 Assessing Climate Change Impacts: Researchers can analyze how climate change affect distribution, abundance catch of different fish species in European waters.
 Evaluating Fishing Management Strategies: Comparing results of different fishing scenarios provide insights into effectiveness of various management approaches.
Developing Adaptation Measures: Understanding potential impacts climate change can inform development of strategies to mitigate risks ensure sustainable fisheries.

 Overall this dataset is valuable resource for understanding potential impacts climate change fishing pressure on European fisheries should be used conjunction with other data sources awareness of limitations of model projections.
---
615
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/ecv-climate-change
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/ecv-for-climate-change
ecv-for-climate-change
comprehensive description of Essential Climate Variables (ECVs) dataset break down key information:
 What is dataset?
 dataset provides monthly data on Essential Climate Variables (ECVs) from 1979 to present. ECVs are key measurements help understand monitor climate change dataset uses data from two climate reanalyses: ERA-Interim and ERA5.
 Why dataset important?
 dataset valuable because provides:

 Long-term trends: data extends back to 1979 long-term trends in climate change
 Global coverage: covers entire globe comprehensive understanding of climate variability.
 Multiple variables: dataset includes multiple ECVs holistic picture of climate change.
 High quality: data derived from well-respected climate reanalyses adjusted for known deficiencies.

 Key features dataset:

 Data type: Gridded data organized on grid system)
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Horizontal coverage: Global
 Horizontal resolution: 0.25° x 0.25° each grid cell approximately 28 km x 28 km)
 Temporal coverage: 1979 to present
 Temporal resolution: Monthly
 File format: GRIB (a common format for meteorological data
 Update frequency: Monthly

 Main variables included:

 0-7cm volumetric soil moisture: Measures water content in top layer of soil.
 Precipitation: Total rainfall and snowfall accumulated over month.
 Sea-ice cover: fraction of grid box covered by sea ice.
 Surface air relative humidity: amount of moisture in air near surface
 Surface air temperature: temperature air 2 meters above ground

 Additional information

 dataset provides monthly averages, climatologies (long-term averages), anomalies (deviations from climatology).
dataset has two reference periods for calculating climatologies anomalies: 1981-2010 and 1991-2020.
 dataset used as basis for Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) monthly climate bulletin, provides assessment of monthly state of climate, particularly for Europe.

 dataset is valuable resource for researchers, policymakers others interested in understanding climate change impacts.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cmip5-daily-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cmip5-daily-single-levels
projections-cmip5-daily-single-levels
detailed informative catalogue entry for CMIP5 climate projections breakdown of key information:
 What is CMIP5?

 CMIP5 stands for Coupled Model Intercomparison Project, Phase 5.
 massive international effort climate modeling groups run climate models under standardized conditions
 allows scientists to compare models assess strengths weaknesses get robust picture of climate change projections

 What data included?

 Single-level data: refers to climate variables calculated at single vertical level near surface or specific pressure level in atmosphere.
 Multiple experiments: data includes results from
 Historical experiments: Simulations of past climate from 1850-2005) compare model performance with observed data
 AMIP experiments: Simulations where ocean conditions prescribed isolating atmosphere's response.
 RCP experiments: Projections of future climate based on different greenhouse gas emissions scenarios (RCP 2.6, 4.5 6.0, 8.5).


 Ensemble of runs: Each experiment run multiple times with different starting conditions model configurations creates ensemble of runs helps estimate uncertainties associated with projections.

 Why data important?

 Addressing scientific questions: Provides data to answer questions from IPCC reports
 Improving climate understanding: Helps researchers understand climate system works
 Future climate estimates: Provides projections of future climate change uncertainties
 Climate adaptation: Supplies input data for planning adaptation strategies to climate change
 Climate predictability: Examines models predict climate on decadal time scales
 Model evaluation: Assesses accurately models simulate recent past

 Data characteristics:

 Gridded: data organized on regular latitude-longitude grid
 Global coverage: Covers entire globe
 Multiple resolutions: Resolutions vary from 0.125° x 0.125° to 5° x 5° depending on model.
Temporal coverage: From 1850 to 2300 (shorter for some experiments).
 Daily resolution: Data provided at daily time steps.
 NetCDF format: Data stored in widely used NetCDF format.

 Key variables:

 10m wind speed: Wind speed near surface.
 2m temperature: Temperature air near surface
 Relative humidity: Amount moisture in air.
 Maximum/Minimum temperature: Daily extremes temperature
 Precipitation: Amount rainfall.
 Sea level pressure: Air pressure at sea level
 Specific humidity: Amount moisture air
 Snowfall: Amount snowfall
 Surface solar radiation: Incoming solar radiation surface.

 Overall CMIP5 catalogue entry provides valuable information for scientists others understanding projecting future climate change data used in research policy-making adaptation planning.

618
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-ice-thickness
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-ice-thickness
satellite-sea-ice-thickness
detailed description of sea ice thickness dataset breakdown of key information
 data

 Sea ice thickness crucial indicator of climate change important component of Earth's climate system
 Satellite observations Derived from radar altimetry measurements by Envisat CryoSat-2 satellites
 Data coverage Covers Arctic region focusing winter months (October to April).

 Data characteristics

 Gridded data: Monthly averages for 25 km grid cells
 Resolution: True spatial resolution 1-10 km data gridded to 25 km.
 Projection: Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area (EASE-Grid version 2.0)
 Temporal coverage: From October 2002 to present
 Data format: NetCDF 4

 Key variables

 Sea ice thickness (m): Mean ice thickness for each grid cell
 Quality flag: Indicates data quality (nominal intermediate
 Status flag: Details processing steps each pixel
 Uncertainty (m): Statistical uncertainty of retrieval algorithm

 Important notes

 Data quality CryoSat-2 period more accurate than Envisat period
 Limitations No data available for Southern Hemisphere or summer months (May to September).
 Updates data updated monthly with one-month delay

 dataset provides valuable information for

 Climate change research Tracking changes in sea ice thickness
 Oceanographic studies Understanding sea ice dynamics influence on marine ecosystems
 Climate modeling Improving models of Arctic climate system

 Additional information

 Product User Guide Product Quality Assessment Report Provide further details about data
 ESA CCI Sea Ice project: Further developments extensions of dataset planned

 dataset offers comprehensive valuable resource for researchers studying sea ice role in Earth's climate system
