619
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-surface-temperature-complete
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-surface-temperature-complete
satellite-sea-surface-temperature-complete
detailed description global sea surface temperature (SST) dataset breakdown key information insights
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides daily estimates global SST from multiple satellite sensors crucial for understanding climate variability change
 Data Source: Measurements from Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometers Along Track Scanning Radiometers (ATSRs), Sea and Land Surface Temperature Radiometer (SLSTR).
 Time Span Covers 1981 to present different sensor coverage periods
 Spatial Coverage Global for Level 3 4 products Satellite swath for Level 2 products
 Resolution Ranges from 1 km x 1 km for ATSR SLSTR Level 2 to 0.05° x 0.05° for Level 3 and 4 products
 Data Format: NetCDF 4 CF Unidata standards
 Update Frequency Monthly 12-month delay

 Data Levels Types

 Level 2 Pre-processed (L2P): Raw SST data satellite's original swath single sensor
 Level 3 Uncollated (L3U): L2P data regridded global latitude-longitude grid
 Level 3 Collated (L3C): Daily global single-sensor SST product based combined L3U data
 Level 4 (L4) Spatially complete global SST product combining data from multiple sensors comprehensive estimate

 Key Variables

 Analysed sea surface temperature (K): Global spatially complete estimate of daily average SST adjusted to 20 cm depth Level 4)
 Sea surface temperature at depth (K): SST adjusted to 20 cm depth 10:30 local time daily comparison with in situ observations (Level 2 & 3)
 sea surface temperature (K): SST measured at surface 10 μm depth by satellite infrared sensors (Level 2 & 3)

 Uncertainty Additional Information

dataset includes variables for uncertainty due to processing sampling methods.
 land/sea/ice mask provided identify type surface in each grid cell.

 Important Notes

 Climate Data Records (CDRs): SST data produced as CDRs ensuring long-term consistency suitability for climate analysis.
 Interim CDRs (ICDRs): Extend baseline CDRs at L3C and L4 levels for more recent data.
 Software and Algorithms: dataset generated using tools for ESA SST Climate Change Initiative (CCI) project.
 Data Access: Level 2 Pre-processed Level 3 Collated products available through Climate Data Store API.

 Applications
 dataset valuable for

 Climate Monitoring: Tracking long-term changes variability in global SST.
 Climate Modeling: input data for climate models
 Oceanography: Understanding ocean processes role in climate system
 Weather Forecasting: Improving accuracy of weather predictions.

 comprehensive SST dataset provides powerful resource for researchers scientists anyone interested in understanding role of ocean in climate system.
---

621
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-uerra-europe-height-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-uerra-europe-height-levels
reanalysis-uerra-europe-height-levels
text provides description UERRA dataset regional reanalysis dataset for Europe breakdown key information
 What is UERRA?
 (Unified European Reanalysis for the Atmosphere) is dataset combining model simulations observations complete consistent picture atmosphere over Europe uses technique data assimilation laws of physics to fill gaps estimate atmospheric variables at locations with sparse data
 UERRA's Key Features:

 Data Type: Gridded data
 Projection: Lambert conformal conic grid with 565 x 565 points
 Horizontal Coverage: Europe from northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic Ocean to Ural mountains
 Horizontal Resolution: 11km x 11km.
 Vertical Coverage: 11 height levels 15m to 500m
 Resolution 15m 30m 50m 75m 100m 150m 200m 250m 300m 400m 500m
 Temporal Coverage: January 1961 to July 2019.
 Analyses available each day at 00, 06 12 18 UTC
 File Format: GRIB2
 Update Frequency No expected updates

 Key Variables

 Pressure (Pa): Air pressure at specified height above model surface
 Relative Humidity (%): Ratio actual humidity to saturation humidity at given height
 Temperature (K): Air temperature at specified height
 Wind Direction (Degrees): wind at given height (0° = north, 90° = east).
 Wind Speed (m/s): Speed wind at given height

 Advantages of UERRA:

 Complete and Consistent: Data assimilation fills data gaps provides comprehensive picture atmosphere
 High Resolution Allows detailed analysis of regional features
 Long Time Series Data spans from 1961 to 2019 valuable for climate studies
 Standard Format: GRIB2 makes data analysis easy

 Limitations of UERRA:

Data Quality Varies: Early data (1960s) may less accurate due to sparse observation networks.
 Limited Forecast Data Only available through CDS API.

 Related Datasets:
 UERRA part of larger collection including data on pressure levels soil levels
 UERRA valuable resource for researchers scientists studying European climate weather patterns high resolution long time series consistent data make it reliable comprehensive dataset for wide range applications.
---

satellite-sea-ice
detailed description valuable dataset for climate change studies breakdown key information used
 Dataset Overview

 Focus: Sea ice characteristics in Arctic Antarctic
 Variables:
 Sea ice concentration: Percentage area covered by ice
 Sea ice edge: Classification sea surface (open water open ice closed ice).
 Sea ice type Indicates ice first-year or multi-year
 Sea ice thickness: Average thickness ice layer


 Importance: Sea ice crucial role in climate regulation marine ecosystems human activities like shipping
 Data Source: Satellite observations from multiple missions

 Data Characteristics

 Spatial Coverage
 Concentration & Edge: Global oceans Northern and Southern Hemispheres
 Thickness & Type: Northern Hemisphere.


 Spatial Resolution:
 Concentration & Edge: 12.5 km grid (actual resolution 40-50 km for concentration ~15 km for edge).
 Thickness & Type: 25 km grid (actual resolution 1-10 km for thickness 40-70 km for type).


 Temporal Coverage:
 Concentration: 1978 to 2019
 Thickness: 2002 to present
 Edge & Type: 1979 to present


 Temporal Resolution:
 Concentration Edge Type Daily (every other day 1978-1987)
 Thickness: Monthly Arctic winter months (October-April).


 Format: NetCDF

 Uses Value

 Climate Change Research Monitor long-term trends in sea ice extent, thickness type key indicators climate change
 Ecosystem Studies Understand changes sea ice affect marine life habitats
 Human Activities: Analyze impact of sea ice on shipping routes logistics tourism
 Uncertainty Analysis: dataset includes variables to quantify uncertainty data researchers confident findings

 Additional Notes

 Data Consistency: Data from April 2015 onwards processed consistently needs verification for continuity.
 Updates: New versions dataset expected in 2020 and 2021 for sea ice concentration 2021 for thickness, edge type.

 Overall dataset provides rich source information on sea ice dynamics valuable tool for researchers across various fields.

623
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-gridded-observations-europe
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-gridded-observations-europe
insitu-gridded-observations-europe
great summary of E-OBS dataset! highlights key features clear unique breakdown of information additional points to consider:
 Strengths of E-OBS:

 High Spatial Density: E-OBS leverages denser network of weather stations than other gridded datasets critical for accurate spatial representation of weather patterns
 Daily Resolution: daily temporal resolution provides detailed understanding of weather changes extremes.
 Multiple Variables: E-OBS provides data on various meteorological variables for comprehensive climate analysis.
 Long Time Series: Data extending back to 1950 allows for long-term climate trend analysis
 Open Access: station data openly accessible through ECA&D fostering collaboration transparency.

 Key Points to Note:

 24-hour Period Variation: exact 24-hour period may differ across regions due to variations in data collection practices by different weather stations important to aware of when conducting analysis.
 No Time Series Adjustments: dataset not adjust for variations in 24-hour periods might inconsistencies across regions.
 Model Validation: E-OBS initially developed for validating climate model simulations utility expanded to broader climate monitoring extreme event analysis.
 Future Updates: dataset updated regularly researchers ensure using latest version for analysis.

 Further Considerations:

 Data Quality: Like any observational dataset E-OBS limitations related to data quality, coverage potential biases. Researchers assess these factors before using data.
 Data Interpolation: E-OBS utilizes interpolation techniques to create gridded data can influence accuracy final product.
 Other Gridded Datasets: Comparing E-OBS to other gridded datasets (like ERA5 or ERA20C) can provide insights into strengths and weaknesses of each dataset.

E-OBS valuable resource for climate research monitoring particularly in Europe Its high spatial resolution daily data multiple variables open access make it valuable tool for understanding past present climate trends investigating climate-related events.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-fire-emissions-gfas
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-fire-emissions-gfas
cams-global-fire-emissions-gfas
detailed informative description of CAMS Global Fire Assimilation System (GFAS) data breakdown of what makes it valuable how used:
 Key Features of GFAS:

 Real-time Information: GFAS provides near-real-time data on fire locations, intensity emissions critical for understanding responding to ongoing fire events.
 Global Coverage: data covers entire globe comprehensive perspective on fire activity impact on atmospheric composition.
 High Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° resolution provides detailed spatial information accurate analyses of fire distribution regional impacts.
 Comprehensive Emissions: GFAS estimates emissions for 40 different pyrogenic species including aerosols reactive gases greenhouse gases complete picture of atmospheric consequences of fires.
 Plume Height Data: system provides estimates of smoke plume injection heights crucial for understanding fire emissions transported dispersed atmosphere.
 Data Availability: GFAS data available from 2003 to present long-term dataset for studying fire trends long-term environmental effects.

 Applications of GFAS Data:

 Atmospheric Modeling: GFAS data provides essential surface boundary conditions for global regional atmospheric chemistry models allows researchers forecasters to simulate predict evolution of air quality climate.
 Air Quality Forecasting: GFAS data important for improving air quality forecasts especially in regions affected by wildfire smoke allows for better planning mitigation of air pollution events
 Fire Management: data used to assess impact of fires on different regions ecosystems inform fire management strategies wildfire risk assessments.
 Climate Research: GFAS data contributes to understanding of role of fires in global carbon cycle climate change helps scientists quantify impacts of fire emissions on atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations radiative balance.

 Summary:
CAMS Global Fire Assimilation System is vital tool for understanding addressing impacts of biomass burning vegetation fires on our planet. Its real-time data comprehensive emissions estimates detailed spatial information make it invaluable resource for researchers forecasters policy makers to mitigate consequences fire activity.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-european-risk-extreme-precipitation-indicators
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-european-risk-extreme-precipitation-indicators
sis-european-risk-extreme-precipitation-indicators
detailed description of climate dataset focusing extreme precipitation in Europe breakdown key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: provide indicators extreme precipitation events in Europe focusing large-scale European trends localized impact on cities vulnerable to urban flooding
 Data Type: Gridded organized spatially into cells (grid boxes).
 Coverage:
 Horizontal: Covers all Europe
 Vertical: Surface only (no atmospheric profiles).


 Resolution
 Horizontal Varies depending on data source
 Vertical: Single level


 Temporal Coverage: Different periods covered depending on data source
 Temporal Resolution Daily monthly yearly 30-year statistics available
 Data Format: NetCDF-4 standard format for scientific data).
 Metadata Adheres to Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6.
 Source Produced by Copernicus Climate Change Service.

 Data Sources and Resolutions
 dataset combines sources:
 Data Source  Spatial Resolution  Temporal Coverage  Description

 E-OBS (European Observation System)| 0.1° x 0.1° | 1950-2019  Land-only observational data (gridded)
 ERA5 (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts, Reanalysis)| 0.25° x 0.25° | 1979-2020  Global atmospheric reanalysis observations models)
 ERA5-2km (Dynamical downscaling of ERA5) | 0.02° x 0.02° | 1989-2018  Higher resolution version of ERA5 focused on 20 European cities
 ECA&D (European Climate Assessment & Dataset) | 0.1° x 0.1° | 1989-2018  Meteorological station network data 
 Key Indicators
dataset includes indicators assess magnitude frequency of extreme precipitation events:

 Maximum precipitation: 1-day 5-day maximums
 Consecutive wet days: Maximum number days with precipitation exceeding 1 mm.
 Precipitation exceeding thresholds: days exceeding 20 mm, 90th 95th 99th percentiles of wet days
 Total precipitation: Monthly yearly sums
 Precipitation at fixed percentiles: precipitation exceeding 90th, 95th 99th percentiles over 30-year period.
 Precipitation at fixed return periods: amounts with return periods of 5, 10 25 50 100 years
 Standardized precipitation: Standardized values rank extreme precipitation events.


 dataset valuable for

 Climate change research trends extreme precipitation events Europe
 Flood risk management vulnerability European cities to urban pluvial flooding
 Urban planning Incorporating extreme precipitation projections into city infrastructure design
 Water resource management Planning for water scarcity flood mitigation.

 dataset provides comprehensive collection of indicators related to extreme precipitation events in Europe valuable insights for applications

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-uerra-europe-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-uerra-europe-pressure-levels
reanalysis-uerra-europe-pressure-levels
description of UERRA dataset clear overview key features
 Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection: Lambert conformal conic grid (565x565 for UERRA-HARMONIE, 1069x1069 for MESCAN-SURFEX)
 Horizontal Coverage: Europe northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic to Ural mountains
 Horizontal Resolution: 11km x 11km (UERRA-HARMONIE)
 Vertical Coverage: 1000 hPa to 10 hPa
 24 levels
 Temporal Coverage: January 1961 to July 2019
 Daily at 00, 06 12, 18 UTC
 File Format: GRIB2

 Data Assimilation

 3-dimensional variational data assimilation
 Combines model data observations
 Benefits Provides complete consistent dataset estimates biases improves data quality sparse data

 Regional Reanalysis

 Utilizes global reanalyses (ERA40 until 1978 ERA-interim from 1979)
 Advantages Higher horizontal resolution more regional details denser observation network integration

 Main Variables

 Geopotential: Potential energy relative to sea level (m2 s-2)
 Geopotential height: Altitude of pressure levels relative to sea level (gpm)
 Relative humidity: Relation between actual and saturation humidity (%) 0% (dry) to 100% (saturated).
 Temperature: Air temperature at pressure levels (K)
 U-component of wind: Zonal wind component (m s-1) positive for westerly winds
 V-component wind: Meridional wind component (m s-1) positive for southerly winds

 Related Variables

 Additional records UERRA data for height levels single levels soil levels available separately
 Forecast data Not accessible format available through CDS API

 well-organized informative description UERRA datasetIt clearly communicates dataset's purpose features potential applications.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/derived-near-surface-meteorological-variables
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/derived-near-surface-meteorological-variables
derived-near-surface-meteorological-variables
great description WFDE5 dataset comprehensive overview key features
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose provide meteorological forcing data for land surface hydrological models
 Source Based on ERA5 reanalysis product ECMWF
 Methodology Utilizes WATCH Forcing Data methodology similar WATCH dataset
 Resolution 0.5° x 0.5° horizontal single level vertically
 Temporal Coverage Hourly data from 1979 to 2019.

 Data Processing

 Re-gridding ERA5 data re-gridded to 0.5° resolution
 Bias Correction Monthly bias corrections applied using CRU GPCC data for temperature diurnal temperature range cloud cover precipitation wet days
 Elevation Correction elevation correction variations altitude
 Additional Corrections Corrections for varying atmospheric aerosol loading precipitation gauge observations included

 Main Variables

 Grid-point altitude (m): Altitude each point corresponding CRU grid points
 Near-surface air temperature (K): Derived from ERA5 2m air temperature corrected for elevation bias
 Near-surface specific humidity (kg kg-1) Calculated from ERA5 vapor pressure saturation vapor pressure elevation correction
 Near-surface wind speed (m s-1) Derived from ERA5 wind speed
 Rainfall flux (kg m-2 s-1) Calculated from ERA5 precipitation corrected for bias
 Snowfall flux (kg m-2 s-1) Calculated from ERA5 snowfall corrected for bias
 Surface air pressure (Pa): Derived from ERA5 surface air pressure with elevation correction
 Surface downwelling longwave radiation (W m-2): Derived from ERA5 data elevation correction
Surface downwelling shortwave radiation (W m-2): Derived from ERA5 data corrected for bias using CRU cloud cover aerosol loading.

 Additional Information:

 File Format: NetCDF 4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.7
 Versions: 1.0 (deprecated), 1.1, 2.0, 2.1
 Update Frequency: No updates expected.

 Overall provided comprehensive well-organized description of WFDE5 dataset clear, concise informative.
 suggestions for potential improvements:

 Add brief introduction Start introduction about significance of meteorological forcing data for land surface hydrological models.
 Expand on correction methods Provide more detail about specific techniques for bias correction elevation correction.
 Mention data availability Indicate where data can be accessed (e. Climate Data Store).
 Highlight potential applications: Provide examples of how dataset used in research modeling.

 By incorporating these suggestions enhance value of dataset description make it more comprehensive user-friendly.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-agrometeorological-indicators
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-agrometeorological-indicators
sis-agrometeorological-indicators
detailed description of AgERA5 dataset breakdown of information provided key takeaways:
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: AgERA5 provides daily surface meteorological data for agricultural agro-ecological studies
 Source: derived from hourly ECMWF ERA5 dataset high-quality reanalysis of global weather data
 Value AgERA5 offers pre-processed data saving users from complex task acquiring preparing ERA5 data
 Target Audience: Researchers modelers in agriculture agroecology related fields

 Data Characteristics:

 Data Type: Gridded (spatial data organized on regular grid)
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid (common geographic coordinate system)
 Coverage: Global (data covers entire Earth
 Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° high resolution more detail
 Vertical Coverage: Data single level varying depending on specific variable
 Temporal Coverage: From 1979 to present long time series
 Temporal Resolution: Daily (data collected daily
 File Format: NetCDF-4 (standard format for scientific data)
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.7 (ensures data consistency interoperability
 Updates: Monthly (dataset updated regularly

 Key Variables
 dataset includes comprehensive set meteorological variables relevant to agriculture:

 10m wind speed: Measures wind strength near surface
 2m dewpoint temperature: Indicates temperature air saturated with water vapor crucial for humidity calculations
 2m relative humidity: percentage of moisture in air relative to saturation point
 2m temperature: Air temperature near surface
 Cloud cover: Indicates proportion of sky covered by clouds
 Liquid precipitation duration fraction: Indicates fraction day when liquid precipitation (rain) occurs
Precipitation flux: total liquid precipitation received in a day.
 Snow thickness: depth of snow on ground.
 Snow thickness LWE: equivalent depth of snow if melted (liquid water equivalent).
 Solar radiation flux: solar energy reaching surface
 Solid precipitation duration fraction: fraction day when solid precipitation (snow, sleet occurs
 Vapour pressure: contribution of water vapor to atmospheric pressure.

 Benefits of AgERA5:

 Time-saving: Pre-processed data simplifies data acquisition preparation
 High Quality: from reliable reanalysis dataset (ERA5).
 Relevance: Variables relevant to agricultural agro-ecological modeling
 Spatial Resolution: High resolution allows for accurate analyses localized studies
 Long Time Series: Provides valuable historical perspective for research.

 AgERA5 dataset offers valuable resource for agricultural environmental research provides high-quality readily available meteorological data for agricultural agro-ecological studies.

630
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-cerra-model-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-cerra-model-levels
reanalysis-cerra-model-levels
detailed description of Copernicus European Regional ReAnalysis (CERRA) dataset breakdown of key information emphasizing important aspects:
 What is CERRA?

 Purpose: provide comprehensive consistent reconstruction of historical weather conditions over Europe
 Method: Reanalysis – combining weather model simulations with observational data using data assimilation techniques
 Data type: Gridded data values assigned to specific locations on grid
 Spatial coverage: Europe including areas Atlantic Ocean Ural Mountains
 Temporal coverage: September 1984 to June 2021 updates planned
 Resolution: 5.5 km x 5.5 km for high-resolution reanalysis 11 km x 11 km for ensemble members
 Vertical coverage: From 10 meters above surface to 1 hPa (about 10 km).

 Key Advantages of CERRA:

 High Spatial Resolution better representation of topography local weather patterns
 Assimilation of Surface Observations: Incorporates more surface data global reanalysis enhancing accuracy
 Consistency over Time: Provides consistent dataset spanning decades useful for long-term climate studies
 Data Availability: accessible through Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS).

 Understanding Limitations

 Data Gaps: quality of reanalysis influenced by availability quality of observations less past
 Uncertainty: reanalysis provides estimates essential to be aware of inherent uncertainties CERRA-EDA provides ensemble members to assess uncertainty

 Main Variables:

 Specific Humidity: Measures water vapor in air
 Temperature at different atmospheric levels
 U- and V-components of Wind Represent horizontal wind speed direction

 Applications of CERRA:

 Climate Change Research: Studying long-term trends variability in weather patterns
Weather Forecasting: Providing initial conditions for weather models.
 Impact Assessments: Assessing potential impacts of extreme weather events.
 Agriculture and Water Management: Analyzing water availability influence on crop yields.

 In Summary:
 CERRA dataset is valuable resource for studying past weather conditions climate over Europe. provides high-quality, spatially detailed temporally consistent dataset with wealth of information used for various applications consider limitations uncertainties associated with reanalysis data.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-hydrology-variables-derived-seasonal-forecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-hydrology-variables-derived-seasonal-forecast
sis-hydrology-variables-derived-seasonal-forecast
detailed description of hydrological seasonal forecast dataset breakdown key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides monthly mean river discharge forecasts across Europe for next 7 months
 Source: Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).
 Production: Operational production by C3S with Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS).
 Coverage
 Spatial: Europe
 Temporal: January 2021 to present 7-month lead time
 Resolution: Monthly



 Data Sources Methodology

 Hydrological Models
 E-HYPE multi-model system 8 model realizations catchment-based resolution
 E-HYPEgrid, VIC-WUR, EFAS (LISFLOOD): 5km gridded resolution


 Initial Conditions European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) daily gridded meteorological observations (EFAS-Meteo) start forecast
 Meteorological Forecasts 51 members of ECMWF seasonal forecast system 5 (SEAS5)
 Bias Adjustment: Quantile mapping for temperature precipitation applied to E-HYPE VIC-WUR models reduce bias in SEAS5 forecasts

 Key Variables

 River discharge primary output variable measured in cubic meters per second (m3/s).
 Reference river discharge terciles: Upper lower terciles of historical EFAS-Meteo driven simulations context for forecasts
 Skill metrics (Brier Skill Score Ranked Probability Skill Score assess forecast performance

 Additional Points

 Data Format: NetCDF-4 Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v.1.6.
 Update Frequency Monthly
 Versions current dataset version v1.0 utilizing EFAS forecasts v4.

 Applications
 dataset valuable for

Flood forecasting warning anticipate flood risks.
 Water resource management Provides information for planning managing water resources
 Climate change adaptation Offers insights potential changes in river flow patterns under changing climate conditions.

 Overall:
 dataset provides comprehensive robust tool for understanding predicting river discharge across Europe use multiple hydrological models bias adjustment techniques skill metrics reliable resource for various applications.

632
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-postprocessed-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/seasonal-postprocessed-single-levels
seasonal-postprocessed-single-levels
entry describes dataset of single-level climate data for seasonal forecasting breakdown information:
 What is Seasonal Forecasting?

 Seasonal forecasts predict changes Earth's climate over weeks to months
 forecasts based on predictable variations of slower-changing components climate system like ocean temperatures
 Unlike weather forecasts focus on short-term precise details seasonal forecasts provide broader outlook with higher uncertainties due to chaotic nature atmosphere
 To account for uncertainties ensembles multiple forecasts used providing distribution of possible outcomes

 Dataset

 contains single-level climate data focuses on single altitude or surface level
 data processed on monthly time resolution
 part of multi-system seasonal forecast service by C3S combines data from various European forecast centers
 dataset includes data from 2017 onwards updates released monthly.

 Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Horizontal Coverage: Global
 Horizontal Resolution: 1° x 1°
 Temporal Coverage: 2017 to present
 Resolution: Monthly
 File Format: GRIB
 Update Frequency Real-time forecasts released monthly on 6th for ECMWF 10th for other centers

 Key Variables
 dataset provides climate variables presented as anomalies (deviations from average). examples include

 Wind: 10m u-component v-component anomalies wind gust speed anomalies
 Temperature: 2m dewpoint temperature anomalies maximum minimum 2m temperature anomalies
 Surface: East-west north-south surface stress anomalies evaporation, runoff soil temperature anomalies
 Sea: Sea surface temperature sea-ice cover anomalies
 Snow: Snow density, depth snowfall anomalies
Radiation: Solar insolation surface latent sensible heat flux anomalies surface top solar thermal radiation anomalies
 Cloud: Total cloud cover column cloud ice liquid water anomalies total column water vapor anomaly
 Precipitation: Total precipitation anomaly

 Use Cases:
 dataset used for various purposes related seasonal forecasting including

 Understanding potential impacts climate variability on sectors like agriculture water management energy
 Developing evaluating seasonal forecasting models
 Supporting decision-making in fields disaster preparedness climate adaptation strategies resource management.

 dataset provides valuable information for researchers decision-makers stakeholders interested in using seasonal forecasts to understand prepare for climate variability.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/seasonal-monthly-ocean
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/seasonal-monthly-ocean
seasonal-monthly-ocean
comprehensive description of global ocean data set provides monthly resolution data on upper ocean temperature salinity. breakdown of key information significance:
 Data Provides:

 Global Coverage: Data covers entire world's oceans.
 Monthly Resolution: Data aggregated provided monthly basis capturing long-term trends in ocean conditions.
 Variables:
 Temperature: Includes depth-averaged temperature for upper 300m of ocean depth of specific isotherms (14°C, 17°C, 20°C, 26°C, 28°C).
 Salinity: Includes depth-averaged salinity for upper 300m surface salinity.
 Other Variables: Provides information on depth of mixed layer, upper layer of ocean where water well-mixed, sea ice thickness.


 Hindcasts and Forecasts: Offers combination of historical data (hindcasts) and real-time predictions (forecasts).

 Why Data Important:

 Seasonal Forecasting: Understanding ocean changes seasonally crucial for predicting weather patterns climate variations impacts on marine ecosystems fisheries.
 Climate Change Monitoring: Long-term data sets essential for tracking impact of climate change on ocean conditions, including temperature increases, changes in salinity extent of sea ice.
 Marine Operations: Information on ocean conditions crucial for shipping, fishing other marine industries.
 Research: dataset provides valuable data for scientists studying ocean dynamics, climate modeling marine ecosystems.

 Key Points:

 Data Source: data from Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), European Union initiative.
 Multi-Model Approach: data combination of outputs from multiple seasonal forecast systems, helps reduce uncertainties associated with individual models.
Regular Grid: data provided on regular latitude-longitude grid easy to analyze integrate with other datasets.
 GRIB and NetCDF: data available in both GRIB and NetCDF formats common standards for meteorological and oceanographic data.

 In Summary: global ocean data set provides valuable information about upper ocean's temperature salinity characteristics on monthly timescale. data vital for understanding ocean's role in climate supporting marine operations facilitating scientific research.

636
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-level-global
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-level-global
satellite-sea-level-global
detailed description of global sea level anomaly dataset breakdown of key information:
 dataset contains:

 Sea level anomaly: difference between actual sea level at given time location and long-term average sea level (calculated over 1993-2012).
 Absolute dynamic topography: height of sea surface above geoid (a reference surface for Earth's gravity).
 Geostrophic velocities: approximation of ocean surface currents derived from sea level data.

 Key characteristics of dataset:

 Global coverage: Data covers entire ocean.
 High resolution: 0.25° x 0.25° grid detailed information.
 Long temporal coverage: From January 1993 to present (with 5-month delay for processing).
 Daily and monthly data: Available for both time scales.
 Climate-oriented: Focuses on long-term trends stability suitable for climate studies.
 NetCDF-4 format: standard format for scientific data.

 Advantages dataset:

 High accuracy: Uses merged constellation of two satellites improve accuracy
 Long-term stability: for climate monitoring consistent data record.
 Open access: Available through Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).

 Potential applications:

 Climate change research: Monitoring studying sea level rise
 Oceanography: Analyzing ocean circulation variability
 Coastal management: Assessing flood risk planning mitigation strategies.

 Limitations:

 Latency: Data updated about 5 months after measurement.
 Potential biases: high-quality dataset potential sources of error in measurement.

 Overall dataset valuable resource for researchers decision-makers climate change, oceanography coastal management high accuracy, long temporal coverage global scope make robust tool for understanding complex dynamics of sea level implications.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-water-level-change-timeseries-cmip6
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-water-level-change-timeseries-cmip6
sis-water-level-change-timeseries-cmip6
detailed informative description of global sea level dataset breakdown of key elements potential uses:
 Strengths of Dataset:

 Comprehensive Coverage: dataset covers entire globe valuable insights into sea level changes across diverse regions
 High Temporal Resolution: 10-minute resolution provides detailed look at short-term sea level fluctuations crucial for understanding storm surge events
 Multiple Forcing Data: use of ERA5 reanalysis CMIP6 GCMs allows for robust assessment of sea level variability under different climate scenarios incorporating historical future projections.
 Uncertainty Quantification: multi-model ensemble from HighResMIP account for uncertainties in climate model projections.
 Standardized Format: NetCDF-4 format CF Metadata Convention ensure data interoperability ease of analysis.

 Key Variables:

 Mean Sea Level: Tracks long-term average sea level highlighting impact of factors thermal expansion ice melt ocean circulation.
 Storm Surge Residual: Separates impact of storm surges from other sea level drivers insights into extreme events potential for coastal flooding.
 Tidal Elevation: clear representation of natural tide cycle isolated from other sea level influences
 Total Water Level: Represents combined effect of all components comprehensive view of overall sea level change

 Potential Applications:

 Coastal Vulnerability Assessments: dataset model predict likelihood of coastal flooding erosion other hazards.
 Port Accessibility Studies: Sea level rise impact port operations navigation data inform infrastructure planning adaptation strategies
 Climate Change Impact Analysis: Researchers use dataset assess potential impacts of climate change on coastal communities ecosystems infrastructure.
 Sea Level Variability Research: high temporal resolution allows for detailed investigations of sea level fluctuations causes potential implications.
Model Evaluation and Improvement: dataset can be used to evaluate performance of existing sea level models inform development of more accurate future projections.

 Points to Consider:

 Vertical Reference Level: understand vertical reference level used in dataset, it affects interpretation of results.
 Model Limitations: GTSM is sophisticated model, still has limitations. Be aware of potential biases and uncertainties in model outputs.
 Future Projections: Remember future projections based on climate scenarios. Changes in emissions other factors can influence accuracy of these projections.

 Overall: dataset valuable resource for wide range coastal studies, providing comprehensive high-resolution picture of global sea level change. By incorporating data into research and decision-making processes, can better prepare for challenges of changing climate.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-c3s-global-temperature-trend-monitor
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-c3s-global-temperature-trend-monitor
app-c3s-global-temperature-trend-monitor
detailed description of interactive application to visualize analyze global surface air temperature trends particularly relation to 1.5°C limit in Paris Agreement. application combines real-world data with simple linear model user-friendly interface for exploring evolution of global warming
 breakdown of application's features, functionality limitations:
 Key Features:


 Data Visualization: application presents clear informative time-series plot.

 Monthly Temperature Anomalies: plot shows monthly average temperature anomalies relative to pre-industrial era (1850-1900).
 30-Year Trend: user-adjustable slider allows user to choose 30-year window application calculates linear trend for chosen period depicting as solid red line.
 1.5°C Limit: horizontal dashed red line represents 1.5°C warming threshold above pre-industrial levels.
 Trend Intersections:
 red circle and dashed line mark where linear trend intersects 1.5°C limit line indicating estimated future date when limit might be reached.
 vertical grey line represents selected month horizontal grey line and grey box mark global warming estimate at specific point in time.


 Uncertainty: orange shaded area on plot visualizes uncertainty range associated with past temperature values and future climate projections based on IPCC's 2018 special report "Global Warming of 1.5°C."
 IPCC 'Likely' Estimate: orange line indicates IPCC's 'likely' estimate of time interval global warming might reach 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.



 User Interaction:

 Slider: user can adjust 30-year window by moving slider changes linear trend line, 1.5°C limit intersection point current global warming estimate.
 Interactive Exploration: application allows users to explore how estimated date for reaching 1.5°C limit varies depending on chosen 30-year period.



Data Sources:

 Surface Air Temperature Data: application draws data from ERA5 reanalysis, comprehensive dataset covering global atmospheric conditions.
 Pre-Industrial Temperature: pre-industrial temperature estimated using IPCC's approximation for 1850-1900 average.
 Climate Projections: application uses climate projection data from IPCC to show uncertainty range around global warming estimate.



 Limitations:

 Simplified Model: application employs linear trend model simplification. useful for illustrating general trends, doesn't capture full complexity of climate change.
 Uncertainty: Despite IPCC's uncertainty range, application's projections should be interpreted with caution. Climate change is complex influenced by various factors future not predictable with complete certainty.
 Data Availability: ERA5 dataset starts in 1971 limiting scope application to post-1970s period.

 Purpose and Interpretation:
 application serves as monitoring tool primarily designed for illustrative purposes. meant to help users visualize evolution of global surface air temperature understand implications of 1.5°C limit. essential to results based on simplified model should not be interpreted as precise predictions.
 Potential Applications:
 application could be valuable for:

 Educational purposes: Demonstrating concept of global warming importance of 1.5°C limit.
 Public awareness: Highlighting urgency of climate action.
 Policy discussions: Providing visual evidence of trends in global warming.

 Overall interactive application offers straightforward intuitive approach to visualizing exploring evolving global surface air temperature data in context of Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target. not a forecasting tool, serves as valuable resource for understanding climate change and potential impacts.
---
639
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-carra-height-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-carra-height-levels
reanalysis-carra-height-levels
summary of CARRA dataset organize information into structured format
 CARRA (C3S Arctic Regional Reanalysis) Dataset
 Overview

 high-resolution regional reanalysis dataset focused Arctic region
 Provides 3-hourly analyses hourly short-term forecasts of atmospheric surface meteorological variables
 Covers two domains West (Greenland Labrador Sea East (Svalbard, Franz Josef Land

 Key Features

 High Resolution: 2.5 km x 2.5 km horizontal resolution higher than global reanalyses ERA5)
 Improved Accuracy Utilizes local observations from Nordic countries Greenland better representation of Arctic conditions
 Detailed Surface Description Incorporates high-resolution satellite physiographic data for enhanced surface characteristics
 Sophisticated Model Based on HARMONIE-AROME non-hydrostatic regional numerical weather prediction model
 Improved Physical Parameterization enhanced parameterization of clouds precipitation

 Data Characteristics

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection Lambert conformal conic grid different points for West East domains
 Horizontal Coverage
 West: Greenland, Labrador Sea Davis Strait, Baffin Bay Denmark Strait, Iceland Jan Mayen Greenland Sea parts Svalbard
 East: Svalbard, Franz Josef Land, Novaya Zemlya, Barents Sea Northern parts Norwegian Sea Scandinavia


 Horizontal Resolution: 2.5 km x 2.5 km
 Vertical Coverage 15 m to 500 m above surface
 11 specific height levels (15, 30 50 75 100 150 200 250 300 400 500 m
 Temporal Coverage From 1991 to present

 Analyses 3-hourly
 Forecasts Hourly up to 30 hours (initialized from analyses 00 12 UTC


File Format: GRIB2
 Update Frequency: Monthly

 Main Variables:
  Variable Name  Units  Description |
 |---
 | Pressure | Pa Atmospheric pressure interpolated to specific height level.
| Relative Humidity | % Relation between actual saturation humidity Values range from 0% (totally dry) to 100% (saturated).
 | Specific Cloud Ice Water Content | kg kg-1 Mass of cloud ice particles per kilogram total moist air.
 Specific Cloud Liquid Water Content  kg kg-1 Mass of cloud liquid water droplets per kilogram total moist air.
 | Temperature | K Air temperature at specific height level.
 | Wind Direction | Degrees| Average wind direction (0°: North, 90°: East).
| Wind Speed | m s-1 | Average wind speed from zonal meridional wind components.
 Importance of CARRA:

 Arctic region experiencing rapid climate change high-resolution data crucial for understanding predicting changes
 CARRA provides detailed accurate representation of Arctic atmospheric surface conditions compared to global reanalyses.

 Additional Information:

 Documentation section of CARRA dataset provides detailed information on reanalysis process input data specific variables
 dataset accessed through Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) website.

 Let me know if dive deeper into specific aspect of CARRA dataset

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/viewer-satellite-ice-sheet-elevation-change
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/viewer-satellite-ice-sheet-elevation-change
viewer-satellite-ice-sheet-elevation-change
information provided describes input variables data sources for application visualizes surface elevation changes in Greenland and Antarctica. detailed well-organized but few things could be improved:
 1. Clarity and Redundancy:

 information about "Rate of elevation change" repeated three times clearer to have it once with Greenland and Antarctica descriptions as sub-points.
 "Rate of elevation change uncertainty" section same explanation for Greenland and Antarctica. more concise to describe general method of uncertainty calculation once then state both Greenland and Antarctica use this method.

 2. Formatting:

 Using table format for input variables easier to read understand.

 3. Additional Information:

 helpful to know time period covered by application.
 Including information about spatial resolution of data beneficial.

 revised version of information incorporating suggestions:
 Surface Elevation Change in Greenland and Antarctica
 Application Description
 application allows users to visualize rates of surface elevation change across Antarctic and Greenland ice sheets shelves over time period since 1992. Negative elevation change rates indicate ice loss (red shades), positive rates indicate ice gain (blue shades). Trends in change rate established by comparing different time periods.
 Input Variables:
 | Variable Name | Units | Description | Source |

 Rate of elevation change | m year-1 | Surface elevation change for each pixel in grid. Measurements taken over period 5 years for ERS1 & 2, EnviSat, 3 years for CryoSat-2 and Sentinel-3 centered on 'time' timestamp. Satellite ice sheets elevation change 
| Greenland: Radar altimeter measurements corrected for instrument effects dry and wet tropospheric effect ionospheric delay surface slope. Height changes derived from repeat-track, along-track crossover plane-fitting algorithms. height change rate derived from weighted averaging of height change maps.
 Antarctica: Radar altimeter measurements over all surfaces corrected for instrument effects dry wet troposheric effect ionospheric delay solid earth tide geocentric pole tide ocean loading tide surface slope. Over ice shelves also corrected for ocean tide inverse barometer effect. Height changes derived from crossover method altimeters from different missions cross-calibrated using multiple regression method. height change rate derived from least-squares fitting. No filling applied to surface or time gaps.
 Rate of elevation change uncertainty  m year-1 | Fitting uncertainty of rate of elevation change. Satellite ice sheets elevation change 
 total uncertainty on surface elevation change is sum of two (Greenland) or three (Antarctica) components in quadrature. modelling component is standard deviation of surface elevation change linear least-squares fit. measurement component (Greenland) includes uncertainties on original altimetry measurements geolocation radar penetration volume scattering radar speckle atmospheric attenuation. In Antarctica additional cross-calibration component accounts for standard deviation of mission-pair cross-calibrations used in 5-year period.
 Additional Information:

 Time Period: application covers surface elevation changes from 1992 to present.
 Spatial Resolution: [Provide resolution of data, e. 1 km x 1 km grid].

By providing this information, users will to better understand data behind visualizations make more informed interpretations.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-ice-edge-type
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-ice-edge-type
satellite-sea-ice-edge-type
great summary sea ice edge type dataset outlines key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides daily gridded data sea ice edge type crucial for understanding climate change impacts
 Data Source: Passive microwave radiometer measurements satellites (SMMR SSM/I SSMIS).
 Parameters
 Sea ice edge Classifies sea surface into open water open ice closed ice based sea ice concentration
 Sea ice type Distinguishes multiyear ice seasonal first-year ice based age



 Data Characteristics:

 Data Type Gridded
 Projection: Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area (EASE-Grid version 2.0).
 Coverage:
 Sea ice edge Northern Southern Hemispheres
 Sea ice type Northern Hemisphere only (mid-October to April).


 Resolution:
 Sea ice edge 12.5 km resolution (~15 km true
 Sea ice type 25 km resolution (30-60 km true


 Temporal Coverage: 25 October 1978 to present
 Temporal Resolution Daily (every second day before 9 July 1987).
 File Format: NetCDF 4.
 Conventions: CF Metadata Convention v1.7 ACDD v1.3.
 Versions: v2.0 v1.0

 Main Variables

 Sea ice edge: Dimensionless classifies sea surface into 1: open water open ice 3: closed ice
 Sea ice type Dimensionless classifies ice into 1: no ice 2: first-year ice 3: multi-year ice 4: ambiguous ice

 Related Variables

 Status flag: Dimensionless indicates processing steps filters applied
 Uncertainty: Dimensionless statistical uncertainty of sea ice classification (0 to 1)

 Strengths Summary:

 Comprehensive Covers all essential aspects dataset
 Concise: Presents information clearly efficiently.
 Informative: Provides valuable context explanations of parameters variables.

 Overall, this is a well-written informative summary of sea ice edge and type dataset. helpful for users to understand dataset's capabilities limitations.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-uerra-europe-soil-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-uerra-europe-soil-levels
reanalysis-uerra-europe-soil-levels
summary of UERRA dataset provides climate information for Europe breakdown key information
 UERRA Dataset Overview

 Purpose Provides estimates European climate based model data observations
 Systems Relies on UERRA-HARMONIE MESCAN-SURFEX (surface analysis) systems
 Strengths:
 Data Assimilation Combines model data with observations to reduce biases improve accuracy
 Physical Laws Uses laws estimate climate conditions in areas limited data
 Gridded Data Provides consistent estimates across Europe on regular grid
 Long Time Period Covers period 1961 to 2019.


 Limitations
 Data Availability Data density varied over time impacting analysis quality
 No Feedback SURFEX operates offline output doesn't influence atmospheric models



 Data Description

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection: Lambert conformal conic grid
 UERRA-HARMONIE: 565 x 565 grid points
 MESCAN-SURFEX: 1069 x 1069 grid points


 Horizontal Coverage: Europe North Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic Ocean Ural Mountains
 Horizontal Resolution
 UERRA-HARMONIE: 11 km x 11 km
 MESCAN-SURFEX: 5.5 km x 5.5 km


 Vertical Coverage
 MESCAN-SURFEX: surface to 12 meters deep
 UERRA-HARMONIE: No fixed depths defined by time constants documentation


 Vertical Resolution
 UERRA-HARMONIE: 3 soil model levels
 MESCAN-SURFEX: 14 levels 0.01 m to 12 m


 Temporal Coverage: January 1961 to July 2019
 Daily analyses at 00, 06 12 18 UTC
 File Format: GRIB2

 Main Variables

 Soil Temperature (K): Model temperature at different soil levels
Volumetric Soil Moisture (m3 m-3): Amount water in soil
 Volumetric Transpiration Stress-Onset (m3 m-3): Soil water content after free drainage
 Volumetric Wilting Point (m3 m-3): Soil water content where plants wilt.

 Related Variables

 Other UERRA Datasets: UERRA dataset split into records based on height pressure levels single levels.
 Forecast Data: Forecast data not accessible through main interface accessed via CDS API.

 Overall
 UERRA dataset provides comprehensive valuable resource for understanding European climate combination of model data observations high resolution long time period useful for research applications.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/app-era5-explorer
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/app-era5-explorer
app-era5-explorer
comprehensive description of application visualizes historical climate data breakdown of features how works:
 Key Features:

 Interactive Map: Allows users explore climate data by clicking anywhere on global map.
 City Search: Users search for specific cities detailed climate statistics.
 Climate Variables: application provides data on
 Temperature Monthly averages anomalies frost days summer days tropical nights
 Precipitation: Monthly averages anomalies
 Wind: Monthly average speed direction gust speed.


 Time Period: application uses ERA5 reanalysis data period 1979-2020.
 Long-Term Averages: Data presented in comparison to long-term average period 1981-2010.
 Data Source: application relies on ERA5 high-quality global climate reanalysis dataset by European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).
 Performance: Designed for optimal performance in European cities slower processing for less populated areas

 Works

 User Input: Users select city or location on map choose desired climate variable
 Data Retrieval: application accesses ERA5 dataset retrieves climate data for nearest grid point (1-degree resolution) to chosen location
 Data Processing: application calculates requested statistics anomalies based on retrieved data.
 Visualization: processed data displayed in interactive charts, graphs visualizations

 Strengths:

 Global Coverage: Provides data for any location world
 High Data Quality: Utilizes ERA5 highly accurate comprehensive climate reanalysis dataset
 User-Friendly Interface: interactive map clear data visualizations easy to understand explore information
 Comparative Analysis: Allows users compare historical climate data to long-term averages identify trends.

 Limitations:

Grid Point Resolution: Data presented for nearest 1-degree grid point may not represent exact location interest especially in mountainous or coastal areas.
 Processing Time: time can be longer for less populated locations outside Europe.

 Overall:
 application provides valuable tool for exploring visualizing historical climate statistics useful for researchers educators anyone interested in understanding climate trends variability.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-sea-surface-temperature
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-sea-surface-temperature
satellite-sea-surface-temperature
comprehensive description global sea surface temperature (SST) dataset breakdown key information
 Dataset Contains

 Daily Estimates of Global SST provides daily measurements Earth sea surface temperature crucial for understanding weather climate ocean-atmosphere interactions
 Multiple Satellite Sources data derived from various satellite sensors AVHRRs ATSRs SLSTR long-term consistency coverage
 Different Processing Levels dataset offers various processing levels users choose data based needs
 Level-2 Pre-processed (L2P): Raw data satellite's original
 Level-3 Uncollated (L3U): Regridded L2P data global latitude-longitude
 Level-3 Collated (L3C): Global daily SST product compiled from L3U data
 Level-4 (L4) Spatially complete global SST product using data from multiple sensors



 Data Characteristics

 Gridded Data arranged regular latitude-longitude grid
 Global Coverage Level-3 Level-4 cover entire global ocean Level-2P products provide data along satellite's swath
 Resolution
 Level-2P 1km x 1km for ATSR/SLSTR ~4km x 4km for AVHRR
 Level-3 Level-4: 0.05° x 0.05°


 Temporal Coverage
 ATSR: 1992-2012
 SLSTR: 2017-present
 AVHRR & L4: 1981-present


 Temporal Resolution Daily
 File Format NetCDF 4.
 Conventions CF Metadata Convention v1.5, Unidata Observation Dataset v1.0.

 Main Variables

 Analysed Sea Surface Temperature Spatially complete estimate daily average ocean temperature at standard depth 20cm (only available for Level-4).
Sea Surface Temperature Anomaly at Depth (K): Difference between SST0.2m daily climatology available for Level-2 & Level-3 from version 2.1).
 Sea Surface Temperature at Depth (K): Ocean temperature adjusted to 20cm depth 10:30 local time (daily average available for Level-2 & Level-3).
 Skin Sea Surface Temperature (K): Temperature measured by satellite infrared radiometers at depth ~10μm available for Level-2 & Level-3).

 Additional Information:

 Uncertainty Variables: dataset includes variables quantify uncertainties measurements.
 Land/Sea/Ice Information: variable identifies each grid cell contains ocean land sea ice.

 Key Points to Note:

 Versioning: multiple versions of dataset latest v2.1. Use most recent version
 Temporal Gaps: Level-2P Level-3 products may have gaps in coverage depending on satellite missions.
 Data Availability: Level-2P Level-3C products served through Climate Data Store API Level-3 Collated Level-4 products available through catalog entry.

 dataset offers valuable resource for researchers scientists studying global ocean climate change related topics

satellite-ozone-v1
informative description of ozone dataset! breakdown of key information:
 Dataset Contains:

 Monthly averaged ozone values: data represents average ozone concentration for each month globally.
 Multiple data levels:
 Level 3: Data gridded on regular latitude/longitude grid presented as map of ozone concentration.
 Level 4: data processed by chemistry-transport model detailed information about ozone distribution.


 Climate Data Records (CDR) and Intermediate-CDR (ICDR):
 CDR: Covers longer time period including data from sensors no longer operational Designed for climate studies.
 ICDR: From active sensors updated regularly More recent data shorter delay.


 Zonal Averages: Ozone data averaged over specific latitude bands.
 Combined Products: Merged data from different satellite sensors.

 Key Features of Dataset:

 Global Coverage: Data collected from all world
 Multiple Resolutions: Different spatial resolutions available depending on product data level
 Long Time Coverage: Data spans from 1970 to present some sensors have shorter time spans
 NetCDF-4 Format: Data stored in standard format for scientific data sharing
 Multiple Versions: New versions released reflect improvements in algorithms, data processing bug fixes

 Data Represents

 Ozone Concentration: dataset measures amount ozone in atmosphere.
 Importance of Ozone:
 Stratospheric Ozone Protects life Earth from harmful UV radiation.
 Tropospheric Ozone: pollutant cause respiratory problems contribute to smog.



 Dataset Important:

 Climate Change Research: Understanding ozone levels changing over time crucial for climate studies.
 Air Quality Monitoring: data used to track ozone pollution impact on human health.
Satellite Remote Sensing: dataset showcases power of satellite data for monitoring Earth's atmosphere.

 learn more:

 Consult dataset documentation get specific details on products, variables algorithms
 Explore dataset on hosting platform to find specific data you need.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-uerra-europe-complete
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-uerra-europe-complete
reanalysis-uerra-europe-complete
detailed informative description of UERRA datasets. breakdown of key information:
 What are UERRA datasets?

 Reanalysis data: combine model simulations with observational data to create complete consistent picture of atmosphere, surface soil over Europe
 Focus provide essential climate variables (ECVs) for various aspects climate system including:
 Atmosphere (UERRA-HARMONIE)
 Surface and near-surface (MESCAN-SURFEX)
 Soil (MESCAN-SURFEX)


 Spatiotemporal coverage: datasets cover Europe from 1961 to July 2019 high temporal resolution (four analyses per day hourly forecasts).

 datasets created:

 UERRA-HARMONIE: 3D variational data assimilation system uses Optimal Interpolation method combine forecasts with observations every 6 hours producing best estimate of atmosphere's state.
 MESCAN-SURFEX: surface analysis system complements UERRA-HARMONIE provides estimates of variables like precipitation air temperature humidity using Optimal Interpolation method.
 SURFEX: land surface platform forced by downscaled forecasts from UERRA-HARMONIE and MESCAN analyses provides detailed information on surface variables soil processes

 Key features of UERRA datasets:

 High resolution: 11km for UERRA-HARMONIE 5.5km for MESCAN-SURFEX
 Multiple vertical levels: cover near surface, multiple height levels pressure levels soil depths.
 Consistent format: datasets provide data in standardized GRIB2 format
 Long-term coverage: over 50 years valuable resource for climate research.

 Benefits of using UERRA datasets:

 Complete consistent picture of climate: offer unified view of various aspects climate system.
 High resolution detail: Allow for regional analyses.
 Long-term perspective: Facilitate climate trend studies.
Convenience: Standardized format easy access through CDS and CDSAPI.

 Limitations:

 Limited temporal coverage: Data only available up to July 2019.
 Dependence on observational data: Quality density of observations influence accuracy of reanalysis.

 summary: UERRA datasets valuable resource for scientists researchers interested in climate studies particularly focused on Europe provide comprehensive high-resolution long-term view of climate system excellent tool for various applications.
---

649
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-methane
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-methane
satellite-methane
detailed description of atmospheric methane dataset breakdown of key information potential uses
 Data Contains

 Observations of Atmospheric Methane (CH4) dataset provides measurements methane concentrations atmosphere collected by satellite instruments
 Two Product Types:
 Column-averaged mixing ratios of CH4 (XCH4) represent average methane concentration entire atmospheric column from Earth's surface to top atmosphere
 Mid-tropospheric CH4 columns provide average methane concentration middle portion troposphere lowest layer atmosphere).


 Satellite Instruments data from instruments including
 SCIAMACHY/ENVISAT
 TANSO-FTS/GOSA TANSO-FTS-2/GOSAT-2
 IASI instruments Metop satellite series


 Data Levels:
 Level 2 (L2): satellite orbit tracks - raw data with geolocation information
 Level 3 (L3): Gridded - processed spatially averaged data grid


 Multiple Algorithms: Different algorithms WFMD, IMAP OCFP used analyze data from each instrument

 Key Characteristics of Dataset

 Coverage: Between 70°N and 70°S (most Earth's landmasses
 Resolution Varies by instrument data level
 L2: Ranges from 10 km (diameter) to 30x60 km2
 L3: 5° x 5°


 Temporal Coverage
 SCIAMACHY (L2): October 2002 until April 2012
 IASI (L2): July 2007 until December 2021
 TANSO (L2): April 2009 until December 2021
 TANSO-2 (L2): February 2019 until December 2021
 L3 products: January 2003 until March 2021


 Temporal Resolution
 L3: Monthly
 L2: Sampling frequency of sensor (more frequent)


File Format: NetCDF4 (a standard format for scientific data)
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast Metadata Convention v1.6 (CF-1.6) for easy data discovery use

 Potential Uses of Data
 This dataset valuable for applications in climate science environmental research:

 Climate Change Monitoring: Tracking changes in methane concentrations over time reveal trends assess effectiveness of climate change mitigation efforts.
 Atmospheric Chemistry Research: Methane key component of atmospheric chemistry understanding its distribution sources model atmospheric processes.
 Source Identification: analyzing spatial patterns in methane concentrations scientists identify major sources of methane emissions agriculture fossil fuel production natural sources like wetlands.
 Environmental Monitoring: data used to monitor air quality assess impact of human activities on atmosphere study effects of methane on climate.

 Important Considerations

 Algorithm Differences: different algorithms used for each instrument could result in slight variations in data important to be aware of differences when comparing results from different instruments.
 Uncertainty: All measurements have some degree of uncertainty. dataset may include information on estimated uncertainty associated with each measurement.
 Data Availability: data updated yearly check for latest version for complete information.

 Overall dataset provides valuable resource for researchers studying methane, climate change atmospheric processes. comprehensive nature of data including different instruments, algorithms data levels makes it valuable tool for gaining insights into important greenhouse gas.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-fire-radiative-power
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-fire-radiative-power
satellite-fire-radiative-power
detailed description Sentinel-3 Active Fire (AF) Fire Radiative Power (FRP) dataset breakdown key information
 provides

 Active Fire (AF) Radiative Power (FRP) Data products derived from observations Sea and Land Surface Temperature Radiometer (SLSTR) on Sentinel-3A -3B satellites
 Level 2 Summary Product text-based table summarizing Level 2 AF FRP data for given month across globe
 Level 3 Synthesis Products Gridded products process Level 2 data
 Daily Global Level 3 FRP Product 0.1-degree resolution grid separate layers for Sentinel-3A and -3B night-time land observations
 27-Day Global Level 3 FRP Product 0.1-degree resolution grid combining data from Sentinel-3A -3B matches satellite's orbital cycle
 Monthly Global Level 3 FRP Product 0.25-degree resolution grid matching MODIS Climate Modelling Grid (CMG) active fire product



 Purpose

 Summarize Simplify gridded products provide user-friendly version Level 2 data
 Consistent Gridded Format Suitable for global modeling trend analysis model evaluation
 Complementary to Fire Burnt Area used combination with fire burnt area data create long-term FRP time series

 Data Characteristics

 Data Type Gridded for Level 3 products point data for Level 2 summary product
 Horizontal Coverage: Global
 Horizontal Resolution
 Level 3 Gridded Products: 0.1° x 0.1° and 0.25° x 0.25°
 Level 2 Summary Product Point data based on 1km observations


 Vertical Coverage: Surface
 Vertical Resolution Single level
 Temporal Coverage From March 2020 to present

 Level 3 Gridded Products Daily, 27-day monthly
Level 2 Summary Product: time stamps active fire events monthly files.


 File Format:
 Level 3 Gridded Products: NetCDF4.
 Level 2 Summary Product: CSV.


 Conventions
 Level 3 Gridded Products Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.7 ESA CCI Data Standards [DSWG 2015].



 Main Variables:

 Active pixels: Number fire pixels grid cell.
 Fire Radiative Power (FRP): Rate heat output fire measured megawatts (MW).
 Mean Fire Radiative Power: Average rate heat output fire.

 Related Variables:

 Uncertainty: Measures reliability FRP measurements.
 Land, water cloud characteristics: Data describing conditions each pixel.

 Update Frequency: February each year.
 Summary
 dataset provides information active fires heat output comprehensive view global fire activity. various gridded products summary product cater different analysis needs

seasonal-original-single-levels
detailed description of dataset single-level seasonal forecasts by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S). break down information
 dataset?
 contains single-level long-range (seasonal) climate forecasts global area combines data from state-of-art seasonal forecast systems across Europe
 Key characteristics

 Data type: Gridded (data points on regular lat-lon grid
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Horizontal coverage: Global
 Horizontal resolution: 1° x 1° each grid box represents 1-degree square area
 Temporal coverage
 Hindcasts (retrospective forecasts): 1993 to 2016
 Real-time forecasts: 2017 to present


 Temporal resolution: Subdaily (6 hours) and daily
 File format: GRIB standard format for meteorological data
 Update frequency:
 ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts): released once per month on 6th at 12 UTC
 Other centers released once per month on 10th at 12 UTC



 variables included?
 dataset includes wide range of variables to atmospheric land surface oceanic conditions examples include

 Wind: 10m wind speed direction gusts
 Temperature Air temperature dew point temperature
 Precipitation: Total precipitation
 Surface conditions: Evaporation runoff snow depth sea ice cover
 Radiation Surface solar radiation surface thermal radiation
 Cloud cover: Total cloud cover cloud water content

 dataset important?
 offers valuable information for purposes

 Climate monitoring Assessing long-term trends variability in weather patterns
 Seasonal forecasting predictions weather conditions weeks months ahead for agriculture water management disaster preparedness
 Climate research Studying interaction of components Earth system influence on climate
Applications in various sectors: Agriculture, energy, transportation insurance, more.

 Additional information:

 dataset documented thoroughly providing information about data processing model details potential limitations
 multi-system approach reduce uncertainties associated with individual models.
 availability of hindcasts and real-time forecasts enables users to validate predictions assess model performance.

 Accessing data:
 data likely available through Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) portal find details about access, download options specific datasets.

sis-hydrology-meteorology-derived-projections
great description of climate dataset breakdown of key information means for users:
 dataset provides:

 Essential Climate Variables (ECVs): core measurements of climate system daily precipitation near-surface air temperature for Europe.
 Climate Impact Indicators (CIIs): derived from ECVs provide more readily usable form of climate information cover aspects related to precipitation and temperature like
 Highest 5-day Precipitation amount Useful for understanding extreme rainfall events
 Longest dry spells: Important for understanding drought risk.
 Number of dry spells: Related to drought frequency.
 2m air temperature: direct indicator of temperature change.



 dataset valuable:

 Regional Focus: focuses on Europe high-resolution data crucial for regional climate analysis impact assessment.
 Multiple Time Scales: Data available from 1971 to 2100 covering historical periods and future projections.
 Future Projections: Includes standard time periods (2011-2040, 2041-2070 2071-2100) and "degree scenario" periods (1.5°C, 2.0°C, 3.0°C warming).
 Accessibility: data provided in readily usable NetCDF format follows standard metadata conventions (CF and ACDD).

 Who dataset for:

 Researchers: use ECVs conduct in-depth climate analyses CIIs for quick efficient impact assessments.
 Water Management Sector: dataset designed for this sector relevant to other sectors like agriculture energy.
 Decision-Makers: access condensed climate information through CIIs to make informed decisions about climate adaptation mitigation.

 Additional points note

 Model Output: data based on simulations from regional climate models (RCMs), not direct observations.
 Bias Adjustment: ECVs bias-adjusted using observations improving accuracy.
Spatial Resolution: data available at 5km x 5km 0.11° x resolution providing detailed regional information.

 dataset offers valuable resource for understanding climate change in Europe potential impacts on various sectors.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/efas-reforecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/efas-reforecast
efas-reforecast
detailed description of European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) reforecast dataset breakdown of key information:


 Hydrological Reforecasts: dataset provides sub-daily reforecasts (predictions retrospectively of key hydrological variables across Europe driven by meteorological data from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).
 Focus on Flood Prediction: EFAS designed support flood forecasting emergency management providing information on river discharge soil moisture snow cover

 Key Features

 Spatial Coverage: Covers area from Northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic Ocean eastward to Caspian Sea
 Temporal Resolution: Reforecasts initialized twice weekly (Mondays and Thursdays) at 00 UTC 6-hourly time step 46-day lead time.
 Data Types: Includes
 River Discharge: Volume water flowing in river channels
 Soil Moisture: Water content in three soil layers
 Snow Water Equivalent: Mass water stored in snowpack


 Auxiliary Data: Provides additional static data like elevation soil depth soil properties to interpret hydrological variables

 Works

 LISFLOOD Model: dataset generated by running LISFLOOD hydrological model with ECMWF reforecasts
 Reforecasts forecasts run over past dates help assess accuracy forecast system improve future predictions

 Benefits for Users:

 Flood Risk Assessment: Provides valuable information for understanding flood risks planning mitigation measures
 Water Resource Management Aids managing water resources ensuring water availability
 Research Supports hydrological research climate change impact studies

 Additional Points

 Data Format Available in GRIB2 and NetCDF-4 formats compatibility with various analysis tools
WMO Standards: Adheres to WMO standards for GRIB2 accessible to meteorological communities.
 Related Datasets: CDS provides operational forecasts, historical simulations seasonal forecasts for broader hydrological analyses.

 this dataset valuable resource for stakeholders in flood forecasting water resource management hydrological research Its high resolution comprehensive nature provide powerful tool for understanding predicting hydrological processes across Europe.

sis-fisheries-ocean-fronts
great summary of ocean front dataset! breakdown of key information potential insights:
 Dataset Provides:

 Monthly Projections: dataset offers future predictions of ocean fronts change over time crucial for understanding impact of climate change on marine ecosystems.
 Spatial and Temporal Distribution: dataset maps where fronts located (spatial) and characteristics change over time (temporal).
 Front Strength, Persistence, Location: tracks key features of ocean fronts:
 Strength: strong gradient between water masses (measured by temperature or chlorophyll-a). Stronger fronts often more productive.
 Persistence: long front lasts in given area.
 Location: front situated relative to baseline.


 Multiple Data Sources: dataset created by combining data from
 Ocean Circulation Models: NEMO POLCOMS models ocean currents.
 Marine Biogeochemical Models: ERSEM biological processes.
 Satellite Observations: ESA CCI sea surface temperature chlorophyll-a readings.



 Key Applications:

 Fisheries Management: Predicting movement and strength of ocean fronts understand changes in fish distribution abundance.
 Marine Conservation: dataset inform efforts to conserve marine biodiversity particularly in areas linked to productive ocean fronts.
 Climate Change Impacts: dataset provides insights into climate change may alter ocean fronts associated marine ecosystems.

 Strengths

 High Resolution: models used fine spatial resolution for detailed analysis.
 Multiple Models: dataset combines multiple models comprehensive view of ocean front dynamics.
 Long Time Frame: projections extend into future valuable insights into long-term trends.

 Potential Insights:

 Shifting Fishing Grounds: Changes in front location could impact traditional fishing grounds.
Changes in Productivity: dataset could reveal ocean fronts stronger or weaker affecting marine productivity biodiversity.
 Effects on Marine Species: Understanding fronts affected by climate change can lead to better management strategies for marine species dependent ecosystems.

 Further Research:

 Validation Verification: Comparing model projections with real-world observations crucial to assess accuracy
 Ecological Impacts: Research on ecological consequences of predicted changes in ocean fronts essential.
 Management Strategies: Developing strategies to adapt to potential changes in front dynamics priority for sustainable fisheries marine conservation.

 dataset provides valuable resource for understanding potential impact climate change on ocean fronts potential to contribute to research on fisheries marine conservation broader understanding of marine ecosystems.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/efas-seasonal-reforecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/efas-seasonal-reforecast
efas-seasonal-reforecast
detailed description of hydrological dataset! breakdown of key information implications:
 dataset is:

 Focus: Modeled daily hydrological time series for Europe driven by meteorological reforecasts.
 Purpose: dataset used to assess flood risks understand hydrological conditions across Europe.
 Variables:
 River Discharge: water flowing in river at given point.
 Soil Moisture: water in soil at different depths.
 Snow Water Equivalent: water contained in snowpack.


 Model: LISFLOOD, open-source hydrological model, used to create simulations.
 Input: Seasonal meteorological reforecasts from ECMWF, provide weather predictions.
 Temporal Coverage: 1991-2020 daily forecasts initiated monthly.

 Important Points:

 Reforecasts: forecasts run over past dates assess model works.
 Ensemble: reforecasts use multiple ensemble members (25-51) range of possible outcomes to account for uncertainty.
 Spatial Resolution: 5x5km grid good balance between detail and computational efficiency.
 Copernicus CEMS: dataset part of operational flood forecasting system within Copernicus Emergency Management Service.

 data useful:

 Flood Prediction: Understanding river discharge and soil moisture predict potential floods.
 Water Resource Management: Assessing water availability changes over time.
 Climate Change Impacts: Analyzing hydrological variables respond to changes in weather patterns.
 Research & Development: Studying hydrological processes improving modeling techniques.

 Key aspects to note:

 Gridded data: data organized in grid covering Europe easy to visualize and analyze.
 Consistent representation: data provides consistent picture of hydrological variables across region, important for studying patterns and trends.
Auxiliary data: Additional variables (like elevation, soil depth.) provided to help interpret main hydrological variables.

 valuable dataset for stakeholders interested in understanding predicting hydrological conditions in Europe with implications for flood management, water resource management climate change research.
