657
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-albedo
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-albedo
satellite-albedo
detailed description of Earth surface albedo dataset breakdown key information for understanding
 What is Albedo?

 Albedo measure of sunlight surface reflects into space key factor in understanding Earth's energy balance climate
 Albedo values range 0 to 1 0 means no reflection 1 means all light reflected

 Dataset Overview

 Data Type: Gridded data organized as grid of values covering Earth's surface
 Projection: Plate Carrée common map projection in geographic datasets
 Horizontal Coverage: Global Land Surface dataset covers land areas Earth
 Horizontal Resolution: Varies by sensor:
 AVHRR: 1/30° (~4 km)
 VGT: 1/112° (~1 km)
 Sentinel-3: 1/336° (~300 m)


 Vertical Coverage: Top of the Canopy data represents albedo of vegetation canopy
 Temporal Coverage:
 AVHRR: September 1981 to December 2005
 SPOT-VGT: April 1998 to May 2014
 PROBA-VGT: October 2013 to June 2020
 Sentinel-3: July 2018 to April 2019


 Temporal Resolution: 10 days albedo calculated for each 10-day period
 File Format: NetCDF common format for storing scientific data
 Versions: Several versions dataset exist each with improvements additions
 V0: Brokered from Copernicus Global Land Service (CGLS)
 V1: Produced by Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), improved uncertainty estimates extended temporal coverage
 V2: Multi-sensor aspect added improved BRDF inversion climatological BRDF used for better data quality
 V3: Built with Sentinel-3 data more spectral bands currently pre-operational


 Update Frequency: Monthly updates dataset regularly updated with new observations

 Main Variables

Broadband Directional Surface Albedo (ALBB-DH): Measures reflection of direct sunlight (also called black-sky albedo).
 calculated for visible, near-infrared total spectrum.


 Broadband Hemispherical Surface Albedo (ALBB-BH): Measures reflection of diffuse sunlight (also called white-sky albedo).
 calculated for visible, near-infrared total spectrum.


 Spectral Directional Surface Albedo (ALSP-DH): Similar to ALBB-DH values given for specific wavelengths.
 Spectral Hemispherical Surface Albedo (ALSP-BH): Similar to ALBB-BH values given for specific wavelengths.

 Related Variables

 Error: Uncertainty estimate for each albedo band.
 QFLAG: Quality flag data quality.
 NMOD: Number of valid observations for 10-day calculation.
 AGE: Age of observation in days.

 Applications of Dataset
 vital for climate weather studies including:

 Climate Modeling: Understanding albedo influences Earth's energy balance
 Weather Forecasting: Albedo factor in determining surface temperatures atmospheric conditions
 Land Use Change Monitoring: Changes in albedo reflect changes in vegetation cover land use
 Environmental Studies: Albedo assess impact of deforestation other environmental changes.

 powerful dataset used to analyze understand albedo affects Earth's climate environment.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-carbon-dioxide
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-carbon-dioxide
satellite-carbon-dioxide
detailed informative description of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) dataset breakdown key information:
 Data Represents:

 Measurements of CO2: dataset contains observations of atmospheric CO2 levels by satellite instruments
 Focus on Greenhouse Gas: CO2 naturally occurring greenhouse gas human activities increased levels leading to climate change
 Seasonal Variation: data captures annual cycle in CO2 levels due to seasonal uptake release by vegetation
 Indirect Measurement: Satellites don't directly measure CO2. observe infrared radiation emitted reflected Earth contains spectral signatures of CO2.
 Retrieval Algorithms: Specialized software analyzes spectral signatures to determine CO2 concentrations

 Data Types Products:

 XCO2 (Column-averaged Mixing Ratios): Represents average CO2 concentration in entire atmospheric column.
 Mid-tropospheric CO2: Represents CO2 levels middle layer atmosphere
 Level 2 (L2): Data along satellite orbit tracks specific sensor retrieval algorithm
 Level 3 (L3): Data gridded on regular latitude-longitude grid.

 Key Features:

 Coverage dataset covers latitudes between 70°N and 70°S
 Resolution Ranges from 5° x 5° for L3 products to 10 km diameter for some L2 products
 Time Span: Extends October 2002 to December 2021 depending on specific instrument
 Frequency: L3 products monthly L2 products at sampling frequency of sensor
 Format: NetCDF4 compliant with CF-1.6 conventions
 Updates dataset updated yearly include latest data

 Important Considerations

 Algorithm Differences: Different retrieval algorithms have strengths weaknesses choosing appropriate product depends on application
Related Variables: In addition to CO2 dataset may include variables like pressure temperature water vapor aerosol properties crucial for accurate CO2 calculations.

 this dataset provides comprehensive valuable resource for studying monitoring atmospheric CO2 levels critical component of climate change research understanding.

efas-seasonal
detailed description European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) dataset valuable information for understanding hydrological conditions across Europe key aspects
 Data Overview

 Purpose Provides gridded modelled daily hydrological time series crucial for flood forecasting water resource management
 Model Based on LISFLOOD hydrological model driven by seasonal meteorological forecasts
 Coverage: European domain northern Africa to Scandinavia across Atlantic Ocean eastward to Caspian Sea
 Resolution: 1x1 arcminute (version 5.0), 5x5km (older versions).
 Variables
 River Discharge Flow rate m3/s averaged each 24-hour time step
 Snow Depth Water Equivalent Water mass equivalent to snow if melted measured kg/m2
 Volumetric Soil Moisture: Water content soil each three soil layers measured m3/m3 instantaneous
 Auxiliary Variables
 Elevation: Mean height above sea level
 Field Capacity: Water content retained soil after drainage
 Soil Depth each soil layer
 Upstream Area Total catchment area river flow each point
 Wilting Point Minimal water content needed for plant survival





 Temporal Aspects

 Forecast Frequency Initialized first of each month at 00 UTC
 Lead Time Forecasts extend up to 215 days future
 Time Step: 24 hours
 Coverage November 2020 to near real-time

 Data Format Accessibility

 Formats GRIB2 NetCDF-4.
 Adheres to WMO standards for GRIB2.
 Accessible through Climate Data Store (CDS).

 Key Points

 Ensemble Forecasts Driven by ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal forecast 51 ensemble members uncertainty analysis
Operational Forecasting: EFAS system used by Copernicus Emergency Management Service (CEMS) for flood forecasting
 Versioning: Versions vary based on forecast initiation date details included in metadata.
 Complementary Datasets: Additional datasets on CDS include seasonal reforecasts medium-range forecasts historical simulations for analysis climatological studies.

 Applications

 Flood Prediction and Warning: Forecasts essential for flood risk assessment early warning systems
 Water Resource Management: Provide information for optimizing water allocation irrigation planning reservoir management
 Climate Change Studies: Historical simulations used to study trends in hydrological variables under changing climate conditions
 Research: dataset offers input for hydrological modeling, validation development.

 dataset valuable resource for applications related to water resources flood forecasting climate change research high spatial temporal resolution availability of multiple variables make powerful tool for understanding managing complex hydrological processes in Europe.

664
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-glaciers-elevation-mass
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-glaciers-elevation-mass
insitu-glaciers-elevation-mass
detailed informative description of glacier change dataset provides comprehensive overview data including
 Key Features:

 Data Type: Point shapefile linked text attribute file
 Projection: Geographic Coordinate System: GCS_WGS_1984 (World Geodetic System).
 Coverage: Global
 Resolution: Individual glaciers (horizontally) single level (vertically).
 Temporal Coverage: 1850 to 2019.
 Resolution Annual to decadal.
 File Format: ESRI Shapefiles comma-separated value (CSV) text files.

 Content:

 Glacier Elevation Change Series
 Derived from geodetic methods (measuring glacier surface changes over time).
 Multi-annual changes (in mm), sometimes overlapping survey periods.


 Glacier Mass-Balance Series:
 Derived from glaciological methods (measuring difference between accumulation ablation of snow and ice).
 continuous annual measurements (in mm water equivalents).



 Important Notes:

 WGMS_ID: unique identifier for each glacier dataset
 Conversion: combine mass balance elevation change data elevation changes converted to annual change rates mm water equivalents using density conversion factor.
 Data Updates: dataset updated annually.

 Variables:
 description outlines variables dataset units descriptions includes

 Glacier Information: ID, region, name location (latitude longitude), political unit
 Survey Information: Date of survey investigator sponsoring agency reference to related publications.
 Glacier Change Data: Annual mass balance area elevation change associated uncertainties.

 Overall
 dataset provides valuable information about glacier changes crucial indicator of climate change impacts detailed description makes easy to understand data structure, content variables researchers scientists access utilize important resource
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/efas-forecast
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/efas-forecast
efas-forecast
comprehensive description European Flood Awareness System (EFAS) dataset breakdown key information relevance:
 What is EFAS?
 operational flood forecasting system developed by European Commission's Joint Research Centre (JRC). provides

 Hydrological Forecasts: Predictions of river discharge soil moisture snow water equivalent across Europe
 Early Warning System: predict prepare for floods reducing impact

 Key Features Dataset:

 Data Type: Gridded - Data arranged in spatial grid suitable for analysis visualization
 Projection: Version 5.0 uses regular latitude-longitude grid older versions use ETRS89 Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection
 Horizontal Coverage: Covers Europe from northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic Ocean to Caspian Sea
 Resolution: 1x1 arcminute (version 5.0) or 5x5km (versions 4.0 and older).
 Vertical Resolution: 3 levels for soil moisture surface level for river discharge snow depth water equivalent
 Temporal Coverage: 10 October 2018 to near real-time 30-day delay).
 Resolution Forecasts initialized twice daily (00 and 12 UTC) 6-hour or 24-hour time steps (depending version lead times up to 15 days.
 File Formats: GRIB2 and NetCDF-4.
 Update Frequency: Published on Copernicus Data Store (CDS) at regular intervals minimum 1 month lag.

 Main Variables:

 River Discharge volume of water flowing through river channel (in m3/s), crucial for flood predictions
 Snow Depth Water Equivalent: amount water in snowpack (in kg/m2) important for understanding potential spring melt runoff
Volumetric Soil Moisture: water within soil (in m3/m3) influencing agricultural productivity water availability infiltration.

 Related Variables:

 Elevation: Mean height above sea level (in meters), context for understanding water flow patterns
 Field Capacity, Wilting Point: soil properties determine water available for plant use influence drought conditions
 Soil Depth: Depth of soil layers (in meters), important for understanding storage movement of water
 Upstream Area: Area river catchment (in m2) water contributes to specific river segment.

 Importance of Dataset:

 Flood Forecasting: EFAS predictions crucial for early warning systems for timely preparation mitigation of flood risks
 Water Resource Management: data provides valuable information for managing water resources assessing drought conditions planning water infrastructure
 Agricultural Applications: Soil moisture information vital for farmers planning irrigation predicting crop yields
 Environmental Monitoring: dataset contributes to understanding dynamics of water cycles impact on ecosystems.

 Accessing Data:

 Copernicus Data Store (CDS): EFAS dataset available through CDS access to historical simulations reforecasts seasonal forecasts.
 Real-time Data: Real-time data available to EFAS partners.

 EFAS dataset valuable resource for understanding managing hydrological processes across Europe key role in flood forecasting water resource management environmental monitoring.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-reanalysis-eac4-monthly
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-reanalysis-eac4-monthly
cams-global-reanalysis-eac4-monthly
summary of EAC4, ECMWF Atmospheric Composition Reanalysis 4. breakdown of key information additional insights:
 What is EAC4?

 Reanalysis EAC4 global dataset of atmospheric composition combines model simulations with observational data
 Data Assimilation: uses complex system data assimilation similar to for weather forecasting system updates model with new observations accurate representation of atmosphere's state
 Long-Term Record: Unlike real-time forecasts EAC4 covers period 2003 to 2022 valuable historical record of atmospheric composition.
 Quality & Completeness: reanalysis process accounts for biases observations fills gaps in data coverage ensuring complete consistent global dataset.

 Data Description:

 Type: Gridded data (values assigned to specific locations on grid)
 Coverage: Global (covering entire Earth)
 Resolution: 0.75° x 0.75° (each grid box represents area roughly 80 km x 80 km)
 Vertical Coverage: Surface, total column one model level 25 pressure levels.
 Vertical Resolution: Detailed vertical resolution pressure levels from 1000 hPa (surface) to 1 hPa (high in atmosphere).
 Temporal Coverage: 2003 - 2022
 Temporal Resolution: Monthly (averaged over a month)
 File Format: GRIB standard weather data format converted to netCDF)
 Versions: Only one version (for consistency)
 Update Frequency: Twice a year 4-6 month delay for quality control further processing data

 Main Variables:

 Extensive List: EAC4 contains vast array of variables related to atmospheric composition including
 Trace Gases: CO, methane ozone formaldehyde
 Aerosols: Dust, sea salt black carbon organic matter sulfates
Meteorological Parameters: Temperature, humidity pressure wind.
 Surface Characteristics: Sea surface temperature snow cover vegetation indices.



 Key Points:

 Observational System: quality of EAC4 depends on quality coverage of available observations. observation networks improved over time EAC4 only available from 2003 onwards.
 4D-Var Assimilation: advanced technique considers timing of observations model's evolution within assimilation window for more accurate representation of atmospheric changes.
 Applications: EAC4 valuable resource for wide range of research applications including:
 Air quality studies
 Climate change research
 Atmospheric chemistry modeling
 Weather forecasting



 EAC4 highly valuable resource for scientists researchers interested in understanding analyzing atmospheric composition changes over time impacts on Earth's environment.

668
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-lai-fapar
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-lai-fapar
satellite-lai-fapar
detailed explanation of Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FAPAR) and Leaf Area Index (LAI) data products breakdown of key information:
 FAPAR

 Definition: fraction of photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) absorbed by green parts of plant canopy
 Range: 0 (no absorption) to 1 (complete absorption)
 Importance related to canopy's ability photosynthesis vital for modeling plant productivity
 Factors influencing FAPAR: Canopy structure leaf optical properties illumination conditions
 Relationship with reflectance: linear easier to estimate from remote sensing data

 LAI

 Definition: Half total area of green leaves per unit ground area
 Range: 0 (no leaves) to high values (dense canopies)
 Importance Measures size of interface between canopy and atmosphere influencing energy mass exchange.
 Factors influencing LAI: Plant species growth stage environmental conditions
 Relationship with reflectance non-linear estimation complex scale-dependent
 LAI vs. Effective LAI: Remote sensing observations sensitive to "effective" LAI assumes random leaf distribution Clumping of leaves can lead to discrepancies between actual effective LAI quantified by clumping index
 LAI vs. GAI: LAI only considers green elements "GAI" (Green Area Index) more accurate term LAI used for simplicity

 Data Products
 text describes evolution of FAPAR and LAI data products several versions with improvements over time:

 Version 0.0: Brokered dataset from Copernicus Global Land Service (CGLS).
 Version 1.0: Produced by C3S service utilizing neural networks validation from existing products Error propagation included
Version 2.0: Utilizes "Two-stream Inversion Package" (TIP) estimate LAI FAPAR from visible near-infrared broadband albedos provides effective LAI instead of actual LAI
 Version 3.0: Builds on Version 2 adding multi-sensor capabilities improving BRDF (Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function) inversion
 Version 4.0: Utilizes data from Sentinel-3 A/B SLSTR OLCI satellites

 Key Points

 FAPAR LAI crucial for understanding plant function ecological processes
 Remote sensing provides valuable data for monitoring variables over large areas
 data products undergone continuous improvements leading increased accuracy comprehensive information.

 Let know specific questions about FAPAR LAI data products
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-water-level-change-indicators

sis-water-level-change-indicators
detailed description dataset on European coastal sea levels breakdown information key aspects
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose provide insights into European coastal hydrodynamics under influence climate change
 Data Type Time-series data statistics sea level indicators at specific points European coast
 Spatial Coverage: Europe varying resolution depending proximity coastline (0.1° near coast decreasing to 1° further out).
 Temporal Coverage: Several periods included
 ERA5 Reanalysis: 1979-2017 (historical data
 Historical Simulations: 1977-2005
 RCP (pessimistic climate scenario): 2041-2070
 RCP 4.5 (optimistic climate scenario): 2071-2100


 Data Format: NetCDF-4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.6
 Source: Copernicus Climate Change Service

 Model Methods

 Model: Deltares Global Tide and Surge Model (GTSM) version 3.0
 Climate Forcing: HIRHAM5 model Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI), downscaled from global climate model EC-EARTH
 Sea Level Rise: incorporated into calculations
 Climate Scenarios:
 Historical (based past observations
 RCP 8.5 (high emissions scenario)
 RCP 4.5 (lower emissions scenario)
 ERA5 Reanalysis (recent historical data)



 Important Notes

 Uncertainty dataset based on single combination regional global climate models inherent uncertainty results may underestimate true variability
 No Temporal Resolution data provides statistics over defined time periods average annual highest high not actual time series data

 Key Variables
 dataset includes wide range variables grouped into categories

 Extreme Water Levels
 Annual highest/lowest high/low water
 Epoch-mean highest/lowest high/low water
Highest/lowest astronomical tides


 Mean Sea Level:
 (including sea level rise)


 Surge Level:
 level for different percentiles (likelihood of occurrence)
 different return periods (time between similar events)


 Total Water Level:
 level for different percentiles
 different return periods (includes tide, surge sea level rise)


 Tidal Range:
 Average tidal range



 Applications
 dataset valuable for various coastal sectors studies:

 Coastal Management: Planning adaptation to sea level rise extreme events
 Port Operations: Assessing potential impacts of rising sea levels on port infrastructure.
 Shipping: Understanding changing conditions for navigation marine transportation.

 comprehensive dataset valuable resource for analyzing impact of climate change on European coastal sea levels important acknowledge inherent uncertainty due to reliance on single climate model combination.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/satellite-aerosol-properties
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/satellite-aerosol-properties
satellite-aerosol-properties
detailed informative description of dataset on aerosol properties from satellite observations break down key information
 What dataset about?

 Aerosols: Tiny particles in atmosphere important for climate influence sunlight reaches Earth's surface
 Satellite observations dataset based on data by satellite instruments
 Variables provides information on
 Aerosol optical depth (AOD): light scattered absorbed by aerosols
 Fine mode aerosol optical depth (FMAOD): AOD for small aerosol particles
 Dust aerosol optical depth (DAOD): AOD for dust particles
 Single scattering albedo (SSA): proportion of light scattered by aerosols
 Aerosol layer height (ALH): average altitude of aerosol layer
 Aerosol extinction coefficient (AEX): light lost due to aerosols per unit distance.



 Why dataset valuable?

 Comprehensive view: Provides multiple aerosol properties detailed understanding of characteristics
 Complementary data: Data from different sensors processing techniques allow for cross-validation uncertainty assessment
 Temporal coverage: Data extends from 1995 to present updates every 6 months

 Dataset characteristics

 Type: Gridded data organized on grid of latitude and longitude).
 Resolution: 1° x 1° for most variables 2.5° x 2.5° for AEX
 Coverage: Global.
 Temporal resolution: Daily and monthly for most variables 5-daily composite for AEX
 Format: NetCDF standard for scientific data).

 Important details

 Data updates: New data added every 6 months delay of 5 months
 Versioning Version 1.11 has error (swapped variables) superseded by version 1.12.
Uncertainty: dataset includes variables related to data uncertainty allowing users understand reliability of measurements.

 Applications:
 dataset useful for researchers studying:

 Climate change: aerosols affect global radiation balance.
 Air quality: distribution types of aerosols in atmosphere.
 Atmospheric modeling: Improving accuracy of weather climate models.

 Overall dataset valuable resource for researchers scientists interested in understanding role of aerosols in atmosphere.

 Purpose

 dataset provides gridded climate data from global regional climate models (CMIP5, CMIP6 CORDEX).
 aims support users need more customized climate data than IPCC Interactive Atlas especially for regional analysis at national subnational scales

 Data Features

 Variables: 22 variables indices relevant for impact-drivers analyzed in IPCC AR6 focusing on
 Heat and Cold heating cooling degree-days frost days)
 Wet and Dry precipitation dry days)
 Snow and Ice snowfall sea-ice area)
 Wind wind speed)


 Spatial Coverage: Global (CMIP5, CMIP6) 11 regional domains (CORDEX)
 Resolution:
 CMIP5: 2°x2°
 CMIP6: 1°x1°
 CORDEX: 0.5°x0.5° (including EURO-CORDEX at 0.25°x0.25°)


 Temporal Coverage: 1850-2100 (depending on experiment)
 Resolution: Monthly or annual
 Format: NetCDF4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.9

 Relationship to IPCC AR6

 dataset direct product of IPCC AR6 Working Group I
 allows users to reproduce, expand customize climate change products in IPCC Interactive Atlas

 Key Advantages

 Provides high-resolution multi-model ensemble of climate projections for wide range of variables relevant for impact analysis
 Facilitates customized regional climate change assessments
Offers flexibility for users to explore specific scenarios, time periods regions.

 Limitations:

 Data frozen to version used for IPCC AR6 no further updates planned
 dataset fully reproducible for CORDEX from Climate Data Store (CDS), CMIP data may differ slightly.

 Overall dataset offers valuable resource for researchers practitioners policy-makers to access analyze climate change projections with high level of detail flexibility particularly for regional applications.

 Model Outputs: data comes from:
 GTSMv3.0: hydrodynamic model for water level indicators.
 SAW: Stand-Alone Wave model for wave indicators.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-soil-erosion

sis-soil-erosion
detailed informative description of rainfall erosivity soil loss dataset for Italy breakdown of key information useful
 Dataset Contains

 Rainfall Erosivity (R factor): measures potential rainfall to cause soil erosion calculated using empirical models considers rainfall intensity duration
 Soil Loss: estimated amount of soil lost due to water erosion calculated using Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE), combines R factor with factors like soil type slope land cover
 Precipitation Indicators: dataset includes precipitation indicators
 Maximum 1-day precipitation
 Maximum 5-day precipitation
 Number of days with certain amounts rainfall
 Total annual precipitation



 Dataset Structure

 Spatial Coverage: Italy
 Horizontal Resolution:
 High Resolution (≈500m): Available for R factor soil loss for ERA5-Land EURO-CORDEX output
 Native Resolution: Available for R factor precipitation for ERA5 ERA5-Land E-OBS EURO-CORDEX output (Exact resolutions depend on source data


 Temporal Coverage: 1981-2080 (2011-2020 excluded)
 Temporal Resolution
 Historical Period: Single value average for 1981-2010.
 Future Periods: Single value average for 2021-2050 2051-2080



 Data Sources

 Historical Data:
 E-OBS (gridded observations
 ERA5 (reanalysis data
 ERA5-Land (reanalysis data)


 Future Projections:
 EURO-CORDEX ensemble climate projections (under RCPs)



 Key Features

 Historical Analysis: Provides insights into past rainfall erosivity soil loss patterns
 Future Projections: assessment of potential future changes in erosivity soil loss
RUSLE Approach: Uses recognized validated method for soil loss assessment.
 Multiple Data Sources: Integrates various sources precipitation data increasing reliability
 Gridded Data: Provides spatially explicit information across Italy.

 Applications

 Environmental Planning: Assess areas vulnerable to soil erosion prioritize conservation efforts
 Agriculture: Identify areas soil erosion significant risk for crop production
 Water Resources Management: Evaluate impact erosion on water quality sediment transport
 Climate Change Adaptation: Understand changing precipitation patterns influence future erosion risks
 Land Management: Develop strategies for reducing soil erosion mitigating negative impacts.

 Additional Notes

 Bias Correction: dataset notes bias-corrected precipitation data used for future projections improves accuracy of projections by accounting for systematic errors in climate models
 Documentation: mention "documentation suggests detailed information about specific models methods data processing available.

 dataset valuable resource for understanding managing soil erosion risks in Italy provides comprehensive analysis of historical future trends inform stakeholders in decision-making processes

678
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-observations-gnss
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-observations-gnss
insitu-observations-gnss
detailed description of dataset containing estimates of water vapor from GNSS radio signals breakdown of key information
 Data Overview

 Purpose: dataset provides estimates of atmospheric water vapor content using data from ground-based GNSS receivers
 Source: Data from International GNSS Service (IGS) EUREF Permanent Network (EPN).
 Data Type: Point data represents measurements at specific locations
 Coverage: Global horizontal coverage temporal coverage starting in 1996.
 Resolution: Hourly data
 Format: CSV (Comma-Separated Values) files
 Availability: Available exclusively through Climate Data Store (CDS).

 Data Acquisition and Processing

 GNSS Signals: dataset relies on delay of GNSS signals atmosphere "Zenith Total Delay" (ZTD).
 ZTD ZTD measure of delay by atmospheric refraction bending of GNSS signal related to water vapor in atmosphere
 Retrieval: ZTD measurements combined with ancillary meteorological data at GNSS station to retrieve total water vapor in atmospheric column known as Total Column Water Vapor (TCWV).
 TCWV integrated quantity also referred to as Total Precipitable Water (TPW), Integrated Precipitable Water (IPW), or Integrated Water Vapor (IWV).

 Data Products

 IGS: IGS provides daily near-real-time products of ZTD and TCWV
 EPN EPN provides second reprocessing campaign (EPN-repro2) includes tropospheric parameters (including TCWV) from consistently reprocessed data over multiple decades
 ERA5 comparison dataset includes TCWV values retrieved from ECMWF ERA5 reanalysis

 Data Formats

csv-lev: One row per report all variables as individual columns in single row.
 csv-obs: One row per observable each row containing information about single variable.

 Main Variables

 Total Column Water Vapor (TCWV): primary variable of interest representing total water vapor in atmospheric column
 Total Column Water Vapor Combined Uncertainty: combined sum of all uncertainties in TCWV from ZTD and ancillary data
 Total Column Water Vapor ERA5: TCWV values retrieved from ERA5 reanalysis.
 Zenith Total Delay (ZTD): delay of GNSS signal due to atmospheric refraction bending
 Zenith Total Delay Random Uncertainty: estimate of uncertainty in ZTD measurement.

 Related Variables

 City: location of GNSS receiver
 Height of Station Above Sea Level: altitude station
 Latitude/Longitude: geographic coordinates of station
 Organisation Name: agency responsible for station
 Station Name: name of GNSS receiving station
 Start Date: first date time of data available station
 Report Timestamp: date time of observation
 Sensor Altitude: difference between GNSS antenna height and WGS-84 ellipsoid.

 Important Considerations

 IGS Data: daily IGS ZTD TCWV products near-real-time might contain jumps in time series when processing models updated not considered reference products.
 EPN-repro2: Provides more consistent reliable dataset spans multiple decades.
 ERA5: Provides independent source of TCWV values for comparison

 dataset offers valuable information about atmospheric water vapor content from GNSS signals suitable for various applications climate research weather forecasting atmospheric modeling
---
679
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-uerra-europe-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-uerra-europe-single-levels
reanalysis-uerra-europe-single-levels
detailed description of UERRA dataset breakdown of key information:
 Dataset Overview

 reanalysis dataset of surface near-surface climate variables for Europe covering long period from 1961 to 2019.
 Purpose Provides consistent high-resolution estimates of climate variables useful for climate studies applications
 Data sources:
 UERRA-HARMONIE: 3D variational data assimilation system for atmospheric analysis
 MESCAN-SURFEX: complementary system analyzes surface data using Optimal Interpolation method.
 SURFEX: land surface model simulates surface processes driven by outputs from UERRA-HARMONIE and MESCAN



 Data Characteristics

 Data type: Gridded organized on regular grid covering spatial domain
 Projection: Lambert Conformal Conic Projection common projection for regional datasets
 Horizontal Coverage: Europe from northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic to Ural Mountains.
 Horizontal Resolution:
 UERRA-HARMONIE: 11 km x 11 km
 MESCAN-SURFEX: 5.5 km x 5.5 km


 Vertical Coverage: Near surface single level
 Temporal Coverage: January 1961 to July 2019.
 Analyses available daily at 00, 06, 12, 18 UTC
 File Format: GRIB2 used format for meteorological data

 Strengths of UERRA Dataset

 High Resolution: capturing more regional details than global reanalyses
 Long Period: Covers over 50 years of data valuable for long-term climate studies
 Consistent Format: Ensures data homogeneous easy to work with.
 Data Assimilation: Combines observations with model simulations improving data quality filling in gaps in coverage
 Advanced Surface Processes: use of SURFEX allows for realistic representation of surface variables processes

 Limitations

Temporal Resolution: provides analyses (snapshots at specific times.
 Observational Network: density of observations varied over time potentially affecting data quality earlier years.
 Forecast Data: only available through CDS-API not directly dataset described.

 Key Variables
 dataset provides rich suite of variables including:

 Wind (direction speed)
 Air Temperature
 Relative Humidity
 Cloud Cover
 Precipitation
 Land Sea Mask
 Surface Pressure
 Orography
 Snow Properties
 Surface Temperature
 Surface Fluxes

 Accessing Data
 dataset available through CDS-API programmatic interface for accessing data
 Conclusion
 UERRA dataset offers valuable resource for climate scientists researchers studying European climate variability change high resolution long period of coverage robust data assimilation make powerful tool for climate-related research applications.

insitu-observations-surface-land
comprehensive description of global land surface meteorological data set breakdown key information:
 Data Overview

 Source: data set collaboration between Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI), World Data Centre for meteorology
 Scope: provides access to land surface meteorological observations collected globally
 Temporal Coverage: Data spans 1755 to 2020 exact period record varying by station
 Spatial Coverage: Global land data from numerous stations Numbers provided for daily monthly sub-daily stations.
 Resolution: Data available at sub-daily, daily monthly aggregations

 Data Quality

 Harmonized Quality-Controlled: Data collated, reconciled quality-controlled
 Potential Biases: No explicit bias assessment performed

 Data Availability and Access

 Formats: Data provided in CSV (comma-separated values) format
 Deposition Service: Users contribute new data sources through data deposition service
 Inventory station inventory provided detailing station name location start/end dates available variables.
 Documentation: product user guide common data model documentation available for detailed information

 Variables Measured
 data set includes measurements for range of commonly observed variables:

 Accumulated Precipitation: Total precipitation over specified period
 Air Pressure: Atmospheric pressure at station's height
 Air Pressure at Sea Level: Pressure reduced to sea level
 Air Temperature: Air temperature (bulk
 Dew Point Temperature: Temperature air reaches saturation
 Fresh Snow: New snow accumulated between observations
 Snow Depth: Vertical distance from snow surface to ground
 Snow Water Equivalent: Surface snow amount
 Wind from Direction: Direction wind blowing
 Wind Speed: magnitude wind velocity

 Key Points for Users

Data Quality Assessment: Users advised to perform own assessment of long-term data quality especially for applications requiring high accuracy.
 Variable Availability: availability variables varies by aggregation timescale station.
 Attributes: data set includes metadata attributes users to select essential attributes or all attributes.

 data set valuable resource for climate scientists researchers users interested in global land surface meteorological observations. combination of extensive data coverage harmonization efforts accessible documentation makes it useful resource for various applications.

app-marine-spatial-planning-explorer
detailed informative description of Marine Spatial Planning (MSP) application integrate climate change modelling data into decision-making breakdown of key components significance:
 Core Features:

 Integration of Climate Modeling Data: application leverages European Regional Seas Ecosystem model (ERSEM) by global climate models (CMIP5) downscaled atmospheric data (RCA4) allows users to access analyze projections of key oceanographic variables including
 Mole concentration of nitrate and nitrite
 Net primary production
 Sea water pH
 Sea water potential temperature


 MSP-Specific Modeling Analysis: application employs Hedges' g statistic quantifies climate change trends helps users identify
 Areas where climate change most significant impact on ocean variables
 Regions where specific variables (temperature, dissolved oxygen experiencing greatest change


 Visualisation and Interactive Map: Users explore data through interactive map
 Select predefined areas define own areas of interest or click on specific locations to access data
 Visualize calculated Hedges' g statistic understand magnitude of climate change impacts in selected region.



 Benefits:

 Adaptive Decision-Making: application provides powerful tool for MSP practitioners to incorporate climate change projections into planning processes facilitates
 Identification of vulnerable resilient marine ecosystems
 Assessment of potential impacts of climate change on human activities in marine environment
 Prioritization of conservation efforts management strategies


 Improved Sustainability: By incorporating climate change scenarios into MSP application helps ensure sustainable use of marine resources account long-term effects of climate change on marine ecosystems industries depend on them.

 Strengths:

 Data Availability: application draws on robust climate modeling datasets providing comprehensive reliable information.
User-Friendly Interface: interactive map visual representations of data make accessible for users with varying levels expertise.
 Timely Information: decadal resolution data allows for direct alignment with European Union's MSP Directive assessment cycle.
 Collaboration: application co-designed with MSP practitioners meets their specific needs integrates seamlessly into workflow.

 Limitations:

 Model Uncertainty: data used based on robust models, projections subject to inherent uncertainty. Users should be aware of this limitation consider multiple scenarios.
 Simplified Representation: models may not capture all complex interactions feedbacks within marine ecosystems.

 Overall:
 This MSP application represents significant advancement in integration of climate change projections into marine management practices. providing accessible informative data analysis tools empowers MSP practitioners to make informed decisions consider evolving challenges by climate change contributing to sustainable use of marine resources.

 Climate Change Impacts: dataset assesses impacts of climate change on sea level providing absolute relative changes for future period compared to present.

 Policy and Decision Making: data provides evidence to support policy decisions regarding climate change adaptation mitigation strategies.

 dataset based on high-emission scenario SSP5-8.5 represents future with continued high greenhouse gas emissions
 vertical reference level is mean sea level (MSL) over 1986-2005 reference period.
dataset produced by Copernicus Climate Change Service.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-carra-model-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-carra-model-levels
reanalysis-carra-model-levels
detailed description of C3S Arctic Regional Reanalysis (CARRA) dataset breakdown of information emphasizing key points potential uses:
 CARRA Offers:

 High-resolution reanalysis: CARRA provides detailed picture of atmospheric conditions in Arctic beyond capabilities global reanalysis datasets like ERA5.
 Focus on Arctic: CARRA targets Arctic region offering greater accuracy and detail for crucial area experiencing rapid climate change.
 Multiple variables: provides data for temperature, humidity wind clouds precipitation turbulent kinetic energy for comprehensive analysis of Arctic atmosphere.
 Analysis and forecasts: CARRA offers 3-hourly analyses) and hourly short-term forecasts for retrospective and predictive studies.

 Key Features:

 High resolution: 2.5 km grid resolution allows for capturing finer-scale atmospheric features events missed by coarser global datasets.
 Local observations: CARRA incorporates local observations from Nordic countries Greenland enhancing accuracy
 Improved surface representation: High-resolution satellite physiographic data provide realistic depiction of Arctic's diverse surface including snow cover, sea ice topography.
 Non-hydrostatic dynamics: HARMONIE-AROME model is non-hydrostatic better represent dynamics of atmosphere particularly in mountainous complex terrain areas.

 Data Details

 Domains: CARRA covers two domains: West (Greenland, Iceland, Baffin Bay) and East (Svalbard, Barents Sea, Scandinavia,.).
 Vertical coverage: Data extends from 12 meters above surface to 10 hPa (high in atmosphere), 65 vertical levels.
 Temporal coverage: Data goes back to 1991 updated monthly.
 File format: GRIB2, widely used format for meteorological data.

 Potential Uses:

Climate change research: CARRA valuable resource for studying changing Arctic climate particularly effects on air temperature precipitation sea ice.
 Weather forecasting: short-term forecasts support improved forecasting for Arctic regions especially extreme events like storms blizzards.
 Environmental studies: Researchers use CARRA to analyze influence of Arctic weather patterns on ecosystems air quality human activities.
 Model evaluation: CARRA provides high-resolution data for validating improving accuracy of global climate models.

 Overall CARRA powerful tool for understanding Arctic atmosphere changing dynamics high resolution local data incorporation focus on Arctic make valuable resource for climate research weather forecasting environmental studies.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cordex-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cordex-single-levels
projections-cordex-single-levels
detailed description of CORDEX (Coordinated Regional Downscaling Experiment) dataset breakdown of key information
 What is CORDEX?

 research project producing high-resolution regional climate model (RCM) simulations for regions
 RCMs downscale climate projections from global climate models providing detailed regional local information

 Why CORDEX important?

 RCMs provide accurate representations of regional climate characteristics extreme events crucial for
 Climate impact studies
 Adaptation decisions



 CORDEX Experiments

 CORDEX uses types experiments to address uncertainties future climate change
 Evaluation: Driven by reanalysis data evaluate quality of RCMs
 Historical: Covers period with modern climate observations assess RCMs simulate past climate.
 Scenario: Uses Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) project future climate scenarios



 CORDEX Data

 Data type Gridded data covering Europe (from 27°N to 72°N 22°W to 45°E).
 Resolution: 0.11° x 0.11° horizontal single vertical level (varies depending variable).
 Temporal coverage: 1950-2100 (shorter for some experiments).
 Temporal resolution: 3h, 6h daily monthly seasonal
 Format: NetCDF4.

 Variables
 description comprehensive list of variables in CORDEX dataset including

 Wind: 10m wind speed u/v-components at various levels
 Humidity: 2m relative humidity 2m specific humidity
 Temperature: 2m temperature
 Pressure: Mean sea level pressure surface pressure
 Radiation: Surface solar radiation surface thermal radiation surface upwelling shortwave radiation
 Precipitation: Mean precipitation flux
 Cloud Cover: Total cloud cover
 Run-off: Total run-off flux

Key Points to Highlight:

 Ensemble Members: CORDEX includes ensemble members for each RCM-GCM combination accounting for uncertainties related to natural climate variability.
 Versioning: description notes different versions data (e.g "v1", "v2") highlights corrections updates made.
 Data Availability: data available through Climate Data Store (CDS) likely other climate data portals.

 Overall valuable resource for interested European climate research CORDEX data provides rich detailed dataset for analyzing past, present future climate patterns.

692
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-reanalysis-eac4
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-reanalysis-eac4
cams-global-reanalysis-eac4
detailed informative description of ECMWF Atmospheric Composition Reanalysis 4 (EAC4) dataset breakdown of key information:
 What is EAC4?

 Global Reanalysis: comprehensive globally complete dataset of atmospheric composition spanning over two decades (2003-2022).
 Data Assimilation: uses combination model simulations real-world observations satellite data ground stations create consistent picture of atmosphere
 4D-Var: EAC4 uses assimilation technique 4D-Var accounts for timing of observations model evolution within 12-hour window.
 High Resolution: provides data at 0.75° x 0.75° horizontal resolution covers surface total column model levels pressure levels
 3-Hourly Updates: assimilation done every 12 hours EAC4 provides estimates every 3 hours.

 Advantages of EAC4:

 Globally Complete: Provides consistent data for entire globe
 High Quality: Combines multiple sources data newer improved versions observations
 Comprehensive: Covers wide range of atmospheric components including pollutants gases aerosols meteorological variables
 User-Friendly: Available in standard format (GRIB), optional conversion to netCDF.
 Long Time Span: Allows for long-term studies of atmospheric trends.

 Limitations:

 Data Coverage: Data quality varies depending on density of observation networks Sparse networks earlier years lead to less accurate estimates
 Start Date: Due to data limitations EAC4 starts in 2003.

 Key Variables:
 provided table lists massive variables covering:

 Meteorological variables: Wind temperature pressure humidity cloud cover.
 Trace gases: Ozone, carbon monoxide methane nitrogen oxides.
Aerosols: Dust, sea salt sulphate black carbon organic matter.
 Surface properties: Vegetation cover land-sea mask soil properties.

 Uses of EAC4:

 Climate Research: Analyzing long-term trends in atmospheric composition understanding climate change impacts
 Air Quality Studies: Assessing air pollution levels identifying sources sinks of pollutants
 Weather Forecasting: Improving weather models forecasts
 Atmospheric Chemistry Research: Understanding atmospheric chemical processes impact on environment.

 Summary
 EAC4 valuable resource for researchers scientists on atmospheric science topics high-resolution data long time span comprehensive coverage of variables make essential tool for understanding atmosphere changes.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-observations-woudc-ozone-total-column-and-profiles
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-observations-woudc-ozone-total-column-and-profiles
insitu-observations-woudc-ozone-total-column-and-profiles
detailed description ozone observation dataset provided valuable information organize easier understand use
 breakdown key information
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose Collects provides long-term access ozone column vertical profile data from World Meteorological Organization's Global Atmosphere Watch (GAW) network
 Data Types
 Total Column Ozone Estimates based on solar UV radiation measurements from ground-based spectrophotometers (Dobson or Brewer).
 Vertical Profiles of Ozone Concentration estimated from ozonesonde observations


 Sources:
 159 Dobson stations
 109 Brewer stations
 135 ozonesonde stations


 Data Availability
 Total column ozone: 1924 to present (start date depends on station)
 Ozone profiles: 1962 to present (start date depends on station


 Data Formats: CSV files (two formats):
 One row per level Each contains all variables for specific height
 One row per observation Each information about one variable at one level



 Data Characteristics

 Horizontal Coverage: Global (403 stations)
 Vertical Coverage:
 Ozone profiles Mandatory range 1000 to 10 hPa (some profiles may extend beyond
 Total column ozone Represents entire atmospheric column


 Vertical Resolution
 Ozone profiles 16 mandatory levels (10, 20, 30 50, 70, 100, 150, 200, 250 300 400, 500, 700, 850, 925, 1000 hPa) plus variable significant levels
 Total column ozone single level


 Temporal Resolution: Sub-daily

 Main Variables
 Variable Name Units Description

 Air Temperature Level air temperature
| Column Sulphur Dioxide | Dobson-units | Daily total column SO2 amount |
 | Geopotential Height | m | Geopotential height in meters |
 | Ozone Partial Pressure | Pa | Level partial pressure ozone in Pascals |
| Relative Humidity | % | Percentage of water vapor relative to saturation |
 | Total Ozone Column | Dobson-units | Daily value of total column ozone |
| Total Ozone Column Standard Deviation | Dimensionless | Estimated standard deviation of total column ozone measurements |
| Wind from Direction | °  Direction wind |
| Wind Speed | m s-1 | Wind speed in meters per second |
 Related Variables (CSV Columns)
 section provides detailed list of auxiliary variables in CSV files helpful for understanding context of observations data collected use list to identify relevant variables for specific analysis.
 Key Points

 Data quality: data undergoes quality control archived by World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC).
 Dataset importance: used in ozone depletion assessments research studies.
 WOUDC website: Visit WOUDC website for additional information, documentation data access.

 How to Use Information

 Understanding dataset: summary foundation for working with data
 Data access: Use information on data formats file organization to download process data
 Variable selection: Identify variables relevant to research questions
 Contextual information: Use related variables to understand conditions under observations.

 Let me know specific questions about dataset, variables or how to use for research.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cmip5-monthly-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cmip5-monthly-single-levels
projections-cmip5-monthly-single-levels
detailed informative description of CMIP5 climate data catalogue breakdown of key information:
 data

 Climate Projections: Monthly climate projections at single vertical levels surface or specific pressure levels atmosphere).
 CMIP5 Framework: Data from experiments within Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) major international effort to understand project climate change
 Large Datasets: catalogue includes data from numerous experiments variety of models model members (variations time periods.

 data important:

 IPCC Reporting: CMIP5 data cornerstone of Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Assessment Reports (including 2014 AR5) crucial information for understanding climate change
 Scientific Research: data helps researchers answer crucial questions about climate:
 Climate System Dynamics: Earth's climate system works responds to changes
 Future Climate Change: Projections of future climate scenarios under different greenhouse gas emissions pathways (RCPs).
 Climate Predictability: climate models predict climate on decadal time scales.
 Model Evaluation: Assessing accuracy limitations of different climate models


 Adaptation to Climate Change: input data for developing strategies to adapt to impacts climate change

 Data characteristics:

 Data Type: Gridded data values organized on regular grid
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid covering globe
 Resolution: Varies depending on model from 0.125° x 0.125° to 5° x 5°
 Vertical Resolution: Only single levels included not full vertical profiles
 Temporal Coverage: 1850-2300 shorter for some experiments.
 Temporal Resolution: Monthly.
 File Format: NetCDF widely used format for scientific data).

 Key Variables
 catalogue details comprehensive list of climate variables including

Atmospheric: Wind components (10m u, 10m v), temperature (2m), humidity pressure cloud cover.
 Surface: Surface fluxes (latent heat sensible heat radiation), precipitation snow soil moisture evaporation runoff.
 Oceanic: Sea ice fraction thickness temperature sea surface height.

 Additional Notes:

 Historical Experiments: Simulating past climate (typically 1850-2005).
 AMIP Experiments Prescribe ocean conditions focus on atmosphere-only responses
 RCP Experiments Project future climate under different emissions scenarios (2.6, 4.5, 6.0, 8.5).
 Ensemble of Experiments: Each experiment run with different model versions or varied initial conditions creating ensembles for better uncertainty estimates.
 Regional Climate Models (RCMs): CMIP5 GCM data used input for RCMs finer-scale regional climate projections.

 CMIP6: next phase of CMIP (CMIP6) producing data available in CDS eventually
 catalogue provides valuable resource for researchers policymakers understanding past climate change predicting future climate trends developing adaptation strategies availability of data ongoing research critical role in understanding of climate change

 thoughts and potential additions to enhance description:

 Clear and concise: text easy to understand and well-organized, accessible to wide audience.
 Comprehensive: description covers all essential aspects of dataset, including purpose, methodology, data characteristics, and variables.
 Detailed: provided specific information about spatial and temporal coverage, resolution, and file format.

cams-global-emission-inventories
detailed description of global emissions dataset! breakdown information highlighting key takeaways:
 What is data set about?

 Global Emissions: dataset contains information about emissions of pollutants greenhouse gases into atmosphere from human activities (anthropogenic) and natural sources.
 Importance: data crucial for understanding climate change air quality overall health planet.
 Use in Models: used input for atmospheric models predict future air quality climate patterns.

 Data Characteristics:

 Gridded: data organized in grid format covering entire globe.
 Resolution: Different resolutions for different emission sources:
 Anthropogenic: 0.1°x0.1° (high resolution)
 Biogenic/Shipping: 0.25°x0.25° (medium resolution)
 Aviation/Oceanic/Soil/Termite: 0.5°x0.5° (low resolution)


 Vertical Coverage: data focuses on emissions at surface.
 Temporal Coverage: dataset covers range of years coverage varies based on source
 Anthropogenic & Aviation: 2000-2020
 Biogenic, Oceanic, Shipping: 2000-2018
 Soil: 2000-2015
 Termite: 2000


 Temporal Resolution: Data provided monthly basis.
 File Format: NetCDF common format for scientific data).
 Conventions Uses Climate and Forecast Metadata Convention (CF) for standardization.
 Versions: multiple versions of dataset updates to reflect new information improved consistency.
 Update Frequency: dataset updated least once or twice a year.

 Emissions Categories:
 data set includes emissions of different substances categorized by source and pollutant type examples:

 Anthropogenic:
 CO2 (from sectors power generation transportation industry)
 Methane
 Nitrogen oxides
 Various Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
 Sulfur dioxide
 Black carbon


 Aviation:
 CO2
 CO
 NOx
 VOCs


 Biogenic:
 Isoprene
 Monoterpenes
 Methane
 Carbon monoxide


 Oceanic:
 Dimethyl sulfide
 Bromoform
 Iodomethane


 Shipping:
 CO2
 CO
 NOx
 VOCs
 Sulfur oxides
 Black carbon
 Organic carbon


 Soil:
 Nitrogen oxides


 Termite:
 Methane



 Strengths of Dataset:

 Comprehensive: includes emissions from many different sources pollutants.
 Up-to-Date: regularly updated reflect latest data
 Consistent: different emission categories internally consistent valuable tool for research modeling
 Standardized: uses CF Metadata Convention easier to use integrate with other datasets.

 data set valuable resource for scientists policymakers on climate change air quality related issues provides detailed consistent representation of global emissions important tool for understanding predicting future of atmosphere.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-carra-pressure-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-carra-pressure-levels
reanalysis-carra-pressure-levels
great description of CARRA dataset breakdown of key features valuable for Arctic research:
 CARRA: Key Features & Importance

 High Resolution: 2.5 km x 2.5 km resolution provides finer detail than global reanalyses like ERA5 capturing local weather patterns variations within Arctic
 Focus on Arctic: Two domains (West and East) cover important Arctic regions including Greenland, Svalbard Barents Sea surrounding waters provides comprehensive understanding of Arctic weather climate.
 Specific Arctic Observations: CARRA incorporates local observations from Nordic countries Greenland crucial for representing Arctic's unique weather patterns
 Surface Characteristics: High-resolution satellite physiographic data improve representation of Arctic's diverse surface features ice, land water model
 Non-hydrostatic Dynamics: feature simulates complex vertical motions of atmosphere important for capturing phenomena like mountain waves convection.
 Improved Cloud & Precipitation Modeling: model utilizes advanced parameterizations for clouds precipitation crucial for understanding Arctic precipitation patterns impact on sea ice other processes.
 ERA5 Integration: CARRA uses ERA5 data as lateral boundary conditions ensuring consistency with global atmospheric conditions.

 CARRA Crucial for Arctic Research
 Arctic experiencing rapid climate change essential to understand region's atmospheric processes CARRA provides valuable information for

 Climate Change Research: Studying impacts of climate change on Arctic weather patterns, sea ice melt other key processes.
 Sea Ice Modeling: Accurate modeling of sea ice formation melt requires precise atmospheric variables CARRA provides.
 Weather Forecasting: Improving forecasts for Arctic challenging due to remoteness extreme conditions.
Environmental Monitoring: Studying impact of atmospheric conditions on air quality ecosystems human activities in Arctic.
 Extreme Event Analysis: Understanding frequency intensity of extreme weather events like storms heavy precipitation in Arctic.

 Additional Notes:

 Data Availability: CARRA dataset available through various data centers archives.
 Documentation: documentation provides detailed information about model data processing inputs used.

 CARRA is significant advancement in Arctic reanalysis providing high-resolution region-specific atmospheric data crucial for studying Arctic's changing climate weather

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-observations-gruan-reference-network

insitu-observations-gruan-reference-network
detailed description of Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) Reference Upper-Air Network (GRUAN). breakdown of information
 What is GRUAN?

 is international network of sites measure essential climate variables above Earth's surface
 Established in 2006, aims to fill gap in global climate observing system providing high-quality data from surface through stratosphere
 GRUAN data used to
 Determine climate trends
 Constrain calibrate data from other observing systems
 Study atmospheric processes



 Key Features of GRUAN Data:

 High Quality: GRUAN data undergoes rigorous processing to adjust for systematic errors quantify uncertainties
 Traceability: Measurements traceable to SI units or accepted standards
 Metadata GRUAN provides extensive metadata full documentation of measurements algorithms enabling full reprocessing from raw data
 Availability: Data publicly available through Climate Data Store includes data products for different radiosonde types
 Format Data available in comma-separated values (CSV) format options for organization by level or observation

 Data Description

 Data Type: Point data
 Horizontal Coverage: 17 stations globally distributed
 Vertical Coverage: Up to 40 km varying with sonde launch
 Vertical Resolution: 5-10 meters varying per station
 Temporal Coverage: 2006 to March 2020 each station own start date
 Temporal Resolution: Sub-daily
 File Format: CSV
 Versions: GRUAN algorithm Version 2
 Update Frequency: Irregular new version expected in early 2021

 Main Variables
 dataset provides 12 main variables including

 Air Temperature
 Altitude
 Eastward Wind Component
 Frost Point Temperature
 Geopotential Height
 Northward Wind Component
 Relative Humidity
 Shortwave Radiation
Vertical Speed Radiosonde
 Water Vapor Volume Mixing Ratio
 Wind Direction
 Wind Speed

 Related Variables:
 dataset includes related variables additional information

 Air Pressure
 Height Station Above Sea Level
 Latitude
 Longitude
 Observation Value
 Observed Variable
 Post Processing Radiation Correction
 Random Uncertainty
 Record Number
 Relative Humidity Effective Vertical Resolution
 Report Time Stamp
 Station Name
 Systematic Uncertainty
 Time Since Launch
 Total Uncertainty

 Accessing GRUAN Data:
 More detailed information found Documentation section GRUAN website (www.gruan.org).
 Overall
 GRUAN dataset valuable resource climate research monitoring high-quality data thorough documentation public accessibility make crucial tool understanding addressing climate change.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-oras5
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-oras5
reanalysis-oras5
detailed informative description of ORAS5 dataset! overview of dataset

 Purpose: ORAS5 is reanalysis product combines model data with observations to create complete consistent dataset of ocean conditions
 Methodology: dataset uses NEMO ocean model NEMOVAR assimilation system assimilates data like temperature salinity sea ice concentration sea level anomalies.
 Forcing ORAS5 data driven by atmospheric reanalysis data from ERA-40/ERA-Interim (consolidated) or ECMWF operational analysis
 Data Properties:
 Data type: Gridded
 Projection: Tripolar model grid
 Horizontal coverage: Global
 Horizontal resolution: ~0.25° x 0.25°
 Vertical coverage: Depends on variable; 2D or 3D up to ~5500m depth
 Vertical resolution: Depends on variable; single level (2D) or 75 ocean model levels (3D).
 Temporal coverage: January 1958 to present (no gaps)
 Consolidated: 1958 to 2014
 Operational: 2015 to present


 Temporal resolution: Monthly
 File format: NetCDF4


 Versions: v0.1
 Update Frequency:
 Consolidated: Possible future extension in time
 Operational: New data added monthly on 15th of month


 Main Variables
 comprehensive list of variables provided each with description units covering important ocean properties processes



 Key Takeaways

 dataset provides valuable resource for understanding global ocean conditions over long time period
 dataset has consolidated and operational products flexibility based on needs for data latency atmospheric forcing consistency
 detailed variable descriptions units make easy to find specific data for research

 Additional Points to Consider

 Spatial Resolution: resolution relatively high (around 25 km), resolution can vary depending on location
Data Quality: good practice to assess data quality of any reanalysis product, may be limitations or uncertainties associated with data.
 Data Access: dataset available through Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) and other sources can easily find and download it.

 Overall, ORAS5 is powerful valuable resource for studying global oceanography, climate change other related fields.

700
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cordex-domains-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cordex-domains-single-levels
projections-cordex-domains-single-levels
detailed informative catalogue entry for CORDEX (Coordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment) data provides comprehensive overview of data including purpose methodology characteristics breakdown of key information:
 What is CORDEX data?
 CORDEX consists of regional climate model (RCM) simulations provide climate change information at finer scale than global climate models (GCMs). valuable for regional local impact studies adaptation decisions
 Key Features of CORDEX Data:

 High Resolution: RCMs offer higher spatial resolution than GCMs capturing regional variations local climate features
 Multiple Experiments: CORDEX includes variety of experiments (Evaluation, Historical Scenario) to assess RCM performance project future climate scenarios
 Ensemble Members: Each experiment uses multiple ensemble members represent uncertainties related to climate forcing model imperfections natural climate variability
 Wide Geographic Coverage data covers 14 global domains including Africa Antarctica Europe North America
 Variety of Variables: dataset provides rich selection of variables including wind speed temperature precipitation humidity surface radiation.

 CORDEX Data Generated

 Global Climate Models (GCMs): GCMs provide boundary conditions regional for RCMs
 Regional Climate Models (RCMs): RCMs use boundary conditions internal physics to simulate climate at finer scale
 Ensemble Members: Multiple simulations with same RCM-GCM combination run with slightly different conditions (initial conditions physical parameterizations to capture uncertainty.

 Uses of CORDEX Data:

 Climate Impact Assessment: Understanding climate change specific regions sectors
 Adaptation Planning: Developing strategies to mitigate risks of climate change impacts
 Research: Investigating climate processes at regional local scales.

 Important Notes:

Data Availability: CORDEX data publicly available through Climate Data Store (CDS).
 Data Licenses: Most CORDEX data unrestricted, some RCM simulations have specific terms of use.
 Data Conventions: data adheres to Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention for easy interoperability.

 catalogue entry provides clear comprehensive description of CORDEX dataset valuable resource for researchers, policymakers anyone interested in understanding addressing challenges climate change.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/insitu-observations-igra-baseline-network
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/insitu-observations-igra-baseline-network
insitu-observations-igra-baseline-network
catalogue entry description two datasets containing vertical profiles standard meteorological variables
 1. Integrated Global Radiosounding Archive (IGRA) v2:

 Source NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information (NCEI)
 Data Global radiosounding profiles temperature humidity wind from 1978 onwards
 Size 30% larger than previous version incorporating data wider range sources
 Quality Control quality procedures including
 Fundamental "sanity" checks
 Plausibility temporal consistency checks surface elevation
 Internal consistency checks
 repetition values
 gross position errors ship tracks
 Climatology-based checks
 Checks vertical temporal consistency temperature
 Data completeness checks


 Uncertainty No uncertainty estimation available for IGRA data

 2. Radiosounding HARMonization (RHARM) v1:

 Source Developed Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S).
 Data Adjusted values temperature humidity wind from 700 IGRA radiosounding stations radiosoundings ships
 Homogenization Systematic effects (sensor changes biases drifts removed
 Frequency Twice daily (0000 and 1200 UTC) data mandatory levels
 Vertical Coverage Up to 250 hPa (humidity) below 10 hPa (temperature due limited
 Uncertainty Estimation of measurement uncertainty provided for each value time series
 Quality Control Inherits IGRA procedures adds checks on
 Physical plausibility
 Accuracy of bias adjustment
 Outliers
 Coherency of adjustments at significant levels



 Key Features Both Datasets

 Data type Point data
 Horizontal coverage Global (656 stations)
 Vertical coverage Up to 40 km varying with sonde launch
Vertical resolution: Mandatory levels (10, 20 30 50 70 100 150 200 250 300 400 500 700 850 925 1000 hPa) significant levels vary between profiles
 Temporal coverage From 1978 to present (start date depends on station).
 Temporal resolution: Sub-daily
 File format: CSV
 Update frequency: Irregular

 Data Download Format
 Radiosoundings downloaded as CSV files in two formats

 CSV one row per level: All variables for given height provided as individual columns in one row Total uncertainty columns included where applicable
 CSV one row per observation Each row provides information about one variable at one level Columns include observed variable, value total uncertainty

 Main Variables
 datasets contain comprehensive meteorological variables including

 Air dewpoint depression: Difference between air temperature dew point temperature
 Air temperature Harmonized temperature obtained using RHARM
 Air temperature total uncertainty: for harmonized temperature
 Ascent speed Calculated from altitude data
 Eastward wind component Harmonized eastward wind
 total uncertainty: for harmonized eastward wind
 Frost point temperature: Temperature moisture condense as frost
 Geopotential height: Height of standard or significant pressure level
 Northward wind component Harmonized northward wind component
 wind component total uncertainty: for harmonized northward wind component
 Relative humidity: Harmonized humidity
 total uncertainty: for harmonized
 Solar zenith angle: Angle between zenith and Sun's center
 Water vapor volume mixing ratio Calculated using Hyland and Wexler method
 Wind from direction: (degrees from north).
 Wind from direction total uncertainty: uncertainty for wind direction
Wind speed: Horizontal wind speed.
 Wind speed total uncertainty: Total uncertainty for wind speed.

 Related Variables:
 datasets include range related variables

 Actual time: Release time sounding.
 Air pressure: Barometric air pressure.
 Height of station above sea level: Altitude.
 Latitude: Latitude station.
 Longitude: Longitude station.
 Observation value: Measurement value variable
 Observed variable: Specification measurand.
 Radiosonde code: Common Code table from WMO definitions
 Report id: Identifier in RHARM meta-database.
 Report timestamp: Observation date and time.
 Sensor model: Details sensor used
 Station name: Station identification code
 Total uncertainty: Total uncertainty for variable.

 summary
 datasets offer rich source of high-quality homogenized radiosounding data for research operational applications. IGRA v2 provides broad long-term perspective RHARM v1 offers highly-processed data with uncertainty estimates. availability of datasets detailed descriptions facilitates advanced meteorological studies improved weather forecasting.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-agroclimatic-indicators
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-agroclimatic-indicators
sis-agroclimatic-indicators
detailed comprehensive description of dataset containing agroclimatic indicators for global agriculture breakdown of information key takeaways potential uses:
 Key Features of Dataset:

 Scope: Global coverage at 0.5°x0.5° resolution
 Time Period: Covers historical (1951-2005) future (up to 2099) periods
 Data Source: Based on ERA-interim reanalysis CMIP5 General Circulation Models
 Indicators: 26 indicators reflect climate variability change relevant to agriculture
 Temporal Resolution: Varies by indicator 10-day, seasonal or annual data.
 Format: NetCDF-4 for easy access processing

 Agroclimatic Indicators Explained:
 dataset provides wide range of indicators each capturing specific aspect of climate relevant to agriculture examples importance:

 Biologically Effective Degree Days: Sum of temperatures suitable for plant growth crucial for understanding plant development stages potential yields.
 Growing Season Length: Length time with suitable temperatures for plant growth critical for determining crop suitability planning planting times
 Frost Days: Number of days below freezing Important for assessing frost damage potential especially for sensitive crops
 Precipitation Sum: Total precipitation over period. essential for understanding water availability irrigation needs potential for drought or flooding.
 Warm Spell Duration Index: Length of periods with unusually high temperatures indicator assess heat stress on plants potential for reduced productivity.

 Applications Users
 dataset invaluable for wide range of agricultural applications users:

 Crop Modeling: Scientists use indicators to improve crop growth models predict impacts of climate change on crop yields.
 Species Distribution Modeling: Researchers study distribution of plant species ranges shift with climate change.
Agronomic Decision Making: Farmers agricultural extension services can use data to make informed decisions on crop selection planting dates irrigation strategies.
 Policy Development: Governments international organizations can use data to assess climate change impacts on agriculture develop adaptation strategies.
 Financial Risk Assessment: agro-policy agro-business communities can use data to understand potential production anomalies inform decisions about pricing subsidies financial risk management.

 Overall Importance:
 dataset provides valuable pre-computed agroclimatic indicators readily available for use. makes easier for researchers agricultural professionals policymakers to access utilize climate data in work.'s critical resource for understanding complex interactions between climate agriculture for building resilient food system in climate change.

reanalysis-cerra-pressure-levels
detailed description of Copernicus European Regional ReAnalysis (CERRA) datasets! provides great overview of data, including

 Purpose: Providing spatially and temporally consistent historical reconstruction of meteorological variables.
 Methodology: Reanalysis combining model data with observations using data assimilation.

 Data Characteristics:

 Subsets: Single levels, height levels pressure levels, model levels.
 Coverage: Europe from northern Africa to Scandinavia extended coverage in Atlantic and Ural Mountains.
 Resolution: 5.5 km x 5.5 km for high-resolution reanalysis 11 km x 11 km for ensemble members.
 Vertical Levels: From 1000 hPa to 1hPa (29 levels).
 Time Period: September 1984 to June 2021.
 Frequency: 3-hourly for high-resolution analysis, 6-hourly for ensemble analysis hourly for forecast range 1-6 3-hourly for forecast range 6-30.
 Format: GRIB2.



 Key Variables: comprehensive list of variables clear explanations of units and meanings.


 Strengths of Description:

 Clear and concise language easy to understand information well-organized.
 Comprehensive: covers essential aspects of CERRA datasets from purpose methodology to data characteristics and variables.
 Detailed explanations: descriptions of variables helpful providing context clarifying usage.

 Potential Improvement:

 Visualizations: Adding visualizations maps showing spatial coverage diagram of vertical levels could make information more engaging easier to grasp.
 Data access information: Including links to users access CERRA datasets valuable.

 Overall excellent description of CERRA datasets provides strong foundation for anyone to understand utilize valuable resource.
