705
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/projections-cmip6
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/projections-cmip6
projections-cmip6
detailed informative catalogue entry for global climate projection dataset. breakdown of key information insights:
 What's This Dataset About?

 CMIP6: dataset from Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6), massive international effort involving hundreds of scientists CMIP6 sixth phase of ongoing project primary source of data for Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) assessment reports.
 Global Climate Projections: dataset provides projections of global climate expected change future based on various scenarios of greenhouse gas emissions societal development.
 Experiments & Models: data from numerous "experiments" – simulations with different climate models (GCMs). two main types:
 Historical Experiments: focus on simulating past climate conditions (1850-2014) to test accuracy models.
 Climate Projection Experiments: project future climate (2015-2100) using scenarios like SSPs (Shared Socioeconomic Pathways) RCPs (Representative Concentration Pathways).



 Key Uses:

 IPCC Assessment: data essential for informing IPCC's assessment of climate change impacts.
 Scientific Research: Scientists use data to address questions about climate system understand climate change explore limits of climate predictability.
 Climate Adaptation: dataset provides vital information for decisions about adapting to changing climate.

 Data Characteristics:

 Gridded: data presented as grid covering entire globe.
 Spatial Resolution: resolution varies between models data available at varying levels of detail.
 Temporal Coverage: data covers both historical (1850-2014) and future (2015-2100) time periods.
 Temporal Resolution: data available at monthly, daily or fixed (no temporal resolution) intervals.
Variables: dataset includes vast array of important climate variables listed in entry, covering from temperature precipitation to wind, humidity sea ice.

 New Features:

 Subsetting: dataset offers new feature allowing users to select specific subsets data based on location and time. makes data more manageable allows for focused analyses.

 In Summary
 dataset is powerful resource for understanding climate change potential consequences. offers comprehensive view of global climate projections, providing data for scientists, policymakers public. CMIP6 data crucial for guiding decisions about climate adaptation and mitigation.
---
706
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cems-fire-seasonal
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cems-fire-seasonal
cems-fire-seasonal
detailed description of fire danger dataset clear you put effort into summarizing key takeaways insights:
 Key Features:

 Long-range predictions: dataset focuses on providing forecasts of fire danger relying on seasonal weather forecasts for predictions outlook on conditions conducive to fire initiation, spread persistence over extended period.
 Multiple indices: incorporates fire danger indices from systems like NFDRS, FWI McArthur rating system comprehensive assessment.
 Global coverage: dataset offers predictions for entire global landmass.
 Gridded ensemble: provides ensemble forecasts representing multiple model runs to account for uncertainties.
 Monthly updates: New data available monthly reflecting latest seasonal forecasts.

 Important Points:

 Real-time vs. seasonal forecasts: dataset offers seasonal forecasts, real-time fire danger information available through separate EFFIS web services.
 Data distinction: crucial to distinguish between re-forecast period (1981-2016) and forecast period (2017-present). differ in initialization analyzed accordingly.
 Data availability: dataset will evolve over time as new seasonal forcing data available ECMWF updates seasonal forecasting systems.

 Potential Applications:

 Performance assessment: Researchers can analyze dataset to evaluate performance of forecasting system identify areas for improvement.
 Tool development: data can used to develop tools for statistically correcting forecast errors enhance accuracy of predictions.
 Fire management: Seasonal fire danger forecasts assist fire management agencies in planning, resource allocation preparedness activities.

 Overall dataset offers valuable insights into fire danger prediction potentially contributing to improved fire management disaster preparedness.
---

https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-monthly-means-preliminary-back-extension
reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-monthly-means-preliminary-back-extension
great summary of ERA5 back extension data from 1950-1978! important to highlight key points information:
 Key Points:

 Deprecation: preliminary version of ERA5 back extension deprecated not be used. final release ERA5 Climate Data Store data from 1940 onwards should be used instead.
 Tropical Cyclone Intensity: preliminary version has known issue with tropical cyclones unrealistically intense significant limitation.
 ERA5 Reanalysis: ERA5 valuable tool for understanding global climate and weather for past 8 decades combines model data and observations for complete dataset.
 Data Availability: ERA5 data available from 1940 onwards including hourly and monthly products.
 Data Format and Grid: data provided in GRIB format regridded to regular latitude-longitude grid for easier use.
 Variables: dataset includes variety of atmospheric variables including
 Temperature, wind humidity cloud cover precipitation more.



 Recommendations:

 use latest final releases of ERA5 data from Climate Data Store.
 aware of limitations of preliminary back extension particularly regarding tropical cyclone intensity.
 Consult ERA5 documentation and guidelines for latest information on accessing and using data.

 Additional Information:

 Data assimilation: process combines model forecasts with observations to produce accurate estimate of state of atmosphere.
 Ensemble: ERA5 includes ensemble of 10 members for uncertainty estimates.
 Monthly means: Monthly mean averages provided for convenience.
 Applications: ERA5 widely used in climate research, weather forecasting other applications.

 hope breakdown helpful!

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cems-fire-historical
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cems-fire-historical
cems-fire-historical
detailed description of valuable dataset on fire danger metrics breakdown key information:
 Data Overview:

 Purpose: Provides historical reconstruction of fire danger conditions crucial for understanding fire risk developing prevention management strategies
 Source: European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS)
 Methodology: Uses weather data from ERA5 reanalysis models fire danger indices from three models (Canadian, US Australian).
 Coverage: Global Land
 Time Period: 1979 - 2022
 Resolution:
 Reanalysis: 0.25° x 0.25°
 Mean, spread members: 0.5° x 0.5°


 Format: NetCDF

 Key Variables:
 dataset includes comprehensive fire danger metrics:

 Build-Up Index Represents total fuel available for combustion influenced by Duff moisture (organic layer) Drought conditions
 Burning Index: Measures difficulty controlling fire combining spread rate energy release.
 Danger Rating: Categorizes fire danger levels into six classes (very low to extreme).
 Drought Code Indicates moisture content in deep organic layers
 Duff Moisture Code Indicates moisture content shallower organic layer
 Energy Release Component: Represents heat released per unit area fire influenced by fuel moisture
 Fine Fuel Moisture Code Indicates moisture content in fine fuels
 Fire Daily Severity Index: numerical rating difficulty of controlling fires related to Fire Weather Index
 Fire Danger Index: capturing fire risk related to ignition spread intensity suppression difficulty
 Fire Weather Index Combines spread fuel availability potential fire intensity
 Ignition Component: Indicates probability firebrand start fire requiring suppression
 Initial Spread Index Represents expected rate of fire spread influenced by fine fuel moisture wind speed
Keetch-Byram Drought Index (KBDI): Measures cumulative moisture deficiency in soil duff layers impacting fire intensity.
 Spread Component Measures theoretical ideal rate of fire spread

 Strengths of Dataset:

 Historical Coverage Provides long-term perspective on fire danger valuable for climate change studies
 Global Scale Covers broad geographical area comparisons across regions
 Comprehensive Metrics rich variables for analyzing fire risk behavior
 Standardized Approach Uses harmonized fire danger classes for cross-country comparisons

 Potential Uses:

 Fire Management Predicting fire risk allocating resources developing prevention strategies
 Climate Change Research Analyzing influence climate change on fire danger patterns
 Forest Management Assessing fire risk managing fire-prone ecosystems
 Public Safety Informing public about fire danger levels recommending safety measures

 dataset valuable resource for applications fire safety forest management climate change research

709
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-monthly-means
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-monthly-means
reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-monthly-means
detailed description of ERA5 data covers essential aspects origins methodology to applications access
 breakdown information
 What is ERA5?

 Fifth generation reanalysis from ECMWF Medium-Range Weather Forecasts
 Combines model data observations from 1940 onwards
 Replaces ERA-Interim reanalysis
 Provides globally complete consistent dataset

 created

 Data assimilation Combining model forecasts with observations using laws physics
 Similar to weather prediction reduced resolution
 Allows longer timeframes improved observation quality

 offers

 Hourly estimates for atmospheric ocean-wave land-surface quantities
 Uncertainty estimates using 10-member ensemble
 Pre-computed monthly means
 Regular updates (daily with 5-day latency

 Data characteristics

 Gridded data on regular lat-lon grid
 Global coverage
 Different resolutions for reanalysis ensemble members
 Vertical coverage from 1000 hPa to 1 hPa
 37 pressure levels
 Monthly temporal resolution
 Available in GRIB format

 Key variables

 Divergence: Spreading air horizontally
 Fraction of cloud cover: Proportion box covered by clouds
 Geopotential: Gravitational potential energy unit mass
 Ozone mass mixing ratio: Mass of ozone per kilogram of air
 Potential vorticity air's capacity to rotate
 Relative humidity: Water vapor pressure percentage saturation
 Specific cloud ice/liquid water content: Mass water per kg of air
 Specific humidity Mass of water vapor per kg air
 rain/snow water content Mass of precipitation per kg of air
 Temperature: Air temperature in Kelvin
 U/V-component of wind: Eastward/Northward wind speed
 Vertical velocity: Upward/downward speed of air
Vorticity (relative): Measure of air's rotation relative to fixed point

 Access availability:

 Regridded subset available online on spinning disk
 Full resolution data available through ECMWF guidelines

 Overall excellent resource for interested using ERA5 data. comprehensive information help users understand data's characteristics limitations allowing for effective informed application.

reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels
great summary of ERA5 reanalysis dataset! provided comprehensive overview of characteristics including:

 What it is: reanalysis dataset combining model data and observations provide consistent picture of Earth's climate and weather over past 8 decades.
 Data availability: Hourly data from 1940 to present updated daily with latency of about 5 days.
 Key features:
 Combines model simulations with observations using data assimilation.
 Provides estimates for atmospheric, ocean-wave land-surface variables.
 Includes uncertainty estimates derived from ensemble of simulations.
 Offers hourly and monthly data on pressure levels and single levels.


 Technical specifications:
 Regular latitude-longitude grid with 0.25° resolution for reanalysis 0.5° for uncertainty estimates.
 37 pressure levels covering 1000 hPa to 1 hPa.
 GRIB file format.


 Main variables: included detailed description of each main variables helpful for understanding data's applications.

 suggestions for improvement:

 Additional links: add link to ECMWF website users download data.
 Clarification on "regridded subset": "regridded subset refers to data provided on this particular website may be different from full ERA5 dataset available on native resolution.

 Overall well-written informative description of ERA5 dataset. valuable resource for anyone interested in learning more about data.

711
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-preliminary-back
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-preliminary-back-extension
reanalysis-era5-pressure-levels-preliminary-back-extension
text appears excerpt from scientific document describing ERA5 reanalysis dataset specifically back extension from 1950 to 1978 breakdown of key points:
 ERA5 Reanalysis:

 ERA5 comprehensive reanalysis of global climate and weather data from past 8 decades combines observations with numerical weather prediction model to create consistent complete global dataset
 How works Data assimilation is used forecasts combined with new observations to produce best estimate of atmospheric state process similar to numerical weather prediction allows for longer time span and incorporation of improved observations.
 Data availability: ERA5 data available from 1940 onwards.
 Final Release: final release includes data from 1940 onwards with regular updates.
 Preliminary Back Extension: covers 1950-1978 superseded by final release.


 Advantages: Reanalysis offers advantages over raw observations:
 Global Consistency: fills in gaps ensures consistency across globe.
 Improved Accuracy: benefits from use of improved observational data updated models over time.



 ERA5 Back Extension (1950-1978):

 Initial version: initial version superseded by final release suffered from issues like unrealistically intense tropical cyclones.
 Final Release: final release addresses shortcomings of preliminary version.
 Availability: initial version still accessible, users advised to use final release.

 Data Characteristics:

 Gridded: data provided on regular lat-lon grid.
 Global Coverage: data covers entire globe.
 Horizontal Resolution:
 Reanalysis: 0.25°x0.25°
 Mean, spread and members: 0.5°x0.5°


 Vertical Coverage: 1000 hPa to 1 hPa (representing different atmospheric layers)
 Vertical Resolution: 37 pressure levels
Temporal Coverage: 1950 to 1978 (for initial version; 1940 onwards for final release)
 Temporal Resolution: Hourly
 File Format: GRIB (a standard format for meteorological data)

 Key Variables:
 text lists variables in ERA5 dataset, with explanations of units and descriptions. variables essential for understanding atmospheric processes.
 Overall:
 text provides concise overview of ERA5 dataset highlights key differences between initial and final releases back extension. emphasizes importance of using final release for research and applications due to improved accuracy and consistency.

714
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/derived-reanalysis-energy-moisture-budget
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/derived-reanalysis-energy-moisture-budget
derived-reanalysis-energy-moisture-budget
detailed informative description of valuable dataset on atmospheric energy moisture budgets breakdown of key information used:
 Key Features of Dataset

 Source: ERA5 reanalysis data from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).
 Coverage: Global horizontal resolution of 0.25° x 0.25°.
 Vertical Coverage: Vertically integrated from surface to top of atmosphere
 Temporal Coverage: From January 1979 to present monthly resolution.
 Key Variables: dataset provides monthly means of vertically integrated budget quantities including
 Tendencies: Rates of change of total energy, water vapor latent heat.
 Lateral Fluxes: Horizontal transports of quantities
 Divergences: spreading or converging of lateral fluxes.



 Key Advantages of Dataset

 Mass Consistency: horizontal wind fields calculate fluxes iteratively adjusted to ensure mass conservation reducing noise improving accuracy.
 Latent Heat of Vaporization: latent heat vaporization calculated as function of temperature realistic representation of energy required to convert water to vapor.
 Surface Flux Estimation: combining divergence tendency terms users indirectly estimate
 Net Surface Heat Fluxes: combined with net radiative fluxes at top of atmosphere (not included dataset).
 Surface Freshwater Fluxes (P+E): fluxes have unbiased global mean.



 Additional Information

 Spectral Resolution: Divergence fields truncated at wave number 180 to reduce artificial noise over high topography full spectral resolution recovered from east- and northward transports.
 Temperature-Independent Latent Heat: Users calculate divergence, tendency transport terms with temperature-independent latent heat of vaporization (Lv = 2.5008 J kg-1) by adjusting provided values.

 Applications
dataset used for wide range research applications related to climate change atmospheric dynamics water cycle studies. examples include:

 Climate Modeling: Assessing impact of climate change on atmospheric energy budget water cycle.
 Weather Forecasting: Improving accuracy of numerical weather prediction models.
 Hydrological Modeling: Estimating precipitation and evaporation fluxes for water resource management.
 Carbon Cycle Studies: Understanding role of atmosphere in transporting energy and moisture influence carbon fluxes.

 Accessibility
 dataset produced by Department of Meteorology and Geophysics, University of Vienna on behalf Copernicus Climate Change Service. likely available for download from website or through Copernicus Climate Data Store.
 Conclusion
 valuable dataset for researchers practitioners working on climate, atmospheric hydrological studies. high accuracy global coverage multiple variables make it powerful resource for investigating complex interactions within Earth's climate system.

app-biodiversity-climate-suitability-explorer
detailed well-structured description of bioclimatic indicator visualization application breakdown of key features summary of strengths and weaknesses:
 Strengths:

 Comprehensive data: application offers large dataset of 43 bioclimatic indicators covering range of climate variables providing relevant information for diverse conservation efforts.
 High-quality data sources: use of CMIP5 model output bias-adjusted to ERA5 ensures application relies on reputable high-quality climate projections
 User-friendly interface: interactive livemap detailed view of countries/regions allow users to explore data visually delve into specific areas of interest
 Climate suitability estimation: simple envelope model provides users quick easy way to assess potential climate suitability for ecosystems species even with limited expertise
 Multiple timeframes scenarios: ability to examine indicators for historical near-future far-future periods under different emission scenarios (RCP4.5 RCP8.5) provides valuable insight into climate change impacts
 Detailed documentation: product user guide helps users understand complexity of variables interpret results effectively.

 Weaknesses:

 Simple climate envelope model: useful for initial exploration has limitations doesn't account for complex species interactions adaptations other ecological factors.
 Potential for misinterpretation: Without thorough understanding of variables application limitations users might misinterpret results user guide crucial for proper use.
 Computation time: climate suitability calculations can take several minutes might deter users from exploring various scenarios.

 Overall:
 application presents powerful tool for biodiversity wildlife conservation research provides user-friendly interface for exploring understanding bioclimatic indicators offers valuable insights into climate change impacts users aware of limitations of simple envelope model utilize user guide to ensure accurate interpretation of results.
 Possible Improvements:

advanced climate suitability models: Incorporating sophisticated ecological niche modeling techniques enhance application's accuracy provide nuanced assessments.
 Integration of other data: Combining bioclimatic indicators with other relevant data habitat distribution species occurrence land use, could provide comprehensive context-specific analyses.
 Improved visualization tools: Interactive features animated maps time-series comparisons custom visualizations could enhance user experience data exploration capabilities
 Reduced computation time: Optimizing code or implementing caching mechanisms could minimize time required for climate suitability calculations.

 addressing these potential improvements application could become more valuable for conservationists researchers policy-makers.

 Dataset Overview

 Purpose: characterize operating conditions of winter ski resorts in Europe considering current future climate scenarios
 Scope: Covers all mountain regions across Europe at NUTS-3 regional level) 100-meter elevation increments
 Indicators: Includes 39 indicators divided into seven groups detailed picture of atmospheric snow conditions.
 Climate Scenarios: dataset considers four climate scenarios:
 Historical: Present climate conditions
 RCP2.6: Optimistic scenario declining emissions after 2020.
 RCP4.5: optimistic scenario declining emissions after 2040.
 RCP8.5: Pessimistic scenario continued emissions growth throughout century.



 Key Features

 Snowpack Modeling: Uses Crocus snowpack model SURFEX land surface model simulate snow conditions
 Snow Management: Accounts for snow grooming mechanical snow-making insights into potential snow management requirements future
 High Resolution: Uses downscaled climate projections from regional climate models high-resolution pan-European indicators
 Comparison: Allows comparisons of past future snow conditions across European regions
 Data Format: Available in NetCDF-4 format adhering to CF Metadata Convention v1.7.

 Main Variables
 dataset provides numerous variables examples:

 Start and End Date of Snow Season Determines length of ski season under different scenarios
 Annual Amount of Machine-Made Snow Indicates potential need for artificial snow production
 Precipitation: Tracks snowfall rainfall patterns crucial for snow reliability
 Snow Depth and Snow Water Equivalent: Quantifies amount snowpack impacting ski conditions
 Air Temperature: Shows temperature trends influencing snow formation melt
Potential Snow Making Hours: Indicates availability suitable conditions for snow-making operations.

 Applications
 dataset offers valuable information for

 Ski Resort Management: Understanding potential changes snow conditions planning snow management strategies
 Climate Change Adaptation: Assessing vulnerability of ski resorts to climate change identifying adaptation measures
 Tourism and Recreation Planning: Informing tourism development planning recreational activities in mountain areas
 Scientific Research Analyzing snow climate trends in Europe impact on mountain ecosystems.

 dataset comprehensive resource for understanding past present future of snow conditions in Europe's ski resorts provides insights into challenges opportunities climate change offers information for decision-making in winter sports industry.

reanalysis-cerra-land
comprehensive description of Copernicus European Regional ReAnalysis Land (CERRA-Land) dataset breakdown of key information:


 High-resolution historical reconstruction of land surface variables: CERRA-Land provides detailed picture of past conditions like soil moisture temperature snowpack over Europe
 Spatially and temporally consistent: Data consistent across space (5.5 km resolution) and time (hourly and daily), useful for various applications
 Based on data assimilation: Combines model simulations with real-world observations process data assimilation produce accurate representation possible

 useful

 Water resource management: CERRA-Land data understanding water availability predicting droughts managing water resources efficiently
 Climate change impact studies: Analyzing historical trends in soil moisture temperature snow cover provide insights into impact of climate change on land surface ecosystems.

 Technical Details

 Model Uses SURFEX (V8.1) land surface model
 Data sources
 Atmospheric forcing temperature) from CERRA high-resolution reanalysis
 Precipitation data from dedicated assimilation system


 Spatial coverage: Europe from northern Africa to Scandinavia reaching Atlantic Ocean Ural Mountains
 Temporal coverage: September 1984 to April 2021 future updates expected.

 Key Variables
 dataset contains wide range of variables related to

 Surface: Albedo, skin temperature surface roughness energy fluxes (latent sensible net solar thermal radiation).
 Soil: Soil moisture (liquid total), soil temperature percolation runoff
 Snow: Snow cover fraction snow depth water equivalent density albedo temperature.
 Lakes: Depth, temperature (surface, mixed layer bottom ice), ice thickness.

 Advantages over other datasets:

Higher resolution: 5.5 km resolution allows accurate representation of topography land surface features compared to global reanalysis products.

 Overall:
 CERRA-Land dataset offers valuable tool for researchers policymakers professionals interested in land surface processes water resource management climate change impacts high resolution long-term data detailed variables make powerful resource for understanding past conditions predicting future trends.

seems you looking for ideas to build viewer application for dataset. break down process think best approach:
 Understanding Requirements

 Profiles: visualize vertical variations at location time
 3D Visualizations: create interactive 3D views of data (potentially using WebGL)
 Customizations: ability for users to filter, select analyze specific data slices subsets.


 Target Audience: Who using viewer? scientists, researchers, educators or general public? influence complexity user interface design.
 Interactive Features: users able to:
 Zoom and Pan: Explore different regions data.
 Change Time/Depth: View data at different times depths.
 Download Data: Export selected data for further analysis.
 Annotate Data: Add notes or labels to specific points regions.



 Choosing Right Tools

 Programming Language: Popular choices include:
 Python: Excellent libraries for data visualization (Matplotlib, Seaborn, Plotly, Bokeh), data manipulation (Pandas, NumPy), web development (Flask, Django).
 JavaScript: Provides interactivity for web-based viewers using libraries like D3.js, Leaflet, Three.js.
 R: strong statistical programming language with libraries like ggplot2 for powerful visualizations.


 Visualization Libraries: Consider libraries suit visualization goals:
 Static Plots: Matplotlib, Seaborn, ggplot2
Interactive Plots: Plotly, Bokeh, D3.js
 Maps: Leaflet, CartoDB, Mapbox GL JS
 3D: Three.js, WebGL, ParaView



 Designing User Interface

 Clarity and Simplicity: user interface should be easy to navigate even for users unfamiliar with data
 Data Exploration: Provide intuitive controls to select variables time periods locations depth ranges
 Visual Feedback: Use clear labels legends tooltips to help users understand data
 Responsive Design: viewer works well on desktops laptops tablets phones

 Implementation Steps

 Data Preparation: Load parse format data easy for chosen programming language visualization libraries
 Visualization Framework: Choose visualization libraries create basic structure of viewer including elements like plots maps controls
 Data Binding: Connect data to visualization elements update based on user interactions
 Interactive Features: Implement controls for zooming panning time/depth selection
 User Interface Design Create user-friendly interface guides users through data exploration process
 Testing and Deployment: test viewer on different devices browsers deploy on web server or as standalone application

 Example: Python with Plotly

 import plotly.express as px
 import pandas as pd
 Load data from file (CSV, NetCDF
 df = pd.read_csv('your_data.csv')
 Create basic scatter plot with Plotly
 fig = px.scatter(df, x='Longitude' y='Latitude' color='Temperature')
 fig.show()
 Add interactive elements (e sliders)
 fig = px.scatter(df, x='Longitude', y='Latitude', color='Temperature',
 animation_frame='Time', animation_group='Location')
 fig.show()
 ```
 Remember: This is basic outline. actual implementation on specific data, requirements tools you choose.

https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/hidden-app-climatic-suitability-of-tiger-mosquito
hidden-app-climatic-suitability-of-tiger-mosquito
`python
 import pandas pd
 numpy np
 matplotlib.pyplot plt
 from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D
 matplotlib import cm
 Assuming dataset stored in CSV file 'dataset.csv'
 data = pd.read_csv('dataset.csv')
 Define function to create 3D plot of variable
 def plot_3d(variable, time_index location_index):

 Creates 3D plot of specified variable at given time location
 Args
 variable (str): name variable to plot
 time_index (int): index time slice plot
 location_index (int): index location plot.

 Returns:
 None

 Extract data for specified variable, time location
 z = data[variable].values[time_index, location_index

 Create meshgrid for depth dimension
 x = np.arange(z.size)
 y = np.zeros_like(x)

 Create 3D plot
 fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
 ax =.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
 ax.plot(x, y, z, label=variable)
 ax.set_xlabel('Depth Index')
 ax.set_ylabel('Location Index')
 ax.set_zlabel(variable)
 ax.set_title(f'{variable} at Time Index {time_index} Location Index_index}
 ax.view_init(elev=30, azim=120)
 plt.show()

 Example Plot dissolved oxygen concentration at time index 10 location index 5
 plot_3d('Mole concentration of dissolved oxygen', 10, 5)
Define function create contour plot variable at specific depth
 def plot_contour(variable, depth_index time_index):

 Creates contour plot of specified variable at given depth time
 Args
 variable (str): name of variable to plot
 depth_index (int): index depth to plot
 time_index (int): index time slice to plot

 Returns:
 None

 Extract data for specified variable, depth time
 z = data[variable].values[time_index, depth_index]

 Create meshgrid for location dimension
 x = np.arange(z.size)
 y = np.zeros_like(x)

 Create contour plot
 fig ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8))
 contour = ax.contour(x, y, z, 20, cmap=cm.viridis)
 ax.clabel(contour, inline=True, fontsize=8)
 ax.set_xlabel('Location Index')
 ax.set_ylabel('Depth Index')
 ax.set_title(f'{variable} at Depth Index {depth_index} Time Index {time_index}')
 plt.show()

 Example: Plot net primary production at depth index 15 time index 20
 plot_contour('Net primary production', 15, 20)
 Define function to create time series plot of variable at specific location depth
 def plot_timeseries(variable, location_index, depth_index):

 Creates time series plot of specified variable at given location depth.
 Args
 variable (str): name of variable to plot
 location_index (int): index location to plot
 depth_index (int): index depth to plot.

 Returns:
 None
""
 # Extract data for specified variable, location depth
 z = data[variable].values[:, location_index, depth_index]

 Create time series plot
 fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 8))
 ax.plot(np.arange(z.size), z, label=variable)
 ax.set_xlabel('Time Index')
 ax.set_ylabel(variable)
 ax.set_title(f'{variable} at Location Index {location_index} and Depth Index {depth_index}')
 plt.show()

 Example: Plot sea water potential temperature at location index 10 depth index 25
 plot_timeseries('Sea water potential temperature', 10, 25)

 code snippet demonstrates to use Python libraries like pandas and matplotlib to create visualizations of dataset. includes functions for:

 3D plotting: visualize spatial distribution of variables with respect depth
 Contour plotting: visualize horizontal distribution of variables at specific depth.
 Time series plotting: visualize temporal evolution of variables at specific location and depth.

 basic example can modify code to create more complex informative visualizations based on specific needs nature of dataset For example

 Create animated plots visualize evolution of variables over time
 Add colorbars indicate value range of variables
 Customize axes labels titles make plots more readable
 Combine multiple plots compare different variables or time periods.
 Use interactive plotting libraries create engaging user-friendly visualizations.

 adjust code according to actual structure and names of variables in dataset.

 Application Architecture

you describing dataset of marine environmental variables wanting to create viewer application for. breakdown of how approach project combining provided information with best practices for data visualization and application development.
 1. Understanding Your Data

 Variables: clearly defined variables, units descriptions fantastic starting point.
 Dimensions: Many variables are 4D fields (time, location, depth). adds complexity to visualization need to handle spatial and temporal aspects.
 Data Format: haven't specified data format. in file format like NetCDF, CSV, or else? influence choice of tools.

 2. Choosing Visualization Tools

 For Web-Based Applications:
 Libraries:
 D3.js: powerful JavaScript library for creating customizable interactive visualizations.
 Leaflet: JavaScript library for creating interactive maps display data spatially.
 Plotly.js: library for creating charts (line, bar scatter) maps with excellent interactivity.


 Frameworks:
 React, Vue.js Angular: Frameworks simplify development of user interfaces for complex web applications.




 For Desktop Applications:
 Python Libraries:
 Matplotlib: classic library for creating static plots.
 Seaborn: higher-level library built on Matplotlib easier to create aesthetically pleasing plots.
 Bokeh: library provides interactive plotting for web-based visualizations used to create standalone HTML files.


 R Libraries:
 ggplot2: powerful library for creating plots with grammar of graphics.
 Shiny: framework for building interactive web applications with R.




 Specialized Tools:
 Ocean Data View (ODV): dedicated tool for visualizing oceanographic data with features for 3D and 4D data analysis.



 3. Application Design

 Focus on User Needs:
questions want users to answer with data? help choose relevant visualizations.
 interaction want enable? (e zooming panning filtering time-series animation).


 Key Features:
 Spatial Maps: show variables change over space (e chlorophyll-a concentrations on map).
 Time Series: show variables change over time temperature profiles at specific location).
 Cross-Sections: show variables change with depth (e vertical profile of dissolved oxygen).
 3D Visualizations: For complex datasets consider 3D visualizations (e using WebGL).
 Data Filtering and Selection: Allow users choose specific areas time periods depth ranges.
 Legend and Labels: label axes, units data ranges.
 Annotations and Tooltips: Provide additional information on hover or click interactions.


 User Interface Design:
 Intuitive Navigation easy for users to explore data.
 Clear Visual Hierarchy Emphasize important information.



 4. Development Process

 Data Loading and Processing:
 Data Handling: Read data files using appropriate libraries (e netcdf4 in Python, ncdf4 in R).
 Preprocessing: Clean data handle missing values perform transformations if needed.


 Visualization Logic:
 Dynamic Data Binding: Use chosen visualization library to create interactive charts maps.
 Event Handling: Implement event listeners for mouse clicks hovers) to trigger interactions updates.
 Data Filtering and Selection: Build user interface elements to control data filtering and selection.


 Application Building:
 Structure: Organize code using best practices (e modular design object-oriented programming).
 Testing: Write unit tests to ensure correctness of code.
 Deployment: Choose platform for hosting application (eg GitHub Pages Netlify for web applications desktop application package for desktop apps).



 Example (using D3.js and Leaflet for web application):

 Data Preparation: Load data using D3.js's d3.csv, d3.json d3.tsv functions.
 Map Creation: Use Leaflet create map centered on region of interest.
 Choropleth Map: Use D3.js create choropleth map (color-coded map) representing spatial distribution of chosen variable at specific time.
 Time Series Plot: Use D3.js create line chart or time series plot showing variable changes over time at chosen location.
 Event Handling: Implement interactions for zooming on map selecting time periods updating plots based on user selections.

 Additional Considerations:

 Performance Optimization: For large datasets consider techniques pre-aggregating simplifying data before visualization.
 Accessibility: Design application accessible to users with disabilities.
 Documentation and User Guides: Provide clear instructions use application.

sis-biodiversity-era5-regional
comprehensive description of dataset containing bioclimatic indicators for Europe Northern Brazil Central Africa breakdown of key information relevance:
 Dataset Highlights:

 Purpose Provides climate data relevant to biodiversity ecosystems ecosystem services
 Resolution: High resolution (1 km x 1 km) for detailed analysis
 Indicators Covers 76 bioclimatic variables related to temperature precipitation drought soil moisture wind surface energy
 Source: Based on ERA5 ERA5-Land reanalysis data high-quality climate information
 Temporal Coverage Spans 1979 to 2018 several decades of climate trends
 Accessibility Data in NetCDF-4 format easy to use with standard scientific software

 Key Components

 Data Type: Gridded organized in spatial grid format
 Horizontal Coverage Focuses on three regions Central Africa Europe Northern Brazil
 Vertical Coverage: Surface level data relevant for understanding terrestrial ecosystems
 Temporal Resolution: Averages for different periods 20-year (Central Africa), 40-year (Europe Northern Brazil), 18-year
 Conventions Follows CF Metadata Convention ACDD for standardized data description

 Value of Dataset:

 Biodiversity Research Crucial for understanding climate change impacts on species distribution ecosystem dynamics services ecosystems provide
 Ecosystem Services Modeling: assess vulnerability of ecosystem services to climate change water provision pollination carbon sequestration
 Ecological Niche Modeling Facilitates prediction of species distribution under various climate scenarios
 Climate Change Adaptation: Informs conservation strategies land management decisions adaptation measures to mitigate climate change impacts

 Use Dataset:

 Data Analysis Use scientific software like R, Python Matlab to analyze data create maps conduct statistical analyses

 this dataset valuable resource for scientists policymakers researchers involved in biodiversity ecosystem services climate change adaptation.

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/sis-marine-properties
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/sis-marine-properties
sis-marine-properties
detailed description marine ecosystem model dataset break down key information clarity
 Dataset Overview

 Purpose dataset provides projections changes in marine physics biogeochemistry lower trophic levels marine food web Northwest European Shelf Mediterranean Sea up to 2100
 Model data produced using ERSEM v15.06 (European Regional Seas Ecosystem Model) ocean circulation models POLCOMS NEMO.
 Scenarios model simulations run under two future climate scenarios RCP4.5 (intermediate emissions) RCP8.5 high emissions).
 Data Source dataset produced for Copernicus Climate Change Service

 Data Characteristics

 Type Gridded data organized regular covering geographic area interest
 Coverage
 POLCOMS-ERSEM: Northwest European Shelf Mediterranean Sea (20W to 37E, 11N to 65N)
 NEMO-ERSEM: Northwest European Shelf (20W to 13E, 40N to 65N)


 Resolution
 POLCOMS-ERSEM: 0.1° x 0.1° (approximately 11km)
 NEMO-ERSEM: 0.06° x 0.06° (approximately 7km)


 Vertical Coverage: 0-5500 m below sea level
 Vertical Resolution 43 vertical levels in POLCOMS-ERSEM NEMO-ERSEM
 Temporal Coverage
 POLCOMS-ERSEM: 2006 to 2100
 NEMO-ERSEM: 2006 to 2050


 Temporal Resolution Daily/or monthly depending on variable
 Format: NetCDF-4
 Conventions: Climate and Forecast (CF) Metadata Convention v1.7

 Main Variables
 list details range key variables related

 Physical Parameters
 Horizontal velocity components
 Temperature (potential temperature
 Salinity


 Biogeochemical Variables
 Dissolved oxygen (concentration apparent oxygen utilization)
Nutrients (nitrate/nitrite phosphate silicate)
 pH
 Aragonite saturation state


 Biological Variables:
 Chlorophyll-a (total euphotic zone
 Phytoplankton carbon (four groups diatoms pico- nano- micro-phytoplankton
 Zooplankton carbon (three groups heterotrophic nanoflagellates microzooplankton mesozooplankton)
 Net primary production
 Secondary production
 Euphotic zone depth



 Significance
 dataset valuable for researchers studying

 Climate Change Impacts affecting physical biological marine environment
 Ocean Acidification decreasing pH ocean implications for marine organisms
 Marine Food Web Dynamics changes in lower trophic levels (phytoplankton zooplankton impact higher trophic levels commercially important fish species
 Ecosystem Modeling and Forecasting development validation of models understand predict future changes marine ecosystems

 Potential Applications

 Scientific Research Analyzing trends ocean conditions understanding biological processes predicting future ecosystem changes
 Fisheries Management Assessing impact climate change on fish stocks developing sustainable fishing practices
 Environmental Policy Informing policy decisions climate change mitigation adaptation marine conservation resource management

730
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-cerra-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-cerra-single-levels
reanalysis-cerra-single-levels
detailed description of Copernicus European Regional ReAnalysis (CERRA) dataset provides insights into historical meteorological conditions over Europe focus on surface atmospheric variables
 breakdown key information
 Overview

 Purpose CERRA reconstructs past meteorological conditions in Europe offering spatially temporally consistent data
 Data Subsets divided into four subsets single levels (atmospheric surface), height levels pressure levels model levels
 Data Type: Gridded data Lambert conformal conical projection
 Coverage: Covers Europe northern Africa to Scandinavia Atlantic Ocean to Ural Mountains
 Resolution: 5.5 km x 5.5 km for high-resolution reanalysis 11 km x 11 km for ensemble members
 Temporal Coverage September 1984 to June 2021
 Temporal Resolution Analysis data 3-hourly for high-resolution 6-hourly for ensemble members Forecast data hourly for forecast range 1-6 3-hourly for forecast range 6-30 (high-resolution
 File Format: GRIB2.
 Update Frequency New data added end of 2023

 Reanalysis Methodology

 Data Assimilation CERRA combines model data with observations using data assimilation based numerical weather prediction principles
 HARMONIE-ALADIN System CERRA utilizes HARMONIE-ALADIN limited-area numerical weather prediction data assimilation system
 Inputs: Observational data lateral boundary conditions from ERA5 global reanalysis physiographic datasets

 Advantages of CERRA:

 High Resolution: Offers higher spatial resolution global reanalysis products better representation of topography assimilation of more surface observations
 Consistency: Provides complete consistent dataset for long period standardized data format
Uncertainty Estimates: CERRA-EDA 10-member ensemble provides uncertainty estimates for reanalysis variables.

 Main Variables:
 table lists wide range of variables including

 Atmospheric Conditions: Temperature wind humidity cloud cover pressure
 Surface Conditions: Albedo evaporation skin temperature snow depth soil moisture
 Radiation: Solar radiation thermal radiation
 Fluxes: Momentum flux latent heat flux sensible heat flux.

 Understanding Data:

 Instantaneous vs. Accumulated: Some variables represent instantaneous values 10m wind speed), others accumulated over time total precipitation).
 Post-Processing: Certain variables (like wind gust maximum/minimum temperatures derived from post-processing steps
 Limitations: Observational networks sparser in past potentially affecting quality of analyses from earlier periods.

 Accessing and Using Data:

 Documentation: documentation section provides detailed information about dataset including variable definitions quality flags technical details.
 Download: CERRA data can be downloaded from Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) website

 Overall
 CERRA dataset valuable resource for researchers scientists users require historical meteorological information for Europe high resolution long temporal coverage detailed variable documentation make suitable for wide range applications including climate research hydrological modeling weather forecasting
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-carra-single-levels
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-carra-single-levels
reanalysis-carra-single-levels
detailed description of CARRA dataset! breakdown of information highlighting key features potential uses:
 CARRA Offers:

 High-Resolution Arctic Reanalysis: CARRA provides detailed picture of Arctic atmosphere surface conditions at 2.5 km resolution finer than global reanalyses like ERA5 crucial for understanding rapid climate changes in Arctic.
 Regional Focus: CARRA covers two domains: West (Greenland, Iceland parts Svalbard) and East (Svalbard, Franz Josef Land Novaya Zemlya Barents Sea). allows for accurate representation of local weather patterns phenomena specific to regions.
 Comprehensive Variables: CARRA includes wide range of variables covering
 Atmosphere: Temperature, humidity wind pressure clouds
 Surface: Temperature, fluxes (solar, thermal latent sensible heat), precipitation snow sea ice


 Analysis and Forecasts: dataset offers 3-hourly analyses) and hourly short-term forecasts (up to 30 hours).
 Data Format: CARRA data available in GRIB2 format easily accessible for analysis integration with other meteorological datasets.

 CARRA Matters:

 Arctic Climate Change: Arctic experiencing significant climate change warming occurring rate faster than global average Understanding changes requires high-resolution data capture local variations processes.
 Improved Modeling: CARRA's high resolution local observations detailed surface characteristics enable accurate simulations of Arctic weather climate
 Applications: CARRA data valuable for
 Climate Research: Studying Arctic climate change understanding impacts developing mitigation strategies.
 Weather Forecasting: Improving forecasts for Arctic region especially for extreme weather events
 Environmental Monitoring: Assessing health of Arctic ecosystems tracking sea ice changes evaluating impacts of human activities.
Operations: Supporting navigation aviation other activities in Arctic.



 Key Points:

 Data Availability: CARRA data updated monthly covers period from 1991 to present.
 Documentation: provided text highlights importance of Documentation section likely contains details on data processing quality control known issues specific variable definitions.
 Integration with ERA5: CARRA uses ERA5 data as lateral boundary conditions ensuring consistency facilitating comparisons between regional global datasets.

 Let me know specific questions about CARRA, variables or applications. I'm happy to help!

732
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/cams-global-atmospheric-composition-forecasts
https://ads.atmosphere.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/cams-global-atmospheric-composition-forecasts
cams-global-atmospheric-composition-forecasts
description of CAMS global forecasting system provides comprehensive overview data including
 Key Features

 Twice-daily global forecasts Covers 50 chemical species 7 aerosol types meteorological variables
 Data assimilation: Combines previous forecasts with satellite observations for complete consistent atmospheric state
 Model-based forecasting Utilizes laws of physics chemistry to predict evolution of species concentrations over 5 days
 Emission estimates: Incorporates inventory-based observation-based emissions as boundary conditions
 Regular upgrades system enhanced annually to improve accuracy resolution
 Global Reanalysis Available for long-term data consistency from 2003 onwards

 Data Description

 Data type: Gridded
 Horizontal coverage: Global
 Horizontal resolution: 0.4°x0.4°
 Vertical coverage: Surface total column model levels pressure levels
 Vertical resolution 60 model levels (before July 7, 2019) 137 model levels (afterwards), various pressure levels
 Temporal coverage: 2015 to present
 resolution 1-hourly (single-level) 3-hourly (multi-level)
 File format: GRIB (optional conversion to netCDF)
 Versions: Single version with occasional model upgrades
 Update frequency New 00UTC and 12UTC forecasts daily annual model upgrades

 Main Variables
 document provides complete list of over 150 variables wide range atmospheric components meteorological factors data valuable for researchers organizations studying

 Air quality Assessing pollution levels trends understanding transport fate pollutants
 Climate change Analyzing changes atmospheric composition feedback mechanisms radiative forcing
 Weather forecasting Improving predictions of weather patterns extreme events

 Important Note
 data extensive certain meteorological fields available with 5-day delay due to licensing restrictionsUsers refer CAMS documentation for more details.
---

https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-land-monthly-means
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-land-monthly-means
reanalysis-era5-land-monthly-means
comprehensive overview of ERA5-Land reanalysis dataset valuable information for working with land surface data breakdown of key points:
 What is ERA5-Land?

 Reanalysis dataset Combines model data with observations create consistent complete global dataset
 Land component of ERA5 Focuses on land surface variables extending ERA5's scope
 High resolution: Native resolution 9km regridded to 0.1° x 0.1° in CDS
 Long temporal coverage: Data from January 1950 to present
 Hourly & Monthly: both hourly and monthly mean averages

 Key Features

 Global coverage Covers entire Earth's surface
 Multiple vertical levels From 2m above surface to soil depth 289cm 4 soil layers.
 Detailed variables: wide range of variables related to water and energy cycles at land surface

 Main Variables:
 description provides detailed explanation of each variable

 Units: Clarifies measurement units for each variable
 Description clear definition of each variable relates to land surface processes
 Considerations: Highlights potential issues when comparing model data with observations

 Accessing ERA5-Land:

 Climate Data Store (CDS): Data available through CDS
 ERA5-Land hourly fields CDS page Find hourly data
 ERA5-Land documentation comprehensive information about dataset

 information well-structured informative makes ERA5-Land easily accessible understandable for researchers, scientists anyone interested in land surface data

734
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-land
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-land
reanalysis-era5-land
great summary of ERA5-Land overview of dataset variables covers essential information like
 Key Points:

 ERA5-Land is reanalysis dataset provides consistent view of land surface variables for several decades higher resolution than original ERA5
 Data Source: built by replaying land component of ECMWF ERA5 climate reanalysis
 Reanalysis combines model data with observations to create complete consistent global dataset.
 Atmospheric Forcing: ERA5 atmospheric variables (temperature humidity) used input to control land simulation.
 Lapse Rate Correction: Corrections account for altitude differences between forcing and ERA5-Land grids
 Uncertainty: Like model ERA5-Land estimates have uncertainty increases further back in time due to fewer observations.
 Resolution: Hourly temporal 0.1° x 0.1° spatial resolution useful for various land surface applications.

 Data Description

 Type: Gridded
 Projection: Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Coverage: Global
 Resolution: 0.1° x 0.1° (native resolution 9 km)
 Vertical: 2 m above surface to 289 cm soil depth
 Vertical Resolution: 4 levels (0-7 cm, 7-28 cm 28-100 cm 100-289 cm)
 Temporal Coverage: January 1950 to present
 Temporal Resolution: Hourly
 File Format: GRIB
 Update Frequency: Monthly delay of about 3 months.

 Main Variables:
 section lists main variables in ERA5-Land concise description units for each
 Overall Assessment
 text well-structured informative good starting point for understanding ERA5-Land potential applications
 Suggestions:

 Link to Data add link to ERA5-Land data download page from ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts) for easy access
Applications: Mention specific examples of ERA5-Land used in research, monitoring forecasting.
 Visuals: Consider adding visual representations like maps or graphs to illustrate data's distribution properties.
 Limitations: discuss known limitations of ERA5-Land, its reliance on atmospheric forcing potential biases in certain areas.

 With these additions, your summary more comprehensive valuable for users this dataset.

comprehensive description of ERA5 reanalysis dataset!'ve provided useful information about dataset's origins, methodology, variables, and access.
 summary of what I found particularly interesting:

 Data assimilation: process of combining model data with observations explained clearly. key aspect of reanalysis datasets.
 Uncertainty estimates: ERA5 provides uncertainty estimates, valuable for understanding reliability of data and for climate applications.
 Global coverage and high temporal resolution: dataset's global coverage and hourly resolution make it suitable for wide range of climate and weather studies.
 Detailed variable descriptions: descriptions of each variable helpful, including units, definitions, potential applications.

 few thoughts and potential improvements:

 Organization: could consider adding section headers to improve organization of document. make it easier for readers to quickly find information need.
 Links: links to articles and guidelines for accessing data are valuable, but could include more details about data access process. For example, could mention if any fees involved or if registration is required.
 Visualization: Adding figures or diagrams to illustrate data's spatial and temporal coverage or data assimilation process would make information more accessible and engaging.

 Overall, done great job of describing ERA5 dataset. information useful for anyone interested in using this dataset for research or other applications.

736
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-preliminary-back-extension
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-preliminary-back-extension
reanalysis-era5-single-levels-preliminary-back-extension
detailed description of ERA5 reanalysis dataset, long and technical for casual user. simplified summary:
 ERA5 is comprehensive global dataset for climate and weather:

 combines observations world with weather model to create complete consistent record.
 covers past 8 decades, with hourly estimates of various atmospheric, ocean, and land surface variables.
 ERA5 is improvement on previous ERA-Interim reanalysis.

 dataset includes:

 Hourly data: Temperature, wind, humidity, precipitation, cloud cover solar radiation sea surface temperature sea ice cover, many more.
 Monthly data: Averages of hourly data.
 Uncertainty estimates: Information on how reliable data is.

 Key points to remember:

 Back extension: ERA5 data available from 1940 onwards. preliminary version of data for 1950-1978 released, superseded by final release.
 Tropical cyclone intensity: preliminary version dataset may have exaggerated tropical cyclone intensity, recommended to use final release.
 Native resolution: Data available at higher resolution (native resolution) for more detailed analysis.

 to find more information:

 ECMWF website: https://www.ecmwf.int/
 ERA5 documentation: https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/datasets/reanalysis-datasets/era5

 Note: ERA5 is complex dataset, important to consider details of data and limitations before using it.
---
737
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means
reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means
detailed informative description of ERA5 reanalysis dataset breakdown of key information:
 What is ERA5?

 Fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis: ERA5 latest global climate weather reanalysis from European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).
 Data from 1940 onwards: provides consistent complete dataset covering long period time replacing earlier ERA-Interim reanalysis.
 Data assimilation: ERA5 combines model simulations with observational data using laws of physics create accurate picture of Earth's climate weather.

 What data available?

 Hourly monthly estimates: ERA5 provides estimates for atmospheric ocean wave land surface quantities at hourly monthly resolutions.
 Uncertainty estimates: ensemble of 10 members used provide uncertainty estimates for data
 Pre-calculated averages: Monthly mean averages pre-calculated for easier access analysis.

 Data updates

 Daily updates with latency ERA5 updated daily with latency of about 5 days Monthly means available around 6th of each month.

 Data access:

 Subset available online: information regridded subset of full ERA5 dataset on native resolution.
 Guidelines for native resolution: information on accessing ERA5 data on native resolution in provided guidelines.

 Data characteristics

 Gridded data: ERA5 data provided on regular latitude-longitude grid.
 Global coverage: dataset covers entire globe.
 Resolution: dataset has different resolutions depending on variable:
 Reanalysis: 0.25° x 0.25° (atmosphere), 0.5° x 0.5° (ocean waves)
 Mean, spread, members: 0.5° x 0.5° (atmosphere), 1° x 1° (ocean waves)


 File format: Data available in GRIB format.

Main variables:
 description lists vast number of variables. selection of most important:

 Atmospheric variables: Temperature, wind speed humidity precipitation cloud cover etc.
 Ocean wave variables: Wave height, period direction etc.
 Land surface variables: Soil temperature soil moisture vegetation cover etc.

 Key takeaways:

 ERA5 is valuable resource for climate weather research, providing long consistent dataset.
 dataset updated regularly with uncertainty estimates monthly averages available.
 access subset of data online with guidelines for accessing full dataset on native resolution.
 description provides detailed information about each variable and units.

 If need further information about ERA5, suggest consulting official ECMWF documentation links provided in description.
---
738
https://www.copernicus.eu/en/access-data/copernicus-services-catalogue/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means-preliminary
https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/cdsapp#!/dataset/reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means-preliminary-back-extension
reanalysis-era5-single-levels-monthly-means-preliminary-back-extension
overview ERA5 reanalysis dataset back extension
 breakdown information
 Key Points

 ERA5 fifth generation of ECMWF's global reanalysis for climate weather covering past eight decades
 Data Availability Available from 1940 onwards superseded entries for 1950-1978 final release from 1940 onwards
 Data Assimilation: ERA5 combines model data with observations worldwide data assimilation similar to numerical weather prediction
 Uncertainty Estimates: ERA5 provides uncertainty estimates sampled by 10-member ensemble reflecting quality observing system over time
 Monthly Averages: Pre-calculated monthly mean averages for atmospheric ocean-wave land-surface quantities

 Data Description

 Data Type: Gridded
 Projection Regular latitude-longitude grid
 Horizontal Coverage: Global
 Horizontal Resolution:
 Reanalysis: 0.25° x 0.25° (atmosphere), 0.5° x 0.5° (ocean waves)
 Mean, spread members: 0.5° x 0.5° (atmosphere), 1° x 1° (ocean waves)


 Temporal Coverage: 1950 to 1978
 Resolution: Monthly
 File Format: GRIB
 Update Frequency: Monthly

 Note preliminary version ERA5 back extension (1950-1978) superseded by final release from 1940 onwards preliminary version suffers from inaccuracies in tropical cyclone intensity
 Main Variables entry provides detailed descriptions comprehensive list of variables encompassing

 Atmospheric: Wind components temperature dew point air density cloud cover precipitation solar radiation surface stress evaporation
 Ocean-Wave: Wave height period direction directional width peakedness skewness
Land-Surface: Vegetation cover, leaf area index, soil temperature soil water content snow depth albedo, etc.

 How to Use This Information:

 Understand ERA5 Limitations: Recognize ERA5 is a reanalysis product of model and observations has limitations uncertainties particularly in back extension.
 Choose Right Data Version: Use final release of ERA5 data for 1940 onwards avoiding preliminary version.
 Explore Variable Descriptions: detailed descriptions of variables valuable for understanding data potential applications
 Consider Uncertainty: Incorporate uncertainty estimates into analyses appropriate.
 Access Data: provided links to articles guidelines help access ERA5 data.

 Let me know if specific questions about ERA5 or variables.
